HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: ALTERNATIVE FORUM; 
Bigger Crowd Urges a Focus On Social Ills

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
While the world's elite set to talking at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York, thousands of the most vocal critics of globalization are here at the World Social Forum, a counterweight to the discussions on Park Avenue.
 More than 14,000 delegates have arrived, four times the crowd in New York, to discuss how to attack global capitalism. Another 25,000 people came to attend parallel events, demonstrations and fringe meetings, some directed against the agenda of this meeting. 
 In contrast to last year, the six-day event began with a drift toward the center. Citing the pacifist underpinnings of this year's theme, "Another World Is Possible," organizers refused entry to groups that use violence, like the Basque separatist group E.T.A. and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. 
But they also barred "neo-liberal elements," including World Bank officials and Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, from taking part in workshops. Mr. Verhofstadt has criticized antiglobalization movements, the organizers said.
"We want a peaceful gathering of participants who agree that the actual system of global capitalism has lost legitimacy," said Oded Grajew, one of the Brazilian organizers. "I doubt that we're on the same page as the World Bank." 
Leading leftist figures like Noam Chomsky of M.I.T. and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, the presidential candidate of Brazil's Workers Party, held news conferences to open the six-day event, but most attendees focused on easygoing conversation with counterparts from more than 100 countries in the cafes and gardens of the sprawling Pontifical Catholic University, where the workshops are being held.
"A new pragmatism is emerging about what can be done to mitigate the effects of globalization," said Maria Ivanova, a delegate from Bulgaria who focuses on the environmental. "I'm here more than anything to form a bond with people who can eventually wield influence over important policy decisions."
Mario Soares, the former president of Portugal; Rigoberta Menchu, the Guatemalan Nobel laureate; and Danielle Mitterrand, widow of the late French president, are among the luminaries here.
George Soros, who shares some of the delegates' concerns, considered attending but decided his presence might be disruptive, said Michael Vachon, a spokesman for Mr. Soros.
In contrast to the $25,000 needed to take part in the World Economic Forum, this meeting charges delegates about $50. Participants dressed for balmy summer weather in shorts and sandals. The relaxed atmosphere extended to the themes of some workshops, like "Samba as an Instrument of Resistance and Fighting Racism," or "Sex, Lies and Business."
In some ways, the forum has a French flavor, although organizers said the second-largest nationality in attendance after Brazilians are Italians. Three French presidential candidates, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, Noel Mamere and Olivier Besancenot, are here, as well as six ministers and representatives of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and President Jacques Chirac.
Last year the French agricultural activist Jose Bove stole the show when he was arrested for ripping genetically modified soybeans out of the ground at a nearby agricultural laboratory operated by Monsanto. Mr. Bove is here this year, too, though he is keeping a low profile after promising organizers he would not do anything illegal. 
The forum's centrist tilt is not endorsed by everyone here. Some 300 homeless families connected to Brazil's National Shelter Struggle occupied an abandoned 14-story building in the old city center today, draping the movement's red flags out of broken windows.
"The World Social Forum is reformist economically, traditionalist politically and conformist socially," said Moesio Reboucas, one of Brazil's first antiglobalization organizers. Mr. Reboucas said he was especially critical of the role played by socialist politicians at the forum.
About $1.5 million of state and municipal subsidies allowed the forum to be held here, a city of 1.2 million people. For much of the last decade, leftist mayors from Brazil's Workers Party have governed this industrial center, a drab cityscape of whitewashed high-rises and low-slung warehouses. It is the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, a state also governed by the Workers Party.
Fausto Bertinotti, the secretary general of the Communist Refoundation Party in Italy, said he was pleased to be in a Latin American city governed by the left. 
"The elite that are gathering today in New York share the mindset of the people at the I.M.F. who ruined Argentina," Mr. Bertinotti said. "They are a world away from us and what we are trying to do, which is to brainstorm for policies that are not a dead end for humanity." 
Few delegates expect concrete proposals to emerge here. Instead, many hope to contribute to a dialogue on ways to mitigate capitalism's ills.
Carlos Rodgrigues, the owner of a video-game store who watched several thousand people gather downtown today for a peaceful march, was surprised by the kaleidoscope of ideas and approaches.
But he added, "I don't know if we taxpayers should be subsidizing an opportunity for Europeans to come to the southern hemisphere in their winter."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the Second World Social Forum, which opened yesterday in Porto Alegre, Brazil, thousands of delegates dramatized what they view as the corrosive effects of the globalization that is being promoted in New York. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/ SAFETY; 
Dummies Feel the Pain of New Rules

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. 

 BODY:
THE government's crash-test dummy has given up his hard-living bachelor ways for family life.
 Automakers are grappling with a new battery of federal crash tests, to be phased in over the next decade. Those tests will require a family of dummies instead of the only federally required test dummy since the 1970's: a 5-foot-7, 165-pound model meant to represent the average guy. New tests will add dummy stand-ins for a small, slender woman, as well as for 1-, 3- and 6-year-olds. 
 These dummies don't sit up straight like proper ladies and gentlemen, but slouch more like real people. One new test will position a childlike dummy standing on the front passenger seat. Another has the child dummy kneeling in the front footwell, in front of the passenger seat, with its head right in front of the air bag -- a position that one engineer called "the worst-case scenario."
The tests are part of extensive modifications announced in May 2000 to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard No. 208, the regulation that governs occupant protection inside automobiles. The changes will be phased in from 2004 to 2010.
The tests aim, in part, to reduce the dangers that air bags pose to small children, who have been hurt and killed by the force of air bags' deploying, while preserving the bags' utility in the many situations where they can reduce injuries. And the new version of 208, as the standard is known, also aims to enhance protection for both belted and unbelted car occupants. That is a point of contention, because some automakers say that designing air bags that protect the unbelted may increase risks for those who heed the law and buckle up.
Companies like Ford and General Motors had already been working on next-generation technologies, using dummies of various sizes, but the 208 standard requires a rethinking of how seat belts and air bags interact with each other and with different sorts of people inside a car.
"It's the most comprehensive regulation we've seen relative to crashes," said James Khoury, manager of advanced safety engineering at G.M.
David Clark, a safety engineer at Ford, said, "You can imagine the number of test considerations and evaluations -- small occupants, belted or unbelted, middle-sized occupants, large occupants, all the different crash scenarios." He added, "Trying to pull that whole picture together and balance the system design so it's completely optimized for all these combinations -- it's a tremendous challenge."
Call it a holistic safety approach. Ford and G.M. are refining computerized safety brains that rapidly collect information from sensors all over the automobile. Some of these sensors are already on the road. This week, Ford had a press conference here to demonstrate its newer technologies as well as some still being developed.
The Ford Taurus is equipped with "dual stage" air bags, as are several G.M. vehicles, like the Chevrolet Impala, and a number of imported cars. The bags inflate in one of two ways: in some crashes, they are only half-filled, or not used at all, depending on how far forward the front seats are positioned and whether the seat belts are in use.
How is this done? Data is collected from sensors and transmitted to the restraints control module, which is bolted to the floor under the front seats and is the car's safety brain. G.M. calls its version the sensory and diagnostic module.
A first line of intelligence gathering is a crash-severity sensor near the front bumper that tells the brain the force of the crash. The Ford Windstar minivan also comes with a sensor that weighs the driver and front-seat passenger. And the Jaguar XK sports car has four infrared sensors that indicate how someone is leaning inside the car. Both G.M. and Ford are also considering digital cameras that track a person's movements during the flickering course of a crash.
Once the brain gathers this data, it can determine if the seat belts are being used and, if so, how forcefully they should restrain the occupant. It also decides whether the air bags should deploy, how much they should inflate and even at what point the steering column will collapse. Ford and G.M. are also working on technologies that would provide a range of inflation options for an air bag, beyond two settings, as well as tethers that alter how far out the air bag will protrude.
"By the end of the year, we'll have two million vehicles on the road with the personal safety system," said Sue Cischke, vice president for environmental and safety engineering at Ford, referring to the company's name for its newer safety technologies.
In recent years, Ford has been troubled by safety problems related to its Explorer sport utility. And this week, an Atlanta lawyer involved in a civil lawsuit raised questions about the fuel-tank design of Mustangs built in the mid-1990's. Ford vigorously defended the Mustang design.
At its safety press conference on Tuesday, the company accentuated the positive. Ford was the first automaker to participate in a government study of vehicles that use advanced air bag technology. Most of the first 60 accidents the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has studied involved the Taurus and its sister model, the Mercury Sable, though a few tests were done on the Honda Accord and other vehicles.
"The whole purpose was to preserve the tremendous benefit of air bags, but reduce some of the risks we saw in the first generation," said Rae Tyson, a spokesman for the highway safety administration.
He said the newer technologies appeared to be addressing some air bag problems, but it was too early in the study to draw definitive conclusions. "What we've seen so far is encouraging," he added.

Below, Rouaa Nakleh, manager of passive safety technology, with a seat sensor that determines a passenger's weight. (Jeffrey Sauger for The New York Times); (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Harvard President Backs Raises for Low-Wage Staff; University Works to End Grade Inflation 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Moving to resolve an issue that has dogged the university for months, Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, said today that he would support substantial raises for its janitors, gardeners, security guards and other low-wage workers. 
 Mr. Summers accepted the recommendations of a commission that called for base wages of $10.83 to $11.30 an hour. Out of 13,000 workers at Harvard, about 400 earn less than $10.25 an hour. Several hundred employees of outside subcontractors and temporary employees also make less than that; some are paid as little as $8.50 an hour. 
 The new pay rates, however, still fall short of the "living wage" that students and other protesters have demanded. They had estimated the "living wage" at $15 to $20 an hour to support a family in Boston.
The wage issue spurred the longest sit-in at a Harvard building, a three-week occupation last spring of the first floor of Massachusetts Hall, which houses the university president's office. About 40 students camped out outside the office of the president, then Neil L. Rudenstine.
Some 400 faculty members signed a letter supporting the protesters, and the students also won the support of the state's two United States senators, the Cambridge City Council and labor leaders. In response to the protests, Mr. Rudenstine appointed a 19-member commission.
The commission did not recommend, and Mr. Summers did not endorse, setting a fixed "living wage," and "living wage" advocates said they would continue their campaign. 
"Janitors at Harvard will still be making less than they made 10 years ago and won't even approach many other universities' wages," Minsu Longiaru, an organizer with the Harvard Workers' Center, said in a statement. 
"There's a lot of questions that still remain, and Larry Summers really needs to answer those questions and answer them pretty soon," said Arin Dube, another student protester.
Mr. Summers agreed with commission recommendations that the raises be negotiated through collective bargaining with unions. The initial wage increases are likely to cost several million dollars a year. 
In a statement, Mr. Summers said he also wanted to encourage scholarly work on "issues relating to income inequality and the challenges faced by lower wage workers."
Harvard also grappled this week with another contentious issue: grade inflation. About half of the grades awarded in recent years to Harvard students were either A's or A-'s. And 91 percent of seniors graduated with honors last June. 
For months, Mr. Summers has been talking with professors about grade inflation, urging them to curb it in their own classrooms.
On Wednesday, Harvard's dean for undergraduate education, Susan Pedersen, raised another proposal, that the university stop giving honors to students who earn only a B average. Dean Pedersen's proposal referred only to a student's overall grade-point average. It would still allow students with a B average to get honors if they do honors-caliber work in their major or concentration, including writing a thesis. 
If such a policy had been in place last year, about a quarter of the students who received honors would not have. Other Ivy League universities, including Princeton and Yale, give honors only for exemplary performance in a major, and some will give honors to a maximum of a third of graduating seniors.
Not everyone on the Harvard campus sees the issue as a clear-cut problem. Some faculty members and students say that grades may be higher at Harvard than they used to be because students are studying more to compete for jobs and graduate schools. They also say Harvard classes are smaller than they used to be, implying that teachers are devoting more time to each student. 
Brian R. Smith, a student who is a member of the undergraduate education committee, which received Dean Pedersen's proposal Wednesday, said he was not convinced that students are given honors too easily, or that Harvard is out of line with other Ivy League institutions. 
"What's the big deal about honors anyway?" he said. "Maybe it helps you with graduate school in the end, but the question is, are you getting a quality education at your school?"

HEADLINE: Panel of Politicians Is to Advise in Rebuilding 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday that it had enlisted several high-ranking state and city political officials, as well as business and community leaders, as advisers in its effort to form a consensus on how to proceed with rebuilding Lower Manhattan.
 The development corporation had been expected to appoint four advisory councils representing various groups, including relatives of victims of the Sept. 11 attack, downtown businessmen, Lower Manhattan residents, and arts and cultural organizations. But in addition, the corporation announced yesterday a general advisory committee made up of political officials, business representatives and a labor leader. 
 The new appointments might dilute one of the primary criticisms leveled so far at the development corporation: that, with 7 of its 11 members appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, its decisions may represent the governor's wishes but not those of city officials and residents. 
But the new general advisory committee adds another layer of oversight to the decision-making process for downtown redevelopment, threatening to slow what some critics have said is already a glacial pace in beginning the planning for a key part of the Lower Manhattan business district.
The new committee, which will be led by John C. Whitehead, includes Sheldon Silver, the state Assembly speaker; Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader; United States Representative Jerrold Nadler; City Council Speaker Gifford Miller; Manhattan Borough President C. Virginia Fields; Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney; Deputy Mayor Dan Doctoroff; and the Senate minority leader, Martin Connor.
Also serving on the advisory panel will be Robert Douglass, chairman of the Downtown Alliance, a business improvement district for Lower Manhattan; Robert Catell, the chairman of the New York City Partnership, a group of business leaders; Dennis Hughes, the president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.; and Charles Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the parent organization of the Lower Manhattan group.
In a news release announcing the appointments yesterday, Mr. Whitehead called the advisory groups "an important vehicle for the public to participate in the revitalization of our great city."
A spokesman for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation declined to offer further comment on the origins of the general advisory committee, which had not been mentioned in Mr. Whitehead's previous statements about the panels that the corporation would name.
The members of the general advisory committee will be able to serve on any of the four specialized advisory councils, each of which will include about a dozen members; two development corporation board members; and several ex officio members, including prominent clergy members, city officials and business leaders.
Some downtown residents who have already been active in efforts to help shape the redevelopment plans said they believed that the general advisory committee suffers from some of the same faults as the corporation itself.
"When I look at it from a neighborhood standpoint, the people who are working most directly with the neighborhood don't appear to have prominent positions on the list," said Beverly Willis, a co-chairwoman of Rebuilding Downtown, Our Town, a group of residents, small-business people, civic groups and others interested in the rebuilding effort.
One notable absence from the general advisory committee is Betsy Gotbaum, the public advocate, who in an interview last night said she was "obviously upset" that she was excluded from the group.
"That's the kind of thing I was elected by the people to do," Ms. Gotbaum said. "A lot of people who live in the areas near ground zero and Battery Park City are confused and frankly don't necessarily trust what they are hearing" about issues involving the redevelopment effort.

HEADLINE: McGreevey Says Republicans Enacted 'Fraudulent' Budget 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Using his harshest language yet to assign blame for New Jersey's budget deficit, Gov. James E. McGreevey today accused his Republican predecessors of brushing aside warnings of the oncoming recession last summer and enacting steep spending increases in a budget he called "fraudulent." 
 Mr. McGreevey, who has spent his first two weeks in office trying to contend with budget gaps estimated at $2.9 billion this year and $6 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1, compared former Governor Christie Whitman and Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco to executives of the Enron Corporation, who are accused of concealing the company's bleak financial situation until it declared bankruptcy in December. 
 Speaking before a meeting of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association, Mr. McGreevey used an assortment of props, charts and internal Treasury Department memos to argue that his Republican predecessors had knowingly deceived state residents and continued to adopt costly tax rebates and spending initiatives even as economists cautioned that the state's revenues were likely to drop significantly.
As a result, Mr. McGreevey said, the state now faces a budget shortfall of 12 percent this year and 25 percent next year, which will force painful cuts in spending.
"What happened here was a disgrace," he said. "Those in power throughout the last year saddled the people in New Jersey with what you might call an Enron budget. They cooked the books, they hid the truth and they left taxpayers to foot the bill."
Mr. McGreevey said that his predecessors had so recklessly overestimated the state's projected revenues that he would be willing to cede some of his power to set projected revenues. That power now belongs solely to the governors' office. But he stopped short of embracing a plan put forth by State Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon, that would constitutionally mandate such a change. 
Although Mr. McGreevey criticized the Republicans' fiscal policies throughout the campaign, his words today were notably acerbic, even by the raucous standards of New Jersey politics. His decision to ratchet up his attacks suggest that the tenor of the budget deficit debate may grow increasingly partisan. 
After ignoring some of Mr. McGreevey's complaints during the transition, Republicans have begun returning rhetorical fire. And State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the state Republican chairman, has repeatedly urged the governor to stop using "campaign trail rhetoric." 
After the broadsides in Mr. McGreevey's speech, Governor Whitman's spokesman said he felt compelled to respond, saying that the new governor had failed to mention that virtually all the spending programs he now decries received significant support form Democrats.
"Every spending decision made, every tax cut, every bond issue to save open space or rebuild our schools was a bipartisan effort," said Peter J. McDonough, Mrs. Whitman's former communications director. "I don't see any Democrats lining up to say, 'Let's take back the School Construction Act,' 'Let's roll back the property tax rebates,' or 'Let's forget about open space.' His revisionism is laughable." 
The spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco did not return calls today.
Whatever tone the political debate eventually takes, the repercussions of New Jersey's budget problems are likely to be severe.
Since taking office on Jan. 15, Mr. McGreevey has tried to plug this fiscal year's deficit by ordering across-the-board spending cuts, slashing more than 1,000 jobs from the state payroll and ruling out any increases in state aid to municipalities, a move likely to prompt property tax increases in many communities. Mr. McGreevey will not unveil his complete deficit reduction plan until he addresses a joint session of the State Legislature on Feb. 11, but administration officials said that he was considering suspending the property tax rebate and dipping into the reserve accounts of the state unemployment insurance fund and retiree medical benefits fund.
The governor also confirmed today that to plug next year's deficit he plans to have the state issue bonds against New Jersey's portion of the national tobacco settlement. That will give the state cash, but contradict Mr. McGreevey's promise not to take on more debt.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Anarchy As a Matter Of Apples

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
MANY of the protesters in town this week call themselves anarchists. But they sound suspiciously like control freaks.
 They like to project themselves as unfettered young rebels, like the goateed guy in cargo pants on the cover of The Village Voice this week. "Anarchists pick up where progressives left off," proclaims the cover, which features an illustration titled "Passing the Torch." It shows the young guy, like a runner getting a baton in a relay race, reaching out to a middle-aged, balding guy in a suit and tie who is handing over a flaming Molotov cocktail. 
 The protesters this week have not yet celebrated violence quite as openly as The Voice has, but they have cultivated their image of Anarchist Chic. They're not like the earnest other protesters -- environmentalists, union members, socialists -- demanding more rules and bigger bureaucracies. Anarchists present themselves as the smashers of rules and hierarchies.
They speak of "direct democracy," which seems to resist direct definition. The author of The Voice article, Esther Kaplan, offers a summary: "They envision an egalitarian society without nation states, where wealth and power have been redistributed, and they take great pains to model their institutions in this vein, with autonomous, interconnected structures and consensus-based decision making."
Got that?
It's not easy to get more detailed plans from anarchists, especially when they're busy planning protests. But in Monday's paper, one of the protest organizers, Brooke Lehman, a New Yorker who lectures at the Institute for Social Ecology, an anarchist school in Vermont, was quoted being mercifully specific. While explaining "communal economics," she illustrated the problems of global capitalism with an example from the supermarket.
"We don't need to be getting apples from New Zealand," Ms. Lehman said.
We don't? I called Ms. Lehman to find out how she had determined this. What if, when apples were out of season in the northern hemisphere, some free-spirited, anarchic members of the community have a hankering for a fresh Braeburn apple from New Zealand? "In a society that was making decisions in a rational way," Ms. Lehman replied, "you'd be looking at not expending fuel to ship apples from across the world if you had them in your own community. Why is it easier to get a New Zealand apple in New York City than to get an apple from upstate New York? Those decisions aren't being made democratically. They're being made by a corporate elite."
Well, there may be corporate elitists at the Waldorf-Astoria this week who would like to decide what kind of apple you eat. But they have not had much luck in the past. The New Zealand Braeburn apple happens to be an illustration of how little power those corporate capitalists have.
In the 1980's, critics of corporations complained about another kind of apple: the American Red Delicious. The national chains wanted to sell cheap, good-looking apples to the masses year round, and the Red Delicious variety was sturdy enough to survive shipping and long periods of storage. Critics complained that supermarket executives and factory farms had left shoppers with no choice but a stale cardboard apple.
MEANWHILE, though, New Zealand's apple industry was pioneering tasty new varieties of apples that could be grown and shipped cheaply. As New Zealand's fresh Braeburns and Gala apples arrived, the produce sections of supermarkets expanded, and the American apple industry was forced to grow more varieties. Free trade enabled individual shoppers to impose their will on corporations, and now, thanks to Federal Express and the Internet, they can order more varieties than ever. If Ms. Lehman prefers apples from upstate New York, she can order them directly from growers there.
How would apples be distributed according to "communal economics" instead of capitalism? Some members of the community, objecting to the energy used in shipping New Zealand apples, would insist on doing without them even when there were no fresh apples from upstate. Others would consider the energy a small price to pay for a tasty, nutritious apple.
Whatever "consensus" was reached, one side would end up imposing its will on the other. A group of people claiming to be anarchists would end up dictating what kind of apple an individual could eat. Somehow that sounds more like the Taliban than like a group of free-spirited rebels. These control freaks are giving anarchy a bad name.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: STREET; 
Officers, Primed for Demonstrations, Find Few to Police

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
There were more than 4,000 of them yesterday, most of them in distinctive attire. They stood in clusters on the cold and rainy streets of Manhattan, chatting among themselves, eyes darting in search of action. They were out in full force for the World Economic Forum, just as they had promised.
 And they were all police officers. 
 On the first day of a highly publicized economic forum at the Waldorf-Astoria, one-tenth of the New York Police Department's work force was deployed to Midtown. There were police officers everywhere: on horseback, on bicycles, directing traffic, guarding shops, searching cars with trained dogs. And just in case, near the East River were an armored vehicle with a water cannon and a tanklike personnel carrier.
All this for expected hordes of demonstrators who, for the most part, never showed up.
David R. Graeber, one of the organizers of the weekend protests and a founder of an anarchist group called the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, said that the demonstrators' plans were centered on the weekend. Yesterday and today, he said, were reserved mostly for workshops on such matters as how to defuse confrontations with the police.
He said that a lot of last-minute work was still being done in preparation for the protests against the forum, which demonstrators say is an elite gathering of 3,000 corporate executives and world leaders intent on controlling the global economy. There are banners to be created, puppets to be made, costumes to be assembled.
"We're trying to create costumes that are both colorful and protective against police batons," he said.
The decision by the protesters to keep their puppets mostly idle ceded the day to the Police Department, which in recent weeks has tried to strike a balance in the message it wanted to convey about its preparations for the economic conference. On the one hand, police officials say, they will protect the free-speech rights of protesters wanting to demonstrate. On the other hand, they emphasize, New York -- which is still recovering from the terrorist attack of Sept. 11 -- will not tolerate any of the vandalism or minor violence that has punctuated protests at other economic conferences around the world.
So the police seized the moment, flooding Midtown with thousands of officers and setting into motion various plans to ensure that they were not caught by surprise. They had police helicopters, they had surveillance cameras, they had uniformed and plainclothes officers sizing up the people walking anywhere near the Waldorf. In addition to the 4,000 officers in the vicinity of the hotel, there were an additional 3,000 in the surrounding areas. 
According to Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, each component was part of a strategy that would allow for peaceful protest, as well as for an immediate response to any destructive or violent behavior. "I wanted flexibility and mobility," he said.
The police also had another factor in their favor: a chilly rain that was not particularly conducive to protest. It rained on the 200 practitioners of Falun Gong chanting at East 48th Street and Park Avenue, and soaked the two flags hanging outside the Waldorf across the street -- the American flag and the World Economic Forum flag, with the motto: "Committed to Improving the State of the World." 
Despite the inclement weather, some protesters still managed to voice their dissent -- and earn the attention of the police. For example, a California man was arrested on charges that he had spray-painted a symbol for anarchy on the window of a Starbucks outlet in Lower Manhattan. And several AIDS activists were arrested after they tried to hang a banner from a building near the Holland Tunnel.
There were other demonstrations and gatherings around the city: for example, an organization called the Students for Global Justice publicized a series of workshops at Columbia University, and then refused to allow reporters to attend. But the day's premier event was supposed to be a demonstration, led by a coalition of labor groups, in front of the Gap store at Fifth Avenue and 54th Street. 
As the rally's organizers assembled a stage on the rain-slickened street, so too were the police assembling, by the hundreds. Officers in uniform and in plainclothes were stationed on all four corners of the intersection, including a row of officers lined up in front of the Gap, as if to provide security for the precious hold of cotton and khaki inside.
"When did dissent become a crime?" asked a passer-by of no one in particular, although she could be confident that with so many officers present, one of them would hear her. A little while later, four burly plainclothes officers stopped and stared at three young men who had stopped to stare at the Gap store (including one whose face sported almost as many metal studs as his leather jacket).
But that was about as tense as it got at the Gap. About 1,000 protesters, most of them union members, filed into a penned-in area, protested against the company's labor practices in developing countries, and then left, their duty done.
"I think they're being very good," said Christopher Dunn, a senior staff lawyer at the New York Civil Liberties Union, referring to the police. "I don't think they're being tested yet. I think the police officers on the streets are taking a very tolerant approach so far."
Mr. Graeber, of the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, said that the Police Department's zero tolerance policy regarding demonstrators had not quenched the passion of the protesters. "I'm really inspired by all the people rising to the occasion," he said. "A lot of people have told me, 'I don't care how much they intimidate us, I'm going to be there.' "
And so will police officers like Francis Spangenberg, one of the thousands of officers who spent the day standing in the rain. His assignment was in front of a Starbucks cafe in Union Square.
"Starbucks can rest easy for another day," he said. "Maybe tomorrow your fair-weather anarchists and sunshine Trotskyites will come marching forth."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rally for 2nd Day on Fed Outlook

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street gained momentum yesterday, surging higher for the second day on the Federal Reserve's positive outlook for the economy.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose by triple digits, bringing its two-day advance to more than 300 points. 
 Investors are feeling more confident that business is poised to turn around after the Fed's statement on Wednesday that the economy was strengthening. Procter & Gamble reported earnings that exceeded expectations, which added to the gains, while an analyst upgrade of Intel helped technology stocks. 
Still, there were some signs of lingering caution, including some early selling of technology stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 157.14 points, or 1.6 percent, to 9,920.00. The biggest contributor to the Dow's gain was P.& G.
The broader market also finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 20.59 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,934.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 16.63 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,130.20.
Investors were also encouraged by the economy's resilience; it grew at a 0.2 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, the government said on Wednesday. That increase could signal that the recession ended late last year.
Also, the Labor Department reported yesterday that Americans' incomes increased 0.4 percent in December, after holding steady the month before.
"What we have seen this week is that we have turned the corner," said Jeff Kleintop, chief investment strategist for the PNC Financial Services Group in Philadelphia. "We have left the recession behind." 
Procter & Gamble soared $3.39, to $81.68, after beating expectations by a penny and reaffirming its projections for fiscal 2002. P.& G., the maker of Crest and Tide also posted its first sales increase in a year. 
Another consumer products maker, Kraft Foods, climbed $1.56, to $37.06 after raising its 2002 earnings projections beyond analysts' expectations.
Intel, also a Dow component, rose $1.18, to $35.04, after its shares were upgraded by Merrill Lynch.
Analysts said bargain hunting also factored into yesterday's advance as buyers took advantage of cheaper prices after a big sell-off on Tuesday, when the Dow tumbled 247.51 points, its biggest one-day point drop in three months. Worries about companies' accounting procedures, precipitated by the collapse of Enron, were cited as the biggest factor in that drop. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as a second day of stock gains and minutes of the December policy meeting of the Federal Reserve solidified the view that the Fed had come to the end of a yearlong course of cutting interest rates.
The Fed ended a two-day policy meeting Wednesday with an announcement that it would keep rates steady after a string of 11 rate reductions that brought the federal funds rate down 4.75 percentage points to 1.75 percent.
The release of minutes from the Fed's last meeting in 2001 showed that several members of the monetary policy committee thought that the December rate cut was a close call and one member voted against it.
The difference in yield between two-year notes and 30-year bonds shrank to 2.27 percentage points, down from recent peaks in mid-January of 2.63 percentage points.
Bond investors were also a little defensive before two major economic reports today -- one on national manufacturing activity and the other on the labor market -- which could provide more evidence that the economy is regaining its strength at the start of 2002.
The benchmark 10-year note fell 7/32 , to a price of 99 23/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 5.04 percent from 5.01 on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond was unchanged at 99 5/32 , and its yield was 5.43 percent.

HEADLINE: City Plans to Prohibit Turns Onto Broadway in Times Sq. 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As the final part of a plan to ease congestion and make the streets safer for pedestrians in Times Square, the city plans to prohibit vehicles from turning onto Broadway from 44th through 47th Streets beginning later this month.
 Those blocks were chosen because traffic planners consistently found the largest pedestrian crowds at intersections there. Problems occur mostly in the evenings, when theatergoers and drivers on their way home engage in their daily duel for dominance of the streets. Usually the crowds win, making it very difficult for cars to turn and backing up traffic for blocks on the side streets. 
 The situation is also very dangerous for pedestrians.
"We found that the lion's share of pedestrians were on those blocks," said Tom Cocola, a spokesman for the city's Department of Transportation. "And obviously what we want to do is give the pedestrians a chance."
The department first addressed the danger last year by instituting a plan known as traffic calming: narrowing some outer lanes and widening several sidewalk areas with painted stripes, raised pavement, stanchions and heavy planters.
The turning ban, first reported yesterday in The Daily News, was originally supposed to go into effect last fall, but after the World Trade Center attack, transportation officials decided to wait and see what effect the event and other traffic restrictions would have on crowding in Times Square. The decision was finally made to wait until after the World Economic Forum, being held in Manhattan this week, and to begin the ban on Feb. 11.
Signs will be installed next week announcing that no turns are permitted at the four intersections, and the police will be out in force to make sure they are obeyed, city officials said.
Mr. Cocola said that the ban was not a response to an accident in Herald Square at the end of December, in which a van lurched wildly out of control and killed seven pedestrians. But he added that the accident had highlighted the city's need to examine crowded neighborhoods where cars and pedestrians are in dangerous proximity.
"You can't avoid absolutely everything at all times in a city like this," he said, "but we're trying to make sure, as well as we can, that pedestrians and bikers and cars can share space safely."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: WORKERS; 
Labor Brings Witnesses to Tell Of a Harsher Side to Growth

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Sofia Sazo, a longtime garment worker from Guatemala, came to New York this week to tell a tale about the world economic order that the corporate chiefs attending the World Economic Forum probably do not want to hear.
 The managers at her blouse factory, which makes clothes for The Gap and Polo, often yell at the female workers and sometimes even hit them, she said. Some days the workers are forced to stay until 4 a.m. and then have to report back four hours later. The pay is typically less than $7 for a 10-hour day, and pregnant workers are often demoted to jobs that pay less. A five-minute stay in the bathroom usually brings a warning letter. 
 Ms. Sazo, who recently quit her job to become a labor organizer, was flown to New York this week as part of an A.F.L.-C.I.O. campaign to make the global economy friendlier to workers. 
Standing 4 feet 8 inches tall, with flowing dark hair, Ms. Sazo had a straightforward message: "Companies should pay a just wage and treat people like human beings."
The World Economic Forum not only is the world's foremost annual gathering of business and government leaders, but also serves as the foremost intellectual seminar about globalization.
Recognizing this, unions have seized on the occasion to try to get across their take on globalization.
More than 500 union members demonstrated yesterday in front of The Gap's flagship store on Fifth Avenue to denounce its use of low-wage factories overseas. About 40 labor leaders are attending the forum at the Waldorf where they will make repeated broadsides against corporate-dominated globalization. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. also sponsored an unusual forum in which three laid-off workers from the United States joined three workers from overseas to rail against the dark side of international business.
These workers and union leaders are scrambling for a strategy or tool, perhaps through trade agreements, that would stop what they call a race to the bottom in which many companies move operations to the lowest-wage countries. 
But many corporate leaders at the forum argue that moving operations to low-wage countries is good for those countries and their workers. This creates jobs, they argue, which usually pay more than subsistence farming. Globalization, these leaders say, helps poor countries develop their economies. 
Ms. Sazo agreed that many workers are glad to have the jobs.
"A lot of people say at least we have enough to buy bread for the children," she said.
Unlike many anarchist protesters who want to roll back globalization, union leaders accept it as a fact of life. "It's clear that globalization is here to stay," said John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president who is attending the Waldorf meeting. "We have to accept that and work on having a seat at the table when the rules are written about how globalization works." 
Labor leaders worked closely with environmental and human rights groups at last year's trade talks in Qatar, but failed to win labor, environmental and human rights protections in trade agreements.
Just before yesterday's demonstration at The Gap, Mr. Sweeney said labor leaders were eager to keep this week's demonstrations nonviolent. "Violence is not the way to achieve a satisfactory resolution of these issues," he said. "If anything, it hurts us in the long term."
Russell Sheffler, a steelworker from Cleveland, says globalization cost him his job. He was laid off in December, after 28 years on the job, when LTV Steel shut down permanently and laid off 7,500 workers. 
Mr. Sheffler, like others, attributed his jobless status on low-price imports from low-wage countries. 
"I don't' think corporations want to lift the standards of the people overseas," he said. "I think they want to bring us down to their level."
Richard Trumka, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s secretary-treasurer, said, "They say the backlash against globalization stems from an image problem. It's not an image problem, it's a reality problem."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: COMPUTER SECURITY; 
Protesters and Police Plot and Thwart Online

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
As the police and federal agents and scores of protest groups prepare for disruptive demonstrations outside the World Economic Forum, both sides are taking up positions on another potential battleground -- the Internet.
 Demonstrators are using the Internet to organize protests and publicize their causes. The New York Police Department is using it to glean information about groups that it says may pose a threat. And federal authorities say they fear that some protesters will use it as a tool of disruption or destruction. 
 Representatives of several of the larger umbrella groups planning protests dismissed the idea of "cyberattacks" and said they had none planned. But federal officials said they had "significant concerns" and, along with forum officials, were taking precautions.
The Secret Service is working with the Police Department on security preparations. So far, the specter of tumult in the streets -- and the kind of vandalism and violence that marred similar economic gatherings in recent years -- has driven concern about the protests. But increasingly, the potential havoc wrought by a computer attack has drawn the attention of federal authorities.
"We're living in a world where a keyboard has the potential to do enormous damage," said Bruce A. Townsend, the special agent in charge of the Secret Service's financial crimes division in Washington. He would not say whether there was a threat specific to the forum. But he said the agency's New York Electronic Crimes Task Force, a joint effort with the Police Department and nearly 50 other state, local and federal law enforcement agencies, had painstakingly reviewed computer systems associated with the meeting to make them less vulnerable. 
Cyberattacks on the World Economic Forum are not without precedent. Last year, a computer hacker gained access to the forum's database and obtained credit card and other information on hundreds of participants who attended the group's regional meetings in 2000.
At the other end of the spectrum is a group planning a "cyberaction" for this year's meeting. The group, called the Electronic Disturbance Theater, is using its Web site to call for a "Net strike" to "disturb the electronic infrastructure of the W.E.F.'s corporate membership." The group wants large numbers of people to swamp the Web sites of the forum and its corporate members. 
But the group's co-founder, Ricardo Dominguez, drew a distinction between his efforts, which he said were aimed at "social disturbance" rather than disruption or destruction, and those of anyone trying to break into or destroy computer systems. 
"It's a very American thing to do," he said, comparing the action to sitting down in the middle of a street in an act of civil disobedience.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: PROTESTERS; 
Paper Giants As a Voice For Ideas

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
Looking like an arts and crafts teacher who had been dropped into a Fellini film, David Taylor was struggling to clothe a papier-mache giant and simultaneously direct paint-splattered volunteers when yet another reporter asked the question: Were he and his fellow protesters planning to clash with the police over the next few days? Mr. Taylor, a 24-year-old computer programmer from Oakland, Calif., put down the puppet he was wrestling and tried to stifle his indignation. 
 "If you want to know what those young crazy radical activists are up to, you've come to the right place," he said, glancing around a vast industrial space buzzing with politically minded artisans and packed with their handiwork. "I'm really getting sick of that question." 
 While the police on the streets seemed to be steeling themselves for civic unrest, the atmosphere yesterday morning inside the garage, along the West Side Highway at 57th Street, was anything but martial. The message from Mr. Taylor and two dozen other volunteers was clear: make art, not war. 
There was, however, a looming sense of panic as the hours passed and the afternoon debut of this cardboard pageantry neared. There were robber-baron style top hats bearing the words "WEF: We Are All En-Wrong" and beachball-sized wine goblets painted like globes that read "Earth For Sale." A blown-up photograph of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, leaned against a pillar, not far from a row of huge pretzels, an apparent reference to the snack food that recently felled President Bush as he watched a football game. 
Over the past week, scores of volunteers from across the country have been flocking to the space to glue, paint and stitch together props that will animate the street protests accompanying the World Economic Forum. Two New York organizations, Arts in Action and Time's Up, helped put together the makeshift workshop. 
But alongside the levity yesterday afternoon there was an undercurrent of fear. Many of those planning to join the protests said they were worried about the potential for violence at the hands of the police. Others said they were frustrated by journalists' single-minded focus on the potential for Seattle-style disturbances. "We're not out there to fight with the police," said Payal Parekh, 28, an oceanography graduate student from Boston who was helping to organize the puppet making. "We're trying to get our voices heard but the media is obsessed with security issues." 
Whether or not their fears are real, even those organizing the puppet workshop were not taking any chances. Bill DiPaola of Time's Up tried to find a backup location, just in case something were to go awry. "You can't be too careful about these things," he said. 
Still, with the demonstration at the Gap at 54th Street near Fifth Avenue already under way, there were more pressing concerns. Clapping to get the room's attention, someone urged the crowd at the garage to head east and "help animate the images we created." A pickup truck was loaded with props; everyone else took the crosstown bus. Ten minutes later, the truck pulled up to the curb at 54th Street and into the arms of the police. "I promise there are no rocks or bottles," one woman joked to an officer who was visibly suspicious. "It's just a bunch of goofy puppets." After a brief verbal tussle and a few tense moments, the police relented, gave the group five minutes to unload and everyone, it seemed, was happy.

HEADLINE: An Architectural Milestone Loses Its Pedigree 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
The Bronx Developmental Center, a complex of buildings that has drawn global praise as a masterpiece of Modernism, is being partly demolished, significantly changed and expanded by its new owner.
 Architectural purists are aghast, but are helpless to stop it. 
 The new owner, Joseph Simone, who bought the complex from the state in May, is making what he hopes will be the largest office building in the Bronx out of the complex, a former center for the mentally retarded that is visible from the Hutchinson River Parkway. In the process, Mr. Simone is replacing the elongated portholes with conventional office windows and peeling off the buildings' celebrated aluminum-colored skin and replacing it with white aluminum. Most significant, he plans to enlarge the 330,000-square-foot complex to as much as one million square feet. 
"We're on the cusp of signing the first big lease," said Mr. Simone, the president of the Simone Development Companies in New Rochelle, N.Y., which paid the state $3.7 million for the property. "This is the biggest thing to hit the Bronx in decades."
The company has both demolition and building permits and work has begun. The goal is to take what everyone admits has become a decrepit, outmoded treatment center and turn it into premier office space. Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, said in 1999 that a transformation similar to the one actually being done could ultimately generate 6,000 jobs.
The casualty is one of the treasures of late 20th-century architecture, in the judgment of many architects and preservationists. After Richard Meier, the architect of such celebrated buildings as the Getty Center in Los Angeles and the Museum for the Decorative Arts in Frankfurt, Germany, and numerous distinctive white houses, finished the Bronx Developmental Center in 1977, Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic for The New York Times, called it "the cynosure of the architectural world."
The AIA Guide to New York City says, "A consummate work of architecture, it is among the great complexes of its time."
Mr. Meier, who is attending the World Economic Forum in Manhattan, said yesterday that the news of the demolition was upsetting. He said preservation laws in Europe, particularly in France, would have prevented such a change.
"I hope that what he's replacing it with has the quality of what we built there," Mr. Meier said. "It's interesting to me that they never come back to the original architect."
Robert A. M. Stern, the architect and historian, called the news "a shocker," saying he felt as if he were losing a familiar acquaintance. "And, my God, we've lost the trade center," he said. "This is a monument of exactly the same period. This is serious."
There seems to be little that preservationists can do. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission can confer landmark status only on buildings that are at least 30 years old. To qualify for the federal and state historical registries, buildings generally must be at least 50 years old.
Sherida E. Paulsen, chairwoman of the commission and an architect, said she was sad that she seemed powerless to help. She lived in the Bronx when her husband was going to medical school there, Ms. Paulsen said, and she remembered how much she loved to look out her window at Mr. Meier's creation. 
"This is a tragic loss," she said. "This is one of the first buildings by one of the pre-eminent architects of the late 20th century, and it's gone."
Preservationists were particularly disappointed that the buildings just missed being old enough to be protected by the city. "It's almost at the eligibility age for landmark protection, and yet it isn't," said Frank E. Sanchis III, executive director of the Municipal Art Society.
Roger P. Lang, director of public affairs for the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a private advocacy group, said, "This is one of the handful of works of modern architecture that deserved care and protection. And it's apparently been lost, and there's no recourse."
In "New York 1960" (Monacelli Press, 1995), the authors -- Mr. Stern, Thomas Mellins and David Fishman -- said the idea of the complex was to convey a comfortable ambience, despite the slick aluminum panels. They called it "rationally planned and utterly logical," but also "dauntingly abstract in form."
But from the beginning, the buildings had critics who insisted the effect was far from inviting. Mark Stevens said in his review in Newsweek, "Architecture is art's ambassador to the real world, but some psychologists and parents of retarded people think Meier has forced an unhomelike art upon the lives of his patients."
He suggested that the architect's hand might have been too visible. "Great buildings seem given, not designed," he wrote.
The book authors suggest that for many people who are not students of design, the buildings may have been a bit unsettling, much like the Guggenheim Museum remains for some. The "symbol of Modernism," they acknowledge, may also have served as "the butt of jokes."
Dean Bender, a spokesman for Mr. Simone, said the buildings had fallen into serious disrepair well before the state put it and four other mental health centers up for sale in 1999. The first step in converting the complex to a new use will be to rip out the interior space. "It really was in a very rundown condition, the building, the grounds," Mr. Bender said. Referring to Mr. Simone, he said, "He's really cleaned up the site."
Plans call for a first phase in which the complex's size will increase to 450,000 square feet. A second phase may increase the total to one million. The interior courtyards, praised by architecture critics, will be preserved.
The pace of development will depend on how quickly tenants sign leases. Several are negotiating for large amounts of office space.
Whatever happens, the edifice will never look the same. But there is a scale model available: it was shown at the Jeu de Paume in Paris in 1999 in a major retrospective of Mr. Meier's work.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Not Even Terror Attack Dims Manhattan Market

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Despite the recession and tremors from the World Trade Center attack, the prices of co-op and condominium apartments in most of Manhattan ended last year with a 5.2 percent gain, reaching a median of $505,000, according to a leading market report. And while closings slipped from the year before, the number of sales contracts has bounced back in the past two months. 
 "It's clear that market activity is returning to more normal levels," said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, the appraisal company that prepared the report for the Insignia Douglas Elliman brokerage firm. 
 "I would characterize the pattern in transactions as a V-shaped trend," he said, "indicating a rapid drop and quick recovery after this market trauma, as opposed to a U-shaped trend with a more prolonged decline and recovery period." 
The Elliman report is based on 7,858 co-op and condominium sales from Battery Park north to 116th Street on the West Side and to 96th Street on the East Side. 
In addition to calculating the 5.2 percent rise in the median price for all of 2001 -- to $505,000 from $480,000 in 2000 -- Mr. Miller also tracked the median price from quarter to quarter. During the first quarter, it was $500,000, up 2 percent from $490,000 in the last quarter of 2000. In the second quarter of last year, the median rose by 8 percent to $540,000. Then, during the third quarter, ending Sept. 30, the market experienced its first price decline in three years, dropping 3.7 percent to $520,000. 
"That trend continued in the fourth quarter, incorporating more of the influence of the Sept. 11 attack," Mr. Miller said. (Closings typically follow sales contracts by weeks or months.) During the fourth quarter, the median price slipped by 8.7 percent, to $475,000. 
Still, the 5.2 percent increase for the entire year "shows the resiliency of the market despite the Trade Center attack and the national recession," Mr. Miller said.
In the past five years, he pointed out, the overall median price for Manhattan has risen by 140 percent, including a whopping 50 percent jump -- to $480,000 from $320,000 -- in 2000.
The chief economist for the Real Estate Board of New York, Gregory Heym, said the 5.2 percent rise indicated by the Elliman report for last year "certainly coincides with our findings." 
"Most apartment size categories are up between 3 and 5 percent from last year," Mr. Heym said. "We do notice a lot of strength in the studio market. I think most of the activity has been driven by the small units; they hold their value well." 
The strength of the small-apartment category, coupled with slippage in the high-end market, was reflected in the findings of another appraisal company -- Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson -- indicating a drop in the average price (as opposed to the median) for Manhattan. 
"We've looked at new mortgage applications below 96th Street, month by month," said Jeffrey Jackson, chairman of Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson. In January 2001, he said, the average price on those mortgage applications was $734,300, while in December it was $645,389, a drop of 12.1 percent. 
"You had fewer sales in the high end of the market, and more at the low end," Mr. Jackson said. "That drags down the average." 
According to the Elliman report, overall sales volume dipped last year, but showed signs of recovery in recent months. There were 7,858 closed deals in 2001, the report said, a 10.7 percent drop from 8,799 in 2000. Those two years came off the all-time high of 9,245 transactions in 1999. 
During the first quarter of last year, 2,039 closed deals were recorded. In the second quarter, there were 1,829 sales. Then, in the third quarter, 1,904 sales were closed. And in the fourth quarter, there were 2,086 sales. "It must be pointed out, however, that many of the transactions that closed in the third and fourth quarters went to contract prior to Sept. 11," Mr. Miller said.
So, to get a further sense of the market, Mr. Miller tracked sales contracts signed, month by month, from August through January. In August, 166 contracts were signed. In September, however, that figure dropped to 35, followed by 29 in October and 42 in November. Then a sizable rebound began in December, when 148 contracts were signed, followed by 195 in January. 
There has also been a slight uptick in contract prices over the past five months. During September, October and November the median contract price was $490,000. That rose by 1 percent during December and January, to $495,000. 
As further indication of a recovery, Mr. Miller said, "If you take the number of contracts for this past December and January, and compare them to the same period a year ago, current sales are 2.7 percent higher."

HEADLINE: What Will Downtown Look Like? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Seeking Safety, Manhattan Firms Are Scattering" (front page, Jan. 29): 
 There may be an unexpected benefit for employees of firms relocating after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
When the firms were in Manhattan, many workers had long commutes that cut into precious family time. 
 My own research on working families in Massachusetts shows that significant commutes -- along with inflexible work hours -- impede volunteerism in schools, child care centers, faith-based organizations and other institutions crucial to the health of local communities. 
While restoring the vitality of Lower Manhattan is a worthy goal, a regional approach is needed. Lower Manhattan draws on a multistate labor market, and its fortunes are tied to the well-being of large numbers of families in many communities. 
If all stakeholders take part in the dialogue on redevelopment -- including families, schools, child- and elder-care providers, along with employers and real estate developers -- there may be gains for working families and their communities.

ANN BOOKMAN
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 29, 2002

The writer is executive director of the M.I.T. Workplace Center at the Sloan School of Management.

HEADLINE: What Will Downtown Look Like? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Seeking Safety, Manhattan Firms Are Scattering" (front page, Jan. 29):
 While it may be true that large companies like Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs are choosing to scatter operations beyond Lower Manhattan for safety reasons, the message that they send the public, and for that matter terrorists, is a lack of loyalty to New York City, just when it needs it most. 
 The companies may fear another catastrophe, but one can wager that the moves to suburbanize are also a matter of convenience and money, coupled with a lack of commitment to the community of New York City. I hope that New York will not become a suburban agglomeration like so many other American cities.

CODY LYON
New York, Jan. 29, 2002

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Loria to Get Help Buying the Marlins

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Major League Baseball not only plans to buy the Montreal Expos from Jeffrey Loria, but it will also subsidize Loria's purchase of the Florida Marlins.
 A person familiar with Loria's pending purchase of the Marlins said yesterday that Major League Baseball would lend Loria $38 million to enable him to buy the Marlins for $158 million, which is the price John Henry paid for the Marlins three years ago. Loria will receive $120 million from baseball for the Expos. 
 Henry has to sell the Marlins because he heads the group that has been approved as the new owner of the Boston Red Sox. Loria wants to buy the Marlins because he wants to remain in baseball, and the Expos are one of the two teams that Commissioner Bud Selig has included in the owners' contraction plan. 
Two legal challenges, however, have stalled contraction. Baseball officials still say they can jettison two teams up to opening day, March 31, but the plan becomes increasingly doubtful with each passing day. If the Expos remain alive this season, baseball will operate them.
The Expos could be an expensive takeover for baseball, though the linked deal with Loria and the Marlins could prove beneficial for baseball down the road. Rather than costing baseball $120 million, the cost in the next year will be closer to, or more than, $200 million, including the team's payroll, which is expected to exceed $35 million this year.
The person who spoke about the loan said Loria would pay no interest the first couple of years. If the Marlins do not get a new park within five years, $15 million of the loan will be forgiven and Loria will owe baseball only $23 million with no interest on the balance. 
On the other hand, said another person familiar with the transaction, if the team gets a new park, baseball would receive 20 percent of the Marlins' profits for the first five years. 
Loria, and not baseball, would also have to pay off financial obligations that he incurred in his purchase of the Expos. He borrowed about $59 million under the industry's line of credit, and he has a $30 million obligation to government authorities in Canada as part of the original purchase price. Loria did not return a telephone message.
Baseball officials had hoped that the deal would be completed by yesterday. One official said lawyers were still working on contract language. The ownership committee is scheduled to meet by conference call today and could nevertheless approve the sale conditionally. 
The league notified clubs yesterday of an owners meeting with the agenda including action on the Marlins and the Expos. No date was given, but the notices were sent yesterday to comply with the 10-day notification rule, allowing Selig to call the meeting for the week of Feb. 11.
The owners want to eliminate two teams with low revenue to improve the economic status of the other 28 teams. National television revenue and shared local revenue under the revenue-sharing plan would be divided by two fewer teams.
But the expense of buying and operating the Expos and subsidizing Loria's purchase of the Marlins would cost each team around $7 million. That's a steep sum for the small-revenue teams that are subsidized by revenue sharing. The clubs might get that money back if the Expos were sold to an owner in Washington, or northern Virginia, but there has been no indication when that might occur.
The other contraction case, involving the Minnesota Twins, also goes on. Lawyers for the Metropolitan Sports Facilities Commission and the state submitted briefs yesterday to the Minnesota Supreme Court. They argue there is no need for the court to review a lower court's ruling that upheld a temporary injunction barring baseball from eliminating the Twins this year.

HEADLINE: Japan Leader, Facing Crisis, Moves to Fill Minister's Job 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, moving to contain a growing political and economic crisis, chose Yoriko Kawaguchi today as his new foreign minister, replacing Makiko Tanaka who was fired in what is becoming known here as "the Tuesday night massacre."
 Ms. Kawaguchi, who was previously environment minister, is not a member of Parliament. With fluent English, a doctorate in economics from Yale University, and several years of experience in Washington with the Japanese Embassy and the World Bank, she is considered a quick study, capable of preparing for President Bush's visit here in two weeks. 
 The appointment came after Mr. Koizumi was blindsided by a wave of popular anger over his firing of Ms. Tanaka, a peppery parliamentarian who appeared on television almost nightly during the last nine months, pushing her crusade against Foreign Ministry bureaucrats.
In the last two days, this anger has been reflected in falling poll ratings and increasing business nervousness that could hamper Mr. Koizumi's attempts to adopt free market changes needed to help pull Japan out of its fourth recession in a decade. On Thursday, the yen briefly hit its lowest level in 40 months, at 135 to the dollar. This morning, the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell 179 points for a morning close of 9,818, one of the lowest levels since Sept. 11. On Thursday, Standard & Poor's, the global risk evaluator, warned that any delay in reviving Japan's stalled economy, weighed down by bad loans and deflation, could result in a further downgrade of its sovereign rating.
"It is by far the biggest problem he has faced since coming to power," Gerald L. Curtis, a visiting professor of political science from Columbia University said of the growing sense of crisis here. Referring to Japan's reformist prime minister, he added: "He is going to have a very tough struggle to regain the high ground. He kicked out the one person, who, whatever her faults, was out to reform the bureaucracy."
In a coordinated counteroffensive, Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa told reporters this morning that the yen's fall was "a little bit rapid." Heizo Takenaka, minister for economic and fiscal policy, responded to Mr. Koizumi's sinking popularity, saying: "I don't think the public wants the government to ease up on the existing structural reform plans." 
Alluding to the dropping popularity ratings, Takeo Hiranuma, the minister of economy, trade and industry, told reporters: "I think it is a temporary phenomenon and will recover as soon as we proceed with the structural reforms which the people have supported."
Mr. Koizumi, who has only a small faction of supporters in Japan's Parliament, has governed largely on the strength of high popularity, generally in the 70 percent to 80 percent range through last weekend.
But on Wednesday morning, hours after he fired Ms. Tanaka, telephone operators at the ruling Liberal Democratic Party headquarters were deluged with 10 times the normal volume of calls, with 80 percent strongly against the firing of the foreign minister. Little sympathy was shown for Vice Foreign Minister Yoshiji Nogami, who was fired along with Ms. Tanaka.
In a telephone poll taken later that day by Television Tokyo Channel 12, Mr. Koizumi's approval rating was at 55.6 percent, down 30 points from 85.6 percent recorded three months earlier in a poll by the same broadcaster. This poll also had his disapproval rating jumping to 34.8 percent. Of respondents, 61.8 percent said he should not have fired Ms. Tanaka.
In the shuffle, Hiroshi Oki, an Liberal Democratic member of parliament, is to become environment minister, returning to a post he held in 1997.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies last Friday about the appointment of Japan's new foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, misstated the economics degree she received from Yale. It was a master's, not a doctorate.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CALPINE SAYS HIGHER COSTS CUT INTO ITS QUARTERLY PROFIT

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Calpine, an independent power producer in California, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit had fallen because of higher costs and lower power prices. It said it had scaled down power plant construction plans because of soft industrial demand and the weak economy. Calpine also said it would take further steps to strengthen its balance sheet and shore up its creditworthiness. Calpine said it had about $1.8 billion of cash on hand. The company said its profit fell to $111 million, or 26 cents a share, on sales of $1.72 billion. A year earlier, the company earned $135 million, or 45 cents a share, on sales of $1.1 billion.
