HEADLINE: Pataki Says He Won't Sign Bill on Lights That Dim Sky 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would kill a bill that would reduce, over time, the light that obscures the stars over cities and highways. He said the measure would have cost the state and local governments too much to enforce and carry out.
 Mr. Pataki's decision not to sign the bill immediately drew fire from environmentalists and members of the International Dark-Sky Association, a nationwide organization of astronomers, environmentalists and others who say unnecessary outdoor lighting has robbed most Americans of a natural wonder: the stars. 
 By refusing to sign the bill, the governor effectively vetoes it under New York's legislative rules: a bill sent to the governor on the last day of the legislative session dies in 30 days if it is not signed. 
The veto came after seven months of negotiations between the bill's sponsors and Mr. Pataki's counsel; the lawmakers tried to amend the bill to satisfy the governor's objections. Last week, the bill's sponsor in the Assembly, Alexander B. Grannis, introduced a number of amendments to change requirements that the governor had found unpalatable.
In a veto message, Mr. Pataki said the bill's goals were worthy but too expensive for local governments to carry out in the current recession. He also said the bill was too restrictive for local officials making decisions about outdoor lights to deter crime and illuminate roads. Finally, he said the passages making it illegal to erect lights that bother neighbors were too broad and poorly crafted. 
"The governor wanted to fix the bill, but there were just so many flaws," said Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman, Michael McKeon. "We could also come back to this in a way that meets the goals, but this bill just had too many problems." 
Mr. McKeon added that the governor did not have an alternative bill to offer.
Had it been signed, the measure would have compelled the state and local governments to gradually replace streetlights and other outdoor lights with lights that focus light downward rather than letting it escape toward the sky. It also would have made it a misdemeanor to put up lights that bother neighbors and would direct the state to designate darkness preserves where outdoor lighting would be restricted.
Proponents of the bill said the new lights, known as full-cutoff luminaires, would save money on energy in the long run. Critics, led by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said the bill would cost cities and towns millions of dollars, since the full-cutoff lights would have to be spaced differently from the prevailing style, known as cobra-heads, because the light hangs below the fixture.
Mr. Giuliani asserted that the city would have to double the number of streetlights it replaced each year, at an additional cost of $20 million annually. Many town supervisors and small-city mayors also bristled at the extra work their police departments would be asked to do, writing tickets for "light trespass." The utilities in upstate New York, which own many streetlights in rural areas, also opposed the legislation.
The governor said in his veto message that the proposed law would have spawned lawsuits. The owners of a house next to a state highway, for instance, could have sued the state if the streetlights' glare flooded their property, he noted. Prisons could be sued because of the bright floodlights around them, he said.
Environmentalists, however, asserted that most of Mr. Pataki's objections were baseless. The bill only required lights to be replaced when they were worn out, and full-cutoff lights cost about the same as other kinds, they said. The amendments would have exempted governments from the light-trespass provision and would have let local officials ignore the rules if they provided a valid reason in writing to state officials.
Mr. Grannis and other Democrats said some version of the bill is likely to be approved again this year in the Assembly, where the Democrats have a majority. More and more environmental groups, astronomical societies and naturalists have signed onto the idea in the last six weeks.
But the bill may have a harder time passing the Republican-controlled Senate this year, as the state is wrestling with a budget shortfall caused by September's terrorist attack, aides to the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said.
Senator Michael A. L. Balboni, a Long Island Republican who sponsored the bill in the upper house, said several of his colleagues who voted for the bill last year had recently expressed worries about the cost. 
"All the governor's objections are actually a way of saying this is not an appropriate time for this kind of measure," Senator Balboni said. "I can't fault the governor for recognizing the change in circumstances. I think it's going to be hard to get through the Senate this time."

HEADLINE: Goodyear to Replace Some Truck Tires 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has offered free replacements for about 200,000 light-truck tires of the same model involved in 31 tread- separation-related accidents that killed 11 people, the company said today. 
 The offer covers 15-seat passenger vans and ambulances and will resolve a 15-month investigation of 21 million Goodyear Load Range E tires by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, an agency spokesman, Rae Tyson, said. 
 "We believe, based on what Goodyear has told us, that this will address the problem," Mr. Tyson said. 
With the investigation closed, no findings will be released, he said. 
The tires to be replaced were sold under more than 50 labels, including private store brands. The 16-inch tires were used on 15-passenger vans and ambulances from model years 1996 to 2000. 
The replacement offer was limited to a portion of Goodyear Load Range E tires because of a government warning last year that 15-passenger vans had an increased risk of rolling over under some conditions. 
Goodyear said it was not admitting any tire defect. It said tread separation could be caused by a number of outside factors, like under-inflation, an overweight load or contact with a curb.

HEADLINE: Study Puts Finland First, and U.S. 51st, in Environmental Health 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
A new study of 142 countries has found that Finland ranks first in the world for its environmental health and the United Arab Emirates ranks last, with the United States coming in at 51.
 The top five countries were Finland, Norway, Sweden, Canada and Switzerland. The five worst were Haiti, Iraq, North Korea, Kuwait and the Emirates. 
 The United States ranked behind Botswana (15) and Cuba (47), but ahead of Germany (54), Japan (62) and Britain (98).
The study found that although economic wealth does not necessarily correlate with a healthy environment, the level of corruption within a government does.
That is, the more corrupt the government, the less likely it is to pay attention to the environment. 
The study also found considerable variation among countries that were at the same level of industrialization and economic development. 
And it found that no country got good grades in every category.
It was conducted by the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network at Columbia University for the World Economic Forum, being held in New York this week. Much of the commentary in the report focuses on the lack of reliable data in most countries, a challenge to experts in their efforts to set a baseline of information for future evaluations, to be conducted annually.
The study took into account 68 variables -- including how a country responds to water and air pollution, how it protects land, whether its government is corrupt and how seriously it takes global climate change -- to measure environmental "sustainability," or likely environmental quality of life over the next generation.
"No country is on a truly sustainable path," the study concluded. "Every country has some issues on which its performance is below average."
Daniel Esty, director of the Yale Center, attributed the United States' midlevel ranking to inadequacies in controlling greenhouse gases and reducing waste, offset by great success in controlling water pollution. 
"It's an interesting question for a country that is so good in some respects, why that global-scale issue has not been given more focus and produced better results," Mr. Esty said.
He said the study was intended to help countries become more rigorous in making environmental decisions.
"Some in the business community take climate change seriously," he said, "but others fear it's an issue created by a set of extreme environmental groups. If they saw the data and the picture of reality that the data presents, they might be willing to take the problem seriously."
He said that Cuba and Botswana ranked higher than the United States because they did not have as much industry and therefore as much stress on their environments. "It's not necessarily better to be in Botswana than it is to be in the United States," he said. "But there are some issues that are more serious in the United States and we can ask if we're taking those as seriously as we need to."

HEADLINE: Economy Shows Healing Signs As Recession Is Still Wheezing 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT and DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
The pace of layoffs clearly slowed last month, the government said yesterday, adding to growing evidence that the recession that began in March could be drawing to a close.
 But the economy still lost 89,000 jobs in January, in a sign that it remained weak and that any recovery was likely to be uneven, economists said. Manufacturers continued to reduce their payrolls, although at a slower rate than last year, and the sprawling service sector added workers for the first time since August. 
 The official unemployment rate fell to 5.6 percent from 5.8 percent in December, but economists called the drop a mirage. With the labor market still deteriorating, more people stopped looking for work and thus did not count as unemployed. The proportion of Americans with jobs, 62.6 percent, fell to its lowest level since 1994. 
"We're on the verge of recovery," said Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, "but the recession hasn't loosened its grip quite yet."
Two other reports yesterday indicated that the economy remained weak, despite recent signs of improvement. Consumer confidence was slightly lower last month than the monthly poll by the University of Michigan had initially suggested, although it remained higher than in late 2001. A survey of manufacturing executives showed that that sector was still shrinking in January, but no longer at the rapid rate of last year.
Forecasters and investors had expected the data released yesterday to be somewhat stronger, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed almost unchanged, down 12.74 points, to 9,907.26.
In Washington, President Bush said the jobs report showed that the economy remained soft. He reiterated his call to Congress to pass a stimulus package. "We've still got problems," Mr. Bush said. "Too many people aren't working. There's not enough job creation."
At its meeting earlier this week, the Federal Reserve, citing signs of economic improvement, decided to hold its benchmark interest rate steady for the first time since December 2000. The Fed had lowered the rate 11 times over the last year to encourage businesses and consumers to spend more money. 
Most economists expect the recovery to be relatively tepid because corporate profits remain weak and consumers, who continued to spend rapidly last year, have little pent-up demand for new items.
With only moderate growth, the unemployment rate will probably rise to at least 6 percent this year, forecasters say. That would be lower than at the end of every other recession in the last 30 years but much higher than 3.9 percent, the level it fell to in late 2000.
"This is not an environment where it's going to be easy to get a job," said Bruce Kasman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "You will see more discouraged workers."
The Labor Department said that 924,000 people dropped out of the labor force in January. Although analysts do not doubt the trend, they said that the number was far too large to be credible and probably reflected a problem in the government's seasonal adjustments.
"There are three times of the year when you pay very little attention" to big swings in economic data, said Daniel S. Hamermesh, a labor economist at the University of Texas, "and that's June, September and January."
Since last March, companies have cut 1.8 million jobs as many executives have come to realize that sales and profits will be lower than they had forecast. Government agencies have made up for some of the losses, expanding their payrolls by 350,000 workers over the same period. But the public sector shrank by 5,000 jobs last month, when budget cuts by state and local governments outweighed the federal government's recent expansion.
With hourly wages flat and the length of the workweek down, average weekly earnings for nonsupervisory employees fell $1.46 in January, the biggest decline in the current downturn. The typical worker made $496 a week, or not quite $26,000 over a full year.
In the early months of the recession, when manufacturers and technology companies were the main enterprises cutting their budgets, an unusually large number of laid-off workers held college degrees or were highly paid. But as the recession has become more broad based, particularly after Sept. 11, most of the newly unemployed have been lower-wage workers. That continued last month.
Still, the report yesterday contained many signs that the economy was starting to recover from the huge job losses that began last summer and accelerated after Sept. 11. 
The 89,000-job decline in payrolls was less than one-third the size of the average drop during the final four months of 2001. The service sector added 56,000 jobs, its first increase since August. Manufacturers cut an additional 89,000 jobs, about two-thirds of their average in recent months.
Perhaps the clearest sign of a change, although still a tentative sign, came among temporary-staffing companies, which have laid off almost 20 percent of their employees since September 2000 as their corporate clients scurried to reduce costs. Last month, these companies cut just 3,000 jobs, the smallest monthly number since the reductions began 16 months ago.
"We're not quite at the end of the process" of corporate belt-tightening, Mr. Kasman said. "But we're getting closer."
Consumers' level of confidence seems to reflect the mixed prognosis for the economy. In recent weeks, their evaluation of the economy's current condition has continued to worsen, even as their outlook for the near future has improved, according to the University of Michigan survey.
"When we ask about the future, there's a significant change in people's expectations in the last few months," said Richard T. Curtin, who oversees the survey. "We may have a stronger recovery than some have predicted but not the robust dreams of those who think that we'll jump back to 3.5 percent growth."
The economy grew 1.1 percent last year, down from more than 4 percent in each of the previous four years.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE POLICE; 
A Second Day of Waiting, And Still No Major Protests

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
Like characters in a world drawn by Beckett, police officers waited and waited and waited some more yesterday for protesters who for the most part never came.
 Outside the Waldorf-Astoria the officers stood in a drowsy drizzle, talking in small groups about the weather and the Super Bowl. In front of Starbucks and Gap stores around the city, they sipped coffee and stood silent sentry. 
 And in Brooklyn, at the once-shuttered brig at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, where the police had set up a center in anticipation of processing hundreds of arrests, dozens of officers were idle. 
In fact, the second day of expected protests at the World Economic Forum, a gathering of corporate and other leaders meeting at the Waldorf through Monday, was largely uneventful. There were no arrests. There were no reports of vandalism. There were no large demonstrations.
"Where are they?" asked one mystified detective, shrugging her shoulders outside the Waldorf at East 51st Street and Park Avenue, where the police had set up metal barricades for an afternoon demonstration for which a permit had been granted -- but which never materialized. By 6:30 p.m., all was quiet and not one protester had arrived.
Earlier, at midday, about 40 demonstrators, some standing on a five-foot-wide redwood stump that had been brought to New York from California, gathered outside a Gap store on 54th Street and Fifth Avenue to take the clothing company to task for, they said, using sweatshop labor and exploiting natural resources. The demonstrators waved pine boughs and held aloft hand-illustrated placards that read "Stop Sweatshops" and "A Living Wage." They also beat on congas and drums as they chanted: "Slash those sweatshops. Boycott the Gap."
In the evening at a vigil at Washington Square Park a group called the Pagan Cluster drew about 200 people to a rally. At least 50 police officers stood at the ready. The group performed a ceremony, then most of the participants wandered the square handing out protest literature or Marxist newspapers, formed drum circles and sang songs. 
Also in the evening, at the Fashion Institute of Technology, a State University of New York campus at 27th Street and Seventh Avenue, about 200 mostly college-aged people arrived to attend a series of speeches held in the Haft Auditorium. A rank of police officers formed across a two-block stretch on the sidewalk in front of the school's campus, a half-dozen mounted police officers sat atop their horses and a police helicopter made low passes overhead.
But senior police officials said yesterday that they expected a much larger turnout at protests scheduled for today. With clear weather expected after two days of intermittent rain, many more people may be drawn to the streets, especially if they are off work for the weekend.
Rallies and marches are planned for today in the area of the Waldorf, and a gala was planned for tonight at the New York Stock Exchange in Lower Manhattan.
Policing marches presents a much greater challenges than a stationary protest. Some senior police officials said they feared that more radical demonstrators bent on destruction may try to take advantage of the moving group, both as a distraction that might allow them to strike elsewhere and as a screen that can cover them if they break away and wreak havoc.
"Everything is directed toward Saturday and always has been," one police official said. But he said the department had drilled and prepared for such actions and was ready.
A briefing paper detailing special instructions for police officers warned them to be alert for impromptu marches and "professional agitators." It also cautioned officers about demonstrators who "may attempt to provoke you into taking improper police action," and warned of "decoys who will get your attention in an attempt to draw you away from an area where unlawful acts are planned to take place."
The document also noted that demonstrators around the country have become increasingly sophisticated, using both bicycle messengers and "electronic communication" to coordinate their actions. "Be sure to enforce bicycle violations," it said. "Riding on the sidewalk, passing red lights, riding the wrong way on a one-way street, etc."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE PARTIES; 
Protecting the Food Supply for Some High-Powered Meals at the Waldorf

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Caviar with creme fraiche on buckwheat blinis, wood-fired foie gras on toast points and crisp black sea bass with truffled potatoes and Champagne sauce were featured on the menu for the 250 guests at Steve and Robert Forbes's nightcap at the "21" Club last night, washed down with sips of Bollinger Grande Annee and Perrier-Jouet Grand Brut. 
 But how did the guests -- chief executives and leaders of countries among them -- know that the lavender honey-glazed duck on baby white turnips was safe to eat? And just how could Steve Forbes be sure that the people serving the tartare of spicy ahi tuna topped with Hawaiian ginger did not constitute a threat by anarchists or terrorists or anyone else? 
 Diane Biederman, a spokeswoman for "21," said that all employees of the restaurant, from the executive chef to the lowliest dishwasher, go through rigorous background checks. "You should have seen the security check I went through," Ms. Biederman said. 
At the Waldorf-Astoria, every ounce of caviar, box of raspberries and case of single malts entering the building is X-rayed, said a catering executive familiar with the hotel's high-security operations. The hotel served 6,000 meals on Thursday, from lunches for presidents to dinners for Secret Service agents; as an extra precaution, most of the ingredients had been ordered in before the World Economic Forum started. 
Security is even more intense for the party planners who usually tend to the quiet dinner parties of Park Avenue. Sonnier & Castle, a catering company in New York, was engaged to provide the food, decor and service staff for two events held last night at the New York Public Library -- the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, David H. Komansky, was the host -- a cocktail party for 400 guests and a dinner party for 100. 
"Security was very intense," said Russ Sonnier, a co-owner of the catering company. He said Sonnier & Castle had to provide, at the request of the Secret Service, the full names, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, home addresses and home telephone numbers for the 55 staff members hired to work the parties. 
"They ran checks on everything from the wait staff to the party rental company to the people who would be delivering the ice," Mr. Sonnier said. The Secret Service swept the library at 3 p.m., he said, equipped with devices that detect explosive residue. They also ran a team of bomb-sniffing dogs through the entire building. 
"I would say we're pretty safe," Mr. Sonnier said. 
Bill Stanton, a private investigator and corporate security expert, said that despite every restaurant's and service's best precautions, there is always a way to use a party or dinner as a way to get close to a major political figure or chief executive. 
"You have to ask a battery of questions," he said. "Are these things prepared outside the kitchen? If so, by who? Where did they get the ingredients? Is the integrity of the food and the service absolutely sterling? More times than not, the answer is no."
Mr. Stanton, who was hired to assess security by planners of one of the grand parties last evening, spoke on the condition that he not reveal which party he had worked on. 
"You always have to think, Has someone done a background check on the dishwasher? Could the dishwasher be paid off? You have to think laterally," he said. "How would someone know that the event was taking place, and would they have an inside person? Could they feasibly put together enough information to plan and target a certain person?" 
Mr. Stanton pointed out that food and terrorism are not two thoughts that together raise a lot of suspicion. Until Sept. 11, he said, even Central Intelligence Agency employees could order large boxes of pizza and Chinese food and have it delivered without any security precautions. "We really can't forget the urgency of security at a time like this," he said. 
If anything goes wrong as the guests are sipping their wine and nibbling canapes, Mr. Stanton said, the only resort is to make sure that armed security agents are on the alert and instantly available. 
"And that's why I'm carrying a gun," he said.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE PROTESTERS; 
To Some, Marching Is Old Hat, Even if the Issues Are Not

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
It is safe to say that when thousands of protesters take to the streets later today, very few of them will be dressed as Russian babushkas. There will, however, be a few exceptions.
 Peppered throughout the youthful throng that is expected to march through Midtown, Molly Klopot and her friends will surely burst the stereotype of anti-globalization agitators -- and turn plenty of heads. Dressed in a kaleidoscope of shawls, straw hats and flowing muumuus, Ms. Klopot and the other members of the Raging Grannies will be there to show the world that hell hath no fury like an angry grandmother. 
 "We don't break windows. We don't get arrested. We just sing," said Ms. Klopot, 82, a social worker and battle-scarred trade unionist who can still summon memories of unrest in years after Sacco and Vanzetti, the Palmer Raids and other iconic episodes in American history. "Back then we always sang, even when we were getting hit over the head by police, and blood was running down our faces."
Passionate about environmental degradation and the increasing reach of multinational corporations, the Raging Grannies, which has 78 chapters around the country, are keenly aware of their public relations prowess. "People are amused by us, but they take us very seriously," Ms. Klopot said. 
The New York branch, which was formed last year by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, has several dozen members, including women who are not yet grandmothers. (The group here is officially called Raging Grannies and Their Daughters.) 
Stephanie Fraser, 37, the mother of a 3-month-old girl, said the group served as a foil to critics, skeptics and TV commentators intent on portraying the demonstrators as privileged Gen X malcontents.
"The media tries to depict us as spoiled brats, which makes it easier to discount our message," she said. "Any creative way we can get around that stereotype helps us get our message out."
That crux of that message is pointing to poverty and inequality around the world. Like many anti-globalization advocates, the Raging Grannies say they believe that increasingly powerful corporations, embodied by the World Economic Forum, are harming democracy and human rights. 
"People need to realize that we are in a death spiral," said Premilla Dixit, 52, a filmmaker from Brooklyn. "The global corporate economy has created a very deep disconnect between the generation alive today and the one that will come after," she said. Like the woman's suffrage and labor movements of yesteryear, the Raging Grannies rely on a repertoire of familiar songs, albeit with new lyrics. One such tune, which will make its debut today, is sung to the tune of Irving Berlin's "There's No Business Like Show Business" and goes like this:
 There's no business like war business, the worst business we know.
Never mind the homeless and the hungry, Never mind the people without jobs
Nowhere can you get that special feeling than when you're piling up the bombs.

HEADLINE: City College, the Faded Jewel of CUNY, Is Recovering Its Luster and Its Achievers 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
For 30 years, City College has been maligned as the good child gone bad in the City University family, with critics saying that its shining promise was smashed by admission policies that turned the college into a lackluster remedial mill.
 But by some measures, City College, once famed nationally as the Harvard of the poor, has begun to match or beat out rivals in the City University of New York like Queens, Brooklyn, Baruch and Hunter Colleges that had been eclipsing it in recent decades. 
 The college is re-emerging at or near the top on indexes like freshman SAT scores and high school averages as a result of a pool of high-achieving immigrants; new recruiting programs that stress its strength in engineering, architecture and science; an enticing honors program; and sharp reductions in the number of less-well-prepared students.
For generations, City College, located in Harlem at West 135th Street, was a refuge for the city's poor and working-class strivers, where students excluded from the Ivies and other top colleges because of race or religion could get a top-notch education. Eight City College students went on to win Nobel Prizes, and the college produced such celebrated graduates as Jonas Salk, who developed the first polio vaccine, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. 
But in the late 1960's, advocates of open admissions argued that too many black and Hispanic students were excluded as a result of poor preparation in failing public high schools. As a result, admissions criteria throughout the 17 campuses of CUNY were loosened and City College began to attract many of the city's poorly prepared high school students. Critics soon complained that the college's quality had declined sharply, and by the 1980's, university officials acknowledged that it was fifth among CUNY's senior colleges instead of first. 
But the most recent admissions statistics indicate that all that seems to have changed. 
"City College is now taking steps to return to those days when its reputation was a reputation of excellence," said Eugene S. Blaufarb, an assistant principal at the city's most selective public high school, Stuyvesant in Lower Manhattan, who said that more Stuyvesant students were again applying to the college.
"Not only is it a turnaround in the numbers of students who are applying," he said. "There is also a turnaround in who's applying. The kids who applied before tended to be our underachievers. Now it is our real achievers."
The top 25 percent of the applicants that City College accepted as freshmen through its regular admissions procedure from American high schools last fall tied for the highest SAT scores among CUNY's 17 campuses: an average combined mathematics and verbal score of 1,200 out of 1,600. Only Queens College matched that figure. If SAT scores for all of the regularly admitted freshmen applicants from American high schools are used, City's 1,089 average was second only to Baruch's 1,096, and up from less than 1,000 just four years ago.
To be sure, CUNY officials point out that the difference between City College and CUNY's other senior colleges on admission statistics is small and can change from year to year. But many CUNY professors who have seen these scores are startled to see how City College has begun to regain its former stature. And it has done so, its top officials stress, without sacrificing the diversity of its student body.
These figures do not include scores for economically and educationally disadvantaged students in CUNY's SEEK program (Search for Elevation, Education and Knowledge), who are admitted separately and are at all the senior colleges. But even those students are now closer academically to the regularly admitted students than they used to be. And the number of SEEK students has been cut; last fall's entering class at City College had 157 SEEK students, down from 279 a year earlier.
"We have a very, very strong student body," Gregory H. Williams, the college's new president, said on Thursday in an interview. "With the end of remediation, it has gotten much stronger this year. We're on the right trajectory." 
Some of the improvement in academic scores is clearly a result of CUNY's fiercely debated decision several years ago to improve its reputation by removing remedial courses from the curriculum of its 11 senior colleges and to direct weaker students to its 6 community colleges.
The shift has probably benefited City College more than the other senior colleges because its student body changed so much after open admissions and because the change drew so much attention. In the book "City on a Hill: Testing the American Dream at City College," James Traub described City College classrooms filled with students who did not write or speak English well. 
That book, along with a growing chorus of attacks from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other critics, prompted CUNY's trustees to remove remedial courses from their senior colleges. The new policy, phased in over three years, took effect at City College last September.
Critics of the tighter admissions policies expressed concerns that CUNY would now be turning away those students who needed its help the most, including many poorly educated minority and immigrant applicants who did not yet have a strong command of English. 
Dr. Williams said that the academic improvement among entering students has not resulted in a change in demographics. Students in minority groups make up more than three-quarters of City's student body, he said, with the largest groups being Hispanic and black. While he acknowledged that the number of E.S.L. students -- those needing to learn English as a second language -- had decreased, he said the college was still hospitable to immigrants.
"This is not being done on the backs of E.S.L. students," he said, adding that half of City's students were born outside the United States.
While the latest SAT scores do not put City College on a par with the Ivy League, the college has begun to capture the interest of some of the city's strongest students for the first time in a long time. Many are drawn by the modest tuition ($3,200 a year for state residents), and free tuition to those who qualify for CUNY's new honors program, which also provides them with free laptop computers and covers other academic expenses. More than 200 honors applicants for next year have designated City as their first choice.
Students interested in areas where City is especially strong, like biomedical engineering and architecture, are electing City, often after being admitted to more selective campuses. "Financially, it came down to City College or Manhattan," said Asad Chaudhary, a freshman honors student at City who was also accepted at Columbia, R.P.I. and the State University of New York at New Paltz. "And Manhattan had absolutely no diversity."

HEADLINE: Rutgers President Known for Fund-Raising Resigns After 11 Years 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
The president of Rutgers University, Francis L. Lawrence, announced today that he would resign as soon as the university's board of governors named his successor.
 Dr. Lawrence, 64, came to the state's flagship public campus in 1990, facing recession-driven budget cuts, and he will be leaving just as a new recession and new budget cuts face the university. 
 During his time at Rutgers, Dr. Lawrence has focused on strengthening undergraduate education and improving campus technology.
But from the outset, critics found Fran Lawrence, as he is best known, to be a cool and somewhat distant figure after the gregariousness and political savvy of his predecessor, Edward J. Bloustein, who spent his energy building up Rutgers as a research campus. Mr. Bloustein died of a heart attack in 1989 while in office.
In a letter to the Board of Governors, Dr. Lawrence gave little reason for leaving his job, which pays $287,000 a year. He said in a statement that, after consulting his family, he had decided that it was "time for me to plan to step down."
He added, "I will return to the faculty upon the installation of my successor."
Gov. James E. McGreevey issued a three-sentence statement this evening that began, "I congratulate President Lawrence for his stewardship of Rutgers University, particularly the successful capital campaign," and ended by saying that the governor looked forward to "a new generation of leadership at Rutgers."
As the governor noted, Dr. Lawrence has been a tireless fund-raiser during his nearly 12 years in office. Since 1988 alone, he has raised nearly $377 million of a six-year program's $500 million goal.
During his time in office, external financing of research and other academic programs at Rutgers grew to $224 million from $92 million. He said in his statement today that he would like to continue to oversee the capital campaign.
Yet Dr. Lawrence was dogged from the outset with problems with a restless and often discontented faculty. Rutgers is one of the few major state universities to be fully unionized, under the American Association of University Professors.
Faculty members shadowed his speeches looking for ammunition to use against him and in 1995 they recorded him telling a faculty meeting that "disadvantaged" students did not have "the genetic hereditary background" to do well on standardized tests.
He later said he did not know why he said it, and insisted that the sentiment was the opposite of his true feelings, but the incident provoked a firestorm of criticism from some student and faculty members demanding his resignation.
The board of governors, however, delivered a vote of confidence in the president.
Many faculty members continue to be critical of Dr. Lawrence, complaining that he cut programs he did not consider important to shift money to other areas.
Thomas J. Figueira, who is leading an effort to form a new union associated with the New Jersey Education Association, the public school teachers' union, accused Dr. Lawrence of unfairly cutting a summer program in classical languages he had founded. "He canceled an economically viable program because he didn't like me any more."
But other faculty members said Dr. Lawrence's focus on building Rutgers's technology infrastructure and on fund-raising deserved praise.
"We were an electronic cow path when he got here," said Professor Barry V. Qualls, professor of English and dean of humanities.
"The ability to attract world-class faculty, and the ability of the faculty to feel that this is a world-class institution -- those are not signs of a university that has no leadership."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the planned resignation of Frank L. Lawrence as president of Rutgers misstated the period in which he raised nearly $377 million for the university. It was the last three and a half years, not the period since 1988.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
White House Is Ordered To Keep Records of Enron
The Justice Department ordered the White House to preserve records of contacts between government officials and Enron executives over the last three years, a sign that federal prosecutors have broadened their criminal inquiry to the company's ties in Washington.
 The request, made in a letter to the White House counsel, prompted the administration to order all agencies not to destroy any records related to Enron. Page A1. 

The sister and a son of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman, both benefited through extensive business dealings, including contracts and investments, with the company. A1.

Stocks Flag After 2 Days of Gains
Stocks slipped as investors took profits after two sessions of advances. The economic data continued to be mixed, possibly indicating a mostly muted recovery, while investors also remained concerned about the general reliability of financial statements. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.74 points, or 0.1 percent, to 9,907.26. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 22.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,911.24. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,122.20. C3.

Ruling Threatens Argentine Banks
In a surprise decision, the Argentine Supreme Court ruled that the country's freezing of bank withdrawals was unconstitutional. Anticipating that the decision could set off a run on banks and on the peso, Argentine authorities declared a bank and currency exchange holiday on Monday and Tuesday. A4.

United Airlines Posts Quarterly Loss
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $308 million that included gains of $332 million, federal aid among that. Its revenue tumbled 39 percent. C2.

Delta Flight Attendants Reject Union
Fewer than a third of eligible Delta Air Lines flight attendants voted in favor of joining the Association of Flight Attendants. The vote was a sharp setback to unionization drives at the traditionally nonunion airline. C2.

White House Seeks Fuel Authority
The Bush administration is requesting broad authority from Congress to revamp the system used to set fuel-economy standards. Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta said in a letter that the current system has led to smaller, lighter cars that are responsible for more highway fatalities. C3.

No Margin Calls for WorldCom Chief
Bernard J. Ebbers, the man who built WorldCom into a giant company, owes $92 million more than his company stock is worth. But because his debts are in different ways tied to the company, it is unlikely he will be selling his stock any time soon. Part of his debt is owed directly to WorldCom, and other loans are guaranteed by the company. C2.

Inflation Rises in the Euro Zone
Inflation in countries that use the euro jumped 2.5 percent in January from a year ago. The rise makes it harder for the 12-nation group to cut interest rates to nudge growth. C2.

U.S. Promises Aid, Our Way
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill defended the administration's decision to cut off aid to Argentina, saying "they just didn't reform." Separately, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the administration was committed to aiding the world's poor as part of an effort to assure widespread economic development. The conditional help left some bristling. A10.

Goodyear Offers Replacement Tires
Goodyear Tire and Rubber has offered free replacements for about 200,000 light-truck tires of the same model involved in 31 accidents related to tread separation. Eleven people were killed in those accidents. C15.

HEADLINE: Starting at Ground Zero 

 BODY:
The news that the developer Larry Silverstein is gearing up to break ground on a new 7 World Trade Center should be a warning bell for all New Yorkers concerned with the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan. The city-state agency created to oversee that redevelopment must finally get organized. The public's views need to be officially heard, and planners should begin working with all deliberate speed. Otherwise the city is not going to get what it really deserves -- a magnificently designed and masterly coordinated downtown Manhattan. 
 Mr. Silverstein, who was the leaseholder on the World Trade Center when it was destroyed, apparently feels that he and his architects will be the leading voices in designing what replaces it. The site of 7 World Trade Center is across the street from the towers destroyed by terrorists, and Mr. Silverstein's power to rebuild there quickly is less legally complicated than his rights over the rest of the site. But whatever he decides to do there will have a big impact on the entire area. While Mr. Silverstein promises a "spectacular" building, his ultimate goal should be a building that fits into a spectacular new plan for downtown Manhattan. 
 The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is in the process of setting up advisory committees on what to do with the site. These panels should immediately begin providing forums for the many passionate voices concerned about downtown's future. John Whitehead, the corporation chairman, is going to have to figure out how to give these many views their rightful due, while still coming up with an inspiring and unified proposal for the area.
The sudden appearance of an array of New York politicians on the advisory panels is worrisome. Too many political egos could produce a collective mush of a design that ultimately pleases no one. Great architecture requires a great architect and a great client. When the public is the client, it is too easy to wind up with little more than a compromise. Mr. Whitehead's corporation has the difficult task of making certain these public figures are heard but that the final plan is also an urban work of art.
While the committees are thinking, the businesses that valiantly stayed in Lower Manhattan after the attack are still having to cope with the problems that come from disrupted utility connections and lack of mass transit service. Unlike 7 World Trade Center, these pieces of infrastructure must be replaced right away. The corporation should step in quickly to determine whether to restore the old clump of electrical substations at 7 World Trade Center or spread smaller stations through downtown. The corporation must find out how much money -- especially federal money -- can be used to revamp PATH, the subways and other transportation links. There are now numerous transit proposals drifting around the city, some temporary and modest, others elaborate ones that advocates have been dreaming about for years.
Somewhere in the middle is a solid plan from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that makes it possible to restore the area's transit in stages. The Port Authority is to begin working immediately on a temporary PATH connection to New Jersey that can be completed within two years. Later the builders could construct underground walkways stretching eastward from the World Financial Center across to a subway transit center at the Fulton Street station. This plan would try to replace the tangle of tunnels and stairways at Fulton Street with a more workable transit hub.
Mr. Whitehead's group needs to juggle many tasks at the same time -- the infrastructure must be mapped out and financed, Mr. Silverstein must be brought into the fuller picture and the public must be allowed to have its say before it is too late. The outcome should be a dramatic monument to the vibrancy of the city, a whole downtown plan far more powerful than the sum of its many parts.

HEADLINE: In New Blow to Peso, Argentine Court Voids Bank Freeze 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
In a surprise decision that pushes both the financial system and the wobbly peso closer to collapse, Argentina's Supreme Court ruled today that a freeze on bank withdrawals, imposed two months ago to prevent nervous depositors from cleaning out their accounts, was unconstitutional.
 President Eduardo Duhalde has warned that local banks do not have enough assets on hand to meet depositors' demands. Anticipating that the court's edict could set off a run on banks, the central bank tonight declared a bank and currency exchange holiday for Monday and Tuesday. 
 In a brief nationally televised speech tonight, Mr. Duhalde said that the court's decision was "very serious" but gave no indication how he intended to respond. 
"I know that a lot of people may be happy today, supposing they will go to the banks and get their money back," he said. "No one should be fooled," he added, warning that Argentina "is at risk."
Speaking of the bank freeze, Mr. Duhalde declared: "I've said since the first day that this is a time bomb that has to be disarmed, and carefully, so that it doesn't explode. If this bomb goes off, not only will those with deposits and accounts not be able to get their money. The whole Argentine system of production will be affected."
Mr. Duhalde had been expected to announce an economic stimulus plan over the weekend in an effort to break out of the economy's paralysis. The presentation of his plan was canceled today.
In its ruling, the court said that the bank freeze, originally ordered by former President Fernando de la Rua two weeks before food riots and street protests forced him to resign, was "unreasonable" and constituted an "annihilation" of the principle of private property. Depositors, it said, "have been the victim of injury to their patrimony" since they originally deposited their money under "a set of rules that guaranteed immutability."
The decision came exactly one month after Mr. Duhalde was sworn in as president, promising amid the worst economic crisis in Argentina's history that he would make this a "normal country" again. Today's ruling generated considerable new uncertainty in an economy that is already at a virtual standstill because of doubts about its direction. 
Finance officials are concerned that if depositors regained access to their accounts, they would immediately rush to convert their pesos into dollars, forcing the the government to abandon the official exchange rate of 1.4 pesos to the dollar and unleashing a steep devaluation. 
Mr. Duhalde's first action as president was to abandon the decade-long policy of linking the peso to the American dollar at a one-to-one rate. But he has repeatedly equivocated on how to lift the freeze on bank deposits, which had been in place for a month when he took office.
Loath to anger ordinary Argentines, Mr. Duhalde initially ordered that all dollar debts be converted into pesos at a rate highly favorable to debtors, which would have meant billions of dollars in losses for banks. But then, when foreign creditors and banks threatened to walk away from Argentina, Mr. Duhalde decided that dollar deposits should also be transformed into pesos, at a rate less advantageous to account holders.
"It's an extremely complicated situation," lamented the government's minister of production, Jose Ignacio de Mendiguren, in an interview today that reflected the government's sense that it has no options. "You touch one thing, and another goes out of balance. You touch that, and something else falls out of equilibrium."
At the same time that Mr. Duhalde has been vehemently blaming the banks for Argentina's misfortune, he and other officials have tried to rebuild their frayed ties with foreign creditors, which were severely strained when Argentina went into default on $141 billion in public debt at the end of December.
In a visit to Washington this week, Foreign Minister Carlos Ruckauf met with Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell as well as officials from the International Monetary Fund.
Argentines' growing fears have prompted them to wait in long lines outside banks and currency exchange houses in recent days in hopes of buying dollars in spite of unfavorable rates of exchange.
By most estimates, only 10 percent of Argentina's 36 million people have money deposited in the banks. But it is precisely that middle and upper class that must begin spending again so that the economy can be reactivated. With most of their money locked up in the banks, however, middle-class Argentines have been too frightened -- or too angry -- to spend anything.
According to a study published this week by Fundacion Mercado, an economic analysis group, only 1.8 percent of Argentine families generated any savings in January and no more than 1.7 percent had plans to buy durable goods. "That is the equivalent of eliminating both those items from the economy," the group said.
Car dealers say that January was their worst month in 40 years, with only 3,000 vehicles sold in the entire country, compared with nearly 29,000 in the same period two years ago and 19,000 last year. 
Businesses selling much cheaper goods appear to have been just as hard hit. During the 1990's, many of them shifted from selling locally made products to imported goods, but now find themselves sitting by helplessly and watching their inventories diminish with no chance to replenish them.
At an office supply and computer parts store here, salesmen are down to their last meager stocks of ink cartridges, computer disks and paper punches. Normally, those items are imported either from the United States or neighboring Brazil, but after Argentina's foreign debt default lines of supply have dried up and sales dropped from $500,000 a month before the recession to one-tenth of that figure.
"No banks are willing to give anybody in Argentina any credit right now, and I can't get dollars out of an account to pay in advance," said Gustavo Tozzo, the store's manager. "We're stuck."

HEADLINE: New Orleans, Amid Revelry, Makes Time to Vote Today 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
They cannot intrude upon the fantasy world of a Mardi Gras parade without defying a local taboo against Carnival campaigning. They can barely claw onto the airwaves without being engulfed in a fog of news about the most carefully guarded Super Bowl in history.
 So a huge field of candidates who want to run this slightly ungovernable city have had a hard time making their voices heard before Saturday's mayoral primary election, which ends less than 24 hours before the football championship. Politics here has always been as much theater as policy, but this year the audience is otherwise engaged. According to the polls, nearly a third of voters have yet to decide on a candidate from among the 15 jostling to succeed Mayor Marc A. Morial. 
 The field mushroomed in October after Mr. Morial's bid to bypass term limits in search of a third four-year term was defeated by the voters. Some of the candidates are linking themselves to his continued popularity, while others are distancing themselves from his reputation for patronage. But even the clear front-runner, Richard J. Pennington, the police superintendent, has only about 20 percent of the vote, most polls have found. So a runoff on March 2 between the top two vote-getters in the nonpartisan primary on Saturday is considered a certainty.
Most of the tussle has been for the No. 2 spot, and the insurgent candidate now considered most likely to get it is C. Ray Nagin, an executive with Cox Communications, which operates the local cable television system. Mr. Nagin won endorsements from The Times-Picayune and the popular political and cultural publication Gambit Weekly by promising to move away from the patronage that has perennially filled municipal jobs and contracts here.
"The city and state have a reputation for being pretty free-spirited," Mr. Nagin said in an interview today as he tried to shake hands with actual voters among the football throngs on the streets. "It's not like people offer you bags of cash in dark alleys, but I think we need to change the nature of politics here by being more customer- and business-friendly."
That approach has propelled him out of the pack in recent weeks and into the front ranks. For years, the city was preoccupied with a high crime rate, but during the tenure of Mr. Morial and Mr. Pennington, murders and other felonies have dropped sharply. Mr. Pennington continues to campaign on that accomplishment, but the race has turned more on economic issues.
"The city is getting smaller, and voters are increasingly concerned about its future," said Edward Renwick, director of the Loyola University Institute of Politics. "We're down to one Fortune 500 company, and many businesses have left the city. People want to hear what the candidates will do about it."
Mr. Pennington says crime reduction and a new emphasis on education will strengthen the city's economy. "I always felt that before you could have economic development, you had to have a safe city," he said. "Now that we have that, we can concentrate on bringing businesses back to the city."
Mr. Nagin, on the other hand, has proposed selling or leasing Louis Armstrong International Airport and using the revenue to rebuild decaying infrastructure and create jobs.
Another candidate, State Senator Paulette R. Irons, has been the most explicit in tying the shrinking of the economy to municipal patronage; she promises to revamp the city's contracting system completely. But her standing in polls dropped after she said she understood the nature of crime in the city because her brother had been murdered. It turned out he had been shot by the police while robbing a supermarket.
A few classic traits of New Orleans politics have not been drowned out. A grocery produce manager on the ballot as Manny (Chevrolet) Bruno says he will have no friends to pay off because he has no friends.
And the negative advertising and campaigning that might be unsettling elsewhere are expected here, particularly because it is often unclear who is paying for telephone messages that bash various candidates. Mr. Nagin, who like Mr. Pennington is black, is often portrayed on the telephone as a tool of the white business community in this predominantly black city, but among the most vicious things said about him is that he personally raised cable television fees.

HEADLINE: Economic Forum Is New York's Gain 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Bereft, Swiss Town Pines for Jet-Set Movers and World-Class Shakers" (news article, Jan. 31):
 Before the famous globalization meetings, Davos, it seems, was "just another Swiss ski resort." 
Well, not quite. Davos was the town station where patients and visitors disembarked to travel the short distance to the tuberculosis sanitarium in Thomas Mann's "Magic Mountain," published in 1924. 
 Since the novel was published, and for a long time thereafter, "Davos" evoked Mann's novel in the minds of Europeans and, later, Americans as well.
And in that novel, while there may be no exact parallels to the globalization meetings and the unruly protesters, Mann's book is full of high politics, loaded with heated and weighty political debates about European history that both globalization defenders and their opponents might find interesting today.
Of course, one wonders what Mann's characters (and Mann himself) would say about McDonald's and street clashes, but that's another story.

EDWARD ENGELBERG
Lexington, Mass., Jan. 31, 2002

The writer is professor emeritus of comparative literature and European cultural studies at Brandeis.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: WORKSHOPS; 
Where McDonald's Sits Down With Arab Nationalists

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
When critics assail the World Economic Forum as a gathering of tycoons and rulers, what they imagine is probably not Jack Greenberg, the fatherly chairman and C.E.O. of McDonald's, sitting alongside Amr Moussa, the often strident secretary general of the League of Arab States, debating the sources of global anger.
 But there they were today, in one of the better attended panel discussions, as the 2,500 participants at the Waldorf-Astoria went into their second day of workshops, lunches and private powwows. 
 The views of Mr. Greenberg and Mr. Moussazap were hardly surprising or radical. Mr. Greenberg defended his global chain of fast-food restaurants, which are often singled out by antiglobalization demonstrators, as "a model of how a corporation has to behave -- through dialogue, facts and solutions." Mr. Moussa said there were "deep grievances" against the policies of the United States in the Middle East, Africa and other parts of the world. 
But there was significance in the very fact that the forum -- known to its regulars as Davos, after the Swiss resort where it has always been held before -- focused several of its workshops, panels and lunches on the rising opposition to the globalization of business. 
Such emphasis on a concern that government and corporate leaders now frequently confront reflected the organizers' effort to give their critics a voice. An impressive security cordon around the Waldorf-Astoria demonstrated the immediacy of that concern, though only one lonely protester braved the chilly drizzle across Park Avenue from the hotel today.
"Davos is always a crash course on what's new in world trends and world thinking, and the fact that it's jumbled, that you feel confused, is part of the process," said Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, author of "Commanding Heights: the Battle Over the World Economy," and one of the panel leaders. 
"For a couple of years," he went on, "Davos was dominated by the global financial crisis, then two years ago it was the New Economy. Now, after major demonstrations at major economic meetings in the past year or two, there are these profound questions about globalization -- how does it work? What it is? What is its impact? For me, the amazing thing in a way is that there is so much passion about a word that has five syllables, about an abstract concept. Much of the debate about globalization doesn't really stop to say what is globalization."
That was a point made by several speakers, and addressed by some. "We still don't know what we mean by globalization, or what we want it to mean in the future," argued Felipe Fernandez Armesto, a professor at Oxford University, at a discussion of the future of antiglobalization. "The antiglobalization coalition is even looser than the coalition against terrorism. Some object to modernity, some to capitalism, some to excesses of capitalism. It is not against globalization, but against process bias -- rich versus poor, north versus south, west versus east."
Back at the "global anger" panel, Zaki Laidi of the Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches Internationales in France, developed the theme further. The reaction, he said, was not against globalization, but specifically against capitalism, against the rich and against the United States. The perception was that globalization is reducing the creation of goods while creating private wealth; that the process is biased against the poor; and that its agenda is shaped by the United States, by the major industrialized countries, by the World Trade Organization, without any tolerance for alternative prescriptions.
Finally, Mr. Laidi said, there was resentment against the United States as the only superpower, "which so influences the world while its own population has no interest in the world."
That theme -- that the United States uses its great wealth and power solely in its own interest -- surfaced repeatedly in various discussions. Michael J. Wolf, of the international consulting firm McKinsey & Company, suggested that the attacks on McDonald's or Starbucks outlets often occurred as a reaction to a perceived invasion of American culture to the detriment of local culture. "The media is a carrier of values," Mr. Wolf argued. "A show about rich people in New York and Los Angeles is incendiary to a lot of people."
The discussion was not all one-sided. Mr. Greenberg, who appeared to hold a special cachet as a spokesman for globalization because of the symbolism that McDonald's outlets have acquired around the world, said he knew that what he was about to say might be deemed provocative, but that "oftentimes the perception about global anger is somewhat different from the reality." 
As an example, he recalled the fiery 1999 World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle, where protesters went on a rampage and, among other things, vented their antiglobalization anger on a McDonald's. In the time that it took almost 2,000 protesters to damage property, Mr. Greenberg said, more than 175 million customers were served in McDonald's restaurants around the world.
Mr. Laidi went further, suggesting that responsibility for the failures of globalization were shared between rich and poor, because less developed countries were unable to put aid to good use. "The transfer of money from north to south is obviously part of the solution," he said, "but in many cases it is solving nothing, because there is a misuse of resources. This is a real problem, a real concern."
At yet another panel -- this one on "Who's Afraid of Globalization?" -- Davos organizers released a poll taken in 25 countries, rich and poor, that found a slim majority in poor countries agreeing that they benefited from globalization. The most negative reactions were in countries that have been hit hard by financial crises, like Indonesia or Argentina. The strongest support was in the United States and other developed countries, and it grew even stronger after Sept. 11.
Several analysts raised the notion that the terror attacks had changed attitudes toward globalization. One of them, John Gray of the London School of Economics, even suggested that "9/11 spelled the end of globalization." Ernesto Zedillo, a former president of Mexico, dismissed this as "hysterical." The attacks only demonstrated that "we need more globalization, not less."

HEADLINE: Enron and Sept. 11 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Great Divide," by Paul Krugman (column, Jan. 29):
 I strongly disagree with the idea that Enron's fall was bigger than the events of Sept. 11. 
Enron was about thousands of people who lost their jobs and their fortunes. It was also about some cowboys in Texas trying to play business, which is placing the focus on corporate governance and impartial accounting. Sept. 11 was about several thousand people who lost much more than that. 
 We sympathize and empathize with those who lost what they did in both events, but one must ask what is more important: money and a job, or your life?
I think that the effect on our economy, national self-confidence and overall well-being was shaken more by Sept. 11 than by selfish and underhanded business tactics. By comparing the two, Mr. Krugman seems to trivialize the significance of that day.

NILAM PATEL
New York, Jan. 29, 2002

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Shrank 5.1% In January 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Auto sales in the United States fell 5.1 percent in January compared with the month a year earlier and shrank even further from the strong sales at the end of last year as the enthusiasm for generous deals began to wane and the rental car industry continued to face problems. 
 But the decline was less than many analysts and economists had feared, and some say 2002 could be better than expected. 
 By January, all of the Big Three had retreated from the interest-free financing deals they had offered after Sept. 11. Those deals drove industry sales to the highest monthly level ever in October. Incentives took a different form, with General Motors offering $2,002 in rebates on its vehicle lineup and the Ford Motor Company offering rebates up to $2,500. Still, the end of interest-free financing was expected by many to bring steep declines. 
"Everyone was waiting for the cliff to fall off of," said Diane Swonk, an economist at Bank One. "Instead of going to a 15-million-unit pace, we could have easily seen sales drop to 13 million units," she said, adding, "The auto industry will surprise a lot of people this year."
Ford officials went further, proclaiming an end to the recession while cautioning that the pace of recovery might be modest. 
"What is particularly encouraging at this juncture is that so many economic indicators are improving at the same time," said Jarlath Costello, Ford's senior United States economist, citing gains in consumer confidence and stronger orders for capital goods. 
Ford raised its expectations for industry sales this year to 15.7 million cars and light trucks, including sport utility vehicles, pickups and minivans, from 15.2 million. In January, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 15.8 million, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a data service in Southfield, Mich.
"Given the fact we're in the middle of a recession and a hangover from zero-percent financing, the numbers are pretty good," said David Healy, an auto analyst at Burnham Securities. 
Still, there was some sobering news. The Lear Corporation, a big auto supplier based in Southfield, Mich., said today that it would cut 6,500 jobs. And Ford, G.M. and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler all lost more market share to foreign competitors.
The sales declines at the Big Three were worsened by a steep falloff in sales to the rental car industry, which has suffered since Sept. 11 because it does much of its business at airports. In November, ANC Rental, which operates the Alamo and National rental car chains, sought bankruptcy protection. Last month, the company said it would close nearly 200 Alamo sites. 
Ripples from the fallout in the rental industry could be seen in sales of passenger cars at the Big Three. At G.M., overall sales fell 13 percent, but G.M.'s light truck sales rose 10 percent while car sales fell 34 percent. At Ford, where overall sales declined 10.4 percent, car sales fell 17.5 percent while light truck sales fell 6.3 percent. But the company, which announced a turnaround plan last month, said the drop was something of a relief.
"We expected our sales to be down in the range of 15 or 20 percent," said George Pipas, Ford's sales analyst. 
At Chrysler, sales fell 9 percent, which was not as bad as some analysts feared after the company made an ominous warning earlier in the week that it was increasing spending on incentives because of a disappointing January. 
If the overall market was a pleasant surprise, the Big Three domestic automakers continue to come under pressure from Asian and European manufacturers. At Toyota, which ranks fourth in sales in the United States, sales rose 7.1 percent as it continued to gain on Chrysler, the smallest of the Big Three. Sales at Honda fell 1.5 percent, while sales at Nissan rose 9.6 percent, helped by a redesigned Altima sedan. Volkswagen sales rose 6 percent, and sales at B.M.W. were up 16.2 percent. 
Those sales gains came with far less spending on incentives than was the case with the Big Three, and foreign car are helped by exchange rates that are highly favorable. 
"The pricing environment has not substantially lessened," Mr. Pipas of Ford said. "It's still very intense. I expect that to remain difficult, and it's one of the challenges we face, we all face, in this coming year and for years to come."

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: EX-CHIEF'S FAMILY; 
Son and Sister Of Enron Chief Secured Deals

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA and KURT EICHENWALD 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
The sister and a son of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of the Enron Corporation, benefited from extensive business dealings with Enron, according to public records and interviews with family members and people close to the Lays.
 The ties included Enron contracts with companies controlled by Lay family members and investments in companies in which family members had substantial holdings. 
 Over the last three years, Mr. Lay and his son Mark, 33, invested about $1 million in two privately held technology companies. Months after the deals, Enron signed contracts with both of them and invested in one of the companies. 
In 1997, as a shareholder group was complaining about such ties, Enron acquired a company co-owned by Mark Lay that hoped to go into the business of trading paper and pulp products. Kenneth Lay knew at the time that Mark Lay and an energy company Mark controlled were targets of a federal criminal investigation of suspected bankruptcy fraud and embezzlement, Mark Lay said.
As part of the deal, Enron hired Mark Lay as an executive with a three-year contract that guaranteed him at least $1 million in pay over that period, plus options to purchase about 20,000 shares of Enron. 
In addition to the dealings with Mark Lay, Enron for years has used the services of a Houston travel agency co-owned by Kenneth Lay's sister, Sharon Lay. According to public filings, the agency, Alliance Worldwide, has booked more than $10 million in revenue from Enron, representing over half of the firm's business.
Mark Lay and Sharon Lay said that nothing improper took place in any of the transactions. All required disclosures on Enron's dealings with family members were made, they said, adding that Kenneth Lay did not use his influence to award Enron contracts to companies with family ties. Enron declined to comment, and Kenneth Lay and his lawyer did not return phone calls.
No charges were brought against Mark Lay in the criminal investigation, which came to an end last year after the United States attorney in Tyler, Tex., decided not to pursue the case. Mark Lay, who left Enron last year to enter a local Baptist seminary, paid nearly $315,000 to settle a related civil case, without admitting to any wrongdoing.
"I walked into a snake's nest," the younger Mr. Lay said in an interview this week, describing the business affairs that led to the criminal investigation. "I trusted the wrong people and ended up in a transaction that everybody decided was wrong." 
Legal experts said there were no clear violations of securities laws in the Lay-Enron dealings. But critics said the transactions were further examples of how top officials of Enron entangled themselves in a pattern of conflicts.
"This only underscores our concern about the self-dealing that permeates the board at Enron," said Bill Patterson, director of the office of investment at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which estimates that its member unions' pension funds lost $1 billion in the Enron collapse.
Enron first mentioned dealings with Lay family members in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the mid-1990's. 
Mark Lay left a low-level position at Enron in 1992, went to work at an energy trading company and then struck out on his own in 1994. After that, the records show, three successive small companies he owned or worked for did business with Enron.
One company was Bruin Interests L.L.C., a natural gas company that had a contract to store billions of cubic feet of natural gas in Enron's underground storage tanks. Bruin, which also did consulting work for Enron, traded and speculated in natural gas; Mark Lay was a co-owner.
Bruin later acquired a stake in R&C Petroleum, an East Texas energy company, after it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March 1994. The company was quickly restructured, but continued to pile up huge losses.
Later that year, a court-appointed trustee for R&C's creditors filed a civil suit against Bruin and several other companies, contending that Bruin and its affiliates engaged in a series of complex transactions with one another that allowed the companies to hide R&C assets and siphon money away from the bankrupt company and its creditors. They charged the R&C management team, including Mark Lay, with embezzling more than $1 million.
"They were hiding assets and stealing assets," said Cindy Scarbrough, an accountant who followed the case with her father, one of the early investors in R&C. "They had all these partnerships and shell corporations, and they would charge transportation costs that were way above normal."
Mark Lay said that he was not involved in the scheme, insisting that his partners in the R&C venture manipulated him and stole the profits. People who worked with Mark Lay said that the lawyers arrayed against R&C focused on him in the litigation because he was the son of the wealthy chairman of Enron.
"I was just 25 years old," Mr. Lay said, "and I trusted the wrong people." Like Mr. Lay, several of his associates in R&C paid to settle civil litigation without acknowledging wrongdoing.
Mr. Lay said his father was "supportive" throughout the episode; it was on his father's advice, for example, that he hired a lawyer from Vinson & Elkins, the law firm that represents Enron.
Robert Crist Vial, a lawyer for one creditor in the R&C bankruptcy case, said in-house Enron lawyers monitored some of the legal proceedings.
"I know and will swear under oath that Enron attorneys attended some of these hearings for him," Mr. Vial said. "I asked them why they were there, and they said, 'Ken Lay is Enron, and this is the man's son.' "
Just months after the civil suit was settled in 1996, and while the criminal investigation remained active, Enron acquired another company owned by Mark Lay, the Paper and Print Management Corporation. Mr. Lay and his partner, another former Enron employee, hoped the company would be a pioneer in the business of trading paper and pulp products, but it had not signed up a single client when Enron acquired it.
Rather than pay a purchase price, Enron gave Mark Lay and his partners three-year, $1 million pay packages. Enron also agreed to pay a division of the Southern Company, another large energy company, $1 million to drop its investment in Paper and Print.
The deal seemed to pay off for Enron; within 18 months of acquiring Paper and Print, the division generated about $20 million in operating profit, Mark Lay said. 
Paper and Print had itself been spun off from another Houston company for which Mark Lay had done consulting work: the United Media Corporation. United Media at one time did about $1 million a year in graphics business with Enron, creating graphic illustrations for executive presentations, according to people who worked at the company. Mr. Lay said that he had no role in the Enron contracts.
More recently, Mark and Kenneth Lay -- like Enron -- turned their attention to the Internet. In May 2000, the two men invested about $500,000 in an Internet start-up called EterniTV, a company that provides video services over the Web. 
Four months later, Enron, which had ambitious plans at the time to build a broadband distribution and trading business, signed a contract to help EterniTV deliver its content. 
Officials at EterniTV said there was no connection between the investment and the contract. "It's pure coincidence that we used Enron," said Jonathan Kirk, chairman and co-founder of EterniTV, which is based in San Francisco.
In December 1999, in an early round of financing, Kenneth and Mark Lay invested close to $500,000 in EC Outlook, a Houston company that develops supply chain management software, Mark Lay said. The two men then recommended the company to Enron, which invested in a later financing round in September 2000 with VenRock Associates, a venture capital fund created by the Rockefeller family. 
In February 2001, EC Outlook said, it signed a licensing agreement with Enron to use its software.
John C. Coffee Jr., an expert in securities law at Columbia University, said it did not appear that Enron was required to make disclosures related to the technology deals.
"It's not a classic conflict of interest," he said. "It may simply be illustrative of the kind of backscratching, incestuous relationships that occur in the business world. And it could have ripened into a conflict of interest."
Enron's disclosures of its dealings with Sharon Lay's travel agency and a consulting agreement with Mark Lay's Bruin Interests prompted shareholder complaints at a union meeting in 1997. The company defended the deals as proper.
Ms. Lay said that her company won the contract as Enron's lead travel agency through competitive bidding. 
"There are some who thought it was only because of my relationship to Ken that we got the contract and that's far from the truth," Ms. Lay said. "It's unfortunate that you can be put at a disadvantage because of a relationship."
For now, Mark Lay, who has worked off and on at Enron for much of the last decade, is taking a break from business. In 1995, when the R&C episode was in full bloom, he said, he paid a visit to the Second Baptist Church in Houston, where the minister was preaching about Daniel's survival in the lion's den.
"That gave me a true appreciation of what a true faith in God meant," Mr. Lay said.
Last year, after serving as president of Enron Investment Partners, a unit of Enron that invested in minority-owned businesses in the Houston area, he enrolled at the Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary in Houston.
"I think God impressed on me that's where he wanted me," Mr. Lay said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about business dealings between the Enron Corporation and the sister and a son of Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive, included an incorrect paraphrase of remarks by the son, Mark Lay, about a criminal investigation into one of his companies. Mark Lay said that he thought the inquiry had concluded in 1995, not that he and his father knew there was an investigation in 1997. The investigation continued until 2001, according to lawyers involved in the case.
