HEADLINE: State of the Enron 

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH; E-mail: frankrich@nytimes.com

 BODY:
I had just finished crying over the tragic news that President Bush's mother-in-law had lost $8,000 on her Enron stock when another heartbreaking story sent me reaching once more for the Kleenex. There on the "Today" show this week was the sobbing figure of Linda Lay, Ken's wife, telling America the most rending tale of dispossession since the Yankees stole Tara from Scarlett O'Hara.
 "Other than the home we live in, everything we own is for sale," said Mrs. Lay. "There's nothing left." Given that her husband has received some $200 million in compensation from Enron since 1999, and that he (as she explained) was kept in the dark about his own company's shell games, the message was clear: The Lays are the biggest victims of the entire scandal, bigger victims by far than those grandstanding employees who complain of having lost pensions in the piddling five, six or seven figures. 
 As if the Lays' predicament is not upsetting enough, the "Today" show left us wondering if the second-biggest victim of Enron's collapse may be the Holocaust Museum Houston, whose representative came on-screen along with various clergy and Lay offspring to testify to the family's beneficence. If the Lays are broke, you had to ask, is it only a matter of time before the Holocaust is consigned to the Houston memory hole along with the Astrodome? 
I'd still be weeping as copiously as Linda Lay had I not subsequently read in The Wall Street Journal that she and her husband still owned 18 properties in Texas and Colorado, only two of which are up for sale, and that Ken Lay still owned $10 million in non-Enron stocks. Thankfully, others are lending emotional support to the couple in my stead. After ministering to Mr. Lay, Jesse Jackson likened him to Job.
Linda Lay's "Today" performance was coached by a freelancing alum of Hill & Knowlton, the wonderful p.r. folks who have made Americans fall in love with such past clients as the Tobacco Institute, the Teamsters and the Church of Scientology. Perhaps Mrs. Lay hoped she might rev up the nation's sympathy for her man, who rolls out his hear-no-evil, see-no-evil, speak-no-evil defense when testifying before Congress on Monday. But what lingers instead is her colossal arrogance. Just as Ken Lay misled his own employees about the sinking financial health of his company, imploring them to buy more stock while dumping his own, so Linda Lay takes us all for dupes, ready to be sold another bill of goods while she and hubby plot their next escape to Aspen. She didn't even identify which of the Lay sons was the target of a criminal investigation for bankruptcy fraud and embezzlement.
This is why Enron may be as much a cultural scandal as it is a business and political scandal. It is, as one friend puts it, as if a window had opened and revealed the way it all really works. What we see is a world in which insiders get to play by one set of rules -- entree to Enron side partnerships that could turn minimal investments into millions overnight -- while the unconnected and uninitiated pick up the bill. And it isn't necessarily illegal. All manner of creative accounting schemes took root in the corporate loophole land that was protected from reform in the 90's by such inquisitors-come-lately as Joseph Lieberman and Billy Tauzin, both recipients of accounting-industry largess. It's going to be easier for the Feds to nail mid-level scapegoats, especially those operating shredding machines, than to prove that a Ken Lay or Jeffrey Skilling had felonious intent. 
Nor is this culture limited to one party or one company. Terry McAuliffe, the Democrats' chairman, has called Enron "simply outrageous" and declared that his "heart goes out to the employees and shareholders who were victimized by a web of greed and deceit." Now we learn that he parlayed a ground-floor $100,000 investment in the Bermuda-based, Beverly Hills-situated telecom company Global Crossing into $18 million and cashed out well before Global Crossing went belly-up this week, after having never turned a single yearly profit. We are to believe it is Mr. McAuliffe's business acumen that landed him on that ground floor in the first place, not the buddy network he cultivated as chief fund-raiser to his president, Bill Clinton. "If you don't like capitalism," said Mr. McAuliffe in defense of his windfall, "move to Cuba or China."
I wonder if Mr. McAuliffe's heart goes out to a schoolteacher who, having lost more than $120,000 in Global Crossing, told The Times this week, "I don't know how the management of this company did so well while small shareholders did so poorly." Gary Winnick, Global Crossing's chairman and a Clinton-McAuliffe golf partner, walked away with $730 million.
Perhaps that benighted teacher should go back to school and study the bipartisan gospel of both Mr. McAuliffe and our Treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, who has cited Enron's swift rise and fall as a natural phenomenon "of the genius of capitalism." Under their tutelage, she would learn how Thomas White, the Bush administration's secretary of the Army, could legally exit with more than $10 million of proceeds from an Enron division that, according to his colleagues, overstated its profits by hundreds of millions on Mr. White's watch (he was vice chairman) and has since tossed overboard most of its employees.
President Bush believes that his impressive stewardship of the war will make these stories go away, and so he chose not to mention the word Enron during his State of the Union address. But the country gets the picture now, and the more Dick Cheney tries to defend the secrecy of his energy policy task force, the more he sounds as arrogant and disingenuous as Linda Lay. No less an authority than John Dean has declared of Mr. Cheney's stonewalling that "not since Richard Nixon stiffed the Congress during Watergate has a White House so openly, and arrogantly, defied Congress's investigative authority."
For all the vice president's lofty talk of the principle of executive branch confidentiality, The Times's Don Van Natta reports that the administration had no qualms about releasing an avalanche of records from the Clinton White House. Mr. Cheney has even violated his sacrosanct principle of confidentiality about his own meetings when it suits him politically. As The Los Angeles Times reported last August, the task force did depart from its pledge of secrecy once, when officials paraded a group of renewable-energy experts before White House reporters after their meeting with Mr. Cheney. How cynical can you get? That show meeting took place on the day before the energy plan was sent to President Bush. In reality, environmentalists had about as much serious access to the secret deliberations over Bush energy policy as common stockholders did to the secret partnerships at Enron. 
Since we already know that Enron did have repeated meetings with the Cheney task force, what is he covering up? Logic dictates there must be some bombshells among the non-Enron names, starting with any from the vice president's former (and now imperiled) employer, Halliburton. Equally revealing are the names of those he rebuffed. This week Dianne Feinstein, the senior senator from California, revealed that her three requests to meet personally with either the president or the vice president during her state's energy crisis were denied even as the administration greeted Enron executives bearing wish lists.
Like Linda Lay, the Bush administration asks that we take its ethical purity on faith. In defending the energy task force, Ari Fleischer went so far this week as to invoke the founding fathers on behalf of clandestine administration dealings with oil company executives. "The very document that protects our liberties more than anything else, the Constitution, was, of course, drafted in total secrecy," he said. Never mind that the names of those drafters, unlike the modern-day patriots meeting with Mr. Cheney, were not kept secret. These days freedom's just another word for nothing left for Enron shareholders to lose. 
POSTSCRIPT: After my previous column, Mr. Fleischer called me to say that I had been unfair to Lawrence Lindsey, the administration's chief economic adviser, when I wrote that during a Jan. 12 appearance on CNN he had not mentioned overseeing an October administration review of the impact of Enron's travails. Mr. Fleischer says that Mr. Lindsey was doing exactly that when he spoke on CNN of his staff "monitoring the energy markets." I guess I didn't notice because I was too busy wondering why Mr. Lindsey, a $50,000-a-year Enron adviser as recently as 2000, would have been connected to any such review.

HEADLINE: Sharon Said to Meet Secretly With 3 Aides to Arafat 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel met here secretly this week with three Palestinian leaders acting as emissaries of Yasir Arafat, Palestinian officials said.
 It was the first time Mr. Sharon had met with any Palestinian official since winning election as prime minister almost a year ago. His office declined to comment on the matter. 
 The meeting did not appear to portend an imminent breakthrough to negotiations. Both sides were said to have restated their clashing views. Also, in an interview published today by the newspaper Yediot Ahronot, Mr. Sharon said he would urge President Bush in a meeting next week to sever ties with Mr. Arafat. 
"Boycott him," Mr. Sharon said, summarizing his message to the president. He said he would urge that Mr. Bush "not hold any contacts with him and not send any delegations to him."
Mr. Bush has not so far met Mr. Arafat, and refused even to shake his hand when the two passed close to each other at a United Nations meeting in New York last fall.
But Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, Mr. Bush's special envoy for the Middle East, has met the Palestinian leader, most recently on a visit this month, before a fresh wave of violence.
Palestinian officials said tonight that Mr. Sharon sent an envoy to Mr. Arafat on Tuesday to set up the meeting with top deputies to the Palestinian leader. The meeting reportedly took place in Jerusalem on Wednesday night.
The Palestinian officials at the meeting were Ahmed Qurei, the speaker of the Palestinian parliament, and Mahmoud Abbas, a top leader of the Palestinian Liberation Organization. Both men, known respectively as Abu Ala and Abu Mazen, are regarded as advocates of negotiations rather than violence. Khaled Salam, an economic adviser to Mr. Arafat, also took part. 
Palestinian officials said the delegation had demanded an end to Israeli military operations in Palestinian-controlled territory and the carrying out of plans to return the antagonists to the negotiating table.
The Israel radio reported that the meeting had focused on stopping violence. Mr. Sharon has repeatedly said he would permit no negotiations while fighting continues.
Mr. Qurei has been meeting frequently with the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, to hammer out a plan for resuming negotiations. But Mr. Sharon, expressing skepticism about their talks, has said he must approve any agreement.
Mr. Sharon was likely to draw severe criticism from his political right for even speaking to representatives of Mr. Arafat. But news of the meeting was first reported by the Israel radio at the beginning of the Jewish Sabbath, during which newspapers are not published in Israel and politicians generally fall silent out of conviction or deference to the religiously observant. 
Mr. Sharon's domestic critics were thus denied a platform for 24 hours. In the meantime, the gesture toward peace was likely to receive wide international attention.
The prime minister has been seeking to isolate and put pressure on Mr. Arafat diplomatically and militarily in order, he says, to prompt him to crush militant Palestinian organizations. Israeli Army tanks are stationed on Palestinian-controlled territory within 100 yards of Mr. Arafat's compound in the West Bank city of Ramallah. Israeli forces have blocked Mr. Arafat from leaving Ramallah for two months now.
In the interview with Yediot Ahronot, Mr. Sharon said, "I don't think that we have exhausted all the pressure."
In an interview published on Thursday by the newspaper Maariv, Mr. Sharon said he was sorry Israel did not kill Mr. Arafat when it had a chance in Lebanon 20 years ago. But in speaking of the current impasse, he told Yediot: "We pledged not to harm Arafat physically. Nor did I set as a goal expelling him from here."
Politicians to his right are urging that he take even more aggressive action against Mr. Arafat. 
Today, in an op-ed article published in Maariv, Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister and Mr. Sharon's chief rival, scorned the notion of any "central members" of Mr. Sharon's government "speaking with the Palestinian Authority."
"Arafat's regime must be toppled, and it must be done immediately," he wrote. A majority of Israelis, 54 percent, believe that Mr. Arafat himself should be toppled, according to a poll published today in Maariv.
Polling here shows that the public overwhelmingly approves of aggressive actions against the Palestinian Authority. But a plurality also supports more aggressive efforts toward peace.
Yediot described Mr. Sharon as amused by a poll showing that 70 percent of Israelis wanted him to deal severely with the Palestinians, while 70 percent also wanted him to give up the West Bank and Gaza Strip. "So what should I do?" the paper quoted him as saying.
Recent polls suggest that support for Mr. Sharon is softening somewhat. Today's Maariv poll showed his public approval rating at 48 percent. In the poll, 37 percent approved his handling of security, and 18 percent approved of his handling of "socio-economic matters." The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: Communities Built on Steel Fear Its Collapse 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WHEELING, W.Va. 

 BODY:
For decades, steel making has meant fat paychecks and steady jobs for thousands of families in the Ohio Valley towns that stretch north from here.
 But now there is fear, bordering on panic, that the hometown steel company that has brought middle-class prosperity could be at death's door. That company, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, has filed for bankruptcy, and its managers and workers say that the blast furnaces, rolling mills, foundries, coke ovens and galvanizing shops -- as well as a way of life -- could go under any day now unless Washington rushes to the rescue and somehow limits low-cost imports. 
 "It would be devastation, absolute devastation up and down the valley," said Charlie Stock, a Wheeling-Pitt worker. "I'm 50 years old, 32 years in the mills, with just a high school education. What am I going to do? I don't think there's much demand for a blast furnace keeper." 
Such fears are being heard in Ohio Valley towns like Beech Bottom, Follansbee, Steubenville and Mingo Junction and throughout steel country, where more than two dozen steel makers have filed for bankruptcy over the past four years. Tens of thousands of steel workers fear that they may soon lose their jobs, their anxiety heightened by the recent decision by one of the largest steel companies, LTV, to shut down, throwing 7,500 employees out of work across the Midwest. These workers, many in their 50's, are left with a few months' health insurance and dismal prospects.
At Wheeling-Pitt, workers and management have long blamed each other for the industry's woes, but they agree on one thing, that President Bush must do something soon to prevent other steel makers from suffering LTV's fate. Now that a federal commission has found that low-priced imports have improperly hurt the industry, they want him to impose tariffs of 40 percent on foreign steel.
While the Bush administration has often professed free-trade beliefs and a dislike of tariffs, the steel industry has one big factor working in its favor. Many mills are in West Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio, swing states that played a major role in the 2000 presidential election and could make the difference again.
Many West Virginians say that if President Bill Clinton had granted the import relief that they are seeing from President Bush, Vice President Al Gore would have won West Virginia and that would have given him the presidency.
"It hurt Gore badly" said Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a West Virginia Democrat and a champion of the steel industry. "The political implications of not doing anything are huge. We're talking about all these people going from $48,000 a year, a big salary here, to zip. No health insurance. No salary. No future. No hope."
Joe Smarella, who has worked for 38 years in Wheeling-Pitt's 80-inch rolling mill, said that he comes from a family of Democrats -- his grandfather worked in the mills for 40 years and his father for 43 years -- and that he voted for President Clinton twice. But Mr. Smarella admitted that he was so angry about the Clinton administration's resistance to higher steel tariffs that he voted for Mr. Bush in 2000.
"I got smacked once or twice," Mr. Smarella said. "That's it for me. I'm not going to let them smack me a third time."
This is a region with long memories. The workers remember that President Clinton visited Weirton Steel in West Virginia, right after he was nominated in 1992, and promised to stop foreign steel from being dumped at rock-bottom prices. The workers also remember that Dick Cheney visited Weirton on the eve of the 2000 election and pledged that the Bush administration would keep the steel industry strong.
If anything, the industry has grown weaker since Mr. Bush's election. One of the historic giants of the industry, Bethlehem Steel, has filed for bankruptcy. Steel prices have dipped to $200 a ton, the same price as 20 years ago. Wheeling-Pitt, a unit of WHX, has lost more than $300 million since it filed for bankruptcy reorganization 14 months ago.
There are many reasons for the steel crisis: the recession, low steel prices, high wages, old blast furnaces, a surge in steel imports after the Asian economic crisis in 1998, the rapid growth of mini-mills that make steel from scrap, and the colossal liability that steel makers face for health insurance and pensions for retirees.
The retirees are both a burden and a weapon. With four times as many retirees as workers -- 600,000 compared with 150,000 active workers, the industry is barely able to finance the health insurance and pensions for the retirees. But those 600,000 retirees and the 400,000 spouses and other family members who share in their benefits represent an even more powerful voting bloc than those still working. The retirees are flooding the White House with postcards because they want Wheeling-Pitt and other steel makers rescued to safeguard their health insurance and pensions.
Wheeling-Pittsburgh's roots go back to 1852, with the opening of a nail factory along the Ohio River -- the steel towns on the west bank are in Ohio, those on the east bank are in West Virginia. In some communities along the Ohio, 40 percent of the families send someone to the mills each day. Supermarkets, auto dealers, bars and gas stations also depend on steel dollars.
"The steel industry is critical to the existence and well-being of our community," said Anthony Paesano, mayor of Follansbee, W.Va., a town of 3,000 that obtains more than 20 percent of its taxes and school budget from Wheeling-Pitt's operations. "Everybody is worried, and everybody is waiting for the president of the United States to act."
The Bush administration has not tipped its hand on what it will do. But administration officials say that if they grant import relief, the industry must consolidate. With this in mind, U.S. Steel, the nation's largest steel maker, has floated a plan to acquire Wheeling-Pitt and three other companies and to close several inefficient plants.
Wheeling-Pitt was ready to close its doors two weeks ago, but after some frantic negotiations, the governors of Ohio and West Virginia, investors and the United Steelworkers of America came up with $27 million to keep the company running. In an unusual move, the union at Wheeling-Pitt agreed to a 27.75 percent pay cut for several months. All this maneuvering saved the jobs of the company's 4,100 workers, at least for a few more weeks.
"If Mr. Bush says no relief on imports, the next day I'm shutting this company down," said James G. Bradley, Wheeling-Pittsburgh's chief executive. 
Saying that imports have badly undercut prices and destroyed profitability, Mr. Bradley argued that high tariffs were needed to lift prices and nurse domestic steel makers back to health.
But many experts say granting the tariffs would only delay the extinction of the nation's steel dinosaurs.
John Casey, a steelworker wearing a Pittsburgh Steelers jacket, had little patience for that attitude.
"We've lost the textile industry," Mr. Casey said. "We've lost the consumer electronics industry. Is the steel industry going to go the same way? And if it does, what's going to be left of the middle class?"

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks to Revamp System for Auto Fuel-Economy Standards 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
The Bush administration asked Congress today for broad authority to revamp the nation's regulation of fuel-economy standards, but it is unclear whether it wants to set more lenient standards or increase the fuel efficiency of the nation's auto fleet. 
 The request was made in a letter from Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta to Congress and came as the Senate Commerce Committee prepared to make proposals on the current system. 
Under corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, standards, each automaker's annual fleet of new cars must average 27.5 miles a gallon, and new light trucks must average 20.7 miles a gallon. 
 "The current CAFE system has created an incentive for manufacturers to produce smaller and lighter cars," Mr. Mineta wrote, adding that studies show that lighter vehicles can be more dangerous than heavier ones. Mr. Mineta proposed setting various guidelines within different weight classes and allowing companies to trade fuel-economy credits. 
The auto industry had been pressing the Bush administration to take the matter out of the hands of the Senate, which is controlled by Democrats. By contrast, the auto industry successfully worked to keep the matter out of the Transportation Department's hands when it was controlled by the Clinton administration. Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts and the chairman of the CAFE hearing, said recently that he took a dim view of "forum shopping" and appears intent on raising fuel- economy standards. 
Leonardo Alcivar, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, said that Mr. Mineta's letter "is a clear declaration that the administration is committed to a significant improvement in fuel efficiency."
But environmental groups continue to be skeptical and say the administration's intent is to delay any action on the fuel standards, which have not been raised significantly since the 1980's.

HEADLINE: Amtrak Sets Austerity Plan And Seeks Aid 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Facing mounting debts, Amtrak announced a sweeping austerity plan yesterday while threatening to end legendary long-haul passenger routes like the Empire Builder if Congress does not provide $1.2 billion in financing next year. 
 To cut costs, Amtrak will eliminate 1,000 union and management jobs, about 4 percent of its national work force. It will also defer station improvements and limit the refurbishment of rail cars to urgent repairs. Ticket window hours at 73 of the least-used rail stations in the nation will be shortened, while spending for advertising, marketing and research will be reduced. 
 Over all, Amtrak hopes to save $285 million this year. But the cost of repairing stations and thousands of miles of track keep mounting, and Amtrak -- which lost $1.1 billion last year -- will remain in the red. 
In making the announcement today, the company's president, George D. Warrington, abandoned efforts to reach operational self-sufficiency by the end of this year, a goal mandated by Congress. By asking for $1.2 billion in the federal budget that President Bush will introduce on Monday, Mr. Warrington made it clear that he thought the railroad could not run properly without subsidies. He issued an ultimatum to Congress and the White House: Provide enough money or Amtrak will systematically end most of the long-haul passenger service that only Amtrak provides. Routes like the Chicago-to-Seattle Empire Builder and the Crescent, which links New York and New Orleans, would disappear as soon as October. 
"Corporate profitability is not compatible with the operation of long-distance trains, which by their nature are and always will be unprofitable," Mr. Warrington said. "Policy makers need to decide what kind of passenger rail system America needs, how much the system requires in capital and operating support and how the government will pay for the system."
Amtrak's moves will sharpen the debate over the railroad company, a government corporation formed in 1971. Ridership has increased steadily over the last few years, but the economic downturn has cut into the railroad's income by as much as $120 million, Amtrak estimates. Adopting additional security measures after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cost $16.5 million. 
Sept. 11 highlighted the importance of a national rail system providing an alternative to air travel. For its part, the Bush administration is pressing for a thorough reassessment of passenger service in the United States.
Amtrak's Congressional authorization expires before the end of the year, and Congress is divided over reauthorizing the system, which carried more than 23 million passengers last year. Members of Congress from the Northeast and the Pacific Coast, where high-speed rail service is heavily used, continue to support Amtrak. In much of the rest of the country, where trains run infrequently and ridership is low, the railroad is often seen as a waste of money. 
In recent months, both the General Accounting Office and the Amtrak Reform Council, which Congress established to keep an eye on Amtrak's finances, have concluded that Amtrak has no chance of weaning itself from subsidies. 
Thomas A. Till, chairman of the council, said the government should pay to upgrade the nation's railroad tracks and bridges and maintain them. But in a report scheduled to be delivered to Congress on Feb. 7, the council will recommend that about 400 miles of track in the Northeast Corridor be taken from Amtrak and financed directly by the government. The council will also suggest that private operating companies be allowed to compete with Amtrak. 
Amtrak officials have argued that the council's actions have hurt the railroad. Mr. Warrington said lenders walked away from $52 million in financing for equipment and services after the council issued its finding on Amtrak's ability to become self-sufficient. 
Railroad unions also opposed the council's actions. A federal judge yesterday denied their request for a temporary restraining order to prevent the council from presenting its restructuring plan to Congress on Feb. 7.

HEADLINE: Budget Would Cut Medicaid Payments 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
President Bush's budget would rein in the growth of Medicaid by reducing payments to public hospitals and by cracking down on state efforts to obtain extra federal money to finance health care for the poor, administration officials said today.
 The administration says it is "closing loopholes" and curbing "abusive practices" that states have used to expand Medicaid without putting up all the state money required by federal law. 
 But state and local officials and members of Congress of both parties have objected to the administration plan. They said the cutbacks, expected to save $9 billion over the next five years, would harm Medicaid recipients and aggravate fiscal problems plaguing most states. 
Two Republican governors, Jeb Bush of Florida and Rick Perry of Texas, have joined Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and the House delegations from New York and California in protesting the administration's plan. 
The United States Conference of Mayors, the National Governors' Association and the National Association of Counties said they would urge Congress to block or postpone the cuts, which are to be made in a new regulation that takes effect this spring.
The president's budget, to be unveiled on Monday, assumes that the federal government will save the $9 billion by reducing Medicaid payments to public hospitals in at least 31 states. State officials said they would lose one-fourth to one-half of the special payments they now receive for public hospitals.
In 1991, the first Bush administration tried to crack down on schemes used by states to maximize their federal Medicaid money, and President Bill Clinton continued the effort, over objections by governors and mayors. The new restrictions go beyond those imposed by Mr. Clinton.
Federal officials said they were stepping up efforts to recover what they regard as overpayments to the states.
The administration is now demanding, for example, that Missouri return $1.6 billion paid to the state in the last seven years. It contends that the state is imposing an illegal tax on hospitals to cover the state's share of Medicaid.
Dana Katherine Martin, director of the Missouri Department of Social Services, said the state was resisting the federal demand.
"The money," Ms. Martin said, "has allowed us to cover many people who were previously uninsured. If we had to return the money or repeal the tax, it would jeopardize health care for more than 850,000 people who are poor or disabled."
Missouri, like most states, is caught in a financial vise. Medicaid costs are soaring, and the number of Medicaid recipients has increased, but state revenues have declined because of the recession.
Federal officials said President Bush would not propose any significant cuts in payments to hospitals under Medicare, the health program for the elderly. But they said the cutbacks in Medicaid were needed to prevent abuse by some states.
Gary B. Redding, commissioner of the Georgia Department of Community Health, said the timing of the cuts in Medicaid "could not be worse." 
Mississippi says it will lose $40 million a year, or 29 percent of the special Medicaid payments distributed each year to 21 public hospitals. Arkansas expects to lose $20 million, or half its allotment.
New Jersey says that University Hospital in Newark will lose $59 million a year, or one-third of its payments, as a result of the new federal policy.
San Francisco General Hospital expects to lose $10 million a year. 
Senators Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, and Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, have introduced a bill to delay the cuts for a year. Representative Nathan Deal, Republican of Georgia, has offered a similar bill in the House.
Medicaid is financed jointly by the federal government and the states, while the federal government raises or supplies all the money for Medicare. Federal spending on Medicaid grew 11 percent last year, to $130 billion. The increase was driven, in part, by spending on prescription drugs, which rose 19 percent.
Under the existing Medicaid rules, which took effect just 10 months ago, states can pay public hospitals up to 150 percent of what would be paid for the same services under Medicare. The new Bush administration policy will lower the ceiling to 100 percent.
Larry S. Gage, president of the National Association of Public Hospitals, said the higher payments were justified because public hospitals had higher costs. Many of their patients are uninsured, he said. Also, he noted, many public hospitals run costly special services like trauma care and burn units.
Bush administration officials say public hospitals do not keep all the extra federal money, but kick back some to state governments, which can use it for education, highway construction and other purposes unrelated to Medicaid. While acknowledging abuses in the past, state officials insist that all the Medicaid money is now used for health care.
In the last few days, administration officials have announced several proposals to help people obtain health care, including income tax credits for buying private health insurance. 
Sara Rosenbaum, a professor of health law and policy at George Washington University, said: "The insurance proposals may help some people over time, but that's speculative. By contrast, the Medicaid cuts will have an immediate adverse effect on states' ability to cover low-income working families."
In justifying the new rule, Thomas A. Scully, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said, "The federal government is effectively paying more than its share of state Medicaid expenditures."
The new policy, Mr. Scully said, will "restore the appropriate balance between the federal government and states."

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: A UTILITY DEAL; 
Enron's Havoc Spills Over To a Utility In Oregon

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore., Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Enron, desperate for cash, hopes to raise $1.4 billion by selling its electric utility here in a deal that the utility's biggest industrial clients say enriches executives at the expense of customers big and small. 
 Electric rates would remain high here, corporate and consumer critics said, because the money for this deal would carry high junk-bond interest rates and require rapid repayment both to investors and to lenders led by Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston. 
 The sale would also impose costs that would, in effect, force the average customer to lend the company $260 interest free, indefinitely, according to a group of industrial energy users; the buyer of the utility disputes that estimate.
Since Enron bought the utility, Portland General Electric, five years ago, electric rates in the Portland area, which had been among the lowest in the country, have risen to among the highest. The terms of the sale of the utility to a smaller local utility, Northwest Natural Gas, will mean high rates for years, critics say. 
As such, Portland businesses and residents are now counting themselves among the victims of Enron's collapse. The troubles at Enron have already cost many of the 2,800 employees of Portland General their life savings, because their retirement savings were in Enron stock.
Enron's Dec. 2 bankruptcy filing is likely to cost Portland General customers an average of more than $500 each in excess payments already made that the utility eventually would have had to refund, according to a consulting firm, Regulatory and Cogeneration Services of Vancouver, Wash.
An alliance of companies like Intel, BoiseCascade, Georgia-Pacific and Fujitsu, as well as advocates for residential customers, say the damage could spread. Businesses say that the high electricity rates will discourage business investment and further retard the economy in Oregon, where the unemployment rate of 7.5 percent is the highest in the nation. 
Opponents of the sale, which was announced last May, passionately made their points Tuesday in a hearing by the Oregon Public Utility Commission. 
Many details of the deal, including its impact on customers and the size of the executives' bonuses, are unknown because Enron sealed most of the documents it filed with the utility commission. 
Melinda Davison, a lawyer for major industrial customers, waved a large sealed envelope at the hearing and said that inside were details of the bonuses. She obtained those documents as a party to the case but was not permitted to disclose their contents. "There are more dollars in this transaction for P.G.E. executives than for ratepayers," Ms. Davison said. "P.G.E. executives get paid first and customers get benefits years from now."
Bonuses to retain important executives are common in mergers, but keeping them secret is unusual.
John Ambler, an Enron spokesman, described the sale of Portland General as a change of strategy, rather than a sign of desperation. Enron, he said, "got involved in Portland General Electric to better understand the utility market, as it appeared there would be opportunities in an environment of deregulation." But, he continued, "as time went on, P.G.E. was not as important to Enron."
"While the returns were good with P.G.E.," he added, "our cash could be better placed in other areas.'
Executives of both utilities said customers would receive some immediate benefits from the deal. Pamela Lesh, a Portland General vice president, said that rates would drop at the end of this year, though not by as much as major customers and consumer advocates wanted. The biggest benefits will come beginning about 2008 to 2010, once debt from the deal is paid off, she said. 
"The industrial customers and the consumer advocates are complaining because this deal will save costs through synergies and they want to benefit right away, not in eight years," she said. 
Bruce DeBolt, the Northwest Gas chief financial officer, said that rates would not be any higher because of the merger. But Northwest Gas shareholders, he said, would benefit substantially from the leveraged buyout.
Enron, which bought Portland General in 1997, has been trying to sell it at least since November 1999. Usually, the sellers in such deals receive payment in shares of the acquirer, an arrangement that would have little effect on a utility's customers. But Enron has been seeking to sell Portland General for cash -- reflecting, local critics say, its deteriorating financial condition.
The deal has come under fire from both corporate customers and consumer groups who say its terms would violate longstanding principles of utility rate-making law by putting the burdens on ratepayers and giving virtually all the benefits to the gas utility's shareholders. 
"Because of Enron, Oregon ratepayers are seriously in harm's way," said Dan Meek, a lawyer for the Utility Reform Project, a consumer group.
Higher rates over the long term will shrivel new investment by companies that come here to obtain cheap power, said Ms. Davison, the lawyer for big electric customers. Intel has already announced a halt to its multibillion-dollar expansion in the Portland area until rates come down. 
At the hearing Tuesday, no ordinary citizens, or Oregon journalists, observed the two hours of testimony, parts of which were also missed by Commissioner Lee Byers, who arrived late and repeatedly nodded off. 
The hearing was filled with stories of the damage witnesses said Enron brought, of the lost retirement savings of utility linemen because of the collapse of Enron's stock, of the bonuses for executives and of the added burdens that customers said they would suffer. Any deal would be subject to a bankruptcy court's approval. 
Edward A. Finklea, a lawyer representing big gas customers, said it was unfair for customers to wait years before sharing in the benefits of merging the local gas and electric utilities. He belittled the benefits that the utilities promise immediately and over the first eight years, saying they amount to $3 annually for each customer "or about enough to heat a house for one day." 
Several witnesses warned that if business conditions worsen, or exceptionally mild weather prevails, the combined company would have trouble paying back the $1.4 billion in debt. Then the company would have to raise electric and gas rates further to avoid bankruptcy, they said. 
Enron plans to sell Portland General for $1.4 billion in cash, $250 million in a special class of stock and the assumption of more than $1 billion of debt by Northwest Natural Gas. The debt burden would lower the combined company's credit rating to junk-bond status until the beginning of 2006, Mr. DeBolt said. 
The deal would force customers to pay an additional $188 million in "phantom taxes" over six years, according to Energy Advocates, which represents major natural gas customers in Portland.
Phantom taxes occur when utility customers pay rates that assume the company pays higher taxes than it actually does. Because the merged utility here would pay reduced taxes, as it deducted its high debt payments, electricity and gas rates would include what amounts to a forced loan from customers to the utility at zero interest.
These loans would average $260 a customer and last for at least six years, according to calculations by Don Schoenbeck of Regulatory and Cogeneration Services, who said he relied on public documents from Northwest Natural Gas.
The average of more than $500 that each Portland General customer has already paid in phantom taxes almost certainly will never be repaid because of Enron's bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE MEETING; 
2 Top Officials Offer Stern Talk On U.S. Policy

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM and DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
The two highest-ranking members of President Bush's cabinet, both attending the World Economic Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria, declared yesterday that the United States was committed to defining its own solutions to some of the toughest international problems, even if that angers some allies.
 Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill told world business and government leaders yesterday that the Bush administration cut off aid to Argentina late last year because "they just didn't reform," while Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warned that the United States would "go after terrorism wherever it threatens free men and women," even if that meant taking on "evil regimes." 
 While the statements themselves were hardly surprising, they were delivered in an unvarnished fashion to an international audience that reacted with a mix of apprehension and disagreement.
During a panel on Afghanistan, a senior State Department official, Richard N. Haass, said that the scheduled six-month presence of an international peacekeeping force around Kabul was "clearly inadequate" and that the force, to which America is not contributing troops, might have to stay as long as two years. The force may have to be expanded, he added, to as many 25,000 troops spread around the country. It now numbers fewer than 5,000, clustered around the capital. 
Mr. O'Neill's blunt message about Argentina came in a lunchtime speech to an audience that included financiers like George Soros, who was once a major investor in the country, the chief executive of Boeing Corporation, Philip A. Condit, and diplomats and business executives from around the world.
It amounted to a comprehensive defense of the administration's decision to end International Monetary Fund emergency aid to Argentina, where default led to the fall of the government, rioting and chaos.
Mr. O'Neill said he was pained to see the images of people being killed or injured, but said it was ridiculous for America's "plumbers and carpenters to pay for someone's bad decisions" in managing economies.
On terrorism, Secretary Powell was equally tough. "We must not step back from the challenge presented by rogue regimes, evil regimes, as the president put it" when he singled out Iran, Iraq and North Korea in his State of the Union address on Tuesday. "And we must make sure that we have the patience and the perseverance to see this campaign through to the end," he said.
But both men tried to balance their stern messages with suggestions that the United States was also prepared to address global poverty, and the root causes of terrorism, in new ways. Mr. O'Neill said he wanted the United States to issue more grants to developing nations, and fewer loans that the countries have little hope of repaying. He said he was worried that the pattern of lending money to such nations, and then declaring partial debt forgiveness, bred cynicism and sent the wrong signals to developing nations.
At the same time, Secretary Powell said, "terrorism really flourishes in areas of poverty, despair and hopelessness, where people see no future." So the United States and its allies must also fight world poverty, he said, adding, "We have to show people who might move in the direction of terrorism that there is a better way." But the cabinet members' messages on intractable problems prompted considerable skepticism and wariness among traditional American allies from Western Europe to Latin American. At a lengthy session in the morning on new directions for American foreign policy, several participants noted that the leaders of the hijacking teams on Sept. 11 were neither poor nor uneducated, and they suggested that even a new focus on economic development in the Middle East would not ease the hatred of America.
Latin American diplomats noted that while Mr. O'Neill was correct in blaming Argentine politicians for failing to rein in their spending and stabilize their economy, the United States has not been actively involved in finding a solution. Argentina's new government remains in considerable chaos as it seeks a strategy that would get the economy running again and give the I.M.F. reason to restore aid.
For the year he has been in office, Mr. O'Neill has often expressed his dissatisfaction with the strategic direction of the I.M.F., which he believes has encouraged a culture of dependency with its repeated bailouts of debtor nations. He has a similar view of the World Bank, which he wants to redirect toward improving the productivity of poorer nations.
"Over the last 15 years the temptation has been to rush in with a fire- station crew and dump money on the rest of the world," he said. "I don't think that's O.K." He said the United States should not partake in a strategy of sending cash to countries that made "mistake after mistake."
He also said the concept of "contagion," the spread of economic troubles from one nation to the next, is "man-made phenomenon." In fact, while contagion was widespread in the Mexican crisis of 1995 and the Asian crisis of 1997 and 1998, Argentina's troubles have stayed inside its borders.
Nonetheless, he said, he went along with a strategy, set up by the outgoing Clinton administration, of agreeing to large loans for Argentina in return for its promises to finally bring some discipline to its budget. "We approved $40 billion, which is still a lot of money," he said. "Then $20 billion more in the spring. And by the summer they needed more."
By this fall, however, the administration had decided that Argentina was not delivering on its promises, and cut off the flow. Since then Mr. O'Neill has faced two contradictory criticisms: Some say he waited too long to shut off the spigot, others say that the decision to cut the I.M.F.'s aid triggered the rioting that has caused violence and a few deaths.
But Mr. O'Neill went to some lengths yesterday to indicate that the administration was not being heartless, and he said he thought Americans would support larger foreign aid budgets if the United States "can demonstrate that we know what we are doing and raise standards of living." 
He made no mention of the fact that the administration quashed a World Bank plan recently to get major industrialized nations to commit themselves to much larger foreign aid budgets over the next five years.
Aid was much on the minds of attendees at the session on Afghanistan, including Foreign Minister Abdullah. (He uses one name.) 
Mr. Haass, the director of policy planning for the State Department, said that security was the paramount challenge that must be met for a stable Afghanistan to grow. He noted that there were "tens if not hundreds of thousands," of Afghans with arms and alliances to various warlords, and said the interim government must find ways to demobilize such forces perhaps by putting some to work on drug eradication programs or road-building, and integrating others into a national army.
But all that will take time, and some participants could not help expressing a certain pessimism. Kieran Prendergast, undersecretary general of the United Nations for political affairs, said that "military victory for the coalition looks more assured than victory on the peace front." He noted that the government is still short of money to pay basic operating costs and salaries, then added, "The Afghans still need bread today even more urgently than they need cake tomorrow."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-12

2 Officials Declare U.S. Will Act as It Sees Fit
The two highest-ranking members of President Bush's cabinet, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, said at the World Economic Forum that the United States was committed to defining its own solutions to some of the toughest international problems, even if that angered some allies. A1

Dissent in Israeli Ranks
More than 100 Israeli Army reservists, including combat officers and soldiers, said in a newspaper statement that they would refuse to continue serving in the West Bank and Gaza Strip because they objected to Israeli tactics. The army's chief of staff suggested that the dissenters were inciting rebellion. A1

Israeli-Palestinian Meeting
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon met secretly in Jerusalem this week with three emissaries of Yasir Arafat, Palestinian officials said. Mr. Sharon's office declined to comment. A3

One Trial for Milosevic
An appeals panel at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague decided that Slobodan Milosevic, former president of Yugoslavia, would face a single trial on charges relating to atrocities committed during the Kosovo, Bosnia and Croatia wars. A4

World Briefing A12

NATION CHALLENGED A8-9

Bush Seeking Big Rise In Military Spending
The Bush administration wants to increase the Pentagon's yearly budget by $120 billion over five years, to $451 billion in 2007, according to Defense Department documents. A1

Reporter's Fate Uncertain
News organizations received conflicting messages concerning Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter abducted in Pakistan 10 days ago. The first message demanded $2 million in ransom; the second said Mr. Pearl had been executed. A1

Expanding Afghan Force
Top officials in Britain and at the State Department have endorsed the idea of expanding the international security force in Afghanistan. A8

Move to Expedite Deportation
The Justice Department wants to revamp its rules so that most immigration appeals are heard by one judge instead of three-member panels. A9

NATIONAL A13-15

Idaho Ends Experiment With Limits on Terms
Idaho became the first state to repeal its term limit laws, which voters there approved in 1994 and affirmed in three elections since. Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, had vetoed the repeal measure, but lawmakers overrode the veto. A13

Bush Choice for Charity Effort
President Bush selected Jim Towey, 45, an advocate for the aging who worked with Mother Teresa's ministry for more than a decade, to lead the president's initiative to give federal money to religious charities. A14

Bush Plan for Medicaid Cuts
President Bush's budget would rein in the growth of Medicaid by reducing payments to public hospitals and by cracking down on state efforts to obtain extra federal money to finance health care for the poor, administration officials said. A14

Amtrak Austerity Plan

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MILITARY BUDGET; 
BUSH SEES BIG RISE IN MILITARY BUDGET FOR NEXT 5 YEARS

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
In a military buildup rivaling that of the Reagan era, the Bush administration will call for increasing the Pentagon's yearly budget by $120 billion over the next five years, to $451 billion in 2007, according to Defense Department documents.
 By the end of the five-year period, spending to buy weapons and other military supplies alone would swell to $99 billion a year from $61 billion this year. Spending on personnel, operations and research programs would also grow, but not as fast. 
 Mr. Bush's proposal would spend about a quarter of a trillion dollars more on the military over the next five years than if the Pentagon budget simply increased at the rate of inflation. That growth would come at the same time that Mr. Bush's tax cut, worth $1.35 trillion over 10 years, gradually phases in. 
Details of Mr. Bush's proposal are to be presented formally to Congress on Monday, but the documents describing the proposal began to circulate in Washington today and their details were provided by industry and Congressional officials.
Mr. Bush has already said that he would propose a $48 billion increase in Pentagon spending for next year alone, pumping money into building new fighter jets and high-tech munitions, raising troop pay and expanding health care benefits. The increase over current Pentagon spending would be about 12 percent, the largest such increase in 20 years.
But spending growth of that magnitude, if approved by Congress, would also create a ripple effect that would probably lock the Pentagon into major budget increases for many years as more big-ticket weapons reach the assembly line and entitlement programs like health care for military personnel expand, military experts said. 
Indeed, Mr. Bush's plan would increase Pentagon spending by about 30 percent through 2007, a pace that is only somewhat slower than President Ronald Reagan's military buildup between 1981 and 1985, the largest ever during peace time.
"By historical standards, this is a big increase," said Steven Kosiak, a budget analyst with the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments, an organization in Washington that studies military policy. 
Though the combination of tax cuts and increased military spending would likely aggravate the budget deficit and create pressure on Congress to restrain domestic spending, many senior Democrats on Capitol Hill said they expected to support Mr. Bush's plan as long as the war on terrorism continues. 
Those Democrats and their aides contend that with Mr. Bush's approval rating at above 80 percent, and with public support for the war running high, opposing military spending would be a political blunder.
"The president will get largely what he asks for in this area," said Senator Kent Conrad, a Democrat from North Dakota who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. "We're at war, and when the president asks for additional resources for national defense, he generally gets it."
Representative Ike Skelton, a Missouri Democrat who is the ranking minority member on the House Armed Services Committee, said the Pentagon budget "will pass at the size the president has asked for," though he said Congress might try to shift money around within the president's proposal. 
"The question is not whether it's the right amount of money," Mr. Skelton said. "The question is how do you spend it. The priority has to be taking care of the troops and their families, because they are the basis of our quality military."
Under the plan Mr. Bush will present to Congress on Monday, Pentagon spending would rise to $379 billion next year. The plan also calls for spending $16.8 billion on Department of Energy programs, principally maintaining the nuclear stockpile, bringing total military spending to $396 billion. 
In a proposal that has caught bipartisan attention on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush has also called for creating a $10 billion contingency fund for the war on terrorism, which would allow him to spend money on military operations without seeking prior approval from Congress. 
Congress historically has resisted efforts by presidents to usurp the power of purse, and senior lawmakers in both parties have expressed skepticism about Mr. Bush's contingency fund proposal. 
Senator Conrad called the contingency fund "highly questionable." He said that Congress historically has opposed giving the president "a pool of money that's not for any designated purpose."
But aides to several senior Democrats said that rather than trying to eliminate the contingency fund, Congress might simply allocate the $10 billion to other military programs, particularly ones that directly benefit their districts. 
Though some of the proposed $48 billion increase next year would help pay for the war in Afghanistan, most of it would go toward improving pay and benefits for troops, rebuilding equipment and reversing what Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has called the Pentagon's "procurement holiday," which followed the collapse of the Soviet Union. 
The part of the budget dedicated to buying weapons and supplies would increase by $7.6 billion, to $68.7 billion, an amount that was considered disappointing by some military contractors. By comparison, President Reagan raised procurement spending by more than $20 billion between 1981 and 1982, as measured by inflation-adjusted dollars. 
Still, Mr. Bush's plan pleased many senior military officers. It would provide $475 million for the Crusader mobile howitzer and $910 million for the Comanche reconnaissance helicopter, Army programs that last year were considered in grave danger of being killed. 
The plan also calls for spending $5.2 billion, a $1.3 billion increase, to buy 23 F-22 Raptor stealth fighter jets, the Air Force's top budget priority. And it proposes to nearly double spending on a surveillance satellite system, known as Space Based Infrared Systems-High, to $815 million. The program, which will be an important component of a missile defense shield, has been over budget and behind schedule. 
The plan proposes keeping research and development on missile defense level at about $8 billion. 
The budget proposes to sharply increase spending on a number of programs that Mr. Rumsfeld contends would "transform" the military into a more lethal, light and agile force. It would spend $1 billion to develop or speed up production of unpiloted aircraft, including the Predator and Global Hawk, which helped spot targets in Afghanistan.
The proposal would also allocate $1 billion to begin refurbishing four Trident submarines so that they can fire conventional Tomahawk cruise missiles rather than nuclear-tipped missiles. Military planners say the plan would greatly increase the Navy's ability to strike in-land targets with great precision.
The plan calls for spending $1.1 billion to expand production of laser- and satellite-guided bombs, which were the weapons of choice in Afghanistan. 
But the procurement budget did not grow as much as many military officers and military contracts had hoped, largely because of sharply rising costs for entitlement programs and maintenance operations. 
As has already been mandated by Congress, the budget would increase military base pay by 4.1 percent and improve off-base housing allowances. And health care spending would rise sharply to pay for a new program that extends military health care benefits to retired career military personnel.
One part of the procurement budget that has already generated disappointment is the shipbuilding account, which calls for building five ships next year, including $2.6 billion for a DDG-51 destroyer and $2.4 billion for a Virginia-class submarine. 
Advocates of shipbuilding on Capitol Hill say the Navy needs to build eight or more ships a year to prevent the fleet from falling much below its current level of about 310 ships.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURITY; 
U.S. and Britain Agree on Expanding the International Security Force in Afghanistan

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Top officials in Britain and at the State Department have endorsed the idea of expanding the international security force in Afghanistan, which is now restricted to Kabul and limited to 5,000 soldiers.
 The British foreign secretary, Jack Straw, said today that Hamid Karzai, the leader of the interim government in Kabul, had presented persuasive arguments for enlarging the force and extending it into other areas of Afghanistan. With the country riven by feuding warlords and gunmen who have switched allegiances regularly during the last 23 years of war, a growing number of Western experts have made similar recommendations. 
 "Our position is that Karzai makes a very strong case for it," said Mr. Straw, who was in Washington for consultations with senior Bush administration officials. "The issue is the practicality of it." 
At the World Economic Forum in New York, Richard Haass, a senior State Department official, said the security force might have to be expanded to as many as 25,000 troops, deployed across Afghanistan. Mr. Haass added that the six-month term for the current international force, now under British command and endorsed by the United Nations Security Council, was "clearly inadequate." He said an appropriate term might be as long as two years.
The Bush administration, however, has not yet decided whether to endorse such an expansion. If the force is enlarged, officials said, the United States will provide indirect military support. But President Bush has indicated that he has no intention of sending American troops as peacekeepers.
An expanded force, the thinking goes, would discourage violent clashes and help Mr. Karzai's government extend its authority throughout Afghanistan while reconstruction gets under way and until an Afghan army is established.
Afghan leaders believe that the force should be deployed in four cities outside Kabul, in the following order of priority: Mazar-i-Sharif in the north, Kandahar in the south, Herat in the west and Jalalabad in the east, Mr. Straw said.
Even if foreign governments agree there is a need, it is not clear that they have the will to provide the additional forces.
Britain has sent 1,500 troops to Afghanistan to join the force, but is planning to turn over command to Turkey by the end of April. Citing other commitments, Britain plans to reduce substantially the number of its troops in Afghanistan. 
Turkey wants the United States to finance the troops it would use in the force and is concerned about the financial and strategic implications of deploying outside of Kabul.
American officials are not offering peacekeepers, but are considering ways to help maintain an expanded force, like flying the troops to Afghanistan, providing intelligence and offering assurance that it will evacuate any forces that are in danger.
It is not clear exactly how many troops would be needed if the force expands. Some experts say 10,000 to 20,000; a retiring United Nations envoy, Francesc Vendrell, talked last week of up to 35,000. Even the limited force now in place has built up slowly: only 3,000 soldiers of a planned 5,000 have been deployed so far.
The United Nations approved a mandate for the force only for Kabul, a limitation that said more about the apprehensions of the nations contributing troops than the security needs on the ground. At the insistence of the French, deployment was limited to six months, a provision American officials never believed was realistic.
The main purpose of the troops, formally known as the International Security Assistance Force, is to ensure that the Northern Alliance does not have disproportionate influence in Kabul. But Kabul is the safest city in Afghanistan, and the peacekeeping force has done nothing to provide security in the rest of the county.
The Bush administration has agreed to provide military training and take other steps to help Afghanistan establish a new army. But the United States Central Command has yet to send a team to assess requirements.
"There is a clear need for an international force to provide security during the transition to a professional Afghan security force," said Barnett R. Rubin, a professor at New York University and a specialist on Afghanistan. "These things are complementary, not contradictory."
Mr. Straw discussed the security force with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell on Thursday in Washington.
Some Pentagon officials are skeptical that an expanded force is needed, but the Defense Department has not taken a formal position, officials say. State Department officials have been swayed by the argument that the troops will encourage stability.
Recently, French troops chanced upon two rival groups of warlords whose men were about to do battle, according to American intelligence. Seeing the French troops, the rival militias decided not to fight. 
"We are moving toward a decision," a senior Bush administration official said. "I think we will come to the conclusion that an expanded force is desirable and should be supported by the United States."
Mr. Straw said: "We want to see a stable Afghanistan. And the best people in Afghanistan are saying you can get that stability by having an outside force in certain of the areas."

HEADLINE: Happy Trails 

BYLINE:  By Linda Greenhouse; Linda Greenhouse covers the Supreme Court for The Times.

 BODY:
 LAZY B
Growing Up on a Cattle Ranch
in the American Southwest.
By Sandra Day O'Connor
and H. Alan Day.
Illustrated. 318 pp. New York:
Random House. $24.95.
 The stark and isolated high desert of the American Southwest "was no country for sissies, then or now," Sandra Day O'Connor and her brother, Alan Day, write in this engaging memoir of growing up on their family's cattle ranch, 250 arid square miles that straddled the Arizona-New Mexico border along the Gila River.
And it goes without saying that Sandra Day O'Connor was no sissy, then or now. Raised in a house without electricity or running water, 35 miles from the nearest real town, she rode horses since before she could remember and counted the ranch's cowboys as her best childhood friends. Her ambition was to be useful to them as they went about their work and to prove to her father, a demanding and somewhat austere perfectionist, that she could do her part.
To Eastern, urban sensibilities, her early life is not only exotic but nearly impossible to reconcile with the Sandra Day O'Connor the public knows: the prim and button-down onetime president of the Phoenix Junior League, at home at formal dinners and on country club golf courses, who grew up to become the first woman on the United States Supreme Court and a central player there for more than 20 years now.
"Lazy B" -- the name her grandfather, H. C. Day, gave to the ranch he established in 1880 -- makes no explicit attempt to reconcile the two Sandra Day O'Connors. Its ambitions are more modest: to paint a loving but cleareyed portrait of a distinctive and vanished American way of life. Both O'Connor and her brother, who stayed on the ranch and managed it for much of his career before subdividing and selling it in 1993, tell their story through anecdotes and sketches rather than extended reflection, with only incidental references to their adult lives.
But like Jimmy Carter's well-received memoir of his rural Georgia boyhood, "An Hour Before Daylight" -- which this book resembles much more closely than it does the only other memoir to be published by a sitting Supreme Court justice in modern times, William O. Douglas's "Go East, Young Man" -- Lazy B" provides a palimpsest of the adult author. (It is evident that O'Connor, rather than her brother, is the principal author of "Lazy B"; the first-person narrative is all hers, while "Alan" is the third-person subject of his adventures.) In this, it transcends the boundaries of its form to suggest, if not expose, rich veins that a future O'Connor biographer, or perhaps the justice herself, might someday mine.
Like Jimmy Carter, Sandra Day was the first-born child of parents who, while deeply rooted in soil that they worked with their own hands, had a wider world in mind for their children. Carter's parents cultivated his interest in attending the United States Naval Academy and preparing for a military career that would take him far from home. Harry Day, thwarted in his own desire to attend Stanford University by his father's premature death, transferred that ambition to his older daughter, who graduated from Stanford and from its law school, where she placed third in her class (to William H. Rehnquist's first).
O'Connor's parents in fact placed such value on getting her properly educated that beginning in the first grade at 6, she was sent to El Paso to live with her maternal grandparents during the school year in order to attend a private girls' school. Published interviews with family members in recent years indicate that this arrangement was the source of great unhappiness for the young girl, but she passes over that quickly here with the comment, "I was always homesick when away from the ranch." This is, after all, the story of life on the Lazy B, not of Sandra's painful acculturation to city life.
Sandra Day O'Connor, born in 1930, and Jimmy Carter, born in 1924, shared other childhood influences. Both were the product of families that, while richer in land than in cash, held unchallenged local positions of social and economic leadership. Both had mothers who were powerful personalities and, given the constraints of their time and place, free spirits. Carter's mother, Miss Lillian, a public figure in her own right during her son's presidency, had progressive attitudes on race. Ada Mae Wilkey Day, who eloped with O'Connor's father because her urbane parents disapproved of the harsh ranch life that marriage to Harry Day would bring, retained a thirst for culture and adventure that led her to subscribe to The New Yorker and Vogue and to design family vacations that included a voyage to Cuba on a banana boat.
Like Jimmy Carter, who spent some of his richest childhood hours with his family farm's black employees and tenants, Sandra Day learned enduring lessons from the Lazy B's cowboys, of whom some were illiterate but all were dignified, purposeful and successful, by their lights and hers. Of Rafael Estrada, known as Rastus, a Mexican-American who could not read but who could identify nearly all the cattle, some 1,000 head on the ranch, she writes, "He knew he was very good at what he did, and he demanded a high standard from those around him." Rastus "was dealt what many would say was a poor hand in life -- he was small, crippled, fatherless, a minority race in his birth land," the portrait concludes, but "he played the hand he was dealt like a master." From Rastus "we learned the contentment of doing the best you can with what you have."
Of Jim Brister, another ranch cowboy and sometime rodeo competitor who did his best and never blamed anyone else when he lost, she writes: "If he won, that was fine. If he didn't, that was all right too. You get the job done, or you don't. We learned from Jim that there were no excuses, only results."
Strong as these figures were, they -- and Sandra and Alan themselves -- all moved in the shadow of "the boss,"+ "the patriarch," Harry Day, who inherited a vast but nearly worthless property and through unremitting labor made it a success. He demanded "total loyalty from his employees and his children." Passing his many tests was the goal. He called Sandra away from a Nancy Drew mystery one summer day so she could watch him shoot a suffering calf whose hindquarters had been gnawed by a coyote.
She was so eager to please, and he was so stingy with his approval, that some episodes are painful to read. Sandra offered to bring lunch to her father and crew, who were branding calves on a remote part of the ranch. In the middle of nowhere, the old Chevy pickup got a flat tire, and Sandra, then 15, struggled for an hour in the summer heat to loosen the rusty lug nuts and change the tire. It was well past lunchtime when she finally arrived. "You're late," her father said. She explained about the tire. "You should have started earlier," he said. "You need to expect anything out here."
She writes: "I had expected a word of praise for changing the tire. But, to the contrary, I realized that only one thing was expected: an on-time lunch. No excuses accepted."
But she leaves no doubt that she counts herself lucky. She grew up with a lasting love for the land and for the harsh landscape where windmills stood out as "kind, benevolent friends" and "we were bit players indeed." "This is our church," her father exclaimed, indicating the landscape around them in answer to her question why the family never went to church on Sundays. She and her siblings gained a perspective rare in modern times on their family as a working unit. "How many young people see their father leave for the office but don't really know what he does for a living?"
And she received an education the value of which became clear only years later. The cowboys' semiannual roundup "had been an all-male domain" before she began to take part. "Changing it to accommodate a female was probably my first initiation into joining an all-men's club, something I did more than once in my life. After the cowboys understood that a girl could hold up her end, it was much easier for my sister, my niece and the other girls and young women who followed to be accepted in that rough-and-tumble world."

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind 

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

TEPPER ISN'T GOING OUT, by Calvin Trillin. (Random House, $22.95.) A Manhattan driver, the hero of this novel, seeks the island's best parking spaces and occupies them, sitting and reading while the meter runs; his offhand concentration makes him a kind of Zen saint and leads to a struggle with a mayor whose rage for order suggests Rudolph W. Giuliani.

POLAR, by T. R. Pearson. (Viking, $24.95.) A quietly unsettling, darkly satirical Southern novel, whose hero, a rural Virginia reprobate, inexplicably acquires oracular familiarity with the Antarctic and knowledge about a little girl's unsolved disappearance three years earlier.

ROSCOE, by William Kennedy. (Viking, $24.95.) In the seventh novel of Kennedy's splendid Albany cycle, Roscoe Conway, heir to the city's three-time mayor, operator and fixer and finder of needful cash, runs out of zeal for the political game and falls in love, of all comic possibilities, with another man's wife.

THE ENGLISHMAN'S DAUGHTER: A True Story of Love and Betrayal in World War I, by Ben Macintyre. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A remarkable excavation of an improbable incident, the concealment for 18 months by French villagers of some stranded British soldiers, one of whom fathered a local woman the author met in 1997.

JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES. Volume Three: Fighting for Freedom, 1937-1946, by Robert Skidelsky. (Viking, $34.95.) The final installment of Skidelsky's life of the most influential economist since Adam Smith, who gave his all in Britain's struggle for survival in World War II, negotiating finances with the United States and trying to save Britain's market economy.

LATITUDES OF MELT, by Joan Clark. (Soho, $24.) A slowly mesmerizing novel in which a baby found on a cake of ice off Newfoundland grows up to construct an existence seemingly untroubled by the nonexistence of a past, leaving it up to her children and grandchildren to figure out who she might be.

BEYOND THE LAST VILLAGE: A Journey of Discovery in Asia's Forbidden Wilderness, by Alan Rabinowitz. (Island Press/Shearwater, $25.) Biological and moral exploration meet in this account of animals and people in remote upland Myanmar, by a wildlife biologist who used his concern for other species to hide himself from humans.

THE CAPRICES, by Sabina Murray. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $13.) A collection of short stories, evocative, dark and intense, set largely in the Pacific of World War II; their characters are obliged to extract the resistance of lone souls from the terror of combat and the hostility of landscape and climate.

DON'T LET'S GO TO THE DOGS TONIGHT: An African Childhood, by Alexandra Fuller. (Random House, $24.95.) A memoir from the "bad side" of African history, presented with plenty of wit and no apologies, by a woman whose family, seeking to escape black rule, batted around several former colonies, surrounded by watchdogs, booze and tragedy.
