HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Roosevelt, N.J.; 
A New Deal Enclave Friendly to the Arts

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
BORN as a Great Depression-era utopian cooperative for unemployed Jewish New York City garment workers, Roosevelt, N.J., looks pretty much as it did when it was started by the United States Department of the Interior in the late 1930's. Its streets meander around hills and stream beds, and most of its houses back up to green belts or woods, including the sprawling, 5,600 acre state-owned Assunpink Wildlife Management Area to the south. 
 Of the 334 homes in the 1.8-square-mile Monmouth County borough, 200 are the original Bauhaus-style structures, which resemble low-slung concrete bunkers and have so much steel rebar reinforcement in their walls that cordless telephone reception is obstructed. "Although our housing lots are a half acre," said the planning board chairman, Ralph Seligman, 79, a 50-year resident, "the woods give us the feeling of infinite privacy." 
 Roosevelt has just a handful of commercial buildings, the largest of which is the Worker's Aim Cooperation Association Building on North Valley Road. Constructed as part of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal in 1936, it started as a garment factory that was owned and operated by the homeowners. That structure has since been subdivided into artists' studios and nonpolluting industrial businesses. 
The town's two gasoline stations, which closed long ago, remain eyesores. There are no traffic lights, virtually no crime, no police and little traffic on internal roads. The one store is Rossi's Deli on North Rochdale Avenue, next to the post office, where residents collect their mail because no letter carriers are assigned to Roosevelt. Residents do their grocery shopping in neighboring towns. The closest major mall is the Freehold Mall 12 miles to the southeast.
"When referring to Roosevelt institutions, we use the word 'the,' -- as in 'the' school, 'the' store, 'the' post office -- because there is just one of each," said the mayor, Michael Hamilton.
The only town in New Jersey on both the National and State Registers of Historic Places in its entirety, Roosevelt was originally named Jersey Homesteads. It was one of 34 municipalities started by the federal Subsistence Homesteads program, an experiment that gave workers cooperative ownership over local farms and factories. In 1945, after President Roosevelt's death and long after the government had sold off the factory and farms, the borough renamed itself Roosevelt to honor F.D.R.
"The economic experiment was a failure, but what developed was a tightly knit social fabric," said the borough historian. Arthur Shapiro, who has lived most of his 63 years in Roosevelt.
"The original residents were all Eastern European Jews, and the minutes of the first borough council were even taken in Yiddish," Dr. Shapiro said. "Within weeks of its founding, there were already 36 organizations. School friends became like brothers and sisters, and we all still keep in touch 50 years after we graduated."
Mel A. Adlerman, 70, owner of the Adlerman Agency in nearby Monroe and one of the original settlers in Roosevelt, says that many home buyers in the town are children of the first residents, returning to their roots. Currently, only three houses, all in the Bauhaus style, are on the market. They range in price from $124,900 to $142,900. Mr. Adlerman said he had a waiting list of half a dozen people seeking homes in town.
The Bauhaus-type houses were built in two styles: detached and semidetached, with the connection between houses being at the garages. "These homes typically sell for between $95,000 and just under $150,000," Mr. Adlerman said. "Price is determined by whether the house is detached or semidetached and whether it has been updated or expanded." 
Roosevelt also has about two dozen geodesic dome houses that were built in the 1970's, when there was a dome factory in town. They sell for between $125,000 for a small two-bedroom model and $175,000 for an upgraded three-bedroom unit. A two-bedroom, two-bath dome house sold in October for $149,900. There are also several dozen small ranches, colonials and bilevels in the Lake Drive section that go for about $135,000 to $150,000. Larger four-bedroom colonials built on four-acre lots during the 1990's along Eleanor Lane, named for the former first lady, can go for as much as $250,000, according to Mr. Adlerman. 
The only multifamily project is Solar Village, a 21-unit low-income senior-citizen housing development on Valley Road, that is heated by solar energy. 
Among the newer residents is Lois Hunt, a retired opera singer who has several family members in town. In 1997, she moved from Oyster Bay on Long Island, into one of the original structures. "I moved for family, but I love the community," she explained in a recent interview. "It's one of those places where everyone knows and speaks to one another. And there are many artists and musicians, which makes this a highly cultured place to live."
THE central focus of the borough is the 105-student Roosevelt Elementary School for kindergarten through sixth grade. The entire borough attends its graduation ceremony, and its meeting rooms are used practically every night for community functions.
In the school foyer, next to an eight-foot-long green dragon painted by a first grade class, is one of the largest frescos in the United States -- the Ben Shahn Mural. It was painted by Shahn and his wife, Bernada Bryson, in 1937 under a grant from the Works Progress Administration, an agency that created employment during the Depression. The mural chronicles the history of immigration, labor reforms and the New Deal. Among the historic figures depicted in the painting are Albert Einstein and the labor organizer John L. Lewis. 
The average class size is 14, and the school has a full-day kindergarten and after-school care. There is a state-of-the-art 16-station Macintosh computer laboratory, every classroom has Internet access and there is one computer for every 2.2 students, compared with a state average of one for every 5.9 students. 
"We are like a private school, only we also have to meet state mandates," said the chief school administrator, Dale Weinbach.
Graduates of Roosevelt Elementary go on to middle school at the Melvin H. Kreps School and Hightstown High School, both in nearby East Windsor. On the 2000 College Board tests, the latest year for which data was available, students at the 1,187-student Hightstown High scored a combined verbal and mathematics average 1,044, compared with a state average of 1,012. On the 11th grade High School Proficiency Test, a statewide standardized test that measures reading, 89 percent of Hightstown High students showed proficiency in all subjects, which was four points above the state average. 
After painting their mural, the Shahns remained in Roosevelt and attracted other artists, including Jacob Landau and David Stone Martin. They, in turn, attracted singers, poets and playwrights, forming the core of an artist colony, which remains active today. Mr. Shahn is buried in the tiny Roosevelt Cemetery. Bernarda Bryson and their son Jonathan continue to live and work in Roosevelt. A large bust of F.D.R. by Jonathan Shahn stands outside the elementary school.
According to Professor David Brahinsky, treasurer of the Roosevelt Arts Project, which stages monthly events at the school or Borough Hall, about 40 accomplished artists, poets and writers currently reside in Roosevelt. The next event is a classical music performance by a local group called the Ellarslie Trio at Borough Hall next Saturday at 8 p.m. Contributions of $6 for adults and $4 for seniors and students are requested to support the program.
Roosevelt's small-town intellectual atmosphere comes at a hefty price. Its property tax rate is the highest of Monmouth County's 53 municipalities. Its water system is the original one built by the Department of the Interior and, according to Mayor Hamilton, the water tower is too small and the pipes are old. 
The tax rate has split the town between those favoring development and those favoring preservation of open land. Roosevelt has about 620 acres of farmland, mainly at the northern end of town, just off Monmouth County Route 571. The 2000 election, which brought Mayor Hamilton to power, ousted a Borough Council that had passed legislation to allow a developer to build a development of 266 homes for people age 55 and older on 260 acres. The current council reversed that action and is being sued by the developer, U.S. Home, a unit of the Lennar Corporation.
Spearheading the preservationist camp is Fund for Roosevelt, an environmental organization started in 1999 to purchase farmland and place it under the protection of the state's Farmlands Preservation Program, which prohibits development but allows farming on the land. Dr. Rodham E. Tulloss, president of the Fund for Roosevelt, says his organization has raised $77,000 in donations, then leveraged that money with state and county grants to purchase and protect 241 acres, most of which has been resold to farmers, except for the development rights. 
One council person who was unseated was Rose D. Murphy, who had served for 10 years. "Not only are our taxes too high, but we have failing infrastructure, and pay an extra $125 per month for water and sewer" beyond the taxes, she said. "Our water plant is in need of upgrading. Housing for senior citizens would have meant an expanded tax base without increasing our school taxes. In the current climate, when there is just no grant money out there, we need new ratables or our taxes will make living here unaffordable for many people."
Mayor Hamilton countered: "It would have changed the feeling of community and extended family. We have an integrated social fabric and that kind of development would have nearly doubled our population and impacted on sensitive environmental areas."

At the end of a visit to the site, Dubinsky is reputed to have told Einstein: "When it comes to physics, you are the professor. When it comes to coats and suits, I'm the professor." HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Office Vacancy Rates Climb in Fairfield County

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
OFFICE vacancy rates in Fairfield County have climbed markedly in recent months, with different real estate companies estimating the current rate at 10.6 percent to 16.5 percent. Well below the 22 to 36 percent of the early 90's recession, the current rates are still a significant jump from the 6 to 8 percent that prevailed in 2000. 
 Only a smattering of leasing resulted from the destruction of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, with the flood of workers from displaced companies mainly going to Midtown Manhattan, the city's other boroughs and New Jersey, areas where many employees already lived. But local realtors say Fairfield County is doing as well as the rest of the country and better than the technology centers of Boston-Cambridge and northern California. 
 Dominated by the financial services sector, primarily in Stamford and Greenwich, Fairfield's office market has been affected more by the floundering stock market and economic recession that produced downsizing of area companies and a flood of space returned as sublets. 
"Longer term, we'll see benefit," said Al Mirin, senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis. "Short term, folks with space in New York have leases. As they come up, they may well relocate or more likely decentralize." Rents, he said, are flattening. "Nobody's lowered their asking rate, but deals include tenant improvements and maybe a month or two of free rent." Alluding to the annual rent per square foot, he said, "You may still be in the mid-$30's but getting more for it."
It is a widely held view among county real estate executives that a "diaspora" of secondary corporate offices in the suburbs may well be the wave of the future. Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth Inc., commercial realtors in Stamford, agrees that decentralization is a popular notion, but, he said, "I haven't seen a lot of evidence yet, and I'm not sure that corporate America has determined what it's going to do."
With the exception of two major leases by American Express and Citigroup Asset Management, rentals here related to Sept. 11 fall into the small-space category of 4,000 to 8,000 square feet. And whether they are disaster-related or not, subleases are driving the current market. 
Companies that took too much space, fearing they would be locked out of room to expand, "are cutting back on employees and jettisoning space," Mr. Tonnessen said. And, he said, "subleases are where price declines start, impacting owners' prices."
"We need earnings and job growth," he continued, "and time for companies to require additional space in a recovery. A sign of a bottom is the reduction in the supply of sublet space, but the market is still adding it." More than 435,000 square feet was returned to the market countywide in the fourth quarter of 2001 alone, bringing the total of available space to nearly 6 million square feet out of more than 43 million square feet countywide, according to statistics compiled by Insignia/ESG, Cushman & Wakefield and CB Richard Ellis.
"We were driving rents north of $45 a square foot in Stamford," said Michael Siegel, executive managing director at Insignia's Stamford office. "Buildings were purchased on the upside, Now, landlords may encounter difficulty justifying rents, and they recognize that there may be a drop. Some companies might still consider taking some of the blocks of sublet space, breaking up their Manhattan concentration, deciding not to be in one location." 
American Express, which negotiated the first and largest Sept. 11-related deal, took a 10-year lease on 195,000 square feet at 400 Atlantic Street in Stamford when its headquarters in the World Financial Center was rendered uninhabitable. It will move most of those employees back to the repaired headquarters in April, said Molly Faust, company spokeswoman, but it will retain part of the Stamford space. "A lot of their senior people live in the area," said Scott Landis, head of the Landis Group, owner of the fully rented 510,000-square-foot building. "They are committed to keeping space here permanently -- if there is such a thing as permanence."
Citigroup Asset Management, which has had 145,700 square feet at 100 and 300 First Stamford Place for several years, took another 145,285 square feet after losing space for 1,300 people at 7 World Trade Center. By midyear, it will add 1,100 employees to the 350 in Stamford now. "We have no plans to go back to New York," said Brenda Sniffen, Citigroup's facilities manager in Stamford.
Greenwich, traditionally impervious to economic fluctuations, has the highest vacancy rate in the county, between 16 and 20 percent, depending on which real estate company tally is used. The reason, said John Goodkind of Newmark & Company Real Estate in Greenwich, is the 350,000 square feet put on the market at Greenwich American Center, or about half of the building, the first corporate campus in the state, built for the American Can Company in 1969. 
"Subtract that building and Greenwich vacancies would be in single digits," Mr. Goodkind said. "Greenwich picked up several small tenants in financial services and telecommunications after Sept. 11. They went into Greenwich Plaza, Pickwick Plaza and Steamboat Road, paying rents of $60 to $90 a square foot. The town has become a small-tenant market for financial services and hedge funds. No longer are big tenants clamoring to be here." 
AMONG the major leases unrelated to Sept. 11 is one of 104,000 square feet taken at the Davis Companies' 33-acre Wilton office park, formerly Perkin-Elmer's headquarters at 40-60 Danbury Road, by the Ryan Partnership. AIG Financial Products took 65,000 square feet. "We were 88 percent leased while we were renovating," said David P. Fiore, senior vice president of the company's Connecticut properties. "Since opening last October we are 96 percent leased," he said. Rents are in the low $30's on 10-year leases.
A second Wilton campus changed hands on Dec. 31, when the Louis Dreyfus Property Group sold 10-20 Westport Road to TIAA-CREF a major teachers' pension fund, for $140 million. One building, No. 10, was built in the 70's, and No. 20 was completed last summer and put up for sale in September. The buildings have a total of 529,000 square feet and sold for $264.65 per square foot. Both buildings were designed by Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo & Associates, and both are fully rented. "We saw an opportunity to build a Manhattan-style quality office building where it was needed," said David J. Friedman, northeast regional vice president of the Dreyfus Property Group, "and we're very happy with the results."
Buildings have been selling for record prices, said Jeffrey Dunne, senior vice president of investments at CB Richard Ellis. Last August his company sold Greenwich Financial Center for J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management to H. B. Nitkin for $26.7 million, or $353 a square foot. "We have 20 written offers for a portfolio of four office buildings on the Post Road in Westport," Mr. Dunne said. "The demand is strong because the returns to real estate investors are increasingly attractive, given the poor performance of the stock market and low yields on bonds and money market funds." 
Sept. 11 had an indirect influence on a decision by Xerox to stay in Stamford when a property to which it considered moving was taken by a company displaced in the disaster. Xerox's headquarters at 800 Long Ridge Road has been for sale since late last March. Built to accommodate 630 people, it currently has only 350. 
Xerox owns the 25 acres on which the 255,000-square-foot building stands and Stamfex Associates of Manhattan owns the building, which it bought from Xerox in a lease-back arrangement in 1984. The two entities are cooperating in marketing the land and the building together in a range of $50 million to $60 million. Stamfex is seeking tenants for half to two-thirds of the building, said Kara Choquette, a Xerox spokeswoman, "and we will occupy the rest, generating cash on the sale of the land and reducing our costs to the space we actually use." 
Eastdil Realty in New York has been the broker for Dreyfus and Xerox. "It says something for the area and the asset," said Douglas L. Harmon, Eastdil broker, "that a number of large institutional bidders like TIAA showed up for the Dreyfus sale." 
Christopher P. Bruhl, executive director of Sacia, the Southwestern (Connecticut) Area Commerce and Industry Association, takes a cautious view of companies leaving Manhattan. "The economic health of the New York Metropolitan region is what assures the economic health of lower Fairfield County," he said. "Companies can move around within the region -- what's important is that they stay in the region, not go to North Carolina. The future of the region over the next three years will be determined as thousands of large and small leases expire. Technology has made it possible to be almost anywhere. Will companies renew, depart, disperse? And if they disperse, to where?"

HEADLINE: Where Does the Orchestra Go From Up? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
THE musicians wander onto the big stage in ones and twos, then take their places and tune their instruments or just stand around chatting. They are wearing jeans and sweatshirts and running shoes. It's almost 10 on a Thursday morning in January, and Prudential Hall, the grand five-tiered wedding cake of an auditorium that has been the symphony's principal home for the past five seasons, is dark and empty except for the business onstage.
 This is Rehearsal 2 in Week 2 of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's Winter Festival. The musicians are about to tackle three fiercely difficult late works of Richard Strauss, from the great dying gasp of German Romanticism. But nobody seems greatly upset when Susan Stucker, the general manager, steps onstage to deliver bad news: Zdenek Macal, the orchestra's music director and the guiding spirit behind the Strauss festival, is down with flu, as he has been all week, and won't be able to conduct either of today's rehearsals. The concert is tomorrow night. 
 Instead, it falls to Mark Laycock, the associate conductor, a tall man in a blue turtleneck, to coax this music out of the orchestra. He strides to the podium and says a few words about the nostalgia and longing he hears in Strauss's "Metamorphosen," a dense, subtly modulated work for 23 string parts (arranged here for 46 players). The musicians listen politely, Mr. Laycock brings down his baton in a fluid motion, and the Strauss begins.
This is the midpoint of the New Jersey Symphony's 79th season. To say it has come a long way since its first concert, at the Montclair Art Museum on Nov. 27, 1922, would require a level of understatement utterly foreign to the language of symphony program notes.
It has survived virtual homelessness, labor-management strife and several near-death experiences, not to mention constant competition from much better-known and better-financed orchestras in New York and Philadelphia for audiences and musicians. Today it ranks near the summit of the American orchestral landscape, if not quite in the class of powerhouses like the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia Orchestra.
Its annual budget is in the top 30 (out of 1,800 nationwide), according to the American Symphony Orchestra League, a nonprofit service organization for orchestras, and Jack McAuliffe, a vice president of the league, says its reputation is climbing.
"As a statewide orchestra, New Jersey is on the cutting edge," he said. "It's taken that role seriously and honed it beyond what any other statewide orchestra has done." 
It has won a Grammy and an Ascap award. It enjoys a balanced budget, a growing endowment and a level of cooperation between musicians and management that astounds outsiders -- and even some of its veteran players, who remember much worse times. Its new hall, in the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, is widely envied for its lustrous appearance and pinpoint acoustics. The hall is also credited with quadrupling annual subscriptions, putting the orchestra on a sound financial footing after decades of struggle.
How the New Jersey Symphony got to these peaks is one story. Whether it can remain there -- and keep climbing -- is another. 
Its most immediate challenge is to find a replacement for the much-admired Mr. Macal, who announced a year ago that this would be his last full season as music director. A longer-term challenge, though no less pressing, is to find ways to ride out economic storms like the current recession and to expand and diversify its audience.

A Sense of Collegiality
"Don't slow down before that note, for the love of God!" a horn player is shouting at Mr. Laycock. "There's no ritard there. You're making something that's very difficult almost impossible."
By this time the orchestra is rehearsing the Symphonic Fragment from "Josefs-Legende," a flashy, undeservedly obscure work that Strauss adapted from an early ballet score in 1947, two years before his death. This will be the showpiece number that ends the weekend concerts, and while the orchestra played it once before, some years ago, it is so far outside the standard repertory that it feels unfamiliar to everyone. 
If the associate conductor is taken aback at this outburst, he doesn't let on. He apologizes for misreading the many-staffed score and adds, "I really appreciate all your input." At this, the musicians applaud him by stamping their feet (they can't hold instruments and clap at the same time), and the tension evaporates. The moment illustrates the collegiality that is usually the second thing anyone talks about when you ask what makes the New Jersey Symphony different from all other orchestras. (The first, always, is the new hall.) 
"We've brought the musicians into everything: the budget, the executive committee, the music-director search committee," said Dr. Victor Parsonnet, a prominent heart surgeon who has been the symphony's chairman for 10 years. "There's nothing we're doing that doesn't involve them. That makes for a very happy group."
Such language could be public-relations gauze, of course, coming from a board chairman. But it finds echoes everywhere. "When I went to my first meetings with the symphony in '98, I was waiting for a war to start," said Les Blasi, president of Newark Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians, the union that represents the orchestra members. "But everyone was talking about mutual needs and desires and ways of moving ahead. I thought it was just talk, that it would break down into yelling and screaming. It never happened. I was amazed." The musicians' current three-year contract carries through next season.
Darryl Kubian, a violinist who is chairman of the orchestra committee, the players' official link with management, calls the orchestra "a rarity -- a very big extended family," and for this he gives much of the credit to the board, especially Dr. Parsonnet. "He was the first to recognize musicians as people," Mr. Kubian said. "His attitude was: 'Listen, I'm a surgeon. It takes a lot of skill, but I couldn't do what these musicians are doing. They should be treated with respect.' "
The current 76-member orchestra is a mix of newcomers and veterans, some of whom well remember the bad times. Robert Wagner, 46, now the principal bassoonist, joined the symphony just out of the Juilliard School in 1979. In 1980 the orchestra ran out of money and had to cancel an entire season. Mr. Wagner cobbled together a living, then rejoined the orchestra for 1981-82, having taken a pay cut from $10,000 to $7,600. "I'd just bought a car and a bassoon," he said. "I sold the bassoon."
Today the pay is respectable for an orchestra in the top 30 -- a base salary of $42,000 for the symphony's 36-week season. Many musicians supplement their wages by teaching and by playing in chamber groups and other orchestras. "It's nowhere near the Philharmonic or the Met," Mr. Kubian acknowledged (those orchestras pay at least twice the New Jersey Symphony's yearly salary, for a 52-week season), "but as far as a living weekly wage goes, it's starting to approach something that's plausible."

Back From a Financial Abyss
The 1980-81 washout was the symphony's worst reversal on the way to financial respectability, but far from the last. It tends to be forgotten that when Gov. Jim Florio took office in 1990, in the teeth of a nationwide recession, he not only raised taxes but also cut spending. The State Arts Council, which contributed more than a third of the orchestra's annual budget, slashed that contribution nearly in half. 
"The symphony was in a really bad financial place," said Lawrence Tamburri, who has been its executive director since 1991. "We had a choice: cut our way out of the problem, or try to raise money, raise our artistic standing and grow our way out of the problem." 
It actually did some of both, canceling some concerts and persuading the musicians' union to accept salary cuts while trying to raise the orchestra's visibility and bolster its fund-raising. By 1993-94, however, it had maxed out its credit and was on the edge of bankruptcy once again.
Then its luck turned. Part of it was the rapidly expanding national economy, which took pressure off the state budget. Part of it was the newfound respect between musicians and management, which resulted in a mutual willingness to work together and make concessions. And part of it was what seemed to many at the time like a hopelessly quixotic effort to revive Newark's sad, wasted downtown: the construction of a $187 million Performing Arts Center on the site of an abandoned hotel.
For the first 75 years of its existence, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra lived everywhere and nowhere. Viewed as a statewide orchestra, it had no principal home. It still gives regular concerts in six halls outside Newark -- in Englewood, Morristown, New Brunswick, Princeton, Red Bank and Trenton -- but before the Performing Arts Center the nomadic life defined its existence. 
"The working conditions were probably toughest of any major American orchestra," said Hugh Wolff, the charismatic young conductor who was its music director from 1985 to 1992. "You can hardly imagine how difficult it was to get an ordinary day's work done. I look back with a certain kind of fondness at the guts we all had." 
The orchestra toured all the locations, playing half a dozen concerts over two weekends. It rehearsed in high school auditoriums. The old Symphony Hall in Newark was particularly depressing. "It was a dank, dark place," Mr. Wolff remembered. "If it was windy the roof would rattle, and if it was raining it would leak. When we played loudly you could see little flecks of dust come down." 
Downtown Newark was a forbidding place, and musicians and concertgoers parked their cars in lots ringed by barbed wire. In 1985 a cellist was almost killed when a backstage elevator malfunctioned and she fell into the shaft.
In hindsight, it's obvious that the orchestra badly needed a permanent home, and that the new Performing Arts Center was a godsend. From the vantage point of near-bankruptcy in 1994, however, it looked more like a bargaining chip in the orchestra's life-or-death negotiations with the state. "Without the symphony, PAC was going to be an empty building," said Dr. Victor J. Bauer, the board's vice chairman and treasurer. "There was a compelling mutual interest in our being around when it opened."
The state saw the point. It made a one-time grant of $3 million to the symphony, almost wiping out the deficit and guaranteeing that it would play at the opening-night concert in October 1997. 
Prudential Hall and its principal tenant were an instant triumph -- New Jersey's real power couple of the late 90's -- and since then the orchestra has never looked back. Almost literally: "I hate to talk about the mess we were in before," Dr. Parsonnet, the chairman, said in an interview last month. "It's an old story -- almost not pertinent anymore."
As the state heads into another round of deep budget cuts, those travails may be more pertinent than the orchestra likes to acknowledge. But the string of successes that began with that opening night has clearly left it in the best financial shape in its history, recession or no. In November 2000, it began a drive to raise its endowment tenfold, to $35 million from $3.5 million. It has received contributions and pledges of $21 million toward the new goal -- though like virtually every other arts organization, it took a beating last fall when donors redirected their giving to Sept. 11 charities.
"It's inevitable there are going to be cycles," Mr. Tamburri said. "But while orchestras can go through difficult times, there's a demand for them. People rally behind them."

A New Level of Refinement
Word of Zdenek Macal's weeklong illness has filtered out, and as concertgoers take their seats in Prudential Hall for the Friday night Strauss concert there's a buzz of disappointment at the prospect that he won't be on the podium. So when he bounds onstage, wan but dashing, his long black coattails and mane of hair flying behind him, the applause has an extra measure of brio. 
Mr. Macal -- Maestro to his musicians, Denny to his friends -- is in his ninth and final season as full-time music director. His hiring was another piece of good luck.
When Hugh Wolff left after the 1992-93 season to take over the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, the management turned to Mr. Macal, then director of the Milwaukee Symphony, as "artistic adviser" while it looked for a permanent replacement. As he has since told it, he liked being close to the center of the musical world -- his apartment overlooks Lincoln Center in Manhattan -- and he liked the challenge of taking the New Jersey Symphony to the next artistic level, in its own new hall. So he decided to remain, and was appointed music director in 1993.
Musicians and audiences have fallen for him in a big way. "I'm very drawn to his unbelievable commitment to the music," said Kelly Hall-Tompkins, a 30-year-old violinist in her third year with the orchestra. "Day after day he comes to work with the same commitment to the spirit and joy of making music." In the orchestra seats at Friday's performance, a subscriber, Lourdes Armada of Tenafly, who teaches music in the Montclair public schools, called his conducting "exquisite." 
Mr. Macal is not unduly shy about accepting such praise. Born 66 years ago in Brno, Czechoslovakia, he got out of Prague just ahead of the Soviet tanks in 1968 and became a peripatetic guest conductor, appearing before scores of orchestras before taking the directorships in Milwaukee and then New Jersey. Now, he says, he has decided to ease up a bit, in part to scale back the demands on his wife, Georgina, who has had health problems. A year ago he stunned the musicians by announcing that the 2001-02 season would be his last as full-time music director, though he will have emeritus status for the next two seasons and conduct a Dvorak festival in 2004.
"I prefer to leave in the peak," he said in a recent interview, still under the weather but warming to his subject in buoyant, slightly fractured English. "If I look back, I reach everything I wanted and even more. 
"Artistically the level is much higher than when I came," he said of his musicians. "When I arrived, they were basically good, but not technically polished or balanced. I spent my first few years cleaning up technical problems, rhythmical things. Now I don't worry about technical problems. They play at a totally new spiritual level."
Even his predecessor, Mr. Wolff, accepts that verdict, despite the implied criticism of his tenure. "We often got the level of refinement that Denny likes to talk about, but not always," he said. "Remember that we worked under severe financial constraints. I offer no excuses for the occasional night when personnel changed and we hadn't all rehearsed together. There was a rough and ready atmosphere that the orchestra had to outgrow."
There is nothing rough or ready about Friday night's Strauss concert. Entrances are precise, the ensemble playing is silken, and the music shines with emotion -- especially in a transcendent performance of Strauss's "Four Last Songs," with the soprano Alessandra Marc, which ends the concert's first half on a chord so hushed and death-haunted that the hall is utterly silent for several long moments before anyone applauds. 
Mr. Macal's conducting manner is exuberant and athletic, with huge, sweeping gestures and tiny, precise ones, like a minute flutter of the left hand to indicate a trill. ("Not many conductors do stuff like that," Eric Wyrick, the concertmaster, said afterward. "It all does mean something -- a little sheen that might not have been there before, a subtle gesture with the elbows and hands that creates extraordinary warmth.")
Clearly the musicians will miss him. But they also sound energized by the task of finding a successor, a task in which they will be closely involved as members of the search committee. A dozen or so guest conductors, many young and up and coming, will lead the orchestra over the next two seasons. Some of those concerts will be widely seen as auditions for a permanent music director. The mantra, repeated by musicians and staff members in half a dozen interviews, is "Everyone's a candidate and no one's a candidate."
There is even a chance that nobody will succeed Mr. Macal, at least in the traditional sense of an autocratic music director who is fully identified with the orchestra yet spends much of his time conducting elsewhere.
"You're never going to get a music director who does everything," said Mr. Wagner, the first bassoonist, "but the idea of a music director who's around 6 to 10 weeks is not the best model. What kind of commitment do you have to the inner workings of an orchestra and community if you have so little contact?"
Backstage after Friday's concert, with a clutch of admirers hanging on his words, Mr. Macal seems far from thinking about such things. His deep-set eyes are still bloodshot from the flu, but he is elated, still thoroughly wired to the music he's just conducted. So are the musicians filing out the stage door.
Outside, the night is cold and bright. The Performing Arts Center gleams like a Christmas package, and the Newark skyline shimmers overhead, benign and apparently untroubled. From this vantage point, it's possible to imagine that the city has finally turned a corner. Clearly its orchestra has.

HEADLINE: Some Not-Too-Subtle Advice On Etiquette for Job Hunting 

BYLINE:  This article was reported by Abby Ellin, Alice Feiring, Melinda Ligos, Marci Alboher Nusbaum and Patrica R. Olsen. 

 BODY:
Did you hear the one about the accountant who squashed a bug in a job interview? Or the woman who wrote a letter to a prospective boss that began, "Dear Blah Blah?" Or the aspiring lawyer who went to interviews in tennis whites?
 No, they are not jokes. They happened. And they hold a lesson for job seekers in these difficult economic times: it really does matter how you behave in those friendly chats with would-be employers. They will notice your indiscretions and probably hold them against you. 
 Of course, some stories told by hiring managers about the gaffes they have witnessed are so outlandish that the garden-variety goofs committed by most people seem harmless by comparison. Even so, they are only extreme infractions of the basic rules of job hunting. Here is an unscientific list of dos and don'ts.

Turn Off the Cellphone
"We've had a lot of candidates blow interviews because of cellphone usage," said Anne Maxfield, president of Project Solvers, a Manhattan staffing firm. She recalled a senior-level candidate who checked in with the receptionist, sat down, called his mother and began "a loud conversation about how he had just gone to the dentist to have his gums trimmed." When a manager finally greeted him, the applicant said, "I'll be with you in a few minutes."

Don't Play With the Boss's Stuff
Alan Towers, president of TowersGroup, a Manhattan public relations firm, interviewed a woman who struck him as intelligent and poised. When he escorted her back to the reception area, he noticed the furniture had been rearranged.
"I thought maybe the cleaning lady or a secretary had done it. When she asked me how I liked it, I realized with a shock that it was her doing," he said. "She was a take-charge individual, but there are limits. My last words to her were: 'We'll call you.' "

Show Good Manners
Anthony P. Carnesi, owner of Profitability Consulting in Manhattan, was surprised by the disheveled appearance of a woman he was interviewing. Even so, her resume was impressive, and he kept an open mind.
Until she plopped her canvas bag on its side on a table, that is, and a large water bug scurried out. "I was shocked, but she reached out and slammed her hand down right on top of the little critter," Mr. Carnesi said. "I was impressed by her swiftness. She then wiped her hand on the napkin that her coffee cup was on, turned to me and continued answering my question as if nothing had happened." But something had: She had just blown her chance to get the job.

Check Correspondence for Errors
A candidate for an editorial assistant's job at Food & Wine magazine wrote thank-you notes to both editors who had interviewed her. But her carelessness did her in; she forgot to insert the name of one of the editors in her form letter.
"On one letter she got the name right," said Dana Cowin, Food & Wine's editor in chief. "The other letter was written to Dear Blah Blah. The woman who got the Blah Blah was really insulted."

Know How to Listen
David Moore, chairman of Sonostar Ventures, a venture capital firm in Millwood, N.Y., recalls a prospective employee's 40-minute monologue about himself. "He hardly came up for air," Mr. Moore said. "At the end of the meeting I said, 'Do you have any questions for us?' He said, 'No, I think you've answered all of my questions.' But he hadn't asked any. This is not the kind of person you want around."

Dress Appropriately
When he was at the Harvard Business School in 1980, before the era of casual dress in the workplace, Mr. Moore and the five law students he lived with often compared notes about their job searches.
One morning, a housemate came downstairs in a tennis outfit and announced he was going to an interview. "He said, 'I go to all my interviews dressed like this. Hey, this is who I am; if they don't like me, they won't hire me,' " Mr. Moore said. "To the best of my knowledge, no one ever did."

Don't Flirt in Interviews
About a year ago, Mr. Moore was interviewing a woman dressed in a sexy black dress for an executive assistant's position and wondered why she started talking about all the times she had gone out to dinner with her former boss.
"But then it became clear that she was not opposed to reproducing that situation in another job," he said. "It was clear this wasn't a path I should go down."

Watch What You Eat
Mark Sirota, an associate general counsel with Reader's Digest in Pleasantville, N.Y., was taken to lunch in 1983 by several partners of a white-shoe law firm seeking to fill a summer associate's position. He kept to simple fare -- until he ordered chocolate truffles in a bed of whipped cream covered with chocolate sauce for dessert. As he pressed down on the first truffle with a spoon, it flew off his plate.
Mr. Sirota sat motionless while the waiter pulled out the table to clean up the mess, then joked about the need to observe job candidates at lunch "to make sure we won't embarrass the firm in front of clients." The lawyers laughed politely. Mr. Sirota didn't land the job.

Know What the Job Is
Janet Lee, fitness director at Fitness Magazine in Manhattan, remembers trying to get a job as a summer intern at the Federal Reserve Bank in Washington when she was studying accounting in college.
She was asked in an interview what she hoped to do. "Well, I really don't like working with numbers," she replied. She realized her goof immediately and tried to talk her way out of it, to no avail. "Since then, I've definitely polished my interviewing skills," she said.

Do Your Homework
Fred Neurohr, a researcher for the Nassau County Youth Board in Hempstead, N.Y., tells this story about a job interview he had at Publishers Clearinghouse, the mailer of sweepstakes offers. To break the ice with the interviewer, he asked, "Is Ed McMahon around a lot?" Getting no answer, he persisted. "Have you met him?" Meeting more silence, he tried again. "I bet he's a trip at the holiday party." Only then did his interviewer reply, "He works for the competition."
Oddly enough, he got the job, going on to become Publishers Clearinghouse's head researcher. He later discovered that most Americans mistakenly associate Mr. McMahon with Publishers Clearinghouse.

Don't Lie
And if you do, admit it. Ms. Cowin of Food & Wine magazine remembers a man who acknowledged his claim to have a college degree was not exactly right.
"And I said, 'You either have a degree or not.' Finally, he said he almost got the degree, falling one credit short." She hired him anyway because of his terrific work. "What made the difference is that he admitted it," she said.

Check Your Zipper
It may be the stuff of jokes, but it happens. Ask Linda Gilleran, a principal consultant for Hewlett-Packard in New York. She left an interview for an associate's position at Lazard Freres, the investment bank, some years ago thinking she had made a great impression.
Once outside, she said, "I looked down to find my fly wide open with just the fluttering silk of my underwear between me and the world." She didn't get the job.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Maxfield of Project Solvers says an invasive cellphone can be a problem. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.; 
An Empty Store Gathers Cobwebs, Not Developers

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR 

 BODY:
FOR years, Hahne's department store was a prestigious anchor for the downtown business district. But 12 years ago, it became yet another retail victim of the malling of New Jersey.
 Now, the vacant two-story building with its flaking white-washed 1950's facade and boarded-over display windows is an anchor all right, many say, only it's one that is dragging the area down. 
 "The building is just kind of deteriorating," said Joe DeFrance, who has watched the changes from the window of his hair salon, Esthetica, across South Park Street ever since Hahne's closed in 1989. "They ought to do something about it. Everyone has the same feeling about that." 
Something was done, or so it seemed -- several times -- but always to no avail.
The on-again, off-again plans for the building at South Park and Church Street, a block from Bloomfield Avenue, the main thoroughfare of the old downtown, perpetually struggling for vitality, has created in many minds a negative image that goes against the grain of a township that likes to see itself as a cosmopolitan enclave in a suburban setting.
Montclair's 39,000 residents, many of them transplanted New York professionals, artists, writers and theater people, take pride in the town's racial diversity, grand old houses, quaint specialty shops and eclectic restaurants. It has Montclair State University, the Montclair Art Museum, several well-established theater groups and several movie houses -- when most towns are fortunate to have one -- that show their share of art films that cineastes usually would have to travel to Manhattan to see.
There have been proposals to turn the old Hahne's into a medical mall bustling with physicians and health and fitness tenants, a minimall, a hotel, a performing space, an office building with retail space. The deals always fell through.
The most recent wrinkle -- a plan for residences with retail space on the first floor -- sees the landlord, Center Montclair Associates, suing the developer, Pinnacle Communities Ltd. of Millburn in Superior Court in Newark. The landlord claims that Pinnacle, which was to buy the property, is in default in making payments. And so one more proposal is in jeopardy.
For many residents here, having a white elephant at the west end of a trendy block on Church Street with Soho-like restaurants and chic antique and clothing stores just won't do.
"It's hard to measure in dollars and cents," said Terence J. Reidy, the township manager, speaking of the effect the ill-fated site has had on foot traffic, the viability of adjacent stores and lost municipal revenue.
Mr Reidy added: "There is also a psychological aspect. The Hahne's building had stood as this marvelous anchor in the community before it closed. Now, it's a symbol. When it stands vacant for so long, people say, 'Oh my God, why can't this get done?' "
Like many people, Mr. DeFrance's next-door neighbor, Todd A. Edelson, a physical therapist and partner in Montclair Physical Therapy Associates, wonders why.
"Well, 12 years is a long time, I think, for a building not to sell, especially with the way the economy was in the 90's," said Mr. Edelson, whose window also faces the store. "It's hard for me to fathom."
Hahne's, (pronounced Haynes), was founded in Newark in 1858 by Julius Hahne, a pocketbook maker, and eventually become known as a New Jersey version of high-quality Manhattan stores. In 1937, Montclair became the site of its first branch.
By the 1980's sales began going flat, partly because of the proliferation of malls. In 1986 May Department Stores Company of St. Louis bought the chain. Hahne's went downscale, sales worsened, and in January 1989, May announced that all nine Hahne's stores would close.
In 1994, Center Montclair Associates, a group of investors, bought the 114,000-square-foot building. One partner, William Brach, a lawyer, said chronic lack of parking was part of the trouble in attracting renters. "We had interest but it did not occur, and a major reason was the lack of parking. It's just horrendous," Mr. Brach said.
Last February, the township decided enough was enough and declared the Hahne's site an area in need of redevelopment -- a designation under state law that requires that the owners develop the site or sell it to a developer with an acceptable plan. It also gives Montclair the authority to take over the property.
A consultant has drafted a redevelopment plan for Montclair -- including Hahne's -- that is to be presented to the planning board for review on Feb. 11.
Last August, the council passed a resolution that authorizes the addition of a $6 million parking deck -- directly tied to any development of Hahne's -- that would add 350 more spaces to a nearby lot.
"Developers are going to have an obligation to provide parking," Mr. Reidy said.
The sale of the building to Pinnacle is "ambiguous" at this point, said Mr. Brach of Center Montclair, which, he added, plans to file papers against Pinnacle next week. "We want them to fish or cut bait," hre said.
Ron Ladell, vice president of business development for Pinnacle, would only say: "We look forward to developing the Hahne's building in Montclair. We think we will be able to develop a first-class mixed-use facility at that site."
But Mr. Reidy put it like this: "If everything falls apart, the town is in the position of stepping in and making something happen. We are really serious about getting this property developed."

HEADLINE: LOVE & MONEY; 
His Thoughts About Her Earning Their Keep

BYLINE:  By ELLYN SPRAGINS; Ellyn Spragins is a freelance writer in Maplewood, N.J. Her column about money's influence on relationships appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: loveandmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LAST month I asked husbands whose wives outearned them to speak up about this apparently taboo topic. More than a hundred did, often in long, sometimes-emotional e-mail messages. Ceding the major breadwinner role to your wife is no big deal, a very big deal and everything between.
 Some men cited the issue as a major factor in a fragile marriage or in the breakup of one, while others expressed amazement that a higher-earning wife could possibly cause problems in this day and age. Plenty felt ambivalent, mostly comfortable with taking a back seat to their wives. But often they said they were lonely, both in the company of "normal" men as well as in the throng of women waiting to pick up their children from school. 
 The happiest seemed to be those who felt that their own contributions to the marriage were fully valued. Steve Miller, who teaches broadcast journalism at Rutgers University, is the primary-care parent for two daughters. His wife is a vice president at a computer company.
"Do I deserve to earn more money than Jane? Absolutely not," Mr. Miller said. "Who receives the more valuable compensation? I feel that I do. Do we both make significant contributions to the economic structure of our family and our relationship? Absolutely."
It helps if husbands and wives have taken turns being the high earner. Peter Carpenter, a former management executive at the Alza Corporation, a pharmaceutical research company in Mountain View, Calif., decided to give up his six-figure salary in 1990 to devote himself to nonprofit work. His wife, Jane Shaw, the chief executive of Aerogen, a pulmonary drug delivery company in Sunnyvale, Calif., now earns 450 times as much as he does.
"We both recognize that our true wealth is not represented by our tax returns; we also get a lot of 'income' from what I do, it is just not denominated in dollars," Mr. Carpenter said. Still, he admits that it was not easy giving up the trappings of conventional male success. Worse, initially his male colleagues thought that he could simply no longer compete in the corporate world.
Strangely, some men, after energetically proclaiming their pride in their wives and their indifference to traditional roles, asked to have their names withheld. Hmmmm. One of these, a man who works in New York and earns more than $100,000 a year, said, "Although her compensation more than doubles mine, I don't feel that my ego needs protection or that my self-confidence would slip if our W-2's were no longer private."
I thought that talking to his wife would clear things up. In a way, it did: they don't really agree on how reconciled they are to her big paycheck. He may say he's proud of her, but she notices that he doesn't appreciate the long hours she puts in.
"He likes me to be home when he's there," she said. And she confessed that she was frustrated with his moderate ambitions: "He doesn't have that same drive that I do." His response: "How much is enough? Why take on more responsibility, work more hours and enjoy life less?"
Some men like being home when the children return from school, and they cook family dinners, do house and yard chores and administer massages when needed. These are the men who, after weighing the price their children would pay for a two-career household, sometimes decide to become nonworking, stay-at-home fathers. 
Most men who wrote shoulder this role by default, because they entered parenthood as the lower earner. A few couples mutually decided that the husband was temperamentally better suited to be the chief nurturer. Either way, children -- or the prospect of children -- seem to heighten whatever insecurities and conflicts lie just beneath the hard-won equilibrium of unequal incomes.
One young husband, a lawyer, is married to a higher-earning doctor who wants to delay having children until he makes enough for her to stay home with them. "What my wife wants is for me to be more aggressive, take a second job and really push myself," he said. "I have no problem with pushing myself, but I am not that aggressive of a person."
ANOTHER couple, both lawyers, started the marriage with the husband earning more but after a move to Los Angeles from New York, the wife's income shot ahead. Her fortune was delicious to both -- until they began a family. "When we started having kids, she wanted the luxury of not having to work. There was a lot of resentment that she was carrying the weight," the husband said. That resentment, as well as other conflicts, led the couple to divorce after 12 years of marriage.
Some men who wrote declared, a bit smugly, that couples struggling with the fact that the wife made more money should look elsewhere for the root of their marital problems. That may be good advice. But after hearing from so many men and women, I wonder. I've come to think that a wife's big paycheck is like a large, intrusive, annoying question mark, prodding both partners to work harder at defining themselves and their roles than they otherwise would have needed to do. 
What is "being successful"? What do I really value in this relationship, anyway? What are we trying to accomplish in our life together? Yes, they're hard questions. The answers can be even harder.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Workers Find Retirement Is Receding Toward 70

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Enron scandal has many people rushing to rid 401(k) plans of ill-advised investments. But the uproar overlooks another shortcoming in the nation's retirement system. People forced to finance their pensions with their own savings are now facing a new retirement age. While their parents stopped working at 65, the children are finding that they must stay on the job until their late 60's or early 70's if they want to live as well in retirement.
 That calculation is just beginning to roll off the spreadsheets of the nation's economists and pension experts. We all knew, without Enron, that too many 401(k) plans were overinvested in the sponsoring company's stock. We knew, also without Enron, that most people do not voluntarily save enough, and what they save is often not invested wisely. The rising stock market papered over these shortcomings. But now that the boom is gone, and the hubris with it, the inevitable bottom line of a 401(k) system -- postponed retirement -- is surfacing. 
 "There are not yet enough studies to pinpoint the new retirement age, but it is probably between 68 and 70," said Annika Sunden, an associate director of Boston College's Center for Retirement Research. 
Ignoring such talk, people in their 40's still look forward to retirement in their early 60's, pollsters say. But reality is already different. Forty percent of the people who have saved for their retirement and are now 67 are still on the job, Ms. Sunden reports, compared with only 20 percent of the 67-year-olds with company-financed pension plans. 
The 67-year-olds were in their mid-40's when Congress, in the late 1970's, authorized tax-deferred 401(k) plans. And without their knowing it, their retirement years changed. With that legislation, the nation began a gradual shift from a private-sector pension system financed by the employer toward a system financed mainly by employees. The employer-financed pensions, combined with Social Security, produced a retirement income at age 65 equal to nearly 60 percent of a typical worker's preretirement pay, according to various studies. The employee-financed system is a distant second. Added to Social Security, the earnings from 401(k) savings produce a typical pension, at age 65, that is less than 50 percent of preretirement pay.
How to close the gap? Teresa Ghilarducci, an economist and pension expert at the University of Notre Dame, offers a back-of-the-envelope calculation. Let's say you are nearly 65. Your income is $50,000, having risen gradually from $30,000. Your 401(k) savings are $33,600, which is right at the median for people in the 55-through-64 age group, according to the Federal Reserve's Survey of Consumer Finance. 
Social Security, in this example, provides nearly 40 percent of the preretirement income. The return on the 401(k) contributes an additional 4.7 percent, assuming the savings earn 5 percent above the inflation rate, or roughly 7 percent today, which is more than most 401(k) plans are earning. Given this math, raising the retirement age is looming as the route of least resistance to closing the gap between the 60 percent of preretirement income that many parents received when they stopped working in the 1970's and the pensions that will go to their children, now in their 60's.
Here another variable enters Ms. Ghilarducci's calculation. Life expectancy for 65-year-old Americans is 84 years, up one year since the 1970's. To collect 60 percent of preretirement income through age 84, people will have to continue working, and saving, to age 69.5. "You lose 4.5 years of leisure," Ms. Ghilarducci said, "but you gain a year of life expectancy, so the net loss is 3.5 years of leisure."
There is another, more equitable solution. Companies have invested much more in the pension plans they have financed than they contribute to 401(k)'s. Prodded by Congress, they could contribute more to 401(k)'s, and maybe shave a year or two off the emerging retirement age. 
Raising 401(k) retirement income through fatter company contributions would soften some of the present inequality. Only the upper end of the work force earns $75,000 or more, which is roughly sufficient, economists say, to save enough to finance, at age 65, a pension equal to at least 60 percent of preretirement pay.
In the absence of such solutions, Americans are revising their retirement age. From World War II until the mid-1980's, they retired at ever younger ages. And then, as 401(k) plans gained acceptance and people stayed healthy longer, the trend gradually reversed. Company-financed plans guaranteed a monthly check for the rest of a retiree's life; the 401(k)'s do not.
"That is causing people to think," said Sara Rix, a policy adviser at AARP, an organization of people over 50, "that maybe if I work a couple of years longer, I'll be O.K."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Welfare Memories

BYLINE:  By LYNNELL HANCOCK; LynNell Hancock is the author of "Hands to Work: The Stories of Three Families Racing the Welfare Clock," published in January by William Morrow.

 BODY:
IN the long, fiery debate over public aid for the poor, there are two distinct sides. One faction holds that welfare creates a permanent class of idle dependents. Others counter that government aid is a compassionate necessity as long as poverty exists. This political rift played out in a dramatic personal way a few weeks ago for the city's new welfare commissioner.
 Commissioner Verna Eggleston of the Human Resources Administration was quoted in news reports as saying her mother cobbled together four jobs to raise her seven children in a Bronx housing project. Welfare, she said, may have consisted of little more than surplus cheese, and public assistance was part of their family life for only one year, maybe two. 
 The commissioner's mother, Dorothy Eggleston, quietly corrected her daughter, saying she needed welfare's help for nearly two decades so she could pay the rent. When her husband abandoned the family more than 40 years ago, Dorothy Eggleston, a former housecleaner, turned to the city's welfare system to help keep her family together. "I wasn't making enough to take care of my kids," she said. A nursing degree, financed by public aid, gave her the skills to escape poverty.
This mother-daughter misunderstanding is a reminder of how political rhetoric has clouded our understanding of aid to the poor. 
The daughter's version squares with the Giuliani administration's rigid assumption that anyone shackled to the dole for more than a few months would inevitably sink into indolence. The way out of poverty was to take a job quickly -- any job, no matter how poorly it paid.
The mother's story supports the belief that most welfare recipients require skills-building government help to rise out of poverty. Dorothy Eggleston needed long-term help and higher education to guide herself and her children into decent jobs. The assistance did not corrupt her character.
This ambivalence toward government aid is as old as the century. When my grandfather lost his railroad job in the Depression, he tried to avoid the shame of government relief as long as he could. His wife and two daughters took in laundry in their southern Illinois town. His six sons picked blackberries and sold them door to door. "I never accepted charity in my life," Grandpa Hancock would say defiantly, "and I'm not about to start."
But piecemeal work was not enough to feed his large brood. So Grandpa finally signed on to help build a public school with the Civil Works Administration in exchange for a federal paycheck. It was called relief then, not welfare, and practically the whole town of West Frankfurt was signing up.
My father, then a teenager, would often point with pride to the large brick structure his dad helped create. As an adult, he came to understand that government had an obligation to help people in his family's position. It was simply the most humane option.
The Giuliani administration returned the welfare system to an era in which suspicion of the poor replaced compassion for people down on their luck. Today, a person who turns to welfare is bounced from fraud office to finger-imaging appointment, from menial workfare assignment back to the welfare center, often before receiving cash assistance.
Mothers with children as young as 3 months must work up to 35 hours a week at a Work Experience Program assignment or risk losing aid. They work in exchange for their benefits, not for wages. Instead of building great public works, most workers sweep streets or clean buildings. There is little time to train for better jobs or get more education. 
Dorothy Eggleston could not have raised and educated her family as she did under these conditions. Five years is the lifetime limit for welfare. Higher education is rarely an option.
Commissioner Eggleston takes over this system at a tough time for the city. She does not have the luxury of managing the $5 billion welfare system during the prosperity her predecessor enjoyed. The lines at emergency food centers are growing. Welfare rolls are climbing. Unemployment is rising. The city lost more than 100,000 jobs after Sept. 11 alone. Thirty thousand people seek places in the city's shelter system every night. 
Ms. Eggleston could be one of those rare city officials whose life story provides hardscrabble inspiration for the people she serves. The city's former child welfare commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, gained credibility because he was once a foster child. Fiorello La Guardia was better trusted to lead the ethnic stew of New Yorkers out of the Depression because of his working-class Jewish-Italian background.
Commissioner Eggleston would do well to embrace her own life story. Her tale can inspire and transform the welfare system into one that assists, rather than punishes, the people who reluctantly seek its help.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Some Beautiful Minds Talk About Acceptance

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
AT first blush, it would seem it is one thing to suffer from a mental illness as an acclaimed mathematician at Princeton University, and another as a New Yorker without special gifts. This, after all, is a city in which the most visible schizophrenic people are subway pushers or homeless beggars.
 But the 20 people standing outside the Cobble Hill Cinema in Brooklyn the other day, all with some form of mental illness, had just seen "A Beautiful Mind," the new film about the mathematician, and they felt a connection. They liked the movie because they thought it got things right and made one of their kind lovable and triumphant. 
 "Did anyone not like it?" teased Danny Frey, a thin young man with big brown eyes who is the editor in chief of New York City Voices, a newspaper for mental health advocates. There were a few giggles from the members of the group, who were on an outing sponsored by the Brooklyn Peer Advocacy Program, a self-help program that operates from space around the corner on Baltic Street.
After the movie, as a light rain fell, the little group walked back to the program's offices to discuss what they had seen. Sitting around a table in a dour beige room with an orange linoleum floor, they resembled passengers on a random subway car: diverse in dress, speech, race and manner. Some were married, others single. Some had jobs, others were too ill to work. The peer advocacy program is a program of the Baltic Street Mental Health Board, which offers an array of services for the mentally ill. 
"I don't think too many marriages survive mental illness," was the only criticism from a woman named Eva, who appeared to be in her 50's and wore her hair in a topknot.
"Not at all," agreed Jean, a lively 26-year-old from the Tremont section of the Bronx. "There are some good women out there." Jean said he did not have a job these days, but added that his mother and his girlfriend were supportive. 
Stephanie, 49, who lives in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has bipolar disorder and works as a senior peer advocate for the advocacy program, piped up.
"They told me I'd never work again," said Stephanie, who has thick glasses and an intense manner. "We have to keep believing we can be inspired by others." 
"A Beautiful Mind," starring Russell Crowe as John Forbes Nash Jr., is a critically praised but sanitized version of the life of the eccentric mathematician who won a Nobel Prize in economics in 1994 for work done decades earlier. Some mental health advocates see it as a breakthrough film, both because of its accuracy and because it offers a positive image. 
It is estimated that there are 100,000 to 250,000 people in New York with chronic, serious mentally illness. 
As gay people have learned, there is a price for coming out of the closet. But there may be a bigger price for staying put. New Yorkers tend not to know the names of friends, neighbors or colleagues who take lithium as well as they know the name of Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic homeless man who was convicted of pushing a woman in front of a subway train, killing her, three years ago.
"Our biggest problem is stigma," said Marvin Spieler, chairman of the Baltic Street Mental Health Board, one moviegoer. Mr. Spieler, a white-haired 57-year-old who acknowledged that he was initially reluctant to tell his neighbors in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that he suffered from schizophrenia, added, "It could be like diabetes, when you just go to the doctor."
But more mentally ill people are coming out of the closet, calling themselves "consumers" and lining up professional allies like Dr. Ralph Aquila, director of Residential Community Services Psychiatry at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Columbia University. 
"This movie takes on a rich debate about how to treat people, how to understand," Dr. Aquila said. "This takes it front and center into popular culture, to the outer boroughs."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Forecast of Future Is No Substitute for Past and Present

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
HARVEY L. PITT, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and senior Bush administration officials are talking up plans for big changes in disclosure requirements for public companies.
 The proposals seem alluring. But the cure may be worse than the disease. 
 In the wake of Enron's collapse, Mr. Pitt and like-minded officials have a theory. They say corporate balance sheets and historical profit-and-loss statements are too easily manipulated and are no longer much use to investors. Who has time to look at a 10-Q anyway? What really matters to Wall Street is the future cash flows a company will produce. 
So, they suggest, companies should produce much more information about their projections for the future. If, along the way, they wind up disclosing less information about the past, who cares?
In the broadest sense, Mr. Pitt is right. Investors buy stocks for the future, not the past. But he has miscalculated what Wall Street does well, and what it does badly.
Investors and analysts are best at getting a picture -- not an exact estimate, but a picture -- of a company's worth versus its competitors, based on its financial results and other data, like its reputation.
That is why, for example, Southwest Airlines is worth more in Wall Street's eyes than the rest of the airline industry combined, even though it is only the seventh-largest carrier. Southwest's record and solid labor relations give investors confidence that it will continue to prosper more than weaker rivals.
But neither investors nor executives are good at projecting a company's profits in any given quarter or year. There are simply too many variables.
By forcing companies to disclose more information about their internal growth projections, the S.E.C. risks creating an environment where companies face even heavier pressure to meet those projections. That atmosphere will foment more abuses of accounting rules.
"The idea of basing an investment decision on the hoped-for results of an interested management seems to me a broken reed," said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "The world got along fine with balance sheets on a date certain and income statements and less leverage."
The S.E.C. should worry about fixing disclosure rules, which have worked reasonably well for two generations, said Arthur Levitt, a former chairman of the commission. Mr. Levitt said he thought that oversight of accounting rules was the agency's weakest link. As chairman, he was largely rebuffed when he tried to force accountants to give up lucrative consulting work for companies they audited.
Now, in the wake of Enron, four of the five major accounting firms have said they will do exactly that. But Mr. Levitt said the S.E.C. should go further, with tighter oversight of the accounting profession and independent financing for the board that sets accounting rules, a board now financed primarily by accounting firms and companies. He would also like to see Wall Street analysts more clearly disclose if they own stock in the companies they recommend.
THE S.E.C. can take other immediate steps. It could force insiders to disclose instantly and electronically when they traded their companies' stock. It could tighten the rules on partnerships so companies had less room to move debt off their balance sheets.
Since the 1930's, investors have learned how to use balance sheets and profits to value companies. The process is not perfect, but it works.
It will continue to work as long as investors get the information they need, and that should be Mr. Pitt's priority. He would do well to remember that predicting the future is impossible, and stick to getting a clear picture of the past and present. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
