HEADLINE: Running in Place 

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
Everywhere in Brooklyn eventually slopes up to Sunset Park. The neighborhood, along the Brooklyn waterfront, north of Bay Ridge, is the borough's highest point. The people who live here can stand on almost any street corner and watch the postcard view unfurl, with the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to the south, the New Jersey shoreline to the west, and on to jagged Manhattan.
 But for all its height, Sunset Park falls squarely in the middle of the city's economic divide, teetering between rich and poor. New York's median family income, according to the latest Census figures, is $48,206. In a three-block pocket southeast of Green-Wood Cemetery, the median family income is $48,214. Although individual incomes vary, the area offers the city's closest match to middle class. 
 A middling income may seem to offer a decent living, and families who earn as much can also be found in mannerly neighborhoods like Unionport in the Bronx and Corona in Queens. But the economy is suffering, and so are families in the middle. 
To fully understand the strain is to walk the streets of a working-class neighborhood like Sunset Park and feel its texture. Here, candy-colored row houses sit among sedate brownstones, and mariachi music wafts from windows. Nearly 2,000 people live in this pocket, and Fifth Avenue is their shopping strip, with clothing stores filing down one side and travel agencies lining the other. Above the rooftops, men fly pigeons.
These families rebuff the notion that there is money enough for their needs. Lately, they've begun dropping tap lessons and even postponing surgeries, whittling shopping lists and moving in with relatives. (Three-bedroom apartments here regularly rent for $1,600.) 
Many people here also know the storied, immigrant history of Sunset Park, how generations of Norwegians, Puerto Ricans and Chinese have been rewarded for spending carefully. But now in this time of recession, coming up on its first anniversary, many wonder if tough choices at the bakery and the grocery will be enough to make do. And if life on the economic bubble is hard, they can only imagine the difficulties for half a city below. Even as the economy seeks to steady itself, scenes from a recent week reveal how one neighborhood tries not to slip. 
Every weekday about 2:30 p.m., Elizabeth Donate stands alongside other mothers waiting in the asphalt schoolyard of Public School 94 at 51st Street and Sixth Avenue. The bell to collect their children rings at 2:50, and so they pass the intervening minutes talking about church and husbands and children. 
"My 13-year-old is going on 21, but he doesn't understand," said Ms. Donate, 35. She wore sweatpants and a windbreaker and she rubbed her bare hands in the cold. "My sister gave him a Game Boy Advance for Christmas and now he's asking for more games. And he wants Jordan shoes, but I can't afford to pay $80. I have to save. I take him and his little brother to Payless, and sometimes I get attitude. But what can I do? I've got to do things little by little."
Ms. Donate, who is of Polish descent, is married to Angel Donate, an easygoing Puerto Rican who lost his warehouse job of eight years last January. The family had to move into the basement of his mother's apartment on Sixth Avenue. He found a $23,000 job at another warehouse in June, and the couple has been saving ever since to buy a house on Staten Island.
For now, she said, the monthly household budget breaks down as follows: $240 in rent to his mother, $480 in groceries, $30 in subway tokens for Mr. Donate, and $1,200 in savings for the house. The two boys have state-provided health care, but the parents do not. The children no longer have an allowance, and the family has no phone. Angel eventually plans to get a cellphone for $40 a month, but now they use the pay phone at the corner bodega. They rent movies, and eat a lot of macaroni, rice and beans. 
Ms. Donate once loved to eat at a cafe called George's Restaurant at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street, but she hasn't been there in months. Her wedding anniversary is Feb. 22; she said she's saving to splurge on a dinner at Red Lobster. 
Just then, the bell rang, and soon her youngest, Matthew, made his way through the crush of children. She gave him a hug and grabbed his hand. With a cheerful nod to a few women, she started walking home, five blocks away.
"I see these other moms in the neighborhood every weekend, and they're walking, just like me," she said. "I think they're not going out on Saturday night, either."
Grace Baptist Church rises one block from the elementary school on Sixth Avenue. Sunday morning services are held in its sanctuary of mahogany pews and creamy stained glass. But business meetings, like the one held on a recent Sunday, are relegated to a low-ceilinged hall downstairs. 
Perhaps to ease the transition, or to encourage some of the church's 220 members to linger for an afternoon of financial reports, several church workers had prepared ham-and-cheese sandwiches, coffee and Kool-Aid. 
In the back, near the nursery, stood Fernando Villamil, 29. He nibbled on a sandwich while his two daughters, 4 and 6, ran circles around his legs. His 1-year-old son, Fernando, waddled past him, mouthing a toy. Mr. Villamil patted his son's head but kept his eyes on the stage. He wanted to concentrate on the discussion about the church budget. An additional $800 would be needed this year for office supplies, but the senior pastor promised to cut $500 from his gas allowance.
Lately, Mr. Villamil, originally from the Dominican Republic, has also been taking a closer look at his own financial situation. He makes $40,000 a year as a network administrator with the Metropolitan Jewish Health System. His wife, Vanessa, used to make $36,000 as a teacher, but she is staying home this year with the children. 
So, he pays $800 for their two-bedroom apartment around the corner on 51st Street. Their one car, a Saturn, is long paid off. He parks it free on the street. He also scouts for the cheapest gas station. (Right now, it is the Shell station at 65th Street and Sixth Avenue.)
More recently, other changes have been made. The two girls take tap and ballet lessons once a week instead of twice. That cut the price in half, to $100 a month. He also canceled his cable service and gave the television set and the video game to a friend.
"You wouldn't believe how much we read now," he said.
Sometimes he misses meals in restaurants, but he says he doesn't mind eating at home. These days, when the children beg to go to the movies, he and his wife take them to children's museums or ice skating rinks instead.
"It's cheaper for the whole family," he said, "and it's good for them."
At one time or another, almost everyone in this corner of Sunset Park finds himself in the Pioneer Supermarket on Fifth Avenue. Lillian Hui, 16, and her mother, Helen Moy, shop here weekly. They live with a grandmother in a first-floor apartment in Brooklyn's Chinatown, three blocks away. Their monthly grocery budget is $100.
The other day, Ms. Moy selected a cart after glancing at the sales posted in the window: Axelrod yogurt, three for $1; Hungry Jack waffles, 10 for 99 cents. 
Half an hour later, she found her daughter in the dairy section and they reviewed the contents in the cart: one loaf of white bread, one bag with four bagels, one box of on-sale waffles, three on-sale yogurts and one package of frozen buffalo wings.
"All of them are 99 cents each," Ms. Moy said.
Her daughter smiled. "Except the wings."
"Those are only $1.88."
"Mom loves chicken wings." 
In the optometrist's office a few blocks away, Nancy Glassman was trying to mask the outrage in her voice. Dr. Glassman, 38, used to work at Morgan Stanley on Wall Street, but for the past five years she has shared this practice with her father, Leonard. She emerged from an examining room after prescribing glasses to a 42-year-old Dominican man. He suffered from alternating exotropy, a condition that gave him a chameleon-like ability to focus both eyes separately but never in sync.
Her anger stemmed from his condition. "He should've had surgery as a child," she muttered. "Twenty years he's been in Brooklyn, and I'm his first eye doctor. It's not right."
Dr. Glassman sometimes sees little to applaud in this neighborhood except its people. She understands that crime is down and rents are up, but her world is one of delayed surgeries and unaffordable remedies. Many of her families do not qualify for Medicaid, but neither can they pay for private insurance. If anything, the sluggish economy and layoffs have actually pushed more of her patients onto the Medicaid rolls. She considers this a mixed blessing.
Still, she continues to give away eyeglasses. She puts new lenses in old frames. She discourages patients from getting contacts, which are more costly than frames, less durable and more likely to be lost. 
"All the teenagers want contacts, but I won't hardly give them out anymore," she said. "It's hard, though. I've got to go in now and convince an 18-year-old to get glasses, even though his parents will probably be relieved." 
She ducked once more into her examining room. Minutes later, she leaned out, no longer ruffled. "He already had glasses," she said, with a sheepish smile. "And he treated them well, so I relented."
Joe Pena has often told neighbors the story of his Mas Que Pan Bakery, how he and his father, Jose, opened during the 1990 recession. Businesses to the left and right closed, but theirs survived.
"We made it solely because we had no payroll," Mr. Pena said. "I have six brothers and sisters and six aunts and uncles here, and for a long time we were an extended family business."
Today, the weekend lines are long for 75-cent espressos and 25-cent doughnuts. The teenage girls in red aprons working behind the counter are still Penas: Julissa, Erika, Elizabeth and Jackie. But they are paid $5.75 an hour, and are allowed to work only after school and on weekends.
Still, Mr. Pena has noticed some unnerving changes. Last summer, one of his sisters got laid off at AT&T and soon after a cousin lost a job at Goldman Sachs. By summer's end, morning traffic at the bakery had slipped 30 percent, about $200. His $1,200 utility bill had also doubled. 
He talked with his father, and in September they began bracing for his second recession. They sold some equipment and raised the refrigerator temperature from 36 degrees to 40 degrees. They affixed sleep timers to other units. Three months ago, they introduced a dollar menu to sell croissants, coconut bread and conchas.
So far, the trimming has lowered bills and kept customers. But Mr. Pena has already decided that, if the economy worsens, he cannot cut prices further. He would either have to stop paying his sisters to work for him or rent out the store he has owned since 1993. 
"In this neighborhood, we're feeling the pinch," he said. "I hear people talk. I hear complaints. Then I go to the bank, and I do the same thing."
It is difficult to hear anything over the surge of hair dryers at the tiny Low-Price Unisex Salon on 55th Street, especially on a Friday afternoon. Haircuts are $10 there, and recently, nine women with wet heads and flushed cheeks were wedged inside the narrow pink shop. Paubla Liriano, the Puerto Rican owner, carried the scissors, and, usually, the conversation.
"Years ago, there was a lot of welfare, but now we all want to work," Ms. Liriano said. 
A 49-year-old Dominican native named Carmen spoke up. "We also want credit but it's hard to get credit in these Fifth Avenue stores now," she said. "They tell us to make more money, to make more than $40,000."
The price of milk and cheese has gone up, Juana Gomez said from beneath her bubble dryer. Rents have too, Ms. Liriano added. Five years ago, her basement apartment rented for $600 a month. Today, it is $900.
Setting down her scissors and grabbing a hand-held dryer, Ms. Liriano said, "You know, most people here send money back home, but many are sending back less because we have less." 
Last year Carmen sent $400 a month to her family in the Dominican Republic. In January, she sent $100. The lasting impact on her family is still murky; for now, her family is buying fewer staples like cereal, juice and milk, which are expensive on the island. If the recession lasts much longer, she and other women might have to send even less. 
Ms. Liriano turned off her blow dryer. The tiny room fell into a rare quiet.
"The neighborhood is good, I think," she said firmly. "We don't have as many gangs or drugs. But we are paying for that. It's expensive to be here."
All nine customers nodded.
The tension in this patch of Sunset Park extends even to the basketball courts at Sixth Avenue and 54th Street, although the teenage regulars rarely speak of it. On a recent Saturday, Spanish was shouted on two courts, Mandarin on a third and nothing on a fourth. The players on the fourth court were four black and Latino youngsters and Shuang Jian Zhu, 15. Jian Zhu has kind eyes and the fuzzy beginnings of a first mustache. He shot well, and his friend, Ying Wu, 14, grinned from the sidelines.
Suddenly, Jian Zhu stopped and watched as a lanky mix of high schoolers sauntered onto his court. Seconds later, he picked up his ball and walked away. Ying Wu followed in silence.
"It's not always nice here," Jian Zhu said as he sat on a nearby bench, tightening his shoelaces. "People curse at me and ask for my ball. Two months ago, they scared me so I said I would call the police. It worked. I kept my ball."
Jian Zhu took the ball in his hands. It was a Spalding stamped with black Chinese characters. His mother had paid $30 for it in China, where she still lived with Jian Zhu's sister. For the past two years, Jian Zhu has lived in Sunset Park, near Eighth Avenue, with his 70-year-old grandparents. Money has become tighter since his arrival, he said, and his grandparents are unemployed. 
What that means to Jian Zhu, though he never said as much to the court bullies, was this: if he lost his ball, he was not likely to get another. So he is careful. His family cannot afford extras this year.

HEADLINE: Notes from Salt Lake City; 
Tiptoeing Out to Meet the World

BYLINE:  By Katharine Biele; Katharine Biele writes frequently about Utah politics.

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY 

 BODY:
As Salt Lake City whips its citizenry into a fraternal frenzy for the 2002 Winter Olympics, there is no loss of irony in the rallying cry, "This is the Place." But the place for what?
 Some 150 years ago, Brigham Young led a small group of Latter-day Saints -- the Mormons -- from persecution in Illinois to a barren lake bottom in Utah. "This is the place," he intoned as they entered a valley that would give them peace and freedom from everyone else. This week, Young's descendants will welcome a world the church's founders once feared, eager to take Utah into the mainstream and onto the world stage. The problem is that Utahans can't seem to agree on what mainstream means and are worried that they will end up mostly mortified and exhausted from two weeks of cultural probing by the world's media machines. 
 In this Mormon-dominated state, known for its healthy lifestyle and its moral proscriptions, the Olympics is all about a big gamble. Salt Lake City is not like Los Angeles or Atlanta, big cities where the Olympics became part of a multifaceted urban experience. Salt Lake is the mildly diverse capital of a monolithic and largely rural conservative state. The last few years have brought outdoor malls and French cuisine, but also the purchase of a downtown square by the Mormon Church, which declared it off limits to loiterers, smokers and sin in general.
People here are used to defending a squeaky-clean, if peculiar, image, but our city's leaders hope to go one better. Both the governor and Salt Lake City's mayor insist that this will not be the Mormon Olympics. This is about Utah and business and sports, they say. Even the church itself has politely told its members to back off from their missionary zeal. Still, there's plenty of reason for stage fright. The Olympic bribery scandal pretty much showed the Salt Lake organizers as hypocritical bumpkins who managed to spend a lot of money giving some influential people a good time. And, of course, this is a city where polygamy has become the name of a beer.
Even the Salt Lake Organizing Committee has been poking fun at our cultural quirks. One pin being sold by Olympic-gewgaw marketeers depicts green Jell-O as the state's favorite food. There are pins showing Mormon missionaries on bicycles, a pin of the "Mormon people mover" (a minivan, a reference to the abundance of children here) and a "super seagull" pin recalling the miracle in which gulls saved the pioneers' first crops by feasting on crickets.
While we Utahans have our inside jokes, it's another thing to see our idiosyncrasies sent up by satellite hookup to every continent. Polygamy is a case in point.
Not too long ago our governor, Mike Leavitt, spoke nostalgically of his polygamist ancestors. That was before the polygamy discussion went uncomfortably global when Governor Leavitt's brother began prosecuting Tom Green, a high-profile and media-savvy fundamentalist with five wives.
Although polygamy is no longer allowed within the Mormon Church and the relatively few polygamists who live here have splintered off on their own, that hasn't stopped the wisecracks or the beer sales. A local ski resort did a couple of polygamy spoofs on billboards. And a local brewery -- not the official Olympic beer maker -- markets Polygamy Porter with the slogan "Why Have Just One?" The stunt has boosted sales and invited censure since the Mormon Church does not condone the use of alcoholic beverages.
So it actually showed a great deal of political brass when Salt Lake's mayor, Rocky Anderson, sought to soften the drinking laws. There have been some concessions, but Salt Lake won't be the kind of party town the mayor had hoped our visitors would find.
As the opening ceremonies approach -- after years of venue construction and road improvements -- it's too late to be anxious about our image. Some already prophesy the hideous aftermath of this giant party: dirt, debts and recession. The excitement here is palpable, though.
Utah will alight on the world stage like a slightly awkward debutante at her first dance. Or it will hit the top of the embarrassment meter and go back to being a wallflower at the party. The challenge now is to silence the wayward polygamists, keep transit running, feed the masses and proselytize only when spoken to.

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTIC; 
Have Pen, Will Grovel

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
LAST June, Brett Forrest, a 28-year-old freelance writer, walked into the West 15th Street offices of Gear magazine and pitched a tent along with large signs reading, "You owe me $3,865." He had written two articles for the magazine for which he had never been paid. It worked: after eating peanuts inside the tent for an hour, Mr. Forrest received his check.
 That strategy might not work for everyone. But it underlines a truism among freelancers these days: as print and online magazines look less like solid institutions and more like falling dominoes, those who rely on them for their livelihood are left scrambling. 
 Perhaps nowhere is this scramble more obvious than in New York, the nation's media capital, where freelancing for magazines and newspapers is as common as screenwriting is in Los Angeles. The city's prominence in the industry only grew in the 90's, with the explosion of content-producing Web sites, many centered in Silicon Alley. 
But then the Internet frenzy slowed and the economy faltered. Moreover, in the past year alone, several major magazines based in New York City have folded, some of them relatively new and some in business for more than a generation: George, Mademoiselle, Working Woman, Lingua Franca, Brill's Content, The Industry Standard and, most recently and most notably, Talk magazine.
Supporting yourself as a freelance writer has never been easy, but with these successive blows, the lot of New York freelancers has substantially worsened.
Even at surviving magazines, freelancers say, editors are taking longer to get back to them and are relying on staff writers for work they once farmed out. Articles that are assigned out tend to be shorter and less lucrative.
Last summer, Ellen Ullman was the technology editor for Working Woman, which had just celebrated its 25th anniversary. Then, in August, it ceased publication. Ms. Ullman had freelanced in the past, but when she returned to it, the market had changed.
"Two years ago, I was turning down work," she said. Now, "I'm eating ramen noodles. I'm 35 years old, and it's like I'm back in college." These days, she said, even getting an assignment is no guarantee: she handed in one article on a Monday and the magazine, a Time Warner publication, folded on Thursday. She did receive a kill fee, a payment that is guaranteed even if an article does not run. But, she said, "It's hard when you're counting on a thousand bucks and you get $250."
Although there are no hard statistics on how many freelance writers live in New York, Mediabistro.com, an organization that arranges parties, panels and training for media professionals, has an invitation list of 70,000 people, and counts 350,000 visits to its Web site a month. Most of its subscribers live in New York, and many were swept up in the Internet frenzy.
"It looked like it was never going to end," said Laurel Touby, the site's founder. "The Internet made media people more valuable than they had ever been. It created the equivalent of a million daily newspapers."
Those newspapers required editors, writers and copy editors, many of whom lost their jobs as online sites foundered.
"I am getting besieged by e-mails and phone calls as never before," Ms. Touby said. "Senior, senior people; deputy managing editors who lost their jobs and went freelance. They can't make a living, they're distraught, they have families to feed. This is their livelihood. It's frightening." At a recent party, one woman approached her in tears. "She sounded suicidal," said Ms. Touby. "She was over 35, saying, 'What do I do? Where do I go?' "
Amid gallows humor about waiting tables or going into public relations, freelancers care coming up with coping strategies.
"We're going to have to stop relying on the magazines we're used to; we now have to go back to trying new ones," said Alix Strauss, who has freelanced in New York for five years. "There's a million new magazines -- a magazine for eating sushi off naked people, a magazine for Christian cats and the people who own them. You just have to decide whether you want to write for them. And of course they're not going to give you the $2 a word" many established writers are used to.
As freelancers are forced to reassess their standards, magazines are able to raise theirs. Mark Cohen, a deputy editor for Men's Journal, says he now has the luxury to be choosy. Last year, he said: "There were people I would encourage to send ideas, people whose copy needed a lot of work. I frankly don't have to do that anymore. People I couldn't get to do assignments before are now doing them for less money than I paid a year ago."
Malcolm Venable, a freelancer who graduated from Columbia University's journalism school last May, said he had not gotten to the point where he would take less money for an assignment. But he is worried.
"I just started out, and I was doing O.K. for a minute," he said. Now, "a lot of people that I made contact with just aren't there." He may temp or tend bar while he waits out the slump.
It is a slump that some in the industry see as a kind of media-Darwinism, a deep freeze that will kill off some freelancers but leave others with more room to thrive.
"It's going to be the hardcore ones who are ready to starve in order to do this work," Ms. Touby said. "It's putting all the pretenders out of it. All the people who thought it was a glamorous, sexy industry are going to be shaken out."
DAVID WALLIS, chief executive of featurewell.com, an online marketplace for new and previously published articles, agreed. "One of the unintended benefits of tough times is we're going to see more of a meritocracy," he said. "The better writers will succeed at the expense of the lesser ones."
In the meantime, he said, writers should reconsider their attitudes about their work. "It's been seen as almost sullying the profession to talk business, to see words as products and editors as clients," he said. "They need to market themselves more aggressively and not be afraid to talk money." 
At the same time, he said, as individual magazines seem more vulnerable, writers should "maybe think twice about taking that 5,000-word assignment right now and putting all their eggs in one basket."
Freelancers say they are confident the industry will bounce back, and that even online journalism remains a viable option.
"The dust hasn't settled," said Lynn Harris, who has freelanced for 12 years. "There was a heady magazine gold rush. With the closing of Talk, there's a fear now that they're going away." But she sees a distinction between the industry's "old war horses" and its "little fancy ponies."
"If we just wait it out and write ad copy at night, it's going to be fine," Ms. Harris predicted.
One freelancer, Mark Boal, said the current climate was actually good for his business. Mr. Boal, who was once on staff at Brill's Content and who has freelanced on and off for six years, said that recently he had found it easier to sell hard-hitting articles. "As the Dow seems to be going down," he said, "the demand for serious investigative work is going up. I imagine that hardship somehow clarifies priorities."
Besides, Mr. Boal added, referring to a recent New Yorker business column, "All the great magazines started in recessions."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Elizabeth R. Bramwell; 
Bramwell Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY was the holy grail for growth investors several years ago. Elizabeth R. Bramwell, who runs the $200 million Bramwell Growth fund, does not ignore the high-tech world, but she now emphasizes growth in homelier areas, like retailing.
 "Christmas sales were better than anticipated, and historically the first quarter is good for retailing," Ms. Bramwell said from her office in Midtown Manhattan, "especially as we come off two years of unusual economic conditions." 
 Bramwell, a large growth fund, lost .6 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with a 5.8 percent loss for its sector and a 3 percent drop in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. It lost 17.5 percent in the 12 months through Thursday, compared with losses of 27 percent for its group and 16.2 percent in the S. & P. 500.
Ms. Bramwell, 61, is chief executive of Bramwell Capital Management, which runs more than $600 million for institutions and in the Bramwell Focus and Growth funds. She started the Gabelli Growth fund in 1987 and managed it until early 1994, when she left the Gabelli Group.
Ms. Bramwell selects the fund's 60 to 70 stocks primarily from among American companies, relying on research by Wall Street and her own firm and industry conferences, followed by talks with company management.
"We look for top-line revenue and sales growth and, ideally, expanding profit margins through operating leverage," she said.
Ms. Bramwell keeps an eye on the economy, she says, because price-to-earnings multiples are inversely related to inflation and interest rates. Both of the latter should stay quite low, she said, adding, "The first half of this year should be tough, but things should start improving in the second half and then look pretty good in 2003."
She generally prefers to look at per-share earnings growth over Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which is favored by many money managers as a measure of corporate performance. 
"Ebitda misses a company's opportunity for expanded earnings growth from falling interest expense or decreasing tax rates," she said.
Over all, the portfolio's companies have an estimated capitalization-weighted per-share earnings growth rate of 17 percent over the next two years, versus 8 percent for the S. & P. 500 companies, she says.
Currently, she sees opportunity among companies with market capitalizations from $10 billion to $20 billion, the lower end of the large-cap range. "They have more liquidity than small-cap and midcap companies," she said, "but they're not so big that their growth rate is compromised by their size." The weighted median market cap of the fund's companies is $32 billion, compared with $61 billion for the S. & P. 500.
Ms. Bramwell prefers companies where the price-earnings ratio equals the estimated 2003 growth rate, but she's willing to pay up to 50 percent more. When she expects consistent earnings growth, she will continue to hold shares even as the multiple approaches two. She reviews shares for sale as valuation increases, or a company loses market share or its finances deteriorate.
The fund has annual expenses of 1.53 percent, compared with 1.46 percent for its group, Morningstar said.
In the retail sector, Ms. Bramwell has been buying shares of the Walgreen Company, the discount drugstore chain in Deerfield, Ill. She first bought shares in August 1994 at $4.77, adjusted for stock splits; the stock closed Friday at $35.54. "Management is continuing to expand, replace old stores and plow back retained earnings into improving operations," she said. "And with the demise of Kmart, and problems with others in the industry, Walgreen is likely to benefit from redirected consumer traffic." She expects earnings growth of 17 percent a year, on average, for the next three to five years.
In October, she began buying shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, in Santa Barbara, Calif., which manages acute care hospitals. She paid $58 a share; on Friday, they closed at $63.31. Tenet, which has a market capitalization of $21 billion, should benefit from higher hospitalization rates as the population ages, Ms. Bramwell said. Management has been reducing and refinancing debt, decreasing interest expense and bolstering earnings. She expects long-term average annual earnings growth of 20 percent.
She also favors Affiliated Computer Services, in Dallas, with a market cap of $6.2 billion, which provides corporations with technological resources. 
"After Sept. 11, everyone has put more emphasis on storage and security," which are among the company's specialties, Ms. Bramwell said. "Affiliated has a very strong pipeline of new contracts." 
Affiliated management is particularly effective at cost control, she said. She expects earnings growth of 20 percent a year in the next three to five years. She first bought shares in November for $93 each; on Friday they closed at $94.20.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Reassessing a Tactic When Its Momentum Begins to Slow

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
EARNINGS momentum strategies have been losing steam, though it is too early to count them out.
 The strategies favor the stocks of companies whose earnings are growing most rapidly, while shunning or even selling short those whose earnings are contracting the fastest. All exploit the tendency of investors to respond slowly to new information. 
 Rather than reacting immediately to a strong earnings report, for example, investors often bid up a stock gradually. Those who use earnings momentum strategies can make a profit by reacting more quickly. The profits have been large enough and enduring enough to impress skeptical academics. 
Recently, however, the strategies have struggled. According to research by Ford Investors Services in San Diego, stocks with the highest earnings momentum had one of their worst years in 2001, not only relative to the market but also relative to strategies based on other popular stock selection tools, like the price-to-earnings ratio, dividend yield or relative strength. In the last three years, stocks with the highest earnings momentum lagged the market by more than they have over any other three-year period since 1974.
The editors of the investment newsletters that I monitor differ over what accounts for the recent struggles of these strategies.
One hypothesis focuses on the Securities and Exchange Commission's Regulation FD, which took effect in 2000. Regulation FD requires companies to release material information publicly, rather than privately to Wall Street analysts. Some newsletter editors think that Regulation FD reduces the market's reaction time to earnings information and therefore the profitability of earnings momentum strategies.
Many finance professors are skeptical about this hypothesis. Academic research suggests that deep-rooted psychological factors cause investors to react slowly to new earnings information. These factors have nothing to do with how companies communicate. For example, investors develop attachments to stocks they love and revulsion to those that have lost them money. They assimilate contrary information slowly, whether that information comes from an analyst or directly from the company.
In another hypothesis, earnings momentum strategies simply do not work in economic downturns. The rationale is that in boom periods, positive earnings momentum genuinely signals growth prospects. In downturns, companies that buck the trend tend to be the best defensive players, a trait that is admirable in a recession but that may have nothing to do with how well a company performs over the long term.
I am also skeptical of this hypothesis because there is no evidence suggesting that investors' reaction time becomes speedier in a downturn. In fact, the data suggest otherwise. Over the last 27 years, according to Ford Investor Services, there were four other years besides 2001 in which earnings momentum strategies lagged the average stock -- 1984, 1995, 1997 and 1999. The economy grew in all four of those years.
There is another explanation why earnings momentum strategies have languished: It may be that so many advisers and investors have started to use earnings momentum strategies that they have begun to kill the goose that lays the golden egg. This is the likely fate of any strategy that becomes too popular, and it is consistent with data showing that these strategies have found it tougher in recent years.
But it is premature to conclude that this is the case for earnings momentum. Given the strategies' stellar long-term record, it will take many more years of mediocre performance to persuade statisticians that this recent experience is not an exception. Since the alternative is giving the boot to every strategy as soon as it stops working, an approach that we know does not work over time, the intelligent bet in the meantime for followers of earnings momentum strategies should be to stick to their guns.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Erratic Lately"Betting on earnings momentum has paid off over the last few decades, but the strategy has stumbled in recent years. Graph shows the difference in performance between the 1,000 largest stocks and 200 of them with the greatest earnings momentum from 1975-2000. (Source: Ford Investor Services)

HEADLINE: After Sept. 11: Getting the Jobless Back to Work 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As "Help for Those in a Wave of Joblessness" (Home Front column, Jan. 27) noted, an estimated 100,000 jobs have been lost since the World Trade Center attack. What most people do not know is that much of the money for job-training programs like the one run by the Consortium for Worker Education comes from the American public. 
 In addition to cash payments to victims and their families and grants for other services like mental health counseling, the September 11th Fund gave a $430,000 grant to the consortium to assist those who lost their jobs as a result of the attack. 
 It's an invaluable service that has helped thousands of New Yorkers get back on their feet.

JEANINE MOSS
Communications Director
September 11th Fund
New York, Jan. 29, 2002

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
From Anxiety toHints of Confidence

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Fears that murky accounting practices could lead more companies down the road to bankruptcy threatened to outweigh a series of better-than-expected economic reports last week.
 After Global Crossing filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday, concern heightened about accounting practices at the PNC Financial Services Group, Tyco International, Cendant and the Williams Companies. 
Worried that accounting problems could portend more Enron-like collapses, investors sent the broad indexes to their lowest levels since November. 
 The market rebounded on the announcement of a rise in gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and on the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates. The central bank said the economy had begun to show modest signs of recovery. Consumer confidence and orders for durable goods also rose. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.18 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,907.26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 11.08 points, or 1 percent, to 1,122.20. The Nasdaq composite index fell 26.46 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,911.24. The yield of the benchmark 10-year Treasury bond fell from 5.07 to 4.98 percent. SHERRI DAY

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Hear the One About . . .?

BYLINE:  By Paul Zielbauer 

 BODY:
ENRON has spawned a new lexicon. Gov. James E. McGreevey, criticizing New Jersey Republicans' handling of budget numbers, used a new term: "Enronize," meaning "to hide fiscal shortcomings through slick financial legerdemain and bald-faced lies." 
Here are more. 
 * Enronic: when a high-flying, seemingly invincible person or entity goes down in flames (figuratively speaking). 
 * N. Ron Hubbard: L. Ron's secret twin brother, founder of the Church of Bankruptology.
* Enronica: cheap souvenirs, like Enron stock certificates. 
* Enrontia: the burning desire to shred things.
* Enronymous Bosch: the company's landscape architect.
* Enronomania: the political and economic fallout of the company going bust, particularly thick in Washington (where Bush is headquartered), Houston (where Enron is headquartered) and Chicago (where Arthur Andersen is headquartered). 
* Enrontropy: the principle that a corporation's greed is directly proportional to how many lives its failure would ruin. Paul Zielbauer

HEADLINE: Correspondence/Touring Somalia; 
When All Else Fails (Like the State), Take the Drug Flight Into Town

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya 

 BODY:
ONE clear sign that a state has failed is that no one asks for your passport when you fly in. There will, though, be someone demanding a $25 or $50 "customs fee" -- the representative of whatever warlord controls the dirt landing strip.
 There are five such "airports" serving Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, not counting the real one, which has been closed for years. The easiest way in is on a drug flight. 
 There are regular flights in from Nairobi for United Nations aid workers, but they're expensive and require United Nations permission and 72 hours notice. There are flights for European Union aid workers; they are free, but journalists get bumped first. 
Then there are khat flights. On a Saturday afternoon last month, I called Bluebird Aviation, a charter agency. They gave me the cellphone number of Abdulkadir M. Sofie, a khat exporter -- in the United States, one might say smuggler or drug lord, but khat is legal in both Kenya and Somalia.
Khat (pronounced somewhere between "cat" and "chat" and short for catha edulis) is chewed while green for a coca-leaf sort of high that speeds up your heart, clears your sinuses and makes you jumpy and a little euphoric -- but still able to drive or shoot as straight as is normally required in Somalia.
Like coffee, it grows in Kenya's Meru mountains, but is picked at night and rushed to Nairobi to fly at dawn, before the leaves dry out.
Mr. Sofie asked if I was a "gentleman" -- meaning that, if he agreed to forgo hauling three bales weighing about what my luggage and I did, would I be at Nairobi's Wilson Airport with $300 at 6 a.m.?
I said I was. To make sure, he picked me up himself at my hotel at 5:30.
I have never seen an airport in Africa service an airline so efficiently. Men in ties swarmed around six newish-looking Czech 25-passenger planes, climbing on the wings to pump in gas, overseeing the loading of khat and Somalis. A Red Cross plane, virtually ignored, slunk off down the runway.
My photographer and I were the only ones the Kenyan authorities put through emigration formalities. A television producer later suggested that I had been racially profiled. After all, she asked, who's the most likely threat: the Somali toting home a 100-pound bag of Kenyan rice, or the white American with the satellite phone who might call in an airstrike from the offshore fleet trying to make sure that Osama bin Laden doesn't slip into Somalia?
We got the only row of seats on the plane, braced by 70 khat bales giving off eau de yard waste. "Perfume," enthused Mr. Sofie. In lieu of an in-flight snack, I nibbled some, expecting a bit of a buzz. But there was nothing. (I was later set straight by Mohammed Abdi Nouh, 46, a roadside khat-seller. To get high, I would have to chomp up two fistfuls, at least $4 worth -- which gives some idea of what a drain khat is on an economy where most people live on less than $1 a day. His clients were doctors and teachers, he boasted. He was a goldsmith and ashamed of selling khat to live, but Somalia is now too dangerous for women to wear gold jewelry in public.)
A T the dirt landing strip, we were met by Faisal Ahmed Abdulle, 32, a translator from the Shamo Hotel. He was, like many Somalis on the streets, missing half an arm. He lost it, he said, to an American bomb on Oct. 3, 1993, in the Black Hawk Down battle, which killed 18 Americans and about 1,000 Somalis in downtown Mogadishu. He said he was just in the neighborhood, but a Somali journalist said Mr. Abdulle had been a bodyguard for the warlord Osman Ali Atto back then, and might have been working that day.
Behind us, a pickup with 12 young men with AK-47's fell in for the drive to the hotel.
"They are good boys, all good boys," Mr. Abdulle reassured us. One, named Galil, later told me he was a freelance journalist, but being a gunman paid better, at $4 a day. Far from being a conventional thug, he had a sweet smile, sometimes helped translate and on a hot day offered to treat me to a watermelon slice from a street vendor.
"You personally mean nothing," Matt Bryden, Somalia coordinator for the War-Torn Societies Project research institute in Nairobi, had explained as he warned me to expect my hotel's airport shuttle to come with a fire team. "If you're staying at the Shamo, your gunmen are from Mr. Shamo's clan, or allies. The other militias in Mogadishu know that if Mr. Shamo loses a guest, his hotel suffers, so his gunmen will come after them."
That almost happened three days later, when we were nearly cut off by a pickup equipped with an anti-aircraft gun and carrying a gang rumored to have recently killed a money-changer with $30,000 in his safe. Presumably, the gang was trying to kidnap us for ransom. Mr. Abdulle swung into a camp of the provisional government's fledgling army, talked 10 overexcited soldiers out of shooting us for racing past their checkpoint, and slipped us out a rear entrance near our hotel. No soldier or policeman would chase the gang, another translator told me, but the money-changer's relatives might.
We left soon after on another khat flight.
S OMALIA wasn't always like this, explained Yusuf Hassan Isaq, a reporter for the BBC Somali Service. A return to Islam, so feared by the West, is how decent people have protected themselves in the Mad Max world of warlord battles and extortion that has prevailed since 1990. Attendance at mosques is way up. The hawala banks hire people with conservative religious beliefs in the hope that they will be more honest. Businessmen have asked clerics to form sharia courts and have hired gunmen to protect them, since there are no judges or police.
In the time of Mohammed Siad Barre, who flipflopped from being a pro-Soviet dictator to being a pro-American dictator during the years from 1969 to 1991, women served in the army and wore pants and short skirts. Now, they are not allowed to work at hawalas except as cleaners, and virtually all are veiled from brow to ankle, as much to lower the risk of rape by displaying modesty, as to display piety. However, the veils are stunning and their faces can be seen.
The self-imposed neoconservative Islam of terrified Somalia is still not as brutal as the Taliban's or as Iran's was under Ayatollah Khomeini in the 1980's. Sharia courts here do not lop limbs; there are no religious police beating women in the streets. When a Somali grabs another's beard, it is a customary way to get attention during conversation.
However, the newly armed society and the newly Islamic society do have one unhappy nexus in the lawless state, Mr. Isaq said: hand grenades.
"Some women, to be safe, carry them under those veils," Mr. Isaq said. "And some men carry them in their pockets. When they pray in the mosque, they sometimes fall out and go off -- boom!"

HEADLINE: A Call to Help Workers Save 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Pension Bubble Loses Some Air" (Economic View, Jan. 20) in which Daniel Altman discusses whether legislation intended to protect 401(k) accounts from corporate failure could reduce people's incentive to save. 
 Workers, the companies they work for and the country would be hurt if the proposals, in particular efforts to limit company stock to 10 percent of a 401(k) plan, kept people from saving. Tougher restrictions could dissuade companies from offering any type of match to retirement plans of employees. Not only do the stock matches encourage saving, but they promote loyalty, or at least create an awareness of company finances.

PHIL SCHMIDT
West Hartford, Conn., Jan. 22

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TERROR CELL; 
English Town Whispers Of a Taliban Connection

BYLINE:  By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: TIPTON, England, Jan. 29 

 BODY:
This has always seemed to be a harmonious town. Not exactly a model of racial integration -- the whites and the Asian people keep themselves to themselves, as the English expression goes -- but a place where everyone gets along, more or less.
 Beneath the facade of tolerant multiculturalism, though, more complicated forces are at work in Tipton, which is near Birmingham in the West Midlands. Teenagers speak of fights between whites and Asians at the local high school. In town elections in May 2000, the neo-fascist, anti-immigrant British National Party drew 24 percent of the vote, one of its best showings in England. 
 While white anger was becoming more focused, a small group of young men, second-generation Pakistanis, were gradually turning away from the West. Meeting in a makeshift mosque at the end of a nondescript street, they reportedly became increasingly devout and radicalized. They took to wearing traditional dress, chastised their families for becoming overly assimilated and made bold pronouncements about going off to fight for Islam. 
At least three of them seem to have done just that. In a development that has sent waves of anger and confusion through Tipton, an economically depressed and generally sleepy spot, two friends -- Shafiq Rasul, 24, and Asif Iqbal, 20 -- were identified last weekend as being among the suspected pro-Taliban fighters held by the United States at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. 
A third, Ruhal Ahmed, 20, is being held in Kandahar, Afghanistan, where he has been undergoing questioning by British and American forces. Meanwhile, Munir Ali, also part of the circle of friends, is believed to have crossed into Afghanistan but has not yet surfaced.
In Tipton, the authorities are still investigating what outside forces were brought to bear on the suspects, and whether they were part of a broader pattern of recruitment among Asians in and around Birmingham. 
Meanwhile, some residents speak of a small radical Muslim sect to which the young men were said to belong, saying that it preached violence against non-Muslims. Whites who live down the road from the mosque talk in whispers about a dozen more Tipton residents rumored to have gone off to fight for the Taliban.
But Tipton is no Bradford, local officials say, a reference to one of the cities where Asian youths clashed violently with the police last summer. It has never been known as a breeding ground for extremism.
"Tipton is a multicultural, multifaith community," said Ian Binnie, the head teacher at Alexandra High School and Sixth Form Center, which Mr. Iqbal, Mr. Rasul and Mr. Ahmed all attended. 
"Relations among the different groups are harmonious," Mr. Binnie said. "This is a tribute to the tolerance of the people of Tipton." 
Still, it is not the easiest place to live. Tipton is part of the borough of Sandwell, a cluster of six towns in the center of the Black Country, which takes its name from the black smoke that used to spew from its factories. Now, the factories are closed and the jobs that were a way of life for the first generation of immigrants from the Asian subcontinent are gone. In Sandwell, unemployment stands at about 19 percent, and many families live on less than $150 a week.
Figures from the 1991 census show that 9 percent or so of the population of 38,000 people is white and that the nonwhites tend to come from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. They also tend to live in a low-income housing project on the seedier side of Alexandra Park. The Pakistani residents, in particular, retain close ties with their families back home, and arranged marriages are common.
It is here that the three suspects lived with their families, went to school together and played together on a local soccer team. It is here, neighbors say, that their discontent began to take root and find a focus in Islamic radicalism.
"He was fascinated by Arab suicide bombers," a friend of Mr. Iqbal told the newspaper The Sun. "He talked about how brave they were and said he thought he had the guts to be one."
According to the friend, Mr. Iqbal hated living in Tipton and told him, "I want to be somebody, and not die a nobody in a dump like this."
Mr. Binnie at the high school said Mr. Rasul and Mr. Iqbal had been "involved in occasional scrapes, but nothing serious." But in 1999, Mr. Iqbal and the third detainee, Mr. Ahmed, were convicted of attacking a 16-year-old Asian youth with hammers and bottles as the youth stumbled into a fight between two Asian gangs. Fining them each about $700 and sentencing them to 150 hours of community service, the judge in the case called the assault "a thoroughly disgraceful incident."
But friends and relatives say they cannot reconcile the accusations with their perceptions of the three men. 
"As far as I'm concerned, these are three safe guys who I used to play football with," said Ala Udddin, president of Tipton United, the local soccer team. "I find it astonishing that they are under arrest, suspected of being terrorists."
The suspects' families say that the first time they heard anything about terrorist connections was when they heard the news from the British Foreign Office. 
"I just want my son to come home," Mr. Iqbal's mother, Imtiaz, said. "He is not a terrorist." 
Mr. Iqbal reportedly told his family that he was traveling to Pakistan to meet his father and prepare for an arranged marriage. 
Meanwhile, the family of Mr. Rasul also thought he was in Pakistan, studying software engineering.
Speaking to reporters at their house a few streets down from the mosque on Wellington Street, which Mr. Rasul was said to frequent, his three brothers described him as a quiet, peace-loving stockroom clerk in an electronics store who loved nightclubs and designer clothes and was thoroughly Westernized. 
An indifferent Muslim who flunked out of law school and had to be prodded into attending mosque, his brothers said, Mr. Rasul once had a white girlfriend named Shirley. He took a three-month leave from his job in mid-October, enrolling in the software course in Pakistan because it was cheaper than similar courses in Britain, his brothers said. 
The family's last contact with Mr. Rasul, they said, was when he sent an e-mail message to his oldest brother, Habib, on Oct. 25 to ask for advice on computer modules. Then there was nothing until last week, when they received a phone call from the Foreign Office informing them that Mr. Rasul was being held in Cuba. 
"At first I thought it was a prank call from one of my American colleagues," said Habib Rasul, who works as a computer specialist. "I just put the phone down and two minutes later my mobile phone rang, and it was my brother, saying Shafiq was in Cuba." 
Habib Rasul said the only explanation he could come up with was that his brother had gone to Afghanistan to help refugees and those left destitute because of the fighting.
"There are questions we still want an answer to," he said. "What the hell was he doing in Afghanistan? How the hell did he get there?"

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Undiminished, That Sporting Connection Lives On

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
The love of sports, as fan and participant, is a joyful thread woven through so many of the lives that ended Sept. 11. It is also a comforting thread: the rugby star on the plane that crashed in western Pennsylvania, the Yankee lover in Rescue 1, the soccer player in the Pentagon, the golfer at Cantor Fitzgerald were bound by more than an act of terrorism. It seems fitting to celebrate their sporting lives on this Super Bowl Sunday, the holiest day of the American sports calendar.
 The sports connection was particularly pronounced among the victims of this attack because they tended to be men on the sunny side of middle age, physical, competitive, used to the quick camaraderie of the team, be it a firefighting squad or a trading desk. 
 "When you hire people at these brokerage houses, you look favorably on athletes," said Carmine Calzonetti, who spent six years at Cantor Fitzgerald, the firm hardest hit by the attack. "They're used to hard work and they're disciplined. They're used to teamwork, playing under pressure and playing hurt. They'll come to work with a stomachache.
"But most important, they bounce back. They can handle defeat, move right on. Athletes are sure they're going to win the next game, make the next trade."
Calzonetti said he had made an easy transition from the win-lose world of sports to the win-lose world of stocks and bonds. A 1969 graduate of St. John's who later coached there and was an athletic administrator, he was recruited to Wall Street in the mid-1980's by a former basketball teammate. His twin girls had just been born, and with four children he needed to make more money.
He moved to Cantor in 1993 and stayed until the end of 1999. He left because of the hours; he didn't want to miss the twins' high school lacrosse careers. Calzonetti is now the commissioner of the New York Collegiate Athletic Conference, a league of a dozen Division II schools like Adelphi, Mercy and Bridgeport. His daughters, Claire and Julia, are playing lacrosse at Stanford.
More than 650 people from Cantor are among the 2,870 dead or missing at the World Trade Center. Some of the varsity athletes among them were Mike Pelletier and Rich Stewart, who played ice hockey at St. Lawrence; Lisa Egan, a basketball player, and Don Adams, a football player, at Fairleigh Dickinson's Madison campus; Ted Luckett, a soccer player at Ohio Wesleyan; Eamon McEneaney, who played lacrosse and football at Cornell; and Christian Maltby, a swimmer at Fordham.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association News memorialized some of its athletes in a special supplement last November. They included Tyler Ugolyn, who played basketball at Columbia and worked at Fred Alger Management on the 93rd floor of the north tower; Michael Weinberg, a city firefighter who played baseball at St. John's; and Mari-Rae Sopper, a former gymnast at Iowa State who had just been hired to coach the women's team at the University of California at Santa Barbara. She was on Flight 77, which crashed into the Pentagon.
Two athletes are thought to have been among the passengers who resisted the hijackers on United Flight 93. One was Todd Beamer, a varsity baseball player at Wheaton College in Illinois. The other was Mark Bingham, a member of the 1991 and 1993 national collegiate rugby championship teams at the University of California at Berkeley.
"It's not about how how good you were as an athlete, it's about how competitive," Calzonetti said. "Being good is sometimes about genes. Competition is in the spirit. The 6-foot intramural center could be more competitive than the 6-5 Division II center who could be more competitive than the 6-10 Division I center. It's about spirit."
However separated socially, economically and professionally, Gordy Aamoth, Antonio Alvarez and Calixto Anaya Jr. shared that sports spirit. Aamoth, 32, was an investment banker at Sandler O'Neill & Partners and a member of the Creek Club in Locust Valley, N.Y., where he played golf. In his hometown, Minneapolis, the Blake School is naming its new football field in his honor. He had been captain of the team.
Alvarez, a 23-year-old immigrant from Mexico, was a grill cook at Windows on the World. His pleasure was soccer and pickup basketball near his home in Jackson Heights, Queens.
Anaya was a 35-year-old firefighter and former Marine who had re-upped for the Persian Gulf war. Among his prized mementos was the hole he had punched in the basement ceiling of his Suffern, N.Y., home celebrating the Yankees' victory over the Mets in the 2000 World Series.
Reading the "Portraits of Grief" as they came out last year, I was struck by the frequency with which family and friends found sports as a way of describing, if not defining, the loved ones they had lost. Last week, rereading the vignettes, I was moved by the diversity of those whose lives were enhanced by the sporting spirit.
Here was Karen Martin, the head flight attendant on American Flight 11. She was 40. Friends remembered how she dipped lower than most water skiing, took steeper trails snow skiing, always hit off the men's golf tee.
Here was Cmdr. William Howard Donovan Jr., 37, considered "in the pipeline," a rising star. He had graduated from the Naval Academy and had flown in the gulf war. He was one of the jocks at the Pentagon, a stalwart of the lunchtime soccer league.
Here was Ira Zaslow, a 55-year-old financial analyst for Lehman Brothers who lived for the weekends and paddleball. His eldest son, Bryan, remembered he would get up at 6 a.m. on Saturdays and Sundays and go anywhere to play. He never minded replaying a disputed shot because it meant playing more.
Then there was Kenny Marino, 40, of Rescue 1, a Mets and Seattle Mariners fan whose favorite ballplayer was Ken Griffey Jr. Katrina Marino sent an e-mail message to the Cincinnati Reds with a request for Griffey to hit a homer for her husband, who would be "looking down with a big grin." Junior went long on Sept. 25, and said it was his most memorable homer. Marino's Rescue 1 teammates thought it fitting that they led the mourners out of his memorial service to the organist playing "Take Me Out to the Ball Game."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
Visitors Temper Revelry and Respect Security

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
They rolled onto Bourbon Street by the thousands Friday night with their numbered jerseys and football war paint, aware that they were expected to carouse, but lacking the slightest bit of tutoring in the act, hailing as they do from the sedate streets of Boston or St. Louis.
 They would hesitate as they beheld the spectacle before them, and their question was obvious: Do you mean that we're allowed to buy sweet hard liquor from this sidewalk bar, and walk with it in the middle of the street, and scream and sing and vomit, and encourage women to remove their clothes? All right, then. Where do we begin? 
 "I figured the city would be locked down," said Craig Brabham, a programmer from suburban Hazelwood, Mo., who had heard that the Super Bowl would be the most oppressively secure ever. "I mean, I always wanted to come to Bourbon Street, but I didn't even know whether it was going to be open tonight." 
Of course it was open, and beckoning, and eagerly accepting the game's auxiliary economic benefits in exchange for huge plastic cups of beer and Southern Comfort. The French Quarter, and most of downtown, was full of stretch limousines with out-of-town plates and tour buses disgorging wide-eyed men and women knitted together with Mardi Gras beads and an intense if disoriented desire to celebrate something. They hung off second-floor balconies, and line-danced, and bayed their city's primacy to the night sky and the ceaseless river.
But Brabham was at least correct in sensing that things would be different this year. Fulfilling orgiastic desires has always been the city's great industry, and it is no accident that it has been chosen by the National Football League to accommodate nine Super Bowls, the most of any city. Never before, however, has a sporting championship been declared a National Security Special Event, with widespread street closures and thousands of imported police officers under the supervision of the United States Secret Service.
Never before has the Mardi Gras season of parades and parties been temporarily halted in midstream, the result of the Super Bowl being postponed a week because of the Sept. 11 attacks. And not for decades have these annual celebrations been burdened by the guilt-inducing presence of an overseas war and a continuing threat of domestic terrorism. This year's revelry, then, has been notably more subdued than usual, less violent and uproarious, and distinguished by an unprecedented respect for authority, which has been out in unprecedented force.
"This is nothing," said one police sergeant standing on the corner of Bourbon and Conti Streets, who said he was technically not supposed to talk to reporters. "You tell people to move on, and they do it. They're not fighting. Even if they're drunk, it seems like they're trying to stay out of trouble this year."
Ernest Watson, known universally as Doc, has seen the crowds ebb and flow as the tenor saxophonist for the Olympia Brass Band, the oldest and most distinguished of the city's indigenous jazz ensembles. Generally, he said, he would much rather play to football crowds than Mardi Gras crowds, knowing that at least a few people will be sober enough to listen to the music. 
"I guess we'll have to get used to a different tone in the city, with all this security and all this worry," he said. "I've seen this kind of thing when we're on tour in Europe, and they still like good music and still have a good time. So I think New Orleans will come through this and it will stay true."
Each neighborhood of the city celebrated according to its means, which as always in New Orleans, tend toward the extremes. At the Hyatt Regency next to the Superdome, the N.F.L.'s headquarters hotel, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue held court as desperate fans searched the crowd for the faces of well-known players. 
Two miles to the east, in the impoverished Ninth Ward where no tourist or celebrity goes, residents prepared to cheer for their favorite son, Marshall Faulk, the Rams running back who grew up in the Desire Housing Project, one of the worst public housing complexes in America. The city has torn down most of the buildings, and what remains resembles a war zone: giant holes in the brick walls, shot-out windows, missing doors. But nearby residents say Faulk hasn't forgotten them.
"He donated the team uniforms over at Carver High, where he went to school," said Michael Moody, a mechanic who was planting campaign signs for today's mayoral primary. "He's helped out with the parks, and he even gave some Super Bowl tickets to some people I know over on Feliciana Street. So tomorrow everybody here is a Rams fan."
There were no limousines to be seen. But then a city bus rolled up Louisa Street and on its side was a big picture of Marshall Faulk. He was urging his native city to buckle up for safety.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: OUTLOOK; 
Foreign Executives Reject American Optimism Toward Economic Recovery

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Foreign economists and executives are much less optimistic than their American counterparts about what is ahead for the United States economy.
 That divide showed up starkly and repeatedly in wall-to-wall conversations at the World Economic Forum, whose cast of more than 2,000 prominent people has been meeting since Thursday behind layers of security at the Waldorf-Astoria. While the Americans focus on the economy's strengths, particularly the persistent consumer spending, the foreigners dwell on dwindling profits, mounting debt and the constant shrinking of corporate operations. 
 "What we have is an ordinary recession made worse by bursted bubbles, and the shakeout will last longer than the Americans seem to realize," said Kenneth H. Clarke, a Conservative member of Britain's Parliament and a former chancellor of the exchequer. 
The disagreement is more than academic. Not only the United States, but Europe, most of Asia and much of Latin America are caught in the first worldwide recession since the 1970's. In panel sessions and interviews, virtually everyone agreed that only the United States has the economic heft to lift the others out of recession. 
But economists, executives and government officials from abroad said Americans were unrealistically optimistic about how soon this would happen.
"It is not going to happen this year," said Klaus F. Zimmermann, president of the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin. "A lot was invested in high-tech equipment for the new economy and that has to be used up before investment picks up and the American economy with it."
A turnaround is not yet visible in economic data. Corporate spending on offices, factories and equipment continued to fall in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department reported last Wednesday. This cutback caused the recession and now the question is when growth will resume. While American forecasters optimistically spy the resumption of corporate spending, the companies themselves continue to shed workers and facilities, prodded to do so because they find themselves capable of producing more than they can sell.
Excess capacity played a role in the decision of Kmart, the nation's third-largest discount retailer, for example, to file for bankruptcy late last month, in preparation for dozens of store closings and thousands of layoffs. 
Still, the persistent optimism is understandable, several of the visiting foreigners suggested. "It is the collective aspiration of what Americans want to have happen, particularly after Sept. 11, and maybe it will somehow be self-fulfilling," said Baba N. Kalyani, chairman of Bharat Forge Limited, an Indian manufacturer of truck parts, whose sales are down, particularly its exports to the United States. "But I do not think the rebound will come very soon."
Stock prices worry Guillermo Ortiz, governor of Mexico's central bank. "American investors have been holding up stock prices in expectation of rising profits," Mr. Ortiz said. "Who knows if that will materialize. If it does not, you could have a pretty negative market reaction in midyear."
Europeans are particularly outspoken. "A lot of Europeans view American optimism as part of the character of the country and not necessarily reasoned analysis," said Peter D. Sutherland, the Irish chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a former top executive at BP, the British conglomerate. 
If anything, the optimism among American forecasters has intensified in recent weeks. In expectation of an imminent upturn, they have focused on a growing number of economic indicators that show an improvement from the previous month -- if not in business investment, then in consumer spending and housing.
The latest spur to optimism came on Friday when the Labor Department announced that employers had eliminated 89,000 jobs in January, down from 130,000 in December, and the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.6 percent from 5.8 percent -- mainly because thousands of unemployed dropped out of the labor force and were no longer counted.
No one at the World Economic Forum spoke more exuberantly about the American economy than Gail D. Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board, a New York research organization. "My role is to spread a little glee," she said at a packed session on the global economic outlook. "The recovery has already begun in the United States." 
Like other American forecasters, Ms. Fosler argues, in effect, that once all the data catch up with what is actually happening today, the upturn will turn out to have started about now, nearly a year after the recession began. Ms. Fosler appeared on the same panel with the more pessimistic Mr. Zimmermann of Berlin and also with Fan Gang, director of a Chinese economic research institute, who tactfully said nothing about the United States, but declared that China's now booming economy might be headed for contraction, joining the rest of the world.
He blamed the yen, in part. Its falling value hurts Chinese exports, by making them relatively more expensive than Japanese goods. The rising value of the dollar, against the yen and other currencies, should also make Americans uneasy, several foreign experts said.
For the moment, however, the strong dollar encourages foreigners to invest their savings in the United States, in effect lending to the ever more indebted Americans. But once the dollar begins to weaken a bit, many foreign experts argue, the economy will slow, because the lending flow will be cut back and the cost of borrowing in the United States will rise.
"We are more worried about this than you are," said Jacques Aigrain, chief executive of the Swiss Reinsurance Company, headquartered in Zurich. 
Only one American economist participating in the World Economic Forum -- Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley -- openly shared the pessimism of the non-Americans, and his pessimism stood out. Mr. Roach appeared on the panel with Ms. Fosler, and he aimed most of his comments at her optimism.
She put her faith in consumer spending, the still strong housing market and her expectation that rising profits would restart investment, particularly investment in high-tech electronics gear. 
Mr. Roach, in contrast, emphasized the downward pull of heavily indebted Americans and the frequent downsizing as companies closed factories and offices and laid off workers, to shed excess productive capacity. 
At least one foreigner offered Ms. Fosler some support. "Let's not underestimate all the stimulus that the Federal Reserve has provided with its rate cuts," said Rakan El-Hoshan, managing director of the Hoshan Company, which sells office equipment in Saudi Arabia. "If there is not a recovery in America soon with interest rates as low as they are, then there is something fundamentally wrong."
