HEADLINE: Downtown, It's Location, Location and Luck 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT and SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
It is the great question, still waiting to be answered:
 A hole is blown in the heart of downtown Manhattan. One hundred thousand workers and thousands of residents are abruptly displaced. Tourism founders, recession settles in. Which businesses survive? Which move away or close for good? And what takes root in their place? 
 Nearly five months after the attack on the World Trade Center, the thousands of businesses in Lower Manhattan are in countless disparate states of recovering, dying and being reborn -- some flourishing, some foundering, many struggling to maintain a foothold somewhere along the rocky slope in between. 
Their different fates can be traced to a complicated mix of factors, including the nature of each business and its customers and things like location, insurance coverage, access to emergency assistance, relationships with creditors and capacity for self-reinvention.
And blind luck.
Handbags are flying out of the Coach store at the South Street Seaport -- in part because the World Trade Center mall and its Coach store are gone. Another store, 14 Wall Street Jewelers, is doing fine -- especially now that all pedestrian traffic turning off Broadway is being funneled in front of its door.
At the Regent Wall Street hotel, where they were cooking with Bunsen burners immediately after Sept. 11, occupancy has been 10 to 15 percentage points higher than a year ago. But the president, Christopher Knable, claims little credit: until recently, every comparable downtown hotel was closed.
In the worst shape are some businesses nearest the trade center, conceived in some cases to serve a population of 50,000 that is no longer there. Trapped in the frozen zone around ground zero, they languish, their future uncertain, their customers scattered or dead.
Those in better health include companies with a customer base beyond Lower Manhattan; businesses that have benefited in unexpected (and sometimes discomfiting) ways, and enterprises that in at least a few cases have struck upon ingenious approaches to adapting to a post-9/11 world.
At AST Sound, a family-owned audio and video retailer in TriBeCa, sales plummeted in the weeks after the attack. Then a neighboring landlord offered the owner, Michael Kramer, three times his current space at two-thirds his current rent. So AST Sound is expanding; last week, it moved across the street.
Mr. Kramer has landed several emergency grants and loans. He was given new office furniture and free legal help negotiating his lease. He is expanding his corporate-contracting department to handle what he hopes will be increased demand for teleconferencing and videoconferencing, an alternative to business travel, when downtown Manhattan rebuilds.
But a dozen blocks south, Vivia Amalfitano has not been able to reopen the three restaurants that she co-owns. They have been mired in the frozen zone around the trade center site for 20 weeks. She says she has failed to qualify for much emergency help -- in one case, she said she was told, because she has not managed to reopen.

Loans Carry Risks
In desperation, she has begun looking for new space. She depends on the restaurants for income, as do her parents, uncle and brother, she said. She has not applied for a Small Business Administration loan because, she said, she cannot risk putting up her house as collateral without knowing the restaurants' fate.
Halfway between Ms. Amalfitano and Mr. Kramer, geographically and otherwise, sits Allison Luongo, the 26-year-old owner of Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory, a 14-month-old candy store on Chambers Street that she says lost as much as $20,000 in business in the three weeks it was closed after Sept. 11.
Business was so slow for months that Ms. Luongo remembers going next door to the barbershop and saying: "I'm not getting a haircut today. So, unless you want chocolate, we should all just pack up and go home for the day." (They did.) Business improved in December. But, she said, "we're still really on the brink."
The fate of businesses like Ms. Luongo's, Ms. Amalfitano's and Mr. Kramer's will determine the future of downtown, many think. They say that unless restaurants, retailers and service providers recover, the bigger companies, residents and tourists who fled on Sept. 11 will not return.
But there is a conundrum: unless the big firms, the residents and the tourists return, the small businesses and cultural institutions will have no customers and will fail.
"Think of a new-growth forest," said Jerrold Nadler, the congressman who represents Lower Manhattan. "A forest fire burns down a lot of old trees. As long as a sufficient base is left, new trees will grow. But if you don't have a critical mass, you will have a major disaster area for a long time.
"If too many of the small businesses are gone in April, say, then it's going to be a wasteland. Other businesses will move or fail. People won't want to move back. The biggest single factor in whether Lower Manhattan again becomes the financial engine for New York or not is whether a critical mass of our small businesses survive."
In many ways, the signs of neighborhood recovery are encouraging.
Consolidated Edison, which lost two substations in the attack, has installed 36 miles of temporary cable. Taxis are available again and most telephones work. The Statue of Liberty has reopened, only one subway station remains closed, and large firms are coming back. Delis are no longer dealing with matters like how to dispose of 400 pounds of rotting chicken.

Layoffs Take a Toll
On the other hand, there will be no PATH service to Lower Manhattan before late next year. Buses have been rerouted and much downtown traffic is jammed. Some sidewalks are a maze of barriers and barricades. Firms have returned, but they are laying people off, or like Goldman Sachs & Company, they are relocating whole departments outside the city. And the drop in international business travel has cut the flow of downtown's biggest-spending visitors.
Two malls that played a key role in the renaissance of downtown in the late 1990's, in the World Trade Center and the World Financial Center, are gone or closed. Century 21, the discount shopping mecca, is not scheduled to open until late this month. And, all in all, there are tens of thousands fewer people in Lower Manhattan every day than there were before Sept. 11.
"It's depressing to be down here," said Mary Pisarkiewicz, managing director of Pisarkiewicz Mazur & Company, a marketing communications firm. "It's sad, it's very sad. Yes, I think the area will definitely come back. But I think it's going to be a long time."
The current conditions of downtown businesses vary widely. On individual blocks, it is possible to find some storefronts shuttered, other businesses thriving, others newly reopened. But patterns are apparent. And though it is not necessarily insurmountable, the problem of proximity to ground zero is, for many businesses, the biggest hurdle.
Steamers Landing, a 12-year-old Battery Park City restaurant damaged in the attack, has yet to reopen. Its windows were broken, its exhaust system ruined, its furniture taken. Rotting food exploded in the refrigerator. Jan Fried, a co-owner, said the cleanup could not even begin until mid-November because the chaos outside made it impossible to get permission to park a trash container. 
Physical damage is only part of the problem. Sale & Pepe Fine Foods, a gourmet deli just south of the trade center that relied heavily on corporate catering, reopened in early October. But its lunch business was decimated by the departure of a half-dozen large firms that Peter Semetis, an owner and a partner, counted as clients, like American Express and Lehman Brothers.
While the N and R trains were not running, Mr. Semetis says, his breakfast trade suffered badly; there were no rush-hour crowds being disgorged from the subway station outside the store. And, he said, the express buses from Brooklyn and Staten Island that used to deposit people at a bus stop outside the deli were temporarily rerouted to Water Street.

Customers Are Ghosts
"For ground zero businesses, there's nobody to serve," said Duane Anzalone, a co-owner of St. Charlie's Restaurant and Bar, in the frozen zone, whose prospects are uncertain. Opened six months after the trade center opened, it was umbilically tied to the towers. "We're talking about probably 100 percent of our clientele gone," Mr. Anzalone said, "How do you recover from that?"
The picture is less bleak for businesses with clients elsewhere. Dr. Jeffrey R. Shapiro, a dentist with an office two blocks southeast of ground zero, says only half of his patients live or work downtown. Although he said his office suffered $150,000 in damage to computers, instruments and furnishings, he expects business to be back to normal within months.
There are also big differences in the ability of different businesses to tap the programs offering emergency grants and loans. While some owners said they had received little or nothing, Mr. Semetis said he had successfully landed a $6,500 grant, a $10,000 grant, a $39,000 grant, a $100,000 loan at 1 percent interest and a $200,000 Small Business Administration loan.
He was accepted into an assistance program that is covering half his payroll for 10 employees for 13 weeks. He has received free legal help to deal with his insurance company. Vendors have extended him credit and he is now in a Salvation Army program under which he and other downtown restaurants are paid to feed workers at ground zero.
Ms. Amalfitano, however, says she was told she was ineligible for one such program because her three restaurants had not yet reopened. Two of them are marooned on Trinity Place, where trucks line up to enter the trade center site. For another program, she was told she could apply for only one grant, not three.
Then there is insurance. Anthony Hidalgo, the chief operating officer of Intercom Online, a company that provides Internet access to small and medium-sized businesses, says the firm lost more than $1 million in revenue because of the attacks. But when he submitted a claim for about $775,000 to his insurance company, he says, he was offered $10,000.
Some businesses have found success through some measure of self-reinvention. Jim Simpson, the artistic director of a small theater company, the Flea, says he watched his theaters drop to 95 percent empty, from 95 percent full before Sept. 11. Searching for a response to the disaster, he opened "The Guys," a play about a fire captain who lost eight men in the attack and an editor who helps him write their eulogies. The shows have been selling out.

Success and Sadness
Other businesses have benefited in unintended, even disconcerting, ways. One restaurant that used to compete with Windows on the World has been busy since mid-October. "Is it true that we get a lot of business because they are not here?" said the owner, who spoke on the condition that he not be named. "Yes. Do I like to talk about it? No. It makes me sad. I wish they were still here."
In the grim early weeks after the attack, when Dr. Shapiro was dusting off dental records of dead patients for their families to take to the morgue, few people downtown did not consider, at least fleetingly, bailing out. But the expense of broken leases and unaffordable Midtown rents made the price of leaving prohibitive for many.
Lehman Brothers is among the firms that have left. It is moving 6,000 people who had been in the World Financial Center and nearby to a Midtown building it bought within weeks of the attack. The firm believed that it could not wait the year or more it could take to repair the damage to its main building downtown, according to Bill Ahearn, a senior vice president.
Others say leaving would be unseemly. They consider themselves pioneers with an emotional stake in a neighborhood they feel they once helped to build. Some admit to being torn, like the head of one organization who said the staff thinks that moving back to its offices overlooking ground zero is the right thing to do, but almost no one wants to do it.
Insisting that neither he nor his organization be identified, he said he worried about the emotional toll on employees who "saw and felt and heard things that nobody should ever have to see and feel and hear." He said he worried about the health effects of working near ground zero, and the possibility that a neighborhood that he always thought had "lousy restaurants" would only "get lousier."
In the meantime, people wait: for their loan applications to be approved, for grant money to come through, for more federal money to flow, for their insurance money to arrive, for the rebuilding to begin, for permission to reopen, for the future to feel more certain, for their customers to come back.
"If anybody asks me specifically what I need, I don't think they really want to hear the answer," Mr. Anzalone of St. Charlie's said the other day. "I need the 50,000 to 100,000 people that are gone from that area back. And I know that nobody can give me that."

HEADLINE: Hard-Pressed Parents Fall Behind on Tuition 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The glossy brochure was mailed late last year to the parents of students at 1,500 colleges and private schools.
 "Are you worried about having enough money to pay for tuition?" asked the brochure, which was from a company that helps those institutions manage their billing. It went on to assure parents, "We can help you now, even in today's uncertain economy." 
 In the weeks since the pamphlet went out, thousands of families from across the country have called the company, Academic Management Services, to arrange extensions on tuition bills or, in some cases, to secure low-interest loans. In December alone, the company says it received 17,000 more requests for assistance than it did in the same month a year ago, an increase of nearly 25 percent. 
The company's phone logs provide fresh evidence of the extent to which the recession is squeezing middle- and even upper-class families. After paying their tuition bills like clockwork, many are having difficulty keeping up with their payments, mindful that if they fall too far behind their children could eventually be expelled.
"People are saying that they're being laid off, their stocks are down or gone, and they're looking for ways to pay the bill," said Gina Mercer, 31, a telephone counselor at Academic Management Services, who has been working six days a week, sometimes 10 hours a day, to keep up with the demand. "They anticipated having a certain way to pay for college, and now that's all changed."
It's not just the antennas at A.M.S., based in Swansea, Mass., that are picking up such static. Analysts at Moody's, the bond rating agency, say that the number of parents across the country requesting at least a year's postponement in repaying federally financed tuition loans has doubled in the last 12 months. Financial aid officers at Rice University in Houston, who fielded calls in recent weeks from at least 10 parents who lost their jobs because of the shaky economy, say they are bracing for calls from current or former employees of Enron, among other companies, in early spring, when next year's college aid will be calculated.
Such projections, university officials said, are already being considered as the university begins assembling its budget for next year.
"We'll see a lot of middle- and upper-income folks facing unemployment for the first time in years," said Julia Benz, the director of student financial services at Rice, where half the students are Texas residents.
For many of the families calling the colleges or A.M.S., the need for such help would have been unthinkable as recently as six months ago. One of the calls that Ms. Mercer, the telephone counselor, fielded recently was from Anne Chelius and her husband, Garrett, a Long Island couple whose combined annual income of nearly $250,000 had enabled them to put their first four children through college without borrowing a dime. 
But in the days after Sept. 11, that income vanished, jeopardizing the $12,300 due on the tuition for their fifth and youngest child, Geremy, who is a junior at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. 
Late last fall, Mrs. Chelius had to close her business, which was in Lower Manhattan and supplied temporary employees to many companies in the World Trade Center. At the same time, her husband, a consultant for J. P. Morgan Chase, also in Lower Manhattan, lost his job when the project on which he had been working was moved to Tampa, Fla.
"We were almost at the end," Mrs. Chelius said of the more than 10 years in which at least one, and sometimes two, of her children has been in college. "I can see the finish line. Now I feel like I can't make it to the finish line."
On Ms. Mercer's recommendation, Mrs. Chelius, 57, and her husband, 60, borrowed $10,000 from A.M.S. through a federal program available only to parents of college students, at an interest rate of less than 7 percent. But that has still left the couple $2,300 short, and they are considering using credit cards to make up the difference.
While A.M.S. has logged nearly 1,000 calls from families directly or indirectly affected by the events of Sept. 11, the company has detected problems throughout the economy.
Another recent caller to the company's help line was Rick Rector, who lives and works in Maine, and who publishes two weekly trade newspapers that serve the technology industry. Mr. Rector's daughter Amanda is a sophomore at Wellesley College, and like the Chelius family, he had arranged with A.M.S. last summer to break his tuition fees into 12 monthly payments, which the company would then pass on to the college, for an annual fee of $55. 
But by late fall, advertising at Mr. Rector's publications had dropped so precipitously -- by 50 percent compared with a year earlier -- that he feared falling behind in his $2,000 monthly payments. So he, too, took out a $10,000 loan.
"It was prudent," said Mr. Rector, who lives in Camden, 90 miles north of Portland. "But it's never pleasant to have to borrow money."
Those parents who have gone directly to their colleges for help have not always fared as well.
Bernie Pekala, the director of student financial strategies at Boston College, said he had heard from several parents recently who said they were worried that they were about to lose their jobs and needed some relief on their children's spring tuition, which was due last month. In such circumstances, Mr. Pekala said, there is little he can do, other than waiving the $100 late fee or perhaps setting up a payment schedule.
"If a family member thinks they will be laid off," he said, "we usually can't react to that."
But those who have called to say they have already lost their jobs -- and Mr. Pekala said that there have been several dozen this winter -- have often been surprised to learn that Mr. Pekala is willing to make a deal, whether in the form of a loan or additional scholarship aid.
Mr. Pekala, who sees his job as equal parts loan officer, insurance agent and psychologist, said that other colleges -- particularly those with less wealth -- often have stricter payment policies, and are sometimes quicker to expel such students. But Mr. Pekala said he will only do so as a last resort, or if he suspects a family is not being fully honest.
"Once they become part of our community, we want them to graduate," he said. "We're here to help them reach their goals."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: PARTY; 
The Other Saturday Affair at the Waldorf

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Call her the bride who would not budge -- not for presidents, prime ministers, mayors or celebrities. 
 Nope, said Elizabeth Friedland, a lawyer. Early in September, she scheduled the celebration of her wedding to Dr. Mark Meyer, a cardiologist, for last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. 
 Despite the fact that the hotel would turn into the barricaded, high-security site of the World Economic Forum, Ms. Friedland and Dr. Meyer persisted in their original plans.
They held fast to their plans partly because they invited almost as many people as did Klaus Schwab, founder of the gathering at the Waldorf.
"Well, not quite," Dr. Meyer said on Friday. "Our party is about 550 people. And there really aren't that many places in New York where you can have that many people."
But the World Economic Forum attendees and Ms. Friedland managed to reach a detente that would make any United Nations security adviser proud. 
To accommodate the wedding, after the global health seminar scheduled for last night in the Jade Room and the "Middle-East Outlook" conversation in the Astor Salon, conference guests went down to the New York Stock Exchange for a multicultural dining and dancing extravaganza, leaving the Waldorf empty for the wedding party, which arrived from Temple Emanu-El at Fifth Avenue and East 65th Street.
The bride and groom did not have to worry that curious conference attendees -- say, the boisterous delegation from Bulgaria -- would accidentally stumble in on them.
The conference visitors at the Stock Exchange dined at buffet tables featuring food from around the world, from ceviche to spaghetti, and danced to mariachi musicians (or enjoyed classical violin quartets), in an evening intended to symbolize global unity.
The wedding guests planned to feast on a Sylvia Weinstock wedding cake large enough to accommodate 500, decorated with edible white flowers that matched those in the bride's hair. 
Ms. Friedland, who has spent much of the last four years living in Europe, had been through a string of unsuccessful relationships. Dr. Meyer had been through a string of graduate schools -- Yale Law School and Yale Medical School -- as well as, he said, "my 9 millionth blind date." 
Their first date was electric, Ms. Friedland said. "It lasted until 4 in the morning," Dr. Meyer said. Courtship was swift. Two weeks later, Dr. Meyer surprised Ms. Friedland by flying to London, where she lived, for the weekend. 
The next six months, he said, were a blur of blossoming love, trans-Atlantic plane trips and stolen weekends. 
When Dr. Meyer started interviewing for positions in cardiology, he investigated jobs in New York. He found none but he moved here anyway. 
"It was so against my grain," he said. "I have always done everything by the book. Suddenly I looked at myself and thought, 'Who is this person who is going to Europe for the weekend? Who is this man who is going to live in New York without a position?' It was surreal."
They chose February for their wedding because, the bride said, "it was pretty much the only Saturday that was available that was not the middle of summer or conflicting with another person's wedding." 
The doctor, confessing to some surprise, said he had never thought he would get married after an engagement of only five months, and then "at some point we found out that there would be this other major commotion going on in the city."
Because most of the wedding's invited guests were from out of town and were unfamiliar with New York, Ms. Friedland said she was happy to show them the city at its most vibrant.
"They're going to look at this city and think, 'Wow, exciting.' " 
Ms. Friedland, who was speaking on a mobile phone from a car, could be heard speaking to a security guard. "Hi, I'm the bride for the wedding," she said. "Right, you remember me? I'm getting married here. I don't have to show ID again, do I? I do? O.K., hold on." 
Dr. Meyer added that the enormous guest list also kept them from moving the celebration. 
"The other options for that many people weren't available until 2003," Dr. Meyer said. Judging from the tone of his voice, there could have been a convention of cannibals at the Waldorf, for all he cared. "Elizabeth didn't want to live together before we got married, and I thought, 'I'm 32 and I can't wait any longer! We're doing it at the Waldorf.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: With a wedding at the Waldorf, conference attendees were to attend a gala at the New York Stock Exchange. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Yonkers Is Designated Federal Empowerment Zone

BYLINE:  By Elsa Brenner 

 BODY:
The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has designated Yonkers, along with six other communities in the nation, a Federal Empowerment Zone. The designation entitles a zone to receive regulatory relief and tax breaks designed to promote job growth. 
 Incentives include wage credits on federal income tax, bond financing for new construction, financing for equipment purchases, tax benefits on capital gains and tax deductions for environmental cleanups, among other things. 
 The announcement was made by Assistant Housing Secretary Roy Bernardi, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers.
The other new zones are in Pulaski County, Ark.; Fresno, Calif.; Jacksonville, Fla.; Oklahoma City; San Antonio, and Syracuse and Onondaga County, N.Y. Twenty-eight others are already in existence.
Applicants had to satisfy a selection process that weighed population and poverty criteria and the community's strategic plan. Elsa Brenner

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: PROTESTS; 
At Least 38 Are Arrested, but Rally Remains Peaceful

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
It turned out to be a beautiful day for protest yesterday, with a little something for everybody. Peaceful demonstrations, catchy slogans, colorful placards, plenty of police officers -- and even a few arrests.
 Yesterday was the ballyhooed day when thousands of anarchists, socialists and just plain-old regular folks came to New York to rally against the World Economic Forum, which has brought 2,700 government leaders and corporate executives to the Waldorf-Astoria for the express purpose of "improving the state of the world." Adding to the mix were thousands of police officers assigned to keep the peace, along with untold numbers of federal law enforcement officials and armed bodyguards. 
 By early evening, an estimated 7,000 protesters had engaged in a loud but peaceful rally within earshot of the Waldorf on Park Avenue, and then disbanded. By that point, police officials said, at least 38 people had been arrested, on charges of disorderly conduct, unlawful assembly and reckless endangerment, and three officers had been injured. 
"So far, so good," Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said last night, although he added that other challenges remained. Some 2,000 guests of the economic forum were to be bused under heavy guard last night for a dinner at the New York Stock Exchange in Lower Manhattan. In addition, two more protests are planned for today and another on Monday.
People intent on protesting had been trickling into the city for days, with a few joining some early demonstrations against the five-day forum, which convened on Thursday. But organizers have always maintained that yesterday would be the marquee day for peaceful protest, although they have not denied that outbreaks of unlawful behavior were possible, from civil disobedience to the kind of property destruction that has marred other protests against economic conferences.
Yesterday morning, as guests of the forum -- at least those who did not linger at any of the exclusive parties on Friday night -- arose to choose from a breakfast buffet of panel discussions, their critics began to assemble outside. So did hundreds of police officers; for every protester's placard, there seemed to be an officer's helmet.
Then, at 9:50, two young men were hauled away on charges that they had tried to block traffic by sitting on Park Avenue, across from the Waldorf. Although charges were dropped against one of the suspects, the incident seemed to serve as the starter's pistol for the day's events: Super Saturday had officially begun.
As the sun rose above the tall buildings along the East Side, a few hundred protesters limbered up in the barricadelike pens outside the Waldorf. Tambourines chimed, cowbells rang, chants started.
"Money for jobs!" shouted a man on the back of a black Ford pickup truck, his hoarse voice amplified by speakers. "Not for war!" responded the protesters -- at least those who had not taped their mouths shut as a silent gesture of dissent. Meanwhile, hundreds of police officers stood on street corners or sat in vans, sipping coffee, waiting. There was nothing leisurely about that wait, as evidenced by the phalanx of 17 officers on horseback, directly across Park Avenue from the Waldorf.
At the same time, on 59th Street along the southern rim of Central Park, hundreds of other demonstrators had gathered in two spots: on the West Side, near Columbus Circle, and at the corner of Fifth Avenue, across from the Plaza Hotel. Police officers on bicycles darted in and out of the crowd, while dozens of others stood in clusters, watching the back-and-forth flow of young people carrying sharply worded signs.
"We're joking that their tactic must be to push us off the sidewalk," said Jeff Bale, 30, of a group called Mobilization for Global Justice.
Why had the protesters come? Mary Libby, 25, who said she worked with the homeless in Michigan, explained that she was "trying to reclaim the streets and our lives." Everything is upside down, she said, when corporate executives hire Elton John to perform at a private party at the Four Seasons, an event that took place Friday night.
She objected to paying Elton John a substantial fee to perform for an hour or two "when that money could be used to feed the homeless right outside the building they're in." 
For a while, the scene felt more like a giddy political bazaar than the staging area for imminent ideological conflict. It was a minifestival of dissent, with colorful puppets and placards bobbing in the air, drums beating out a catchy beat and people handing out leaflets that decried capitalism in general and the forum in particular. Even some in the blue arc of police officers around the scene allowed a few smiles.
The intense preparation by the Police Department may have allowed for a relaxed smile or two from its ranks. As late as yesterday morning, police officials were meeting with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to go over last-minute details, and Commissioner Kelly was planning to monitor the scene in a helicopter.
From above, he might have seen general cooperation between those in blue and those who were not. At noon, Police Chief Allan H. Hoehl and other officials huddled with several lawyers for the rally; they looked like two sets of coaches wishing each other well before a game.
Ronald L. Kuby, one of the lawyers, later said that the two sides were ironing out minor details, like whether speakers could stand on the pedestal of a statue of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman. They were allowed to stand on the first step. "We compromised," he said.
By 1:15 p.m., most of the protesters who had assembled at Columbus Circle had joined the others in front of the Plaza, and together they began a somewhat circuitous march toward the Waldorf, where hundreds of other demonstrators were continuing to chant and poke the sky with their placards.
Near the front of the parade were several women dressed as the Statue of Liberty, draped in silver and carrying papier-mache torches. At one point, people hoisted two of the women above the crowd, in classic cheerleader formation, bringing a chorus of approval. The women in silver also delighted the crowd by forming a chorus line and singing "New York, New York."
Along the parade route, protesters stopped to photograph officers standing guard outside a Starbucks cafe, and occasionally shouted out to the people on the sidewalk, "This is more fun than shopping."
And at East 51st Street and Lexington Avenue, the parade passed a small counterdemonstration, in which people waved signs that said, "The Police Are Great, It's Terrorists We Hate," and "Seek Therapy."
But the day had its share of tension, of clashes between protester and police officer. Three people were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct at Columbus Circle; four at 47th and Lexington; two others at 52nd and Broadway. 
The most dramatic moment, however, came at 1:30 p.m., when police officers waded into the tail end of the parade, at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue, and arrested 27 people on charges of unlawful assembly and disorderly conduct. Mr. Kelly said that the police had received information that this group -- which included people who he said were carrying plastic shields and masks -- "were about to attack the police."
Debra Sweet, a spokeswoman for an activist organization called Refuse and Resist, said last night that the circumstances of the arrests were unclear. But, she said, "from reports we have, the police seemed to be extracting particular people, especially people wearing masks."
After the arrests, a few lawyers and legal assistants stood alongside a large Department of Correction bus containing some of the arrested, and tried to get their names. One young woman mouthed her first name: "L-A-U-R-A."
Another young man in custody shouted, "I think it's imperative to report that we did not do anything illegal." Then the bus pulled away.
At Grand Central Terminal, a group of about 200 protesters entered the station just after 7 p.m. and were surrounded by dozens of uniformed police officers, many of them from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. A number wore white visored helmets and heavy vests, carried riot sticks, and had gas masks and plastic handcuffs strapped to their belts. Two police dogs appeared.
The protesters clapped, sang and beat on drums, and were then surrounded by the police. After a period of tension, the protesters sat down on the floor of the terminal, but neither side made a hostile move and the air of confrontation gradually dissipated. Eventually, the demonstrators wound up gathered in small groups in the terminal, chatting or eating, as the police stood and watched, chatting among themselves.

(Photographs by Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Island's Future Requires A Regional Approach 

 BODY:
Long Island's business and social agenda has become a hot political issue in recent weeks. The Long Island Association's president, Matthew Crosson, has taken some heat for suggesting that the state should do more to address housing, transportation, education and other issues on Long Island "The Island's Economic Issues," opinion, Jan. 27 .
 While each of these complex issues needs to be addressed, the underlying issue for Long Island is to find a better marketplace for ideas, information and solutions. We need to invent a process that permits us to come together, review information, discuss ideas and reach agreements. Such an approach will lead to broader coalitions and effective advocacy on behalf of our region. 
 If our political leaders, business executives and nonprofit directors work together and use a regional lens, pragmatic solutions to the challenges of affordable housing, transportation and education can be found. These issues are not partisan matters.
What would we have to do to set a regional agenda? Probably the biggest obstruction is the fragmented governmental structure with its overlapping jurisdictions.
This cumbersome public framework impedes both a sense of community at a local level and a sense of region for the Island. Parochialism, greed, jealousy and nimbyism thrive under such conditions. Over the past 50 years, Long Island has paid a heavy price for having no plan or vision -- sprawling development, the loss of open space and farms, long and tiring commutes, and increased segregation by race and income with related educational disparities.
We need to be conscious of these constraints and proactive in our attempts to grow a regional identity. Models of regional development from other parts of the country demonstrate significant results and indicate the value of engaging in such a process.
In Silicon Valley, a suburban area with similarities to Long Island, foundations, business groups and community organizations worked together to set a regional agenda. In the past five years more than $20.2 million has been raised for affordable rental housing for 3,000 families and more than $190 million has been leveraged for additional housing development through loans to developers. Silicon Valley voters twice passed a transportation bond designating a 0.5 percent sales tax for mass transit projects. This program will operate until 2036 and is estimated to have generated $6.54 billion during its first five years alone.
We are not Silicon Valley, but its results suggest that an inclusive private, public and civic regional agenda could be worth exploring. Certainly, Long Island's business and social agenda is too important not to give it a try.

NANCY RAUCH DOUZINAS
President
Rauch Foundation
Garden City

HEADLINE: Discounts And Ports Close to Home 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL reports on real estate and travel for The Times.

 BODY:
AFTER the events of Sept. 11, the cruise industry went into a slump so serious that over the next couple of months, occupancies on cruise ships seldom reached 50 percent, compared with an average of 90 percent over the last decade, according to James G. Godsman, president of the Cruise Lines International Association. 
 Many passengers on cruises in the months just after the disaster took their trips because they had booked well in advance, and risked forfeiting all or part of their payments if they didn't show up. Since then, as the industry has struggled to get back on its feet, a number of cruise lines have implemented more flexible cancellation policies, usually at additional cost. 
 Holland America's new policy, for example, will refund up to 90 percent of the fare to passengers who cancel for any reason at least 24 hours before the scheduled departure, for a fee of 5.2 percent of the fare at booking. 
Crystal Cruises also gives travelers the option to cancel for any reason, but only until three days before departure and then for a 90 percent credit (not cash) toward any cruise within the next 12 months. The policy costs $200 a person for cruises costing up to $8,000 (with air fare), or 3 percent of fares $8,000 and above. The policies are optional and are in addition to the usual cancellation policies. 
Passengers who booked a cruise after Sept. 11 generally did so because the cruise lines lowered fares as much as 50 percent, considered their broadest and steepest discounts ever -- more so even than during the Persian Gulf war in 1991. 
As during the gulf war, the cruise industry pulled its ships from the eastern Mediterranean, and rescheduled cruises closer to home for the remainder of last year and throughout 2002. But there are far more ships, and far bigger ones, now than a decade ago and that means there will be a big increase this year in itineraries in the Caribbean, Mexico, Alaska, the Panama Canal and other ports closer to the mainland United States. 
The questions the industry is agonizing over are how many passengers will book and whether they will book if the bargain fares disappear. 
For an industry that has already lost millions of dollars because of no-shows and rock bottom fares, the questions are hardly rhetorical. During the fourth quarter of last year, the Carnival Corporation's profits dropped 40 percent from those of the same period the year before, a drop that it attributed largely to cheap fares.
The bargains included Caribbean cruises as low as $50 a night a person, Panama Canal cruises at 50 percent off for the second passenger in a cabin, and even two-for-the-price-of-one Asian and South American cruises. 
The six-day trans-Atlantic crossing early this month of Cunard's Queen Elizabeth 2 from New York to Southampton, England, the first cruise from New York since Sept. 11, included a one-way upgrade from economy or business-class air to the British Airways' Concorde for an additional $1,995, rather than the regular one-way price of about $6,000. 
With such bargains and promises of heightened security, bookings have slowly increased. Also helping are the decisions to schedule trips close to American shores and to add more departure ports within driving distance of other than the usual Florida and California ports.
Holland America says that 360 of its 450 sailings this year will be from 15 ports that are within a half-day's drive of 40 percent of North American households. And a number of cruise lines are providing bus transportation: Royal Caribbean and its sister cruise line, Celebrity, offer passengers bus service to ports in Florida, California and Texas from a total of more than 50 cities. 
This approach is not a ground-breaking one. In recent years many other cruise lines, Carnival perhaps chief among them, experimented with cruises from such cities as Savannah, Virginia Beach, Baltimore, New Orleans, Galveston, Houston and Seattle. 
But the expansion of this experiment isn't likely to overcome the losses caused by fear of flying. Cruise lines are the nation's biggest private-sector buyer of air fares, accounting for four million tickets annually, according to Michael Crye, the president of the 17-member International Council of Cruise Lines. The additional passengers traveling by bus or car probably cannot make up the deficit. 
A Lazard analysis of Carnival's recent performance, published in December, noted that during the fourth quarter of 2001, 17.6 percent of Carnival Cruises passengers flew to their ports of departure compared with 23.7 percent the same quarter the previous year. This drop cost Carnival $16 million in revenue.
For the embattled cruise industry, getting passengers on board is the most important consideration. And getting nonfliers on board means getting ships to ports near them. That is why there are so many cruises this year from ports that have been lucky to have more than a couple of cruises a year.
Holland America, for example, which began operating from Tampa, Fla., in 1982, and last month boarded its one millionth passenger there, has 19 departures scheduled from Tampa this year, compared with 8 in 2001. Celebrity Cruises is offering 19 10- and 11-day cruises to the Caribbean from Baltimore, compared with 7 last year.
Norwegian Cruise Line is offering seven-day round-trip cruises from seven ports in the United States -- including Seattle, Boston and New York -- and from Vancouver, British Columbia. Royal Caribbean and Holland America are planning weekend cruises from Seattle to Victoria and Vancouver, British Columbia. 
Carnival's Holiday will operate eight cruises from Mobile, Ala., next month, five to the western Caribbean and three to nowhere. On April 27, it will begin year-round Caribbean cruises from New Orleans. 
And Royal Caribbean will offer dozens of cruises to the western Caribbean from Galveston, on the Rhapsody of the Seas beginning in April, and from New Orleans, on the Grandeur of the Seas beginning in October.
The discounts the last four months provided a helpful lifeline to an industry that until Sept. 11 had little reason to think the good times would ever end. The cruise lines had ordered dozens of new ships in anticipation of ever-growing passenger loads, and this year 13 of them, as well as two refurbished vessels, are scheduled to join the North American cruise market. The Cruise Lines International Association said the addition of 15 ships would be the most at one time in the association's 26 years.
Even if some are postponed or delayed, as expected, the ships likely to go into service will add thousands of new berths. That in turn will exert additional pressure on prices, despite the exodus of Renaissance Cruises and American Classic Voyages, both of which halted operations after the terrorist attacks and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Renaissance on Sept. 15, and American Classic on Oct. 19. 
The drop in bookings also took its toll on two small luxury ships, Radisson Seven Seas' Song of Flower and Silverseas' Silver Wind. Both were taken out of service for all or most of this year, leaving Radisson with five ships for now, and Silverseas with three. 
Another sign of hard times was the proposed merger in November by Royal Caribbean Cruises, the second largest cruise line (after Carnival), and P&O Princess Cruises, the third largest. Both companies conceded that the proposal was partly an effort to reduce costs, with potential savings of $100 million or more a year, beginning 12 months after the merger. 
But last month, Carnival made a $6.4 billion offer for Princess, well above Royal Caribbean's $2.9 billion offer. Princess rejected it, and a court battle may ensue, but regardless of which suitor wins Princess, analysts say that there are likely to be additional mergers, although not on that scale.
With a recession, new ships and passenger expectations of continued bargains, it is anybody's guess what the rest of this year holds for the industry. But Andrew Stuart, the executive vice president of Norwegian Cruise Line, said he was heartened by how quickly occupancy increased in so short a time, exceeding the expectations of most people. 
For example, the new Norwegian Star -- which began weekly cruises on Dec. 16 from Honolulu to the other Hawaiian Islands and Kiribati in the Fanning Islands -- is already sold out through March. What's more, many of the passengers on recent cruises and those booked on the cruises in February and March are from New York and the Midwest, meaning that they are willing to fly. "What we're seeing so far has taken us by complete surprise," Mr. Stuart said.
Felicia Kantor, the leisure analyst at Lehman Brothers, said there would still be bargains around, although not like those available late last year.
"Those were important to stimulate demand, to get people back on ships and show that it was safe and still fun," Ms. Kantor said. "And now that people don't seem to be as fearful, and are starting to think about vacations, demand will probably pick up."

HEADLINE: FOOTNOTES 

BYLINE:  By William Norwich

 BODY:
1. Definitions of simplicity change with time. Somehow, for some people, the simple balloons of one's childhood become one perfect diamond in adulthood. "All I care about is diamonds and a sunburn," a socialite in 1920's Newport once remarked on the way to her "cottage," which was anything but simple, unless you think a French-style chateau on a cliff overlooking the Atlantic Ocean qualifies. The latest in "simple" diamonds? The new "Lucida" from Tiffany & Company, a square mixed cut with a high crown intended to reveal the stone's inner sparkle. 
 Not everyone is so glib about simplicity, however. The folks in the Pacific Northwest went so far as to formalize a sentiment that dates back to Buddha. Voluntary Simplicity advocates slowing down, chilling out, buying less. There are newsletters, support groups and conferences. In 1994, the Trends Research Institute of Rhinebeck, N.Y., chose Voluntary Simplicity as a top trend of the 90's. (The next year, the institute, sensing a switch in economic fortunes, listed Involuntary Simplicity.) Read Duane Elgin's "Voluntary Simplicity," reissued in 1993 by Quill/William Morrow & Company. 

2. What do kids think are some of the most "simply marvelous things" in fashion? A) Barbie T-shirt, $13, and jean skirt, $20, from Kids "R" Us. B) D & G's red sneakers with gold and rhinestones, $130. At Z Baby, 996 Lexington Avenue. C) The "heart" headband, $4, from Kids "R" Us. D) Graffiti DKNY dress, $50 (very Stephen Sprouse). At dkny.com. E) Oilily's "Poodle" bag, $52. At Oilily stores.

3. The documentary "Gene Kelly: Anatomy of a Dancer," will be shown on PBS next month. It was written, produced and directed by Robert Trachtenberg, the photographer for this article. A little-remembered factoid: Before Kelly became famous, he taught children their first steps at a dance school. William Norwich

HEADLINE: 'Enron Professor of Economics' Has a New Ring Now 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Before they oversaw America's biggest corporate collapse, Arthur Andersen, Enron and even Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's former chief executive, opened their wallets for academia. All three have endowed professorships -- Andersen alone has 40 to 50, mostly at its workers' alma maters, like the University of Southern California and Texas A&M. The financing of some of them is now in doubt. Even those academics whose positions are secure have found that the names now have a taint.
 Mark E. Wohar, the Enron professor of economics at the University of Nebraska in Omaha (where one company now part of Enron was based), said he was trying to find out whether the financing for his position was still there. 
 Professor Wohar said he had been subjected to "a little bit of ribbing," and had stopped using the Enron name when identifying himself.
The situation is worse at Rice University, in Enron's hometown of Houston. In June 2000, amid much fanfare, Rice signed an agreement to develop communications technology with Enron's broadband services unit. As part of a $5 million gift intended to seal the deal, Enron endowed two chairs, in e-commerce and risk management.
"As often is the case with a large pledge like that, it was going to be paid in installments," said Terry Shepard, Rice's vice president for public affairs. Officials at the university began to worry about those installments when Enron started spiraling downward.
"We intentionally kept quiet over here and didn't start asking about it or anything," Mr. Shepard said. But on Jan. 7, Enron sent a letter saying payments would be suspended.
No one has been named to the chairs. "It's our practice to wait until we get the full amount, then fund the chair, then search for the faculty member," Mr. Shepard said. Rice and Enron are discussing other uses for the money donated, he said.
Across town, at the University of Houston, the two Kenneth L. Lay professorships are on safer ground. The money for the chairs, one as yet unfilled but supposed to be in economics, came from donations in 1994 and 1995 by Mr. Lay's friends and family. But the name now carries baggage for the filled chair.
"When I came down here, this was a huge honor, because a year or so ago Mr. Lay was the No. 1 guy in Houston," said Keith T. Poole, who left Carnegie-Mellon University to take the Lay professorship in political science at Houston. "I could impress people just by telling them, 'I'm the Kenneth L. Lay professor at the University of Houston,' " he said, "but now his name is mud."
After Mr. Lay's wife, Linda, said on television that the couple had "lost everything," a friend, as a joke, sent Professor Poole an e-mail message asking, "Has Ken asked for his money back?"
Mr. Lay's donations went elsewhere. His foundation endowed a professorship in international economics at his alma mater, the University of Missouri at Columbia, in 1999. Kenneth R. Troske, the professor leading the search committee, said the name had not yet become an issue in recruiting. But even if Mr. Lay were ever convicted of a crime, for instance, the university would not be able to change the name by itself. "He would have to agree to any changes that would be made with the chair," Professor Troske said.
A name change could also become an issue for dozens of other universities if Andersen followed Enron into bankruptcy. The professorships bearing the accounting firm's name around the world are mostly in accounting, Howard S. Engle, chairman of the Andersen Foundation, said.
Florida State University has two, one as yet unfilled. "In my vision, if Andersen does go down, they'll be absorbed by someone else," said Bud Fennema, chairman of the accounting department. A name change might thus be automatic. Professor Fennema predicted that the new name would be "the PriceWaterhouseCoopersAndersen chair," or something similar. But, Professor Fennema said, "I'm an alumnus of Arthur Andersen. I would push to keep the name the same."
Partners and employees of Andersen are raising money for the newest Andersen professorship, at the University of Texas, Mr. Engle said. The company will provide a significant part of the endowment by matching its workers' donations -- that is, if the company is still around.
Because Andersen has already given all the money that is needed to Florida State, stigma and name changes are the worst of the potential problems. William Hillison, who holds one of the Andersen professorships in accounting there, said he didn't mind a little teasing from his friends. "There's got to be a little light side," he said. "I'm sure it's pretty heavy down at the company."
But Professor Poole said the potential loss of Enron's philanthropic presence was sad. "Enron put up a lot of money locally for all groups across the spectrum," he said. "The perspective from inside Houston is just shock."
Despite the teasing, he was glad to hold the Lay professorship. "It's a very nice chair, by the way."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Amtrak: Nothing Like It in the World, So Far

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
AMTRAK'S new Acela trains can dash from New York to Washington at a top speed of 150 miles an hour. Sleek and shiny, they represent the pinnacle of American passenger rail, Amtrak's defiant response to critics who say the government wasted $25 billion over the last 30 years preserving a national railroad.
 But does the Acela really show how far railroads have advanced in 30 years, or how little things have changed? When Amtrak was formed in 1971, it inherited the Metroliner, which could go 160 m.p.h. but did so only in tests, because tracks were too far gone. Three decades later, track conditions are still so poor that Acela rarely runs at its own top speed, let alone that of its predecessor. 
 Amtrak's critics, and there are many, say this is no way to run a railroad. Amtrak is a railroad created by committee, a Congressional committee, and it shows. Its mission has always been contradictory -- offer national rail service, and at the same time make money. 
"Amtrak was asked to do too many things," said Thomas A. Till, chairman of the Amtrak Reform Council, which oversees Amtrak's finances. 
Amtrak was given a monopoly over intercity rail service. But because it was underfinanced, it didn't create much of a market for new technology, so private industry largely stopped developing it. Performance declined, and passengers stayed away in droves. 
After Sept. 11, the railroad, rickety though it was, suddenly seemed to be essential to national security and an important part of an integrated national transportation system. The problem was that everybody, including Amtrak, agreed that Amtrak didn't work. 
Now, as in 1971, Congress is debating Amtrak's fate, and questions about the role of rail are on track once more. But the framework has changed. The key issue used to be how much a government should get involved in running a railroad. Now it is how far the government can stay away. 
In evaluating the issue, transportation experts are looking at recent successful efforts in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and Japan to offer private companies concessions to run trains. 
They also are mindful of Britain, where, in a privatization frenzy in the mid-90's, the Conservative government allowed more than a dozen private companies to run passenger trains, as well as tracks, stations and bridges, with results just short of disastrous.
Aggressive private operating companies have lowered fares and offered special promotions that helped increase ridership to its highest level since 1947. But on-time performance declined severely, and after several deadly wrecks, fingers are pointing at Railtrack, the company that owns the rails. The tracks and bridges it took over were in worse shape than anyone knew, and Railtrack didn't benefit from the ridership growth because of the wording of the privatization contract. 
"The British experience shows that yes, there is a role for private carriers in passenger rail," said Anthony Perl, a visiting scholar at the City University of New York's Institute for Urban Systems and author of "New Departures" (University Press of Kentucky), about passenger rail policy. "But it has to be connected to a public role in providing infrastructure." 
Of course, such support is not entirely new. Railroads were among the first real symbols of American capitalist might, helping forge a vast nation. But much of that track could not have been laid without government help, especially western land grants. 
"That help was pretty much a one-shot deal," said Professor Perl -- unlike the government's continuing involvement in aviation and highways. 
For decades at the beginning of the 20th century, the railroads thrived without government support, and the passenger rail system became a world leader. But when it was time to reinvest after World War II, there were a series of government decisions to support other transportation modes. The government provided huge (and continuing) subsidies for the construction of airports, traffic control systems and the 41,000-mile interstate highway system. 
It was the bankruptcy of the Penn Central Railroad in 1970 -- the largest corporate collapse of its time, as shocking then as Enron's collapse is today -- that moved Congress to act. The freight lines, eager to wash their hands of passenger service, encouraged Congress to create Amtrak, although few people in Washington or elsewhere believed it could survive for long. 
TODAY, Amtrak carries 23 million passengers a year, a tiny fraction of those who travel by air or on the highways. In 2001, it lost $1.1 billion, making self-sufficiency by the end of 2002 -- a goal set by Congress in 1997 -- unachievable. Even Amtrak conceded that, on Friday, when it asked for $1.2 billion in next year's budget, and threatened to cut hallowed long-haul lines, like the Empire Builder, if it did not get the money.
After Sept. 11, Congress quickly intervened in aviation, setting aside $15 billion for the airlines and airports. Amtrak asked for $3.2 billion, but Congress refused to provide more than $105 million, mostly for security upgrades in century-old New York-area tunnels. 
Perhaps Congress turned a blind eye because of Amtrak's small share of passengers or because Amtrak's reputation for misspending runs too deep. But whatever the reason, the days of Congress just appropriating more money for Amtrak may be finished -- as may Amtrak itself. 
The reform council must submit a restructuring plan to Congress by Thursday. The council thinks it may be possible to allow private companies to bid on concessions to run some lines, an idea opposed by organized labor. 
The council already has made clear that, just as airports and air traffic control systems are paid for by government agencies, so too should tracks, stations and bridges be owned by government agencies. So just as the airlines are free to concentrate on carrying passengers, operating companies could make the trains run on time. 
"People are going to look back at the 1990's and see that the United States got to the point where it thought government should take a back seat in every part of economic life," said Professor Perl. "But from the point of view of transportation, it's clear that the government shouldn't be that far in the back seat."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Finding Gems of Genius Among Enron's Crumbs

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
ENRON gave off flashes of brilliance even as its financial wizardry and creative accounting spun the company out of control. These flashes could merely have been bubbles bursting, or they might have been something far greater -- glimpses of the future.
 Historically, innovative ideas are incorporated into the economic system only through a painful shakedown process. Often, these new ideas have signaled a sea change in the economic order of things, but the system often readjusted only after a brutal upheaval. 
 It's a familiar pattern. First, a profitable, socially beneficial idea appears. At the start, a few lucky people make a lot of money using the idea. Others rush in for a share of the spoils. Pretty soon, too many people with only a crude understanding of what the idea is about seek to exploit it. Then the hype becomes more important than the idea itself, until the inevitable reality-check causes this bubble to burst. Afterward, the markets are stunned -- but only for a while. The idea is incorporated, in its most useful form, into the business and financial world.
That, said Charles R. Morris, the author of "Money, Greed, and Risk: Why Financial Crises and Crashes Happen," is what could ultimately happen in Enron's case. "The business model is not a bad business model," Mr. Morris said. "The whole idea of trading energy contracts and having free markets is a really sound one."
Enron's fall could one day be viewed as one of the many fits and starts by which the modern economy has developed. In fact, much of the economy's evolution has come through revolutions, whether in technology for transportation or communications or methods of trading and financing. In the economy, where these revolutions often take the form of bubbles and panics, they have something of the two-steps-forward, one-step-back dynamic, Mr. Morris explained.
In fact, bubbles and panics have dogged -- or benefited -- the American economy virtually since its inception. Often, the exposure of a single company's problems has led to the questioning of entire industries and markets.
Yet these are not automatically good parallels for Enron. When actions by officials of the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Company and the Mercantile National Bank set off panics in 1857 and 1907, respectively, the questions that followed were more about lawbreaking and corporate connections than about whether the innovation itself was valuable.
One example of hysteria driven by innovation was the railroad speculation of the 1830's in Britain and the United States. It began when the building of a few profitable routes led to scores of companies constructing rail links in all directions.
"The first ones exploited the best, most lucrative lines," said Peter M. Garber, an economic historian who now works as a global strategist for Deutsche Bank. "They kept getting flung farther out until the traffic just didn't justify the building, and then there's a bust." The promise of many investments went unfulfilled, but more than a century later, the tracks and trains and passengers remain.
Enron was not a case of over-building, however. Its innovation was in the way it did business rather than its product. The company synthesized existing ideas from the Texas oil business, Wall Street and Silicon Valley to create an online exchange where financial bets, not assets, backed energy trades. In that way, the Enron case parallels more recent "big ideas," like leveraged buy-outs, financial derivatives and hedge funds.
Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund that imploded in 1998, may come the closest to a historical parallel. "L.T.C.M. was 100 percent a trading model that people thought was a superior one," Mr. Garber said. The company went around "collecting nickels," in the form of small inefficiencies in financial markets, until eventually "those nickels got harder and harder to come by." Finally the hedge fund lost one big bet, and crashed. But unlike Enron, L.T.C.M. wasn't taking extraordinary measures to hide what it was doing.
In Enron's early years, Mr. Morris said, its online trading platforms for energy and natural gas found deserved success. "You had a nice, middle-sized innovative business." In cases like this, he said, "the first guys make money, and they really earn it because they make social value."
Soon enough, Mr. Morris continued, Enron got carried away with its own "brand-new magic." But Enron's original contribution could well remain. Indeed, a slew of companies that mimicked Enron quickly picked up the bankrupt company's business, and even some of its employees.
David M. Dilts, director of the Management of Technology program at Vanderbilt University, saw another parallel. "It's basically the gold rush. Everybody rushes to the gold, and they'll figure out how to make money later."
Once the shake-out occurs, Professor Dilts said, there may be far fewer companies, growing at a slower pace, though the business may in fact be a sound one. He cited the auto industry, where a group of about 300 producers shrank to just a handful in the first half of the 20th century. He also brought up the payment-clearing industries for credit card charges and hospital payments, which each have only two or three major players.
But will Enron's model endure? Paul M. Romer, a professor at Stanford who studies the effects of scientific and technological changes on the economy's growth, is not so sure.
"It's hard to tell if there's something real here or not," he said. With Enron's mystique dispelled, new companies may have trouble seeing the potential profits in applying the business model, even among a small number of competitors. 
Professor Romer recalled a sign that warns people crossing tracks in French railway stations: "One train may hide another." Rather than becoming a new economic model, Enron's business may only have been the result of some very special times. That was not so true during the California gold rush, the railroad bubbles, the stock frenzy of the 1920's or even the financial experiments of the past two decades.
If those special times change, so could Enron's usefulness. For example, a decision to re-regulate the energy markets could stifle the entire online trading business. Or changes in current accounting standards and securities regulation could relegate Enron's exotic financing vehicles to the past.
So, for the moment, Enron's legacy remains in doubt. And whether its business model offers a glimpse of one possible future could remain uncertain for some years to come.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ASIAN MILITANTS; 
School in Indonesia Urges 'Personal Jihad' In Steps of bin Laden

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SOLO, Indonesia, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Among the nearly 2,000 students crammed into Al Mukmin boarding school, Osama bin Laden is a hero. His photo, in full color and poster size, is plastered on the walls of the dormitories much as rock stars decorate teenagers' bedrooms in America. His face peers out from the inside of locker doors and appears on T-shirts worn under the preppy blazers of senior prefects.
 The lionization comes from the top: the principal, a fiery preacher, Abu Bakar Baasyir, champions Mr. bin Laden and exhorts Muslims to follow his example. More important, say American and Asian officials, he has recruited operatives for Al Qaeda in Southeast Asia. According to the government of Singapore he is the leader of Jemaah Islamiah, or the Islamic Group, which officials say is a terrorist organization with cells throughout the region. 
 Mr. Baasyir, 64, a vision in white with his Muslim cap, long gown, scarf, toothy smile and snowy beard, denies any involvement in terrorist activities. But under questioning by the Indonesian police last week, he acknowledged that he had taught 13 of the people arrested in Malaysia and Singapore in connection with a plot to blow up the American Embassy in Singapore. 
In an interview at the school, Mr. Baasyir declared that the United States was "the terrorist nation." It was not Mr. bin Laden who masterminded the Sept. 11 attacks. Americans organized the attacks on the World Trade Center, probably with the help of Israel, he said.
"I rejoiced because it seemed Allah punished the United States for its arrogant behavior," he said of his reaction to the attacks.
Some of the preacher's statements appear to be more emphatic expressions of popular ideas in the mainstream news media here.
There are plenty of people in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim nation, who say they feel more sympathy toward Mr. bin Laden and his cause than toward the United States. It is not unusual to hear that Jews were responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks. Many agree with Mr. Baasyir, including those who wrote an editorial this week in the newsmagazine Tempo, that the United States should produce any evidence against Mr. bin Laden in an international court.
Still, given Indonesia's history, it is striking that a boarding school -- one of the thousands that specialize in Islamic curricula and are known as pesantren -- would breed such a politicized interpretation of Islam.
For hundreds of years, Indonesia has prided itself on a system of religious schools where students, mostly from poor backgrounds, learned a laissez-faire form of Islam and acquired a sense of self-sufficiency and initiative. Though somewhat feudal in nature because they tended to be closed societies led by a charismatic preacher, the pesantren were regarded as the incubators of democracy, institutions that tried to instill justice and moral values. During the authoritarian era of General Suharto, the schools were thought to be crucibles of tolerance set against an unyielding secular state.
In contrast, Mr. Baasyir founded Al Mukmin in 1972 as a standard-bearer for an Islamic state, a place where the curriculum emphasizes carrying out a "personal jihad" to defend Islam.
The school is largely a collection of shabby one-story classrooms and offices. The one exception to the general air of decay is a new three-story dormitory financed by friends of the school in Saudi Arabia.
One man arrested in the Philippines, Fathur Rohman al-Ghozi, who was arrested on suspicion of being a crucial figure in the plot by Al Qaeda to blow up the American Embassy in Singapore, spent four years studying at Al Mukmin.
During a visit to the campus, it was easy to see how young boys, some as young as 5, could become foot soldiers in an anti-American campaign organized in the name of Islam.
"Jihad is the way of Allah," said Dwi Purwanto, 19, one of the boys sporting the image of Mr. bin Laden across his chest. "We will attack the enemy who attacks Muslims." 
With barely any exception, boys from junior high school to the final year seniors, said their goal in life was to ensure that Islam was applied "correctly." On further probing this meant that Indonesia should become an Islamic state, and that "anti-Islamic forces" -- usually described as the United States -- must be destroyed. They were proud of their alumnus, Mr. Ghozi, saying he had glorified Islam.
The students are awakened at 3:30 for first morning prayers, followed by study groups on particular topics of the Koran. Sixty percent of the curriculum is devoted to the study of Islam: how to read the Koran; the speeches of the Prophet Muhammad; and the interpretation of Islamic law. "We try to emphasize Islamic law," said Sarid Maruf, the director of the school. 
Arabic is a compulsory subject, and is another opportunity for teaching Islam. Nurul Hidayap, a young Arabic teacher, showed the day's lesson: questions and answers about the Prophet Muhammad's life that had to be written down in Arabic script. Question: When did Muhammad set aside the most time for contemplation? Answer: When he was 46.
With lights out at 10 p.m., the boys get little sleep. There is no television, no radio. The students are allowed out of the school one Friday a month from 5 a.m. to 5 p.m. Life is spartan.
In one cluster of buildings, the school caters to girls; some had hidden makeup in their dorms, and many seemed to have more varied professional aspirations than the boys. For the most part, boys said they wanted to go back to their villages and preach, or further their Islamic studies. Several girls said they wanted to become doctors, social workers or psychiatrists. 
Mr. Baasyir founded Al Mukmin after graduating from Gontor, a distinguished religious school in East Java, sometimes referred to in Indonesia as the Harvard of pesantren. His aim, he said, was to create a different kind of religious school, one that produced students who "if and when they become leaders of the nation they would abide by Islam." 
His fealty to the idea of Indonesia as an Islamic state brought him into open hostility with Mr. Suharto. Mr. Baasyir was jailed and subsequently fled to Malaysia, where he said he had founded another pesantren, Lukmanal Halium. "I was received warmly in Malaysia, especially by the youth," he said. In Malaysia, he read all of Mr. bin Laden's books, he said. "He published various books about why he's against the United States," Mr. Baasyir said. "I absorbed that into my preaching." 
The Singapore authorities contended that Mr. Baasyir was involved in more than that. They said he was a central figure in setting up the network in the region.
On his return to Indonesia in 2000, Mr. Baasyir took up the cause of an Islamic state again, addressing a gathering at the stadium in Solo on the theme of women not being suitable to serve as president. (The current leader, President Megawati Sukarnoputri, became the first female president of Indonesia six months ago.)
In some ways, the fact that Al Mukmin operates in Solo, a commercial city known as a bastion of conservative Islam, is not surprising. According to one count, more than 70 Islamic organizations exist here, many of them new and radical. Among them is the Solo Islamic Youth Front whose militia accompanied Mr. Baasyir to his police questioning. Others include Laskar Jundullah (Army of God) and Laskar Hizbullah (Army of the Party of God).
Are members of the major Muslim organizations in Indonesia worried about Mr. Baasyir, his school, and the surge in radical Islamic groups here? Yes and no.
Dahlan Rais, the regional leader of Muhammadiyah, one of the two largest national Muslim groups, put it this way: "To some Muslims, Baasyir is a symbol of truth and courage. In the current circumstances, people are alienated from their surroundings, economically and socially. It doesn't take much to incite the masses."

(Photographs by James Nachtwey/VII, for The New York Times) Map of Indonesia highlighting Solo: An Islamic boarding school in Solo idolizes Osama bin Laden.
