HEADLINE: For a Not-So-Private Citizen, All the World's Still a Stage 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
He has been a private citizen for a month now, but the world still regards him as synonymous with New York City. He is known simply by his first name, though out of habit and respect, he is still called Mr. Mayor. Crowds and television cameras still swarm around him at every opportunity -- perhaps now more than ever.
 Rudolph W. Giuliani is still everywhere. 
 In recent days, Mr. Giuliani has been a star at the World Economic Forum. He accompanied leaders of the forum to ring the bell at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday morning and later spoke, along with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki, at the forum's opening event. 
In between, he met privately with the mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delanoe. And on Friday, Mr. Giuliani appeared on two different World Economic Forum panels, including one with the director of homeland security, Tom Ridge, and many corporate executives.
On Tuesday, Mr. Giuliani attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the new Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Battery Park City. (Mr. Bloomberg was also there.) Last week, Mr. Giuliani led members of the United States Conference of Mayors on a tour of ground zero. (Mr. Bloomberg was in Washington that day.)
During the Super Bowl today, Mr. Giuliani will appear in a 30-second Monster.com commercial in which he will thank America for helping New York after the Sept. 11 attacks. He was not paid to appear, but Monster.com is making a $350,000 donation to the Twin Towers Fund, which he controls. 
With few exceptions, modern mayors of New York City have left office only because voters tossed them out. Even Fiorello H. La Guardia and Edward I. Koch, who each served three full terms and were regarded as two of the most popular mayors, left City Hall after the electorate had tired of them. 
But the events following Sept. 11, and term limits barring him from seeking re-election, have put Mr. Giuliani in a situation unprecedented for a former mayor: he is as popular now as he ever was in office -- and in even greater demand. 
"The media demand for him comes from South America, Australia, China, all of Europe; it is literally international and it is unsolicited and relentless," said Sunny Mindel, the former mayoral communications director, who continues to serve as Mr. Giuliani's spokeswoman. 
Add to all this Mr. Giuliani's strong endorsement and support of his successor, and the situation gets even weirder: Mr. Giuliani still seems to be dominating the stage and -- at least for now -- Mr. Bloomberg does not seem to mind. "There are a lot of people in this city to whom his presence means a great deal," Edward Skyler, Mr. Bloomberg's press secretary, said of Mr. Giuliani. "And for good reason. The man did an incredible job." 
Some aides, however, have grumbled privately that they do not understand Mr. Giuliani's proclivity for showing up at events where the objective was clearly for Mr. Bloomberg to shine. Mr. Bloomberg's aides are not publicly revealing concerns. Several noted, however, that some positive publicity Mr. Bloomberg has received -- particularly for the openness of his administration -- has come to a certain degree at the expense of Mr. Giuliani. 
They also noted that many of Mr. Giuliani's public appearances had been perfectly understandable. He helped, for example, bring the World Economic Forum to New York and now that he is working in the private sector he has a legitimate interest in meeting more people in the corporate world. 
Fred Siegel, a historian and senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington, said he expected Mr. Giuliani to remain in the limelight and Mr. Bloomberg not to fret over it. "There is no precedent for leaving office like that," he said. "Let's look back: La Guardia is dying; O'Dwyer is fleeing; Impellitteri is an interim mayor; Wagner is so tired; Lindsay is utterly discredited; Beame is a monumental failure; Koch -- from 1933 we have to go all the way up to Koch -- Koch leaves, he's on television he's on radio, he doesn't go away." 
Several of Mr. Giuliani's former aides said they were impressed that he had refrained from publicly commenting on Mr. Bloomberg or city affairs. When Mr. Bloomberg put plans for new baseball stadiums on hold, Mr. Giuliani did not weigh in. Nor has he commented on Mr. Bloomberg's meeting with the Rev. Al Sharpton. 
"Who would have thought that the man who was so undisciplined in office -- and commented on everything -- could be so disciplined once he left office," a former senior Giuliani aide said. 
Mr. Giuliani, of course, is busy enough. His schedule has quickly filled with lucrative speaking engagements even as the former mayor's closest aides struggle to start up his new consulting business, Giuliani Partners. 
Last month, Mr. Giuliani went to California, where he appeared on "The Tonight Show"; promoted an HBO movie about the days after Sept. 11; campaigned for his friend William E. Simon Jr., who is seeking the Republican nomination for governor; and attended a benefit for the Twin Towers Fund. 
Later this month, Mr. Giuliani will go to England, where he is to be knighted by the queen, tour Parliament, visit with Prime Minister Tony Blair and raise more money for the fund. (Because he is not a British subject, he cannot use the title Sir Rudy.) He is also scheduled to visit the Netherlands to give a speech and go to Germany to receive an award. 
In the months ahead, he is booked to speak at several conventions and events. Next week, he is to be the keynote speaker at the International Builders Show in Atlanta, and over the weekend there is a fund-raising event for a Jewish group in Miami. In March, he is scheduled receive the Ronald Reagan Freedom Award from Nancy Reagan. In April, he plans to give speeches in Washington, Pennsylvania, Oklahoma and Texas. And the first of two books he has agreed to write is due out in the spring.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE FORMER CHAIRMAN; 
His Influence Lost, Lay Prepares to Answer Questions in Washington

BYLINE:  This article was reported by David Barboza, Don Van Natta Jr. and Jim Yardley and was written by Mr. Yardley. 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
The last time he appeared before Congress, Kenneth L. Lay did not lack confidence. In May 1996, his company, the Enron Corporation, was the emerging force in the energy business, and Mr. Lay was its apostle. His testimony, calling for opening electricity markets to competition, was part lecture, part sermon.
 The lawmakers that day were deferential to a man whose campaign donations had helped elect many of them. Enron, Mr. Lay boasted, was "one of the new breed," and those who opposed him represented "the threatened status quo." Follow Enron, he promised, and "we will unleash a new era of productivity and creativity." 
 "The vision I have in mind," he said triumphantly, "will have a dramatic impact on every household and every business in America." 
For his next appearance, scheduled on Monday before a Senate subcommittee, Mr. Lay will face a panel eager to pulverize him. Mr. Lay, 59, is now deposed and discredited, and Enron's collapse into bankruptcy, with its Shakespearean themes of greed, ambition and arrogance, has become a corporate scandal rippling into the highest reaches of Washington politics.
Mr. Lay, who resigned last month as the company's chairman, is expected to provide his first public explanation of what went wrong at Enron and to describe his own role in the collapse. His critics are portraying him as a greedy corporate chieftain who brazenly used enormous campaign contributions to push his deregulatory views on politicians in Washington and in state capitals all over America. A scathing report released yesterday by a special committee of Enron's board said that Mr. Lay bore "significant responsibility" for the breakdown of controls and ethics at the company.
But an examination of how he spent the last three decades rising in business and accumulating political influence reveals that Mr. Lay is too complicated for caricature. He can be avuncular and unpretentious, a religious man once admired by his employees and revered in Houston, his adopted hometown, for his civic leadership.
But he also has huge ambition and energy; he wanted to change the business world, and to do so he could be ruthless and petty. He was a demanding boss who, if not always immersed in details, created and condoned a cutthroat corporate environment that spun out of control.
"Ready, fire, aim," went the joke colleagues often told about Mr. Lay's approach as a young executive.

Politics, Cut With Business
The constant theme in Mr. Lay's career over the last three decades is his understanding of the symbiotic relationship between business and politics and his willingness to aggressively play the game.
His famous friendship with the Bush family helped establish him as a man politicians needed to know. He never hesitated to sprinkle money to generate good will, whether through political contributions to two-thirds of the members of Congress, or through gifts to charities and nonprofit groups in Houston, the sort of giving that corporate image makers call "reputational capital."
Mr. Lay, temperamentally a Republican, directed three of every four dollars Enron contributed to Congress to the Republican Party. But he dabbled with Democrats, too. In Houston, after an incumbent congressman irritated downtown business leaders, Mr. Lay led the fund-raising efforts to help elect a little-known challenger, Sheila Jackson-Lee, now one of the most liberal Democrats in Congress. He worked in the 1992 campaign of former President George Bush, and the next summer was playing golf with the man who beat him, Bill Clinton.
"He was pretty pragmatic in who we ought to support," said his longtime lobbyist at the Texas Statehouse, George Strong. "He thought we should support who was going to get elected."
He did not hesitate in trying to exert his influence on those he helped elect. When Mr. Strong ran into problems in the Statehouse, he often asked Mr. Lay to call the governor, George W. Bush. With Mr. Bush's ascension to the presidency, Mr. Lay had a private meeting with Vice President Dick Cheney on the administration's energy policy and was an important supporter of the appointment of a fellow Texan, Pat Wood, as chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
"The Enron and Ken Lay stories are best told in an English literature class, or a classics class where you are trying to explain what hubris is all about," said Bill Burton, a Houston lawyer and former Clinton administration official who has known Mr. Lay for 10 years. "The classic Greek story of Icarus -- a pretty classy guy, he had these big moral aspirations, then he tries to do too much, and he tries to fly too close to the sun."
Mr. Lay's scheduled Monday appearance comes more than 30 years after he first went to Washington as a bright young man following his favorite economics professor at the University of Missouri. The professor, Pinkney Walker, had been appointed to the Federal Power Commission, the forebear of F.E.R.C., and he contacted his former student about becoming his assistant.
The son of a Baptist lay preacher and sharecropper, Mr. Lay grew up humbly in rural Missouri before the family moved to Columbia, a university town. He worked his way through college and told Mr. Walker upon graduation that he needed "to make some money." When Mr. Walker later approached him about going to Washington, Mr. Lay was working at Exxon and was uncertain about leaving.
"Hey, Kenneth," Mr. Walker recalled telling his protege, "what if this had their blessing?" He said he called the chief executive of Exxon and explained the benefits of having a former employee working for such a powerful regulatory agency. "They liked that," Mr. Walker said.
For Mr. Lay, it would be his first lesson on the nexus of business and politics. He became indispensable at the commission, arriving every morning by 6, organizing the daily agenda. He got noticed and later was an under secretary at the Interior Department, specializing in energy issues, before he was hired as a vice president by Jack Bowen, the chief executive at the Florida Gas Corporation.
When Mr. Bowen left for Transco, a larger gas company in Houston, Mr. Lay eventually became a top executive at Florida Gas and began lobbying in Washington for the deregulation of the natural gas industry and laws allowing the interstate transport of gas. By 1981, his first marriage had disintegrated, and Mr. Lay, who would later marry his secretary, Linda, began looking for a change.
He contacted Mr. Bowen, who again hired him, this time as president and chief operating officer at Transco. Mr. Bowen welcomed him to Houston, and Mr. Lay joined the clubby social circle of oil executives and other business leaders that included, by extension, James A. Baker III, then chief of staff for President Ronald Reagan, and George Bush, then the vice president.
"At first, I would have considered him more of an introvert than later on," said Robert A. Mosbacher, a Houstonian who became commerce secretary when Mr. Bush became president in 1989. "He sat back and listened more than he talked. And he obviously learned a lot."
Mr. Mosbacher introduced the new man to his friend, the vice president, while Mr. Bowen took him on business trips to Washington that included meetings with Mr. Bush. "I remember somewhere along the line mentioning to Bush that he was a can-do kind of guy who would like to do some work for him and the Republican Party," Mr. Mosbacher said.
A long-time Republican Party fund-raiser from Texas said Mr. Lay "was one of the people Mosbacher brought into the political fund-raising world. Mosbacher showed him how it was done."
At first, other fund-raisers recall, Mr. Lay was awestruck that a preacher's son from Missouri was rubbing elbows with the vice president of the United States. He eventually became a natural.

The Creation of Mr. Houston
Mr. Lay's political ascent coincided with his growing stature in the Houston business community. He joined Houston Natural Gas in 1984 as chief executive and adroitly maneuvered himself and his company when it merged with a larger company, Internorth, based in Omaha. He emerged as chief executive and earned $4 million in stock options. The company that would become Enron was born.
Mr. Lay was an aggressive executive, pushing for new deals, fast. A former Houston Natural Gas executive recalled that the firm once sold a chemical company in a weekend. "One joke went, 'Linda is pregnant,' " the executive recalled. " 'How long is it going to take?' Ken would ask.
" 'Well, nine months, Ken,' " the joke continued. " 'That's unacceptable,' Ken would say. 'Can you do it in six?' "
Mr. Lay was never a screamer and was always polite. But he was hardly soft. "It's Ken's way or you're out," the executive said. "We flew on some trip, and I read a nonbusiness book. And he looked at me and said, 'How can you do that?' Well, I never did that again."
Mr. Bush's 1988 presidential victory meant Mr. Lay could count as a friend the most powerful man in the world. "The velocity of his political ascent was pretty dramatic," one friend, a Washington lobbyist, said.
That ascent was fueled by the campaign contributions Mr. Lay began giving to both parties in Texas and Washington, as well as his sheer friendliness. Mr. Burton, the Clinton administration official who is now a Texas energy lawyer, said, "He quickly figured out how the game in Washington was played."
Mr. Lay became co-chairman of President Bush's re-election campaign in 1992 and chairman of the Republican National Convention in Houston that summer. When Mr. Mosbacher stepped down as commerce secretary, Mr. Lay's name came up. He could have had the job, too, a friend said, but he wanted to stay at the helm of Enron.
Mr. Bush's defeat altered the political landscape, but as Mr. Lay's golf game with Mr. Clinton attested, he adjusted quickly. He built a Washington lobbying office that by the end of the decade would employ more than 100 people. Despite such a huge staff, Mr. Lay preferred to meet with cabinet members or senior White House aides in private.
"Ken would stroll in alone, and that was the exception," Mr. Burton recalled. "He did not need an entourage, and it was one of the things that impressed us about him."
Mr. Lay needed political power because Enron was trying to rewrite the rules of the energy business. By 1992, Mr. Lay wanted to dominate the natural gas market and was also calling for the deregulation of the electricity market, a political fight that meant taking on the entrenched public utilities. Enron itself was evolving, becoming less a traditional pipeline company than a Wall Street-styled trading operation that believed energy could and should be traded like stocks, bonds and futures.
The federal government opened the door to deregulation in 1994 but, in doing so, shifted much of the debate to individual states. In Texas, another Bush was rising, with Mr. Lay's help. Mr. Lay gave generously to George W. Bush's 1994 upset victory and, with Enron, has contributed nearly $575,000 to the younger Mr. Bush's political races. The company has also donated $1.9 million in soft money to the national political parties, of which $1.5 million went to the Republicans.
The pre-eminent issue in Texas for Enron was electric deregulation. The debates began in the Texas Legislature in 1993, but deregulation was not approved until 1999. Mr. Lay stuck with it all the way. "When we needed some help with the governor or the governor's office, Ken would make the calls," Mr. Strong, the former Enron lobbyist, recalled.
Enron's influence on Mr. Bush's politics included his failed 1997 effort to revamp the state tax code. Mr. Bush's original plan, which would have cut taxes for companies like Enron, was based on a proposal by Charles Walker, a former Reagan Administration official then on Enron's board. Another Enron executive, Richard Kinder, helped conduct public hearings on the issue.
In the midst of it all, Mr. Lay was emerging as Mr. Houston, partly because of the money he had spread over the city. He became chairman of the United Way, and Enron became its biggest supporter. He helped lead the campaign to persuade voters to approve new taxes to build a football stadium and a baseball stadium that would become Enron Field, and convinced former President Bush to make a personal appeal in a commercial.
He also was willing to get personally involved in certain races. In 1994, he worked to defeat a Democratic member of Congress, Craig Washington. Mr. Washington was a folk hero among black politicians in Houston, but he had angered business leaders, particularly by voting against an appropriation bill for the NASA space center in Houston. Local Democrats say Mr. Lay became the de facto finance chairman for Mr. Washington's opponent, Ms. Jackson-Lee.
"He made it acceptable for people in the business community to give money in the Democratic primary against an incumbent for Congress," a local Democratic consultant said. "That usually wouldn't be done."
One local politician said Mr. Washington's defeat by Ms. Jackson-Lee sent an unmistakable message: Do not mess with Ken Lay.

Friends Can't Stop the Fall
The presidential campaign of the younger Mr. Bush began to focus national attention on Mr. Lay. He became one of the early "pioneers" who raised more than $100,000 for the campaign, and he eventually placed Enron's entire political action committee behind Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush's victory immediately brought speculation that Mr. Lay would be appointed to the cabinet. Colleagues dating to his days at Houston Natural Gas say Mr. Lay harbored such ambitions, and two of his friends say that Mr. Lay wanted to be Treasury secretary.
"I don't think it was ever seriously considered by the president and vice president," one of the friends said, noting that the new administration already had three Texas oil men, Mr. Bush, Mr. Cheney and the designated commerce secretary, Donald L. Evans. 
But Mr. Lay, one associate said, was still "the best positioned guy in America" on Inauguration Day. Enron's stock was soaring, and his candidate had become president. Little could he have imagined that the slide of Enron, and the disintegration of his own political power, had already begun. Perhaps, as Mr. Lay is expected to argue on Monday, he had spent so much time politicking, wielding influence and building his civic legacy that maybe he did ignore his company at his own peril.
If anything, associates agree, Mr. Lay has always understood a fundamental rule of politics, namely that contributions make friends of elected officials. But those same contributions, and the potential taint they carried, made Mr. Lay politically radioactive when he began secretly asking administration officials for help in bailing out Enron. The answer was no, and even Mr. Bush, who used to call him "Kenny Boy," suddenly began describing him as "a supporter."
"I feel sorry for him," said Mr. Strong, the former lobbyist who was fired with a two-sentence letter. "On the other hand, I'll be real mad if I find out he not only knew about this but lied to employees."

HEADLINE: Gore Rebukes Bush, and Tries to Mend Fences at Home in Tennessee 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
Declaring that "I intend to rejoin the national debate," Al Gore re-emerged in his home state tonight and unleashed a searing critique of George W. Bush's policies on issues from the economy to the environment to campaign finance to health care.
 While he did not waver from his steadfast support for the White House's handling of the war, this speech was the first in which Mr. Gore has derided Mr. Bush's programs since they faced off in what was perhaps the most contentious presidential competition ever. Mr. Gore even invoked former President Bill Clinton -- whom he steered clear of for much of the presidential campaign -- in accusing Mr. Bush of squandering the last administration's economic successes. 
 "Not long ago, our economy was very strong because we made the right decisions, decisions that reflected our values," Mr. Gore declared at a fund-raising reception here for the Tennessee Democratic Party. "Whatever anyone wants to say, I believe Bill Clinton and I did a good job on the economy. But now, our economy is back in recession, an unbelievable $4 trillion in projected surpluses have disappeared in a single year and public investments in priorities like job training, school construction and health care are once again being slashed." 
On the environment, Mr. Gore said, "They're trying to open up the most beautiful and pristine wilderness in Alaska."Noting that a campaign finance reform bill would have been his first priority as president, Mr. Gore did not cite the Enron debacle but said pointedly, "We need campaign finance reform to stop the ever growing, alarming examples of too much buying access and influence in Washington, D.C."
After more than a year of virtual political seclusion, Mr. Gore sounded tonight as if he were back in the heat of a campaign against Mr. Bush. But he told the crowd here what he has told friends: "whether or not I will" run "as a candidate in 2004, I don't yet know." 
This event was the first of what Mr. Gore's advisers say will be dozens of appearances around the country for candidates in November's elections. The speech left no doubt that the former vice president wants to keep his options open. If he runs in 2004, his candidacy could not be dismissed. After all, he won the popular vote in 2000, and he is far better known than the other Democrats with designs on the White House.
In appearing before more than 1,000 Tennessee Democrats, who paid $25 a head for pretzels and chips and to hear Stella Parton, Dolly's younger sister, at the Renaissance Hotel here, Mr. Gore was also taking a vital step if he decides to try for a rematch: convincing Tennesseans that he is still a viable candidate.
"I live this state with all of my heart and soul," he said.
Yet the hurdles for Mr. Gore extend beyond making amends in Tennessee, which he lost to Mr. Bush by a humiliating four points. Although he almost became president, and while his supporters in 2000 credit Mr. Gore for delivering a gracious concession, many are eager for a fresh candidate. And, close race or not, many Democrats argue that Mr. Gore should have swamped Mr. Bush.
In the Senate alone, several Democrats who backed Mr. Gore in 2000 are already preparing their own campaigns for the party's nomination. Even senators who are not running are openly critical, even dismissive, of their last standard-bearer.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, for one, laughed uproariously when asked about supporting Mr. Gore again.
"Al Gore lost North Dakota by 28 points!" Mr. Dorgan said. "The entire ticket went down with him in North Dakota. When you lose by 28 points, that's a megalandslide."
Asked about Mr. Gore's prospects, Mr. Dorgan said, "I don't hear anybody say much of anything about Al Gore."
Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana said about Mr. Gore: "Things change. In politics, it's here today, gone tomorrow. It's a whole new scenario right now. You have to be likable before they can vote for you."
Even Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who is so close to Mr. Gore that the former vice president held a fund-raising event for him in the fall, is not ready to commit to him again. 
"We have to see what the lay of the land is," Mr. Harkin said. "It would be harder for him because he's not the sitting vice president."
Mr. Harkin said that if Mr. Gore ran, he would have to contend with his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who announced this week that he, like Mr. Gore, had established a political action committee to help candidates this year. Mr. Harkin said he was skeptical of Mr. Lieberman's promise not to run if Mr. Gore does.
"Joe has said if Gore runs, he won't run," Mr. Harkin said. Asked whether he took Mr. Lieberman at his word, Mr. Harkin replied:
"Don't know. It's easy to say that now. But when the fever hits you, you don't know."
The primaries may be two years away, but the presidential contest is under way, with possible contenders traveling to important states and assembling staffs. The most aggressive have been Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, Senator Lieberman, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who made his first presidential prospecting trip into New Hampshire this weekend. 
The Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, has not taken steps toward running. But many leading Democrats are encouraging him.
In an interview, Mr. Daschle said that Mr. Gore "would be the front-runner" if he made the race and "deserves to be in the mix." But Mr. Daschle added that there would be many other formidable candidates.
Mr. Gore still has steadfast supporters who argue that he is far more popular among voters outside Washington than inside. 
"In the base of the party, there's still a great deal of support for Al Gore, and in Washington there isn't," said Mitchell Berger, a top fund-raiser for Mr. Gore in 2000 who said he would back him again. "When I worked for Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton, nobody in Washington wanted them. Currently, a similar thing is going on with Al Gore."
Steve Hildebrand, a strategist in South Dakota who ran Mr. Gore's campaign in Iowa in 2000, said: "We would be foolish to not want someone as qualified as Al Gore to serve our country. He is still the most qualified individual out there at a time when the economy is in question and international affairs are of great concern. He is still deeply beloved by activist Democrats and regular Democrats."
Indeed, Mr. Gore drew fervent ovations from the party loyalists here tonight. "I don't think there's anyone else that would make as good a leader as he would," said David R. Harper, chairman of the Macon County Democratic Party. "I think he's ready to go."
Mr. Harper's wife, Carol, said she was disappointed that Mr. Gore waited until tonight to resurface. 
In his speech, Mr. Gore conceded that "some disagreed with my choice to withdraw" from policy debates until now. But he said, "I thought it appropriate given the nature of the election."
Many Democratic strategists said the move by the Democratic Party last month to advance the primary schedule by a month in 2004 would benefit Mr. Gore, who is far better known than the other prospects. That could be particularly helpful for Mr. Gore in a large field, where he would be assured of a minimum of support, while his opponents might split the rest of the vote. 
The strategists also argued that if Mr. Gore appeared to gain steam, naysayers would happily climb back on board for his candidacy.
Still, despite all his advantages, even Mr. Gore's advisers agree that he would have a more arduous climb to the nomination than when he was vice president and had the resources of the White House and President Clinton -- albeit the baggage of Mr. Clinton as well -- at his disposal.
Mr. Gore has failed to engender deep support from many past backers. Several top strategists from 2000, including Michael Whouley, Robert Shrum and Ronald A. Klain, have been talking to other Democrats who plan to run in 2004. At a recent strategy session that fund-raisers for Mr. Gore held at Mr. K's, an expensive Chinese restaurant in downtown Washington, six people showed up.
Even among Democrats who are willing to support Mr. Gore again, there seems to be rather tepid interest in a Gore candidacy. Several people said they would back him if he ran. But they were not willing to encourage Mr. Gore to run.
Orin Kramer, an investment manager in New Jersey who was a top fund-raiser for Mr. Gore in 2000, has been eyeing other candidates. 
"Until people declare that they actually want to run for president," Mr. Kramer said, "people like myself have the liberty of waiting. It's easy for people to interpret that they're all falling off the wagon. But the process in 2000 was enormously expensive and tremendously emotionally draining. So there's a natural inclination for people to sit back and not be engaged."
But Mr. Kramer was not about to publicly distance himself from Mr. Gore. He said he was raising money for Mr. Gore's political action committee. He also said he would have traveled here for the event, "if I did not have a longstanding ticket to take my son to the Nets-Raptors game." 
Several of Mr. Gore's backers said the former vice president had been tarnished by his connection with Mr. Clinton. They contended that he might be more of his own candidate if he ran again.
"The country was against him because of Bill Clinton," said Representative Norm Dicks, a Washington Democrat who was one of Mr. Gore's most ardent backers. 
Saying he could still envision a President Gore, Mr. Dicks invoked Richard M. Nixon's comeback. "You think about Nixon, who lost in '60 and then came back and had, I wouldn't say a great presidency," Mr. Dicks said. "But he got elected twice."
Although Mr. Gore's intentions are unclear, one certainty is that he is not devoting himself full time to politics. He is a vice chairman for Metropolitan West Financial Inc., a financial services company in Los Angeles. He teaches at several universities, and he is writing a book about family with his wife, Tipper.
Mr. Gore's advisers said the first crucial step if he were to run again would be to improve -- and solidify -- his political position in Tennessee. 
Mr. Gore was the first presidential contender to lose his home state since George McGovern lost in South Dakota in 1972 and was trounced in a national landslide by Nixon.
"Obviously," Mr. Harkin said, "if he had carried his own state, he'd be president today. You can't just lose your home state, for gosh sakes."

HEADLINE: Porto Alegre Journal; 
A Leftist City Makes Money to Its Own Drummer

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Few people here were surprised when organizers of the meeting to counter the World Economic Forum in New York told the World Bank and other pillars of the global economic establishment they were not welcome. It was just another expression of anti-globalization sentiment in this socialist stronghold in southern Brazil.
 The meeting here, the World Social Forum, is an opportunity for Porto Alegre's leaders to swap ideas on containing global capitalism with representatives of the European and American left. 
 The participants run the gamut from members of Brazilian fringe groups in ragged outfits to polished members of the European Parliament. 
Olivio Dutra, a former Porto Alegre mayor who is now governor of Rio Grande do Sul State, denounced the "dehumanization" of the economy in a raucous opening speech.
This city of 1.2 million offers a complex view, though, of how the fortunes of developing countries are intertwined with international economic activity. Porto Alegre developed into a socialist center in the 1980's, when Brazil's military government was preparing to hand over power to democratically elected representatives. Its large number of organized civil servants helped the Workers Party to win control of the city.
Few places in Brazil are more enmeshed in the global economy, though.
General Motors makes compact cars here, and Dell Computers assembles PC's. Telefonica of Spain controls wireless communications. British American Tobacco produces cigarettes nearby, and John Deere assembles tractors. Porto Alegre is also home to Brazilian multinationals like Gerdau, a steel producer with plants in the United States; Taurus, a maker of handguns, and Varig, the airline.
As a result of investments by those companies, this city has the nation's lowest urban unemployment rate, though it is still high at 15.1 percent. Beyond a city center of old high-rises is an extensive system of parks and plazas. Poor districts that started as shantytowns mostly have paved roads and treated water. Crime is a concern -- gunmen were thwarted in an attempt to rob an armored car this morning in front of the building where the forum was taking place -- but it has not reached the level of larger Brazilian cities. 
"The city has little exotic appeal because we're far from the archetype of what people expect from Brazil, but it's a decent place to live and work," said Marcelo de Almeida Fleck, a researcher at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul.
Companies choose Porto Alegre because of its location as a gateway to the pampas, stretching into Argentina and Uruguay, two important markets. Another reason is a relatively well-educated and prosperous citizenry.
With its economy so dependent on interaction with the rest of the world, it is no surprise that socialist politicians here tread a fine line between vociferous critiques of globalization and subtle efforts to lure foreign investment and financing. 
Mr. Dutra learned this strategy the hard way at the start of his term as governor in 1999 when the Ford Motor Company dropped plans to build a factory in Porto Alegre after he refused to honor his predecessor's promise of more than $400 million in incentives.
The poorer northeastern state of Bahia quickly reached a deal with Ford, its 1,500 jobs went there and Mr. Dutra's popularity declined.
Since then his administration has largely focused its policies on supporting small- and medium-sized businesses and on agriculture in the interior, where state police were encouraged to avoid confrontation in land seizures by the Landless Workers Movement.
"We have tried to protect the DNA of our economy, which is not the large multinational but the small businessman and farmer," Mr. Dutra, a former bank clerk who sometimes dons traditional gaucho clothing for public events, said in an interview.
Hard-liners aligned with him have locked horns with followers of Mayor Tarso Genro of Porto Alegre, Mr. Dutra's main rival in the socialist Workers Party. Mr. Genro, a lawyer who backs a more market-friendly type of socialism, has shown an interest in challenging Mr. Dutra in the upcoming gubernatorial election.
Rio Grande do Sul, with a population of more than 10 million, has long been a Workers Party redoubt. With presidential elections this year in which the Workers Party candidate, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, is leading in the polls, the rivalry here is troubling party leaders.
Recent corruption charges against associates of Mr. Dutra involved in an effort to legalize electronic gambling have further tarnished the party's image. "The party stands a fair chance of losing here in presidential elections for the first time since 1989," said Rosane de Oliveira, political editor of Zero Hora, Porto Alegre's main newspaper. "Its support among the middle class is not what it used to be."
Serving as host to a forum that excludes the World Bank has not prevented local officials from showing pragmatism in some instances. The state government has drawn on $170 million in World Bank loans to improve roads and alleviate rural poverty. Mr. Genro's municipal administration has received $76 million from the Inter-American Development Bank to improve water sanitation in poor neighborhoods, widen roads and develop bicycle paths.
The socialists were able to secure the financing by agreeing to contain budget shortfalls. Mr. Dutra, who halted a privatization process initiated by the previous governor, has resisted pressure to raise government salaries and pensions. Mr. Genro says he has controlled city spending through "participatory budgeting," a system of close coordination with community associations.
Not everyone is convinced of the socialists' effectiveness. As a counterpoint to the World Social Forum, the Institute of Business Studies, a nonprofit organization supported by large companies, organized their own Liberty Forum here last year to discuss market-oriented strategies for dealing with social problems.
"The thinking of the left is authoritarian and stagnant," Jorge Gerdau Johannpeter, a steel executive and vocal critic of the Workers Party, said at the event. 
For others, like the 300 families from the National Housing Struggle who occupied an abandoned office building during the World Social Forum, Workers Party politicians are not radical enough. 
"There is no realistic housing policy for poor people," said Ancelmo Schwertner, one of the group's coordinators.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Andersen Hires Volcker To Lead Oversight Board
Arthur Andersen, rushing to contain the damage from attacks including those in the Enron board's report on Saturday, has hired Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, as an adviser. Mr. Volcker will lead an oversight board with a mandate to change the firm's policies and practices, Andersen's chief executive, Joseph F. Berardino, said.
 In Washington, meanwhile, the House and Senate have a full week of hearings on the collapse of Enron. Section A. 

$1 Billion Settlement Over Implants
Europe's biggest orthopedics maker, Sulzer Medica, has agreed to a $1 billion settlement in an effort to avoid a long legal battle with thousands of United States patients who received defective hip and knee implants. C2.

A New Test for Internet Offerings
A new stock offering by Paypal, which provides a payment system for goods and services bought over the Internet, should give some sign of whether investors have forgiven Internet investments. Adding to the intrigue is that Paypal at once embodies elements that attracted rabid Internet investors as well as those that drove investors away screaming. New Economy. C4.

Cray and Dell in 3-Year Agreement
Cray, the maker of supercomputers, plans to announce a deal today to resell smaller computers by Dell that can be linked into clusters that solve complex problems. With the three-year deal, Dell hopes to build more of a presence in high-performance computing. C8.

New Urgency for Hynix Negotiations
Hynix Semiconductor of South Korea faces more negotiations in what has turned into a contest between Micron Technology of Boise, Idaho, and Infineon Technologies of Germany, over the sale of its memory chip unit. C6.

The Scion vs. the Board at Hewlett
The dispute over Hewlett-Packard's plan to buy Compaq tends to be personalized as a confrontation of two individuals: Carleton S. Fiorina pitted against Walter B. Hewlett. But the real break is between Mr. Hewlett, a son of the co-founder and a director of Hewlett-Packard, and the rest of the board. C4.

NBC West Coast President to Leave
Scott M. Sassa, the president of NBC's West Coast division, will leave his position in June, several NBC executives said. The move has been expected for some time. C8.

Viacom Executives in a United Front
The joint appearance of Mel Karmazin and his guest, Sumner M. Redstone, left, at a dinner last Thursday for about 40 institutional investors was clearly intended as a counterpoint to a week of reports in the news media about the friction between the two top executives of Viacom. It came a day after the Viacom board urged them to end their personal conflict for the good of the company. C7.

Forks in the Road After Journalism
Mark H. Willes, the former chief executive of Times Mirror and Kathryn M. Downing, the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times, have emerged with new careers. He has been working since June in Honolulu, leading a group of 200 Mormon missionaries. She has been accepted to an intensive new program that will train her to be superintendent of an urban school district. C7.

WebMD's Stock Comes Back a Bit
After 15 months of turnaround therapy administered by Martin J. Wygod, who took over WebMD from its founders, the stock price has rebounded somewhat. Market Place. C5.

HEADLINE: McGreevey Struggles to Cope With a Budget Shortfall He Inherited 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Across-the-board budget cuts, the layoff of more than 1,000 state workers and a freeze in state aid to New Jersey cities and towns announced during Gov. James E. McGreevey's first two weeks on the job have suggested that much of his first year in office will be defined by the state deficit.
 But despite all the publicity that Mr. McGreevey's belt-tightening has generated, the cuts announced so far will save less than $200 million -- roughly one-fifteenth of the deficit he must eliminate by June 30. 
 So as Mr. McGreevey tries to fix this year's $2.9 billion budget gap and cope with next year's shortfall -- which may reach $6 billion -- he must now confront three uncomfortable and politically volatile options: increased borrowing, increased taxes or huge layoffs and program cuts. 
Mr. McGreevey has refused to discuss details of his budget plan before he addresses a joint session of the State Legislature on Feb. 11. But finding short-term solutions may be easier than finding long-term ones: Wall Street financial analysts and Mr. McGreevey's budget advisers say there is a reasonable chance he may be able to solve this year's problem without having to resort to any of those measures. The next year's budget is a different story.
New Jersey grew so prosperous during the past decade, when the pharmaceutical industry flourished and the Wall Street boom enriched the state's 45,000 residents who work in financial services, that several of the state's special revenue funds now have hundreds of millions of dollars in reserve. Mr. McGreevey's budget team is poring over the treasury records of all 80 of the funds, and several, like the unclaimed personal property trust fund and the retired employees health care fund, are likely to be tapped to close this year's deficit, administration officials say.
The governor may also seek to divert contributions from the unemployment insurance fund to pay for the state's Family Care program for low-income families. Such a move might allow him to cut $300 million or more from expenditures.
But if Mr. McGreevey uses those one-shot solutions now, they will not be available for the budget year that begins on July 1, thereby depriving him of easy answers. That means the effort to close next year's budget gap will involve more difficult choices, and explains why Mr. McGreevey has taken so much trouble to remind the public that he inherited the deficit from Republicans.
His options are further limited by his own words. Mindful that New Jersey's last Democratic governor, Jim Florio, was run from office for pushing a steep tax increase, Mr. McGreevey made a campaign promise not to raise taxes. He has been also been unrelenting in his criticism of former Gov. Christie Whitman for increasing state debt, calling it "irresponsible" and "immoral."
Republicans were quick to condemn Mr. McGreevey last week when he acknowledged that he planned to authorize the state to issue bonds against its part of the tobacco settlement. By issuing a tobacco bond, New Jersey will be able to quickly recoup part of the $7 billion the state is scheduled to be paid over the next 25 years, but at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars in interest.
Counting the proceeds from that proposed bond issue, Mr. McGreevey's budget team has tentatively identified possible ways to bridge about two-thirds of next year's $6 billion gap, administration officials said on Friday. But the challenge of getting those measures through the State Legislature, and finding an additional $2 billion in revenues or spending cuts, will test Mr. McGreevey's skill at cutting both budgets and deals, according to municipal finance experts.
"We're soon going to see the painful decisions," said Richard Marino, an analyst for the bond rating agency Standard & Poor's. "One way or the other, there's going to have to be agreement on what direction to go and what are the appropriate spending levels."
If the last week is any indication, the road to any such agreement will be bumpy. Mr. McGreevey last week escalated his criticism of Republicans, calling their budgets "fraudulent" and comparing them to the C.E.O.'s of Enron, who have been accused of concealing their company's frail financial condition before it went bankrupt. Administration officials said they were simply keeping the public informed about the dire financial information Mr. McGreevey discovered upon taking office.
"It's important to explain to the public the scope of the problem, a problem of historic proportions," said Jo Astrid Glading, the governor's chief of policy and communication. "And explaining how we got here is part of that."
Republicans, from legislators to former Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, strenuously deny the suggestion that they misled the public or ignored warning signs about an imminent decline in tax revenues. They blame the deficit on the combined effect of the national recession and repercussions of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
But even many of those who disagree with Mr. McGreevey acknowledge that it is politically shrewd for the governor to remind people that he did not create the budget problem he is now scrambling to solve.
"He's laying the groundwork for doing something unpopular and wanting to shift the blame for it," said Larry Weitzner, a Republican political consultant.
The questions remaining are how many unpopular things Mr. McGreevey will be compelled to do and which ones he will choose.
The administration is considering several low-impact measures to increase revenues. By refinancing New Jersey's debt, Mr. McGreevey can take advantage of the current low interest rates and cut the state's debt service costs. An increase in a variety of fees the state charges individuals and businesses could also bring tens of millions of additional dollars to the state treasury.
The administration may also call for a tax amnesty. Although Mr. McGreevey has expressed reservations about the idea in the past, he has grudgingly begun considering it, his staff members say, because the plan could raise more than $200 million.
The governor's advisers are also reviewing a plan to encourage New Jersey's Blue Cross to privatize, as it has in several other states, because the company would then be obligated to spend $40 million on health care, thereby reducing the state's health care costs.
While those initiatives will not come close to fixing next year's $6 billion shortfall, administration officials say Mr. McGreevey is committed to holding firm on his no-tax-increase pledge, although he recently revised that promise by saying that he was referring only to the income and sales taxes. New Jersey imposes more than 30 taxes.
Despite persistent reports to the contrary, the administration is not currently considering any possible increase in the gasoline tax, Mr. McGreevey's aides said.
There are, however, serious discussions under way about possibly suspending, or significantly reducing, the New Jersey Saver property tax rebate program, which is scheduled to cost nearly $1 billion next year, officials said. Any such move would probably encounter stiff resistance from Republicans. New Jersey's property taxes are among the highest in the nation, and Mr. McGreevey's decision not to increase aid to municipalities is all but certain to raise levies in some communities.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Who Can Part The Red Tape? Who Knows?

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
HERE it is, the most widely whispered line of the month: "We need a Moses."
 "We" is New York City; Moses is Robert, the domineering master builder from a less democratic era in the city's history. 
 Mr. Moses comes to mind increasingly as New Yorkers look to the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site and wonder how it will ever be accomplished, given clashing agendas and a large and ever-growing cast of characters, not one of them a leader with the kind of power and authority it will take to bring order to fragmentation, vision to necessity. 
A latter-day Moses could do it -- a sensitive Moses, if that is not a contradiction in terms -- with the vision to realize that there is more at stake than constructing an appropriate memorial and putting up new buildings. There is the larger task of reinventing a strategic section of the city.
"This is a major opportunity for the city to engage in planning on a scale that has only been matched a few times in our history," says Kenneth T. Jackson, a Columbia University historian who is president of the New-York Historical Society. "I think of the grid in 1811, which affects the whole future of the city because that, in a sense, sets up Union Square, Madison Square, Times Square -- because that's where Broadway crosses the avenues.
"I think of the laying out of Central Park. I think of Lincoln Center and, in some ways, the United Nations. Whether you like them or don't like them, you can certainly see they have influenced people's lives for at least a half-century or longer."
"WTC: Monument," a collaboration between the Skyscraper Museum and the Historical Society that is set to open tomorrow at the society on West 77th Street, is a reminder of the more phantasmagoric plans in the 1960's for Lower Manhattan. One model shows elaborate clover-leafed exits from the Brooklyn Bridge, underground highways, a green, traffic-free mall surrounding City Hall, the Municipal Building and Tweed Court traffic-free mall surrounding City Hall, the Municipal Building and Tweed Courthouse, and the Moses proposal for a Lower Manhattan expressway running across Broome Street and connecting the Holland Tunnel with the Williamsburg and Manhattan Bridges.
That plan was never built, and the expressway, which would have destroyed neighborhoods, was fiercely opposed and ultimately discredited. But the model, along with others in the exhibit depicting early versions of the trade center site and Battery Park City, sure showed vision.
NOBODY wants a Lower Manhattan Expressway, but people were thinking big," Mr. Jackson said. "If we miss this opportunity, we won't get it again. It's like Central Park. If they'd waited 25 years, it would have been too late. There are moments in time when you have to act."
It's not as if there aren't imaginative ideas around. Architects and planners are talking about restoring Greenwich and maybe Fulton Streets, interrupted by the trade center, about building more housing and improving mass transit beyond restoring the destroyed subway and PATH stations. The financial district has long suffered from inaccessibility compared to Midtown. Now, says Daniel Doctoroff, deputy mayor for economic development, might be the time to fix the problem by linking the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North to Lower Manhattan; Metro-North would be extended from Grand Central Terminal, and the Long Island from the Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn.
"It's something that deserves serious discussion," Mr. Doctoroff said. "Everyone agrees we have to think more broadly about transportation and zoning."
But who makes the decisions when so many people are involved? Consider the list so far: Survivors of the victims of Sept. 11; Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg; the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the land; Larry A. Silverstein, who bought control of the trade center complex two months before the attack and is already planning to rebuild 7 World Trade Center; the 11 members of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, 7 appointed by Mr. Pataki, among them its chairman, 79-year-old John C. Whitehead, and 4 by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani; an advisory panel to the development corporation that includes several state and city politicians; more advisory panels to be appointed by Mr. Whitehead; neighborhood representatives; and assorted interested parties from editorial boards to academicians.
Robert Moses in his prime would have pretty much ignored all those players and done as he wished. Nobody would defend that today. But more than a few New Yorkers are asking if there is something halfway between a willful master builder and decision (or indecision) by committee.

HEADLINE: Out Here, Doubt Springs Eternal; 
Another Decade, Another Plan For Redeveloping Rockaways

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
On a Friday afternoon in the spring of 1964, Peggy and Albert Thomas stood on Beach 66th Street in Queens and watched, heartbroken, as a wrecking ball demolished their first home, the big white house with a wraparound porch.
 The Thomases were among the thousands of people whose houses and beachside bungalows were condemned and then torn down in the 1960's, as the city promised to rebuild a proud but decaying stretch of the Rockaway Peninsula. 
 But decades passed, and plan after plan for what is the city's largest tract of undeveloped waterfront land was drawn up and then abandoned. Now, almost 40 years after the houses were leveled, 308 acres in a neighborhood called Arverne remain empty, except for tumbleweeds and trash, prostitutes and wild dogs.
"It was a utopia out here," Mrs. Thomas, 65, said recently, standing on the vacant lot where her home once stood, not far from the housing project where she has lived since the house was razed. "But they came along, and they decided to destroy the Rockaways." 
In December, city officials unveiled a new plan to develop part of Arverne, a $350 million, 2,300-unit housing development called Arverne by the Sea, with a school, a day care center and a small shopping mall. The project is to be built on about 100 acres by a Long Island developer, Benjamin-Beechwood. Construction is scheduled to begin in June, and discussions are under way about what to do with the remaining 200 acres of Arverne, with a meeting scheduled for this week between Rockaway officials and the Bloomberg administration.
The project, described on the developer's Web site as "The Dawn of a New Day," is the scaled-down reincarnation of an earlier plan to develop all 308 acres, which collapsed when the real estate market crashed in the late 1980's and the developer, Forest City Ratner Companies, pulled out.
Despite the feeling among many people on the peninsula that the land is jinxed, city and state officials say they are confident that the project will move forward and that the 11-mile Rockaway Peninsula is on the threshold of fundamental change.
They say the plan, which would move ahead in phases, is less ambitious and more realistic than previous ones. And this time, they say, Rockaway, which is now represented for the first time by elected officials from the peninsula who are in Congress and on the City Council, is not going to fall off the radar screen.
Audrey I. Pheffer, a longtime state assemblywoman has lived for 45 years in Far Rockaway, on the peninsula's eastern end, which is home to some of the city's most destitute residents. "Every time you say something is going to happen in Arverne, people laugh," she said. "This time I believe it -- well, I believed it every other time, too -- but I've been here a long time, and I see real change. I couldn't have told you that 10 years ago."
But as often as some Rockawayites, as they call themselves, sound optimistic, others agree with Jean Berrios, a resident of the sprawling Edgemere Houses in Arverne, considered by many to be the roughest housing project on the peninsula.
"Rockaway is dying," said Mrs. Berrios, who moved into Edgemere in 1969, after her house near the beach was torn down. "We have been promised so many things that I can't even list them. We have no stores. Nobody invests here. We don't have a check-cashing place. Can you imagine? No place to cash a check."
Arverne is a neighborhood of 15,000 people on a peninsula of 110,000. Above it, between the Atlantic Ocean and Jamaica Bay, are the hulking housing projects -- the Edgemere and Arverne Houses. In all, there are more than 5,000 units of public housing on the eastern end of the peninsula, one of the city's highest concentrations of public housing.
The vacant land, owned by the city, made headlines in December when a pack of wild dogs attacked two joggers on the Boardwalk in Arverne, critically injuring a 74-year-old man. Stray dogs, along with mosquitoes that breed in the swamps near the bay, remain a major problem.
Residents say they have fought for years for more aggressive dog-catching and pesticide-spraying programs, saying these problems have come to symbolize the longstanding neglect of the eastern end of the peninsula. Unemployment is as high as 30 percent in some neighborhoods there, one in four people receive public assistance and the public schools are among the worst in the city.
There are no major supermarkets in Arverne. Most residents take one or two buses or a taxi to Beach 116th Street on the west end, or they do their grocery shopping on Long Island. Across the peninsula, residents complain about the dearth of major stores.
Transportation ranks as one of the residents' greatest concerns and was seen as a major obstacle to at least one of the grander plans for Arverne, the $1.2 billion Destination Technodome, which included a roller coaster, indoor ski slope and about 20,000 permanent jobs for Rockaway residents. The only subway that stops in Rockaway, the A train, takes at least an hour to reach Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. Various plans for ferries to Manhattan have fallen through, and the Long Island Rail Road line that once ran between Rockaway and Manhattan was abandoned decades ago.
Arverne, a popular resort for beachgoers in the late 1800's and early 1900's, was condemned and cleared under a federal urban renewal plan that was intended to help the city rebuild the neighborhood from scratch.
Between the Depression and the 1960's, as the entire Rockaway Peninsula began to lose its lure as a tourist destination, Arverne deteriorated badly, historians say.
After the houses were razed, factories and other major employers, including companies that made paper, curtains and bicycles, left the peninsula. The movie theaters and department stores that had once bustled in Far Rockaway were shuttered, too, leaving almost every block either empty or lined with boarded-up buildings.
The decline of the east end was also the beginning of a deep economic and racial divide on the Rockaway Peninsula, with largely white, middle- and upper-class people living on the west end and largely poor black and Hispanic people living on the east, though the area has a few affluent enclaves. 
Many residents consider the Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge, which connects the peninsula and mainland Queens at about the middle of the Rockaways, as a kind of Mason-Dixon line.
Some of the contrasts between the two ends are stark. There is the gated community of Breezy Point, with a pristine private beach, and million-dollar homes in Neponsit. In Arverne and Far Rockaway, there are the housing projects, soup kitchens and crumbling shanties. Public School 114, in Belle Harbor, is ranked as one of the top city schools. About four miles away, in Arverne, Public School 42 ranks at the bottom.
And some people view what happened to Arverne -- or what did not happen -- as a major factor in the east-west division, saying that if there were anything there to bring the two ends together, there might be a semblance of unity. 
"You have to have the experience of rubbing elbows," said the Rev. Sean G. Ogle, until recently the pastor of St. Mary Star of the Sea, a Roman Catholic parish in Far Rockaway. "It's sad to see how many people say they've never been to the other end. And I do think that the hole in the middle of the peninsula generates the separateness."
(The west end of the peninsula, where many firefighters and police officers live, mostly in Breezy Point and Belle Harbor, has had its own share of troubles in recent months. Almost 100 residents from the west end lost their lives in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, and two months later, an American Airlines jet crashed into a residential block of Belle Harbor, killing all 260 on board and 5 people on the ground.)
The latest development plan has stirred some criticism from Arverne residents, who say that building housing -- with homes for middle-income buyers and expected to be priced from $250,000 to $500,000 -- will do little to ease the troubles of the surrounding neighborhood.
"Just to have new homes here is not going to do it," said Desmond Bailey, president of the Arverne Civic Association, a contractor who said he sends his two youngest children to a private school in Brooklyn because the neighborhood elementary school is so troubled.
Officials involved in negotiations over income requirements for potential residents of Arverne by the Sea say a debate is brewing over whether to provide subsidies for low-income home buyers from the neighborhood or, in order to bring more working families and middle-class people into the neighborhood, restrict the development to households with an annual income of $50,000 or more.
But even among the loudest skeptics, there is a stronger sense of optimism about Arverne than most people can remember feeling.
Since the Technodome project was declared dead last year, the political landscape has changed, small developers are building -- and quickly selling -- one- and two-family houses in Arverne and other neighborhoods, and community and civic groups have been gathering to discuss their stake in development plans.
Representative Gregory W. Meeks, who in 1998 succeeded the Rev. Floyd H. Flake in the Congressional district that represents southeastern Queens and the Rockaways, is from Far Rockaway. James Saunders Jr., a newly elected city councilman, lives in Arverne and is chairman of the Council's economic development committee.
"There's definitely a new sheriff in town," said Curtis L. Archer, who took over in 1998 as executive director of the troubled Rockaway Development and Revitalization Corporation, the peninsula's only economic development group.
Mr. Saunders, one of those scheduled to meet with Bloomberg administration officials this week to discuss the fate of Arverne, said, "Everything you can do wrong has been done here." But, he added, the latest plan "will go forward precisely because so many others have failed."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: NOTEBOOK; 
One Hand Upholding The Law

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
A red minivan had lurched east across Fifth Avenue into the shadow of St. Patrick's Cathedral, which was lighted by the moon and hundreds of lights directed by the police.
 For a moment, it seemed as if the van would not stop. But it came to a halt in front of the raised hand of Police Officer Tell Beharry on Friday night. 
 A woman lowered the van's tinted window and spoke with all the breathless urgency of an underling trying to rush her boss to an important meeting. "I have the prime minister of Serbia in the car," she said. "Please let us through." 
For a time, all the millions being spent on security for the five-day World Economic Forum came down to Officer Beharry, 25 and still in the Police Academy. He did not flinch, consulted his superiors and spoke in a sparse, courteous tone.
Then the van pulled to the side and its occupants got out, wrapping coats around their credential-clad bodies. It became evident that Zoran Djindjic, the prime minister of Serbia, was being made to walk the two blocks to the Waldorf-Astoria. 
"I am the only dignitary here in New York who is without bodyguards," Mr. Djindjic said in broken English, trying to put the best face on an embarrassing moment. "I don't have anything to fear and because of that I am walking free."
As for Officer Beharry, he was glad he didn't just submit under pressure, even when confronted by a world leader. "Safety is paramount," his superiors had told him.

It's Not 1968 San Francisco
Did the protesters outside the Waldorf-Astoria accomplish anything? Did the world leaders notice them? Or have their ideas been co-opted by the mainstream? Those questions, and others, were on the minds of some inside the hotel.
"Somehow, the protesters are in this phase of being more interested in being able to complain than to help," said Jaron Z. Lanier, a computer scientist from TriBeCa and a forum participant who said he holds protests as one of the most precious parts of the American tradition.
"The world inside is so much more like the way the people on the outside wish it would be than they realize," Mr. Lanier said yesterday, brushing his dreadlocks from his face. "This meeting has really opened up."
The current anarchists do not realize their own importance, Mr. Lanier said. They have not articulated a clear point of view.
"You have to do the work of thinking about what to do," he said. "I just feel like this is a lazy movement. It is sort of like saying, 'We don't like it and it's not our job to figure out what to do. Instead, it's your job to make us happy.' It's like little kids and it really bothers me. This is totally different than other protest movements."
Oscar Holenweger, the president of Tempus Private Bank Ltd., in Switzerland, looked over the thousands of protesters on Park Avenue Saturday and shook his head.
"I protested against the Vietnam War as a student in 1968, in San Francisco," Mr. Holenweger, 56, said. "There we had a cause."

High Finance: A Few Bucks
Money, it seems, quickly runs short when you are a police officer assigned around the Waldorf. 
Take Officer Michael Fantroy, 32, annual earnings $36,000. Officer Fantroy was good and hungry yesterday when he went inside the Delmonico delicatessen. He studied the soda case, picked up a one-liter bottle of Mountain Dew but put it back. Then he picked it up again. "I had a 20 this morning," he said. "I got four kids and a wife and a mortgage to pay. I had breakfast; now I have a 10."
All weekend, the police have heard protesters rail against such global issues as third world debt, international capitalism and the pillaging of rain forests by the rich. It was small comfort for them to know that some also protested the officers' pay, or lack of it. One of those was Frank Lang, 42, a sculptor from the Lower East Side, who stood in the throng Saturday and held a homemade sign that read, "More pay for NYPD."
"Police in suburbs get at least 20 percent more pay than police in the city, and that doesn't seem fair to me," Mr. Lang said. "Mayor Mike could give them a raise right out of his own pocket, not to mention all those people in the Waldorf."
Officer Fantroy, who has five years on the job and usually patrols the subways in Queens, bought a ham and cheese sandwich and the soda. Maybe, he said, he never should have left his $47,000-a-year job at the post office. If the police do not get a raise soon, he may have to resign, he said.
"I still got $2," he said, stuffing his change into a pocket. It was 11 a.m., eight hours before his shift ended. Maybe he could get coffee later.

HEADLINE: 'Saving' Wild Salmon's Bucket-Born Cousins 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ALSEA, Ore., Jan. 30 

 BODY:
There are wild salmon in rivers across the Pacific Northwest, fish that spawn in gravel beds and grow in the rushing fresh water. Then they head deep into the Pacific Ocean before journeying back to spawn -- and die -- in the streams where they were born.
 There are also salmon that complete a similar voyage, though they are born in and return to a different place, a government-run hatchery. Spawned in plastic pails, raised in concrete pools, they are the majority in many Northwestern rivers now, as their wild cousins battle extinction. 
 But because the wild and hatchery salmon are of the same species, they are at the heart of a legal battle over the issue of extinction, and of just how much should be done to protect and restore the habitat that wild salmon need to spawn. The question is this: What is the difference between wild fish and hatchery ones? 
Absolutely none, say some critics of the Endangered Species Act, who contend that federal fish regulators have wrongly looked only at the condition of the wild salmon to determine whether fish in rivers like the Alsea, here in the Oregon coastal range, should be considered threatened. A federal judge largely agrees with them, ruling in September that regulators "arbitrarily and capriciously" treated the Alsea's wild and hatchery salmon differently when listing the wild fish as threatened.
The ruling, by Judge Michael R. Hogan of Federal District Court in Eugene, Ore., is being appealed. But it has prompted the Bush administration to announce a thorough review of the listings for two dozen groups of Pacific salmon and steelhead (another kind of fish, capable of returning to sea after spawning) in other Western rivers and to consider new rules that would factor in the strength of hatchery stock in designating species as endangered.
Meanwhile, the property-rights group that prevailed in the first round of the fight here is opening a new front this coming week, filing a lawsuit to block protections for fish in the Klamath River basin, where enraged farmers were denied irrigation water last summer to protect the wild fish there. The group's initial suit was intended to overturn logging restrictions that had been put in place to safeguard the salmon.
Environmental groups say that if the ruling is upheld, it could fundamentally alter the intent of the Endangered Species Act.
"It is supposed to protect creatures in their natural habitat, in the wild," said Patti Goldman, a lawyer for Earthjustice, an environmental group involved in the lawsuit.
"Otherwise," Ms. Goldman said, "it's like we're saying that lions in zoos are exactly the same as lions in the Serengeti."
Her opponents are happy to use the same analogy.
"That just seems to make our argument, because they're both lions," said Russell C. Brooks, a lawyer for the Pacific Legal Foundation, a private group that litigates on behalf of property rights. "Whoever is making this statement, I'd certainly challenge them to go stick their head in the lion cage in the zoo, because that lion is just as wild as the lion in the jungle. It's the same species."
Indeed, the two types of coho salmon at issue here are the same species, capable of interbreeding when a hatchery fish veers into the habitat of a wild fish, or vice versa. Nevertheless, the growing reliance on hatchery fish raises questions about the long-term health of the salmon population. Hatchery fish are more genetically similar to each other, and they are also more prone to mass outbreaks of disease.
At the Alsea fish hatchery here, run by the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, where nearly half a million fish are raised each year, the hatchers are quick to point out that hatchery fish were never intended to replace the wild fish.
"They can complement, but they can't replace wild fish," explained Tim Schamber, the hatchery manager, taking a break the other day from harvesting eggs from winter steelhead, a magnificent gray fish with a shimmering rainbow collection of colors in its scales.
"You can run into a real genetic bottleneck for future fisheries if you do that," Mr. Schamber said, returning to squeezing and pumping fish with air to force the eggs, 3,000 per average female, into a bucket.
But because hatchery fish augment the wild fish and in some cases wind up breeding with them -- the offspring are called "strays" -- it is difficult to make precise biological and physical distinctions between them. For that reason, the National Marine Fisheries Service said Judge Hogan's ruling raised a valid point in questioning why the two fish categories are treated differently.
"The hatchery fish certainly have a role in recovery, and a part to play in an E.S.A. listing," said Brian Gorman, a spokesman for the service, referring to the Endangered Species Act. "It's time that we articulate what the proper role of hatchery fish is when we make a listing."
David Bayles, conservation director for Pacific Rivers Council, an environmental group based in Eugene that is involved in the legal battle, said, "The Endangered Species Act was designed to protect habitat for wild fish, not concrete pools for man-made salmon." 
"In a wild salmon stream, it's survival of the fittest," Mr. Bayles said. "In a hatchery situation, everybody survives, and ultimately you're producing a lot of unfit fish."
But Mr. Brooks, the Pacific Legal Foundation lawyer, said such protections amounted to a "political agenda" that had brought economic pain.
"Our rivers and streams are teeming with salmon," Mr. Brooks said, "yet farmers have been allowed to go bankrupt, businesses are closing and lives are being destroyed while government officials explain away listing fish that really aren't endangered at all."
Among fisheries biologists, there is virtually no support for making hatchery fish the sole source for a river, though in some places, including the Snake River in Idaho and Washington, the returning numbers of wild salmon are so small that hatcheries are the dominant provider of some types of salmon. However, biologists differ on just how much of a role the hatcheries should play.
T. Charley Dewberry, a restoration ecologist, has been studying salmon in Knowles Creek, on the western slope of the Oregon coast range near here, for 20 years. His efforts to restore the salmon habitat have been financed by the national Forest Service, private timber companies and Pacific Rivers Council.
Studying schools of juvenile wild salmon the other day, Mr. Dewberry pointed to areas where logjams had helped create the shady, protected areas where they like to spawn. Wild coho salmon populations in the Oregon coast area are at less than 5 percent of what they were in 1900, when more than a million fish returned to spawn each year, according to the Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations.
Hatcheries have been around for more than 100 years and have a role to play, Mr. Dewberry said. But the long-term aim, he said, should be to restore most rivers and their ecosystems to a condition in which wild salmon can thrive on their own.
"We've got a patient in cardiac arrest, and that's what the coho situation is," he said. "So they're on a heart machine right now. But the goal is not to keep your patient on the machine. The goal should be to get the patient off the machine."
