HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE STREETS; 
So Long New York, and Thanks for a Mostly Well-Ordered Bash

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
The World Economic Forum closed its five-day conference yesterday afternoon with panel discussions on things like "recommended priorities to reconcile environmental and development agendas" and the "psychosocial factors on health and healing." Then came one final cocktail reception, and that was it.
 Adios. Au revoir. Farewell, city that is like a big apple. 
 As for how well New York managed an event that brought together 3,000 world leaders and corporate executives, attracted 7,000 or so protesters, and created widespread apprehension about the potential for violent cultural clashes in the streets, consider:
Number of buildings vandalized -- one.
Number of protesters charged with crimes of violence -- zero.
In the end, the elite conference and the various street protests that it spawned went off so smoothly that -- aside from some traffic inconveniences, a few minor tussles, and the temporary transformation of Midtown into a police state -- the lives of most city residents were unaffected. Over five days, the event created tens of millions of dollars in revenue for the city, while just 201 people were arrested, all but one charged with disorderly conduct or some other standard, protest-related misdemeanor.
The lack of serious incident also seemed to provide a response to a question that accompanied the opening of the conference last week, namely: Would swarms of protesters contribute to the lingering sense of vulnerability in a city still recovering from the terrorist attack of Sept. 11? 
The answer, it seemed, was no. Not with more than 4,000 police officers on foot, on horseback, on bicycles, and in helicopters, anticipating and containing every move by the handful of protesters interested in wreaking havoc. And, according to demonstration organizers, not with the general good will most protesters carried with their placards and puppets.
"It certainly was a big test for New York City," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. He said that the city had passed that test, and that the weekend had been an economic and public-relations success -- particularly given that protests at past economic conferences in other cities had been marred by violence.
"In terms of sending a message, in terms of helping us in soliciting other events going into the future, all you've got to do is look at what happened when the World Economic Forum was elsewhere," he said, and "compare it to what happened in New York."
It may be unfair to compare last weekend's events with the conferences held in other cities. Fewer than 10,000 demonstrators came to New York; some 50,000 came to Seattle in 1999, and more than 100,000 came to Genoa last year. In addition, New York's police officials were able to develop pre-emptive strategies based on the illegal tactics used by some protesters in other cities.
The Police Department's level of preparedness was in evidence throughout the forum's five days. Beyond creating a heavily guarded frozen zone around the Waldorf-Astoria, where the conference was held, the police seemed psychic in their ability to pounce at the moment that an expression of free speech morphed into a criminal act.
They arrested 27 people at the tail end of a protest parade on Saturday, based on what they said was solid information that those particular demonstrators were about to attack the police and storm the Plaza Hotel. Early Sunday afternoon, they emerged from seemingly nowhere to put an end to a raucous, secretly planned rally in the East Village, arresting 87 people. And later that afternoon, the moment that someone smashed an apartment building's windows on the Upper East Side, the police wrestled a suspect to the ground and later arrested an additional 60 or so people for blocking sidewalks.
Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer for protesters who helped negotiate the logistics for Saturday's rally, generally praised the Police Department for working with the demonstrators. "For the most part there were very few lines drawn in the sand," he said. "And the tone the police took was: we want this to work."
But Mr. Kuby said that credit should also go to the organizers of the protests who worked hard to keep things vocal -- but legal and safe. On Saturday, he said, some protesters became frustrated with delays in the march down Lexington Avenue and were agitating for a massive sit-down, but organizers "made a conscious decision not to do that."
All told, more than 70 events, often attended by heads of state, were held at locations around the city; among them were a dinner for 2,000 guests at the New York Stock Exchange in Lower Manhattan and a Sunday-morning prayer service at the ruins of the World Trade Center. In addition, there were 16 scheduled protests over the five days, including an all-day rally attended by 7,000 people.
And of the 201 people arrested, only one stood out. Sherman Austin, 18, was originally charged with disorderly conduct and unlawful assembly after being arrested during Saturday's rally. But Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, said that the F.B.I. had been interested in a Web site of Mr. Austin's that gave bomb-making instructions and that a recent search of his mother's home in California had found bomb-making materials.
The police commissioner also said that Mr. Austin would soon be facing a federal charge of placing bomb-making information on the Internet and that the investigation was continuing.
"I believe that our hard work has paid off," Mr. Kelly said. "The arrests that were made were done in a professional manner; there were no serious injuries to protesters or to the police."
As for the cost of deploying so many police officers for so long, Mr. Kelly said that the overtime bill would run into several million dollars. But he echoed the position of Mr. Bloomberg in saying that it was "certainly money well spent."
Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of the city's tourism board, NYC & Company, estimated that the conference, "at a bare minimum," had generated $100 million in revenue for the city. She said that she based this estimate in part on hearing of how the conference's guests were spending lavishly at the city's exclusive shops and restaurants.
"This is a crowd that pumped a lot of money into the entire economy," she said.
But not everyone was at the receiving end of that pump. Take the owners of businesses on the East Side that wound up being in the restricted zone that the police established around the Waldorf. Several of them said that they had lost out on tens of thousands of dollars.
"The customers see the barricades and they go somewhere else," explained Silvio Gamba, the sharply dressed owner of the Cinquanta Restaurant, at 50 East 50th St. "Look at my reservation book. Today we have 2 people; last Monday we had 40 people for lunch. Last Saturday we did 140 covers for dinner; this Saturday we were closed."
Not only did he have to throw out $2,000 worth of fresh fish, Mr. Gamba said, but one of his waiters "told me this morning that the police horses were urinating on the sidewalk in front of our restaurant."
Such is life in the city that is like a big apple.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: THE PROTESTERS; 
Mostly Pleased, but Knowing Few Heard Their Message

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
They came, they marched, they chanted (and a few landed in jail). But as the last of the rallies and teach-ins petered out yesterday afternoon, the demonstrators who came to New York to rail against the World Economic Forum expressed exhilaration, vindication and yet frustration, saying that their cause had produced larger-than-expected crowds and had defied predictions of violence -- but that their voices had fallen on largely indifferent ears.
 Still, after the ugly confrontations in Seattle and Genoa, Italy, organizers said that events in New York represented a turning point for a movement that has been so strongly associated with televised images of riot police and tear gas. 
 "I think we showed that we are peaceful, and that even when the police try to intimidate us, we will still come out in large numbers," said Starhawk, 50, a San Francisco woman who led a pagan ceremony in Washington Square Park over the weekend that drew as many officers as participants. 
Exactly how many people took to the streets was unclear. The Police Department estimated that 7,000 people made their way from Central Park to the Waldorf-Astoria in Midtown on Saturday. Organizers said the crowd was closer to 25,000 and complained that the lower number was an attempt to discount their power and their message.
In many ways, the dueling attendance figures were emblematic of the tensions between marchers and the police. Protest organizers said their rights had been trampled by overzealous officers -- that groups of demonstrators had been held for more than 30 hours without food and water. Lawyers who had helped get the necessary permits complained that public assembly guarantees were not always honored. Police officials countered that unruly provocateurs had sparked a handful of confrontations that led to the arrests of 201 people.
While the marches and rallies drew plenty of attention from journalists, the organizers said the attention was the wrong kind. Most press accounts focused on security concerns and the potential for violence, they said, leaving little room for explanations of why people were protesting in the first place.
"The news is not the protesters or the police," said Antonia Juhasz, an organizer with the San Francisco-based International Forum on Globalization. "The news should have been what issues brought us to the streets. The coverage was just appalling."
But they acknowledged that for many reporters on deadline, the panoply and complexity of issues was too much for a simple sound bite.
The collection of causes and protesters was wide: groups as disparate as Save the Redwoods/Boycott the Gap Campaign, the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, Queers for Racial and Economic Justice, the Pagan Cluster and even the Earth and Animal Liberation Coalition attended. They seem united by a sense that many world problems can be traced to a profit-hungry corporate elite.
For many, the convergence of so many people -- many of them young, some of them stooped and wrinkled -- was inspiring. Hundreds of New Yorkers opened their homes to strangers and many people, moved by the impassioned words of advocates, took to the streets, some for the first time.
Until last Saturday, Goldie Weissman, 74, a retired teacher from New Jersey, had not been to a demonstration in more than three decades. Why did she come? "All I know is that the free-market system has not saved the world as promised," she said. "I'm not anti-capitalist, but we've got to find a better way to bring about less suffering."
Beth Orem, a nurse practitioner who lives on the Upper West Side, had a similar awakening. Until recently, she said, she had no idea what the term globalization meant.
"Seattle was definitely a wake-up call," said Ms. Orem, 48, the mother of two teenagers. "I didn't even know what the World Trade Organization was." But she quickly learned, plowing through books that convinced her that the growing reach of corporations was leading to "a grotesque and dangerous polarization and inequality around the world."
"I came to realize that there had been a sea change in the way the world is governed," she said, "and I knew that corporations have so much to do with it."
Last Thursday, Ms. Orem welcomed nine people from Minnesota, Chicago and Kansas City to her cramped apartment, and on Saturday all of them, including her children, joined the protests. It was an enlightening day, she said, but also depressing. "When I left the protests and I got beyond Park Avenue, life was going on as normal," she said. "In fact people seemed annoyed by what we were doing."
Then it got worse. On Sunday, her 16-year-old daughter, Jesse, was arrested with a group of other protesters in the East Village. "She wasn't shoplifting, she wasn't smoking pot, she was just marching peacefully," Ms. Orem said. As of last night, Jesse was still being held.

HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY CRISIS EASES IN NEW YORK 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City, which faced a looming electricity crisis last summer as more computers and air-conditioners bought in a booming economy bumped up against the limits of the local power supply, now has all the energy it needs through at least the middle of next year and perhaps beyond, electricity experts say.
 The sharp turn of events is partly a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, which removed in one horrific day about 100 megawatts of power demand -- enough to supply nearly 100,000 homes -- as buildings in Lower Manhattan fell and companies and residents were dispersed. 
 The recession, which has stripped tens of thousands of jobs since then -- meaning fewer office cubicles to be lighted or heated and less money in the economy being spent on electronic toys and gadgetry -- has further reduced pressure on the system.
Consolidated Edison, which delivers electricity to the city and its northern suburbs, is projecting no growth in demand this summer -- the first flat-line forecast in more than a decade. 
But the supply side of the electricity equation has also fundamentally changed. The collapse of Enron, the giant energy trading company -- and the prospect of an energy glut in many parts of the country -- has frightened investors who were once eager to pour money into power plant projects. Of the 22,000 new megawatts proposed for New York State, almost two-thirds, according to some economists' estimates, are now considered unlikely to be brought online. From politics, where energy is off the table as a likely issue in New York's election for governor, to environmentalism, where hot topics like energy efficiency have cooled, the transformation has been sudden. 
"I think the crisis, as it were, if it hasn't already passed, is well on its way to being behind us," said Fred Zalcman, executive director of the Pace Law School Energy Project, an energy research and advocacy organization based in White Plains.
Mr. Zalcman and other experts caution that one year -- especially one of tumultuous change and upheaval like the last half of 2001 -- does not in itself a new trend make. The forecasting department at Con Ed expects growth in electricity use to resume in 2003, as downtown Manhattan rebuilds and the city's economy improves. Natural gas, which is used to make much of the region's electricity supply, is also subject -- as always -- to fluctuations in price because of global politics and war. The winter has also been unusually warm, reducing energy use and thus keeping prices perhaps artificially low.
But there is general agreement among industry officials, environmentalists and big energy users that the urgent momentum that was pushing the system last year -- lots of money from Wall Street for power plant construction, and lots of anxiety that growth in demand would outstrip supply, crimping New York's economy -- has been shattered.
One of the clearest examples of the new rhythm might be called, "The Tale of the 80 Megawatts." That is how much power the World Trade Center was allocated for use at peak times, like midsummer. After the attack on Sept. 11, the State of New York said that the now-surplus 80 megawatt pool, provided at low cost by the state-run New York Power Authority, would be redistributed to companies that were displaced by the disaster. 
Nearly five months later, not a watt has been allocated. A spokesman for the power authority said the complicated task of identifying and finding companies that are eligible for the electricity pool has slowed the effort. Energy industry officials say the bigger problem is that with electricity prices so low right now from Con Ed, there is little incentive for electricity users to switch.
"You've got 80 megawatts walking around -- that's how much things have changed," said David Neiburg, the president of Energy Spectrum Inc., a Brooklyn-based consulting firm that works with large energy users. "They're saying, 'We have extra capacity, here we go.' But after 9/11, the capacity issues just aren't as much of a concern. The scare is gone."
Nationwide, the demand for construction of plants also seems to be plummeting. About 50 percent of the power plants that have been proposed across the country in the last few years will probably not be built, according to Platts/RDI, an energy industry research division of the McGraw-Hill Companies. In the Midwest, the Southeast, New England and Texas -- areas with more capacity than they can use right now -- it will not matter as much as it could in New York, said Will Dailey, a senior consultant at Platts/RDI.
Other industry experts say the energy lull could have a major impact all by itself -- mostly from the things that will not happen now because the pressure is off. Few people, for example, expect that Gov. George E. Pataki will have to confront voters angry about high utility bills or brownouts in running for re-election.
The mosaic of new conservation programs created by the state last year to reduce electricity demand at peak periods -- financed by a yearly pool of $150 million from a surcharge on utility bills -- also becomes a harder sell when energy prices are low because the payback time to recoup an investment in a more efficient air-conditioner is much longer.
Vincent Croce, the director of property management at Max Capital Management Corporation, a commercial real estate firm in Manhattan, said his company was considering installing some on-site generators in two of its Midtown buildings last year, using conservation money from the state. 
"But when the power shortage went away, we looked at the dollars and cents," Mr. Croce added. "And we said: 'Know what? For that small of a return, it doesn't make sense. Why go through this? We're not a utility company.' "
A spokesman for the State Energy Research and Development Authority, which administers most of the conservation fund, conceded that the economics have temporarily changed, and that enrollments did drop off after Sept. 11. But he attributed most of the decline to the agency's advertising cycle, which peaks in the summer, rather than the impact of lower prices.
Other industry experts view the lull as offering potential benefits to the environment. 
The State Department of Environmental Conservation, for instance, issued regulations last year allowing thousands of owners of diesel generators -- considered one of the most polluting forms of energy production -- to turn on their machines in times of short supply. This year the agency is considering tightening the rules so that generator owners will also need to go through a permit process. Last month, state regulators said that potential pollution from an expanded Con Ed plant on the Lower East Side would require further hearings. 
Some newer ideas for supplying energy for New York are also emerging in this climate. Two large projects have been proposed for new transmission lines that would supply New York City and Long Island from power plants in New Jersey, and industry analysts say there might be more to come -- not because it suddenly makes more sense to import power, but because it can be more readily pitched to investors.
"It's more difficult now to get a plant project financed than it was six months ago," said Edward Krapels, the director of gas and power services at ESAI, a Wakefield, Mass., energy market research firm. "But there's less impact on transmission projects than building projects because if you go in with a transmission project, you're offering diversification, and some people think it's a better investment."
How to balance the energy industry's needs and wants with the desires and safety concerns of residents has been a running question since the state first began stepping away from its traditional oversight system in 1999. 
Some experts say the lull of 2002 confirms the view that the market has won: electricity in New York, they say, is now subject to the boom and bust cycles of Wall Street. Others say that government has proven its worth. The 400 megawatts that were added to the city's system last summer -- 10 house-sized generators built around the city by the New York Power Authority, sometimes in the face of lawsuits and claims of bias -- created a supply cushion for this summer at the same time that government-sponsored efficiency programs took the edge off the system's most severe surges in demand.
But what could be the biggest consequence of the lull by far is the expected falloff in power plant construction. Especially for New York, fewer plant proposals are far enough along to have lined up capital, mainly because of the length of time it takes for siting plants and meeting environmental approvals, Mr. Dailey of Platts/RDI noted. He estimated that about 60 percent of those proposed in the state are now likely to be dead in the water.
The chairwoman of the State Public Service Commission, Maureen O. Helmer, said that so far she had not seen many signals that power plant developers were pulling out. But she said that new trends like the move toward more interstate transmission lines would probably play a bigger role in the regional energy mix than had seemed likely a year ago.
Other experts say that the lull could be a defining moment for the city -- one that could be wasted. 
"If this breathing room in terms of electricity demand gives us an opportunity to makes some smart decisions for New York's future, that will be a benefit," said Anne Reynolds, the air and energy program director for Environmental Advocates, an Albany-based lobbying and conservation group.
Otherwise, she said, "we're going to end up making fast and dirty decisions two years from now."

HEADLINE: European Regulators Drop Investigation ofIntel 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
European regulators have dropped a yearlong investigation into accusations that Intel abused its position as the world's leading computer chip maker to keep rivals from winning market share, officials said today.
 One of two complaints filed by Intel rivals with the European Commission, which enforces antitrust law, has recently been withdrawn, a commission spokeswoman, Amelia Torres, said. 
 After investigating the other complaint, the commission has "come to the preliminary conclusion that the accusations made against Intel are unfounded," she said. "Our intention is to close the file soon."
In New York, a spokesman for the competition commissioner, Mario Monti, who was speaking at the World Economic Forum, said the investigation was considered dropped.
"We believe the complaints were not founded, and the decision has been made to drop the investigation," the spokesman said.
The investigation in Europe came after a similar inquiry by the United States Federal Trade Commission, which ended in September 2000 with no legal action taken.
Intel, which has more than 80 percent of the PC microprocessor market, has also successfully defended itself against civil lawsuits brought by rivals.
Europe has declined to identify the complainants, who accused Intel of abusing its dominant position in the market for chip sets and microprocessors to try to run smaller companies out of business.
Intel has denied that its marketing practices, including loyalty rebates offered to Intel customers and exclusive purchasing obligations, were unfair or illegal.
Shares of Intel fell 69 cents, to close at $33.98.

HEADLINE: The Wrong Lessons of the Somalia Debacle 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"Black Hawk Down" is, regrettably, a pretty good movie.
 It puts you in the heart of the Mogadishu gun battle in 1993 between Somali paramilitary forces and American Army Rangers, and you leave the theater, heart pounding, wanting to pull out a machine gun and mow down crowds of Somalis. But the real problem is that the film powerfully reinforces the two main lessons that America absorbed from the Somalia debacle -- and both lessons are wrong and have already hurt the struggle against terrorism. 
 They are:
1. Nation-building is bloody, costly and futile. So if people in piddling third-world countries want to tear each other apart, let 'em. 
2. Casualties are completely unacceptable in American military operations. At the first sign of blood, politicians abandon missions and generals are retired.
These phobias were counterproductive and ultimately helped produce more terrorism and more casualties. They meant that in the 1990's we stayed away in droves from places like Afghanistan, Sudan and Somalia, allowing a chaos that breeds terrorism.
Even now President Bush continues to stiff Afghanistan's caped hero, Hamid Karzai, as he pleads for American troops to help secure all of Afghanistan. 
There is nothing Afghanistan needs more desperately. At the moment, every time you drive between cities in Afghanistan you look nervously out the windows for signs of bandits who shoot up cars (or even cut off travelers' noses and ears). But we refuse to contribute to the international security force because of our dread of another Somalia scenario. 
It is not even necessary to wrestle with the humanitarian argument for helping tottering countries. Afghanistan, Serbia and Somalia all demonstrate the realpolitik merit of solving messes as they happen: if we leave countries to rot, eventually the rot spreads and comes back to infect us. 
No one is in favor of American casualties; the question is simply how best to minimize them in the long run. And many diplomats and military officers alike agree -- although they are reluctant to say so out loud, because they remember the Vietnam-era slogans about old men dreaming up battles for young men to die in -- that the zero-casualty standard of recent years has been counterproductive. It creates more American casualties in the long run by showing weakness and by turning nations into petri dishes for terrorists. 
"Bin Laden learned lessons from Somalia, too," said Ken Menkhaus, a Somalia expert at Davidson College in North Carolina. "He learned that you go kill a few Americans and they go away."
To his credit, Mr. Bush has reversed his initial hostility to nation-building and ended up in favor of what one senior administration official impishly calls "nation-building lite" in Afghanistan. Mr. Bush has also tried to drum in the truth that in military action, body bags are inevitable as well as tragic. 
The United States need not dispatch troops in every direction. But we should lead an international order that confronts the problem of failed states. It's difficult but not hopeless. Even Somalia might, with better policy and luck, have made gradual progress -- rather like its once equally hapless neighbors Ethiopia and Eritrea.
"It was a mishandling of the situation by the U.S. and the U.N., rather than any innate hatred among the Somalis for us" that led to disaster, says Robert B. Oakley, a former ambassador to Somalia and Pakistan. Likewise, an American who watched the fighting involving American troops in Somalia from a rooftop in Mogadishu, where he then worked for the United Nations, said: "The mission was not fated to fail. It failed because of U.N. and U.S. blundering." 
Nation-building is a blunder-prone business, but it can succeed. In 1992 Mozambique was forlorn and war-ravaged, but with military and civilian help from the United Nations it has since become one of the faster-growing economies in the world.
Likewise, Uganda was one of the world's horror stories in the 1970's, and now (after a push by Tanzanian troops in 1979 to evict Idi Amin) it's among the stars of Africa. I have a special warmth for Uganda because I was on a small plane that crash-landed there five years ago; with its fire trucks and unflappable immigration officials, Uganda makes an outstanding country in which to crash. 
And now, with luck, Afghanistan will again prove that helping war-torn third-world countries is a smarter policy than running away from them.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Offers Turkey $16 Billion in Loan Aid 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund agreed yesterday to lend Turkey $16 billion over the next three years, greatly increasing financial aid to a nation seen as a front-line state in the battle against terrorism.
 The rescue package for Turkey comes only a few weeks after the I.M.F. cut off aid to Argentina, which shares Turkey's chronic economic difficulties but not its strategic importance. 
 Turkey has received a series of rescue packages from the I.M.F. since 1999. But the nation has fallen into its deepest recession since World War II and is struggling to make payments on its foreign debt. 
Bush administration officials, who supported the fresh loans for Turkey, have often argued that the fund should not repeatedly bail out troubled nations. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill pointed to that philosophy when the fund decided to deny money to Argentina in early December.
But officials of both the Bush administration and the fund said Turkey is different. Unlike Argentina, they said, Turkey has closely followed a prescription for overhauling its economy and generating surplus budget revenues to lower public debt.
"Today's decision is a recognition by the international community of Turkey's success in developing and implementing a bold and comprehensive economic reform program," Horst Kohler, the fund's managing director, said in a statement. "Progress is impressive."
The new loan package includes $12 billion in fresh aid and $4 billion carried over from an existing loan. Altogether, Turkey has received about $31 billion since 1999 to stabilize its economy. 
That makes it the largest borrower from the fund since the giant rescue efforts for Indonesia, Russia and South Korea in 1997 and 1998.
Bush administration officials said early last year, when they signed off on a smaller increase in the fund's lending to Turkey, that the nation's economic leaders should not seek more loans if they were unable to restore growth to the economy.
But the attacks in the United States on Sept. 11 contributed to a change in thinking, analysts said.
Turkey, a member of NATO, straddles the divide between the Middle East and Europe. Though it is an Islamic nation, it has a secular government that has staked its credibility on building a Western-style market economy.
Turkey also plans to send 261 soldiers to join the British-led peacekeeping force in Afghanistan. In the past, it also has been a staging ground for operations against Iraq, which President Bush warned could be a future target in the fight against terrorism.
"The world is round, and it's foolish to deny that there are a range of considerations involved in making these loans," said Edwin M. Truman, a former Treasury and Federal Reserve official who is now a scholar at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. 
Mr. Truman said Turkey has followed the script of its existing I.M.F. program -- in contrast to Argentina, which has repeatedly missed targets set as a condition of the fund's loans. But he added that Turkey's debt problem and its deep recession remain serious challenges.
"The fund management is making a bet that Turkey can recover," he said. "But there's no assurance it will end up any better than Argentina."
As a condition of new aid, the Turkish government, with the approval of its Parliament, has shored up its banks, which have been hit hard by the country's problems; ended the state's monopoly on tobacco sales; and worked to eliminate corruption in state contracts.
Kermal Dervis, Turkey's economic minister, said the latest loans, which extend through 2004, will suffice to restore growth.
"We will not need this kind of large-scale financing after 2002," he said at the World Economic Forum. "The big shock is over."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE POLICE; 
Shrewd Anticipation Helped Avert Trouble

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Like a fastball pitcher brushing back a batter, the Police Department staked out a claim to its home plate -- the streets of New York City -- before the World Economic Forum even began, with a carefully choreographed strategy that officials say helped keep the peace by keeping protesters off balance.
 Using a combination of intelligence, a large deployment of police officers and elaborate planning, the department seemed to be everywhere at all times -- and, much to the consternation of some protesters, seemed able to anticipate their moves. 
 The police claimed the streets first, putting in traffic restrictions and flooding the area around the Waldorf-Astoria with thousands of officers at 5 a.m. on Wednesday, more than 24 hours before the meeting began. They surrounded the demonstrators, bracketing marchers on the streets, at one point with city buses and at another with police motorcycles, and monitored the protests with television cameras mounted high above the Waldorf and on a police helicopter. 
The result: over the past five days, the violence and destruction that had marred similar meetings in other cities failed to materialize. And, despite some small disturbances and 201 arrests, largely for minor violations, most of the protest organizers were in large measure satisfied that they had had a chance to demonstrate.
For the city, and in particular for Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, the relatively peaceful outcome showed that the new administration could maintain order while allowing demonstrators to exercise their First Amendment rights.
The world was watching. And it was a coming-out party of sorts, not just for Mr. Kelly, who faced his first major challenge since taking over the department he headed nearly a decade earlier, but for a city still recovering from the devastating effects of the Sept. 11 attack.
"People had the ability to demonstrate, people had the ability to say what they thought, and they did it generally without impinging on others' rights," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. And when protesters became unruly, he said, "the Police Department acted appropriately, with restrained but forceful consideration for the citizens of this city."
In at least two of the three cases in which large numbers of arrests were made, the police, through plainclothes officers on the street, learned in advance that trouble might erupt, and were ready. They had a plan in place to make arrests swiftly, and did so.
And despite concerns that anarchists and other protest groups would use swift strikes to catch the police off guard, the department, time and again, appeared to be prepared. "It was our intention from the beginning to set the tone and have a robust force in place from the beginning to show that we were prepared for anything," Mr. Kelly said yesterday. "And I think that was very helpful in dissuading those people bent on causing a problem from doing that."
Of course to some extent, the tenor of the demonstrations was in the hands of the protest groups. In large measure, the potential for violence depended on a combination of their actions and the police response. In fact, some in the protesters' ranks said they could have done more property damage, but ultimately rejected that tactic because they did not feel it was appropriate after Sept. 11.
Other protesters said they had achieved their goals. "The ultimate point, obviously on our part, was to show that the global-justice movement is alive and well and hasn't been defeated by the events of 9/11, as some have suggested," said Eric Laursen, a member of Another World Is Possible, an umbrella organization that included several protest groups.
Nonetheless, Mr. Kelly said, the Police Department was prepared, having visited cities like Seattle, Genoa and Quebec to study how protests there degenerated into violence and vandalism, and how police failures to quickly quell minor violations resulted in bedlam.
"We had a lot of resources ready to respond quickly," Mr. Kelly said, explaining that protesters in other cities had tied up smaller departments with a flood of low-level arrests that took so many officers off the streets that too few were left behind to maintain order.
The tactics were not without critics. Leslie Brody, a lawyer with the National Lawyers Guild who helped get permits and advised those who were arrested, complained that people were arrested for carrying plastic cafeteria trays that looked like police riot shields, but, she said, were being used as painted placards. "These are kids who wanted to act out in a creative way, and I think early on they were tagged for dressing or looking differently," she said. "Arrest first and ask questions later."
Some civil liberties groups said that what they called an "excessive show of force" discouraged protests.
But Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer for the demonstrators who helped negotiate logistics for Saturday's rally,, had qualified praise for the permit process and the way the city and the Police Department handled the protests.
"The entire tone this new administration took with the demonstrators was profoundly different than taken in other cities, and profoundly different than the approach that Giuliani had taken," he said. "In the Giuliani era, the permit process was manipulated to stifle groups that Giuliani objected to." 
As the forum drew to a close late yesterday, the police, who said their successes so far were won in part by taking the field early, were determined to be the last to leave. "We are going to be in place to respond to anything that might happen tonight or tomorrow," Mr. Kelly said. "Some of the participants will still be in the area and in the process of leaving. So, we are keeping our force in place."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: DIARY; 
Final Item On Agenda: Slow Down

BYLINE:  By Jim Dwyer 

 BODY:
As the certified masters of the universe prepared to roll out of town at the conclusion of the World Economic Forum yesterday (exact motto: "Committed to Improving the State of the World"), many of them finally got down to business.
 They jammed a room for a last-minute talk on how to repair their frayed lifestyles. 
 "How many of you are Type A personalities?" asked Dr. Mehmet C. Oz, director of the Cardiovascular Institute at Columbia University's New York Presbyterian Hospital. 
About half the men and women put up their hands. As for the others, quite a few appeared too busy multitasking to lift a hand: while listening to the doctor, they were tapping at handheld computers, scribbling on legal pads and collecting voice mail from their cellphones, which were set to the silent vibrate mode, so as not to aggravate anyone but themselves.
"Some people are honest," Dr. Oz muttered at the partial show of hands. "I don't think most of you'd be in this room if you weren't Type A."
This, after all, was a crowd where no man went without a necktie, not only on getaway day, but also at the most abstruse Saturday morning seminars.
Dr. Oz, a heart surgeon who pursues alternative therapies for patients, put the case that investing money to manage stress would end up saving big expenses on the kinds of surgeries he himself performs. He had teamed up with Dr. Dean Ornish, a physician and author who reported that his patients had been able to reverse heart disease by following a regimen of a very low-fat meatless diet, moderate exercise and stress reduction.
They had booked a room for 40 people, but more than 90 showed, along with about three dozen who had paid $75 extra to come early for an Ornish-approved luncheon of two salads, a lasagna made with polenta and layered with roasted vegetables and soy cheese, a sandwich wrap containing various representatives of the plant kingdom, and a fat-free apple strudel. Those who commented on the meal said it was very tasty.
"A lot of you think that you have a choice between an interesting, productive, stressed-out life, in which you die early, or a life in which you go sit under a tree," Dr. Ornish said. 
He noted that the mortality rate in the room would eventually add up to 100 percent. "We're all going to die," he said. "I don't want to be the one to break the news to you." 
To connect with the audience, the doctors turned to an expert: the vice chairman of the Nasdaq, Al Berkeley. 
Now 58, Mr. Berkeley said that in 1998, he noticed that his stamina was sinking, and he could only run for a minute before he got tired. "I just thought I was getting older," he said. By then, his younger brother already had two stents to keep blood flowing to his heart. Their father and grandfather had died of heart attacks before the age of 60. 
Mr. Berkeley learned that he had had a 95 percent blockage in the left anterior descending artery. "That's the one they call the 'widow maker,' " Mr. Berkeley said. "I felt like I was on a slow decline to death."
He had realized, he said, that "You're not completely in charge of your own show."
After getting a stent in the obstructed artery, he collected his brother and some other family members and neighbors and headed to California for a week with Dr. Ornish and his staff. Now he has stopped eating meat, and a combination of diet and drugs has brought his cholesterol readings down to about 160 from 280. As important, Mr. Berkeley said, he and his friends now talk regularly about their health. 
"Just sharing these fears of dropping dead is incredibly important," Mr. Berkeley said. "I feel like I am totally in control of whether I'm going to drop dead of a heart attack. That's a good feeling."
At restaurants, he said, he simply asks chefs to make him a good meat-free meal with as little fat as possible. While he often ends up with a plate of broccoli, carrots and cauliflower, some chefs rise to the challenge and bring him delicious meals. "I've lost my mouth for fat," he said.
He tries to squeeze in at least one minute a day of meditation, as Dr. Ornish prescribes, and he has found that his own emotions are never far from the surface. 
"I've gotten a little gentler with myself," he said. "It has given me a better relationship with everyone in my life. Having a disease is a very humbling thing."
"And humility," Mr. Berkeley said, "is a very good thing. "
Practically everyone in the audience put down their mini-computers and cellphones to applaud.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MEETING; 
Annan Cautions Business as Forum Ends

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan closed the World Economic Forum yesterday with a stern message from the devastation of Sept. 11, which had brought the gathering to New York and posed many of the issues that dominated the five-day meeting of business and political leaders from around the world.
 The world had entered the new millennium "through a gate of fire, such as none of us ever wished to see," Mr. Annan said. 
 "The forces of envy, despair and terror in today's world are stronger than many of us realized," he said. "But they are not invincible. Against them, we must bring a message of solidarity, of mutual respect, and, above all, of hope." 
In this context, he warned, "Business cannot afford to be seen as the problem."
Mr. Annan's comments seemed a fitting conclusion to an annual event that was often portrayed by outsiders as a gathering of the world's richest and most powerful men shaping a global agenda from which the weak and poor were excluded.
From within, by contrast, the impression was often of an elite struggling to comprehend the increasingly threatening forces of anti-globalization, militant Islam, terrorism and poverty, forces that gained an immediacy in the inferno of Sept. 11.
The forum was shifted from its usual venue in the Swiss ski resort of Davos to New York as a sign of solidarity after the terror attacks, and the attacks were repeatedly invoked in the many discussions, workshops and conversations, whether about global anger, security or the role of America.
Mr. Annan made no suggestion that the attacks were somehow justified by injustices, and he has been consistent in his denunciations of terrorism. Rather, he warned that business leaders cannot ignore the inhuman conditions in which much of the world lived -- or the image that the world had of them.
The problem, he said, was "one of reality multiplied by perception. 
"The reality is that power and wealth in this world are very, very unequally shared, and that far too many people are condemned to lives of extreme poverty and degradation," Mr. Annan said. "The perception, among many, is that this is the fault of globalization, and that globalization is driven by a global elite, composed of, at least represented by, the people who attend this gathering."
That perception, in fact, formed a major subtheme throughout the meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. . Though a good portion of the discussions focused on economic and business trends, the best-attended sessions seemed to be those centered on social issues.
"They've done a good job of broadening the dialogue," said Irene Zubaida Khan, the secretary general of Amnesty International.
Organizers said there were more nongovernmental participants this year, but they added that the move to New York had enabled them to increase total participation by about 25 percent, and that the breakdown of who attended was not yet available.
Reviews of the New York setting were mixed. Some participants missed the intimacy of the Davos village, and the absence of corners in which to talk and swap gossip. Many complained about the elevators, which were always packed. There were also the distractions of the city.
Many participants paid a call on ground zero, many went to theaters and restaurants and many had to return to work in their New York offices yesterday, before the conference was over. The advantage, organizers and participants said, was that New York allowed for more voices in the mix, and the lobby of the Waldorf served as a crossroads in which many chance and planned encounters took place.
Security, though tight, proved easy to navigate, perhaps because the demonstrations that were held outside never developed into the violent protests of the sort that accompanied recent international economic gatherings elsewhere.
Mr. Annan, who has spoken to previous Davos gatherings, acknowledged that participants were not always what their critics made them out to be, though the list of the rich and powerful -- including celebrity magnates like George Soros and Bill Gates, sheiks and princes from Persian Gulf oil states, and corporate chiefs and senior politicians -- was long and inclusive. The core of the World Economic Forum comprises the world's 1,000 largest corporations, at least those identified as such by Klaus Schwab, the founder and organizer of the gatherings.
"Perhaps no one in this hall feels as rich, or as powerful and influential, as he or she is perceived by others to be," Mr. Annan suggested. "And yet I believe that all of you, whether you are business leaders, political leaders or opinion leaders, know well that you are enormously privileged, compared to the great majority of your fellow human beings, both in your standard of living and in the power and influence that you wield."
Mr. Annan, who comes from Ghana, reminded the audience that a larger, rival gathering was held in Porto Alegre, Brazil, in parallel with the World Economic Forum. "Its title, 'World Social Forum,' is intended as a criticism of yours, implying that you are interested 'only in economics, or in profit, and that you do not care about the social effects of your economic activities,' " Mr. Annan said.
He did not share that perception, he said, and he believed that globalization in fact held the best hope of overcoming poverty and other social ills. "But it is up to you to prove it wrong, with actions that translate into concrete results for the downtrodden, exploited and excluded," Mr. Annan said.
Mr. Annan made many of the same points in a parallel message to the Porto Alegre gathering, though there he challenged participants to "show that you are ready to work in partnerships for change, rather than remain aloof through the politics of confrontation." 
In New York, Mr. Annan challenged a contention that was frequently made in the carpeted meeting rooms of the Waldorf, that it was for governments, not businesses, to set social policy.
"In many cases, governments only find the courage and resources to do the right thing when business leaders take the lead," he said.
He cited various channels through which corporations could contribute, including a Global Health Initiative that was discussed at the meeting, the United Nations Development Program, and a variety of other United Nations funds, programs and agencies.
At the forum, most business leaders seemed to agree with the general sentiment expressed by Mr. Annan. "We need a discussion about whether the rich world is giving back what it should in the developing world," Mr. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, told a session on "Business Leader to Global Leaders." "I think there is a legitimate question whether we are."
The problem that increasingly surfaced was what exactly that meant. David H. Komansky, the chairman of Merrill Lynch, cited the example of China's Three Gorges Dam. Environmental groups were fiercely opposed, while the Chinese government said the project was urgently needed. What was business to do? 
"We're trained as businessmen, but we're being asked to pass judgment on the moral and ethical value of these projects," Mr. Komansky said. "We need to recognize there are two sides to this story."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Chip Sales Fell In December 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Global chip sales in December declined 4 percent from November, bringing to an end the worst year in the industry's history, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. It said chip makers recorded sales of $10.18 billion, a slight decline from $10.6 billion in November and a 43 percent plunge from $17.89 billion in December 2000. 
Sales for 2001 were down 32 percent. Despite growth in the United States, Europe and Asia, fourth-quarter sales were flat versus the third quarter because the slumping Japanese economy dragged down sales by 12 percent there, the association said. George Scalise, the association's president, predicted that first-quarter sales would be flat or slightly up from the fourth quarter, instead of the flat-to-down sales common for that period. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: N.Y.U. Gets $150 Million Gift To Help Lure Top Professors 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Eighty-three years ago, New York University gave Julius Silver, a poor boy from Brooklyn, an annual scholarship of $77.50 and a $100 loan.
 Before he died last month at the age of 101, Mr. Silver, a New York lawyer, paid the university back -- with a bonus of more than $150 million. The donation, the largest cash gift N.Y.U. has ever received, will be used to endow roughly 150 faculty chairs over the next 25 years, and to pay for scholarships. 
 Mr. Silver, who worked with Edwin Land to create the Polaroid Corporation and guide it for more than 50 years, had said he wanted to help N.Y.U. woo an army of top professors, with an emphasis on science and technology, according to university officials. They said they were stunned by both the size of his gift and his willingness to leave the bulk of his estate to the university. 
"Holy mackerel; it took me by surprise," said L. Jay Oliva, N.Y.U.'s president, who devised the idea for the gift but until recently did not know just how generous it would be. "I had this dream about creating a chair machine, where you don't spend the principal but only spend the income to create faculty chairs. If you create six chairs a year for 50 years, that's 300 chairs -- almost the whole faculty of arts and science."
Mr. Silver, whose father ran a sweater shop, would often talk about how the N.Y.U. scholarship had opened opportunities for him. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from N.Y.U. in 1922, he attended Columbia University Law School and helped start a New York law firm, Silver, Saperstein, Barnett & Solomon. 
Mr. Silver's links to Polaroid grew out of his days as a summer camp counselor, when he met a young camper named Edwin Land. Mr. Land called Mr. Silver "the most extraordinary person" he had ever met, Peter C. Wensberg wrote in his book, "Land's Polaroid."
Mr. Silver, known as Julie, became Mr. Land's mentor and helped round up early investors in Polaroid. He was Mr. Land's principal business adviser for more than 50 years, serving as Polaroid's executive committee chairman, a member of its board of directors and a vice president.
The long association with Polaroid not only contributed to Mr. Silver's economic success, but immersed him in science and technology and shaped his philanthropy, said David C. Oxman, Mr. Silver's lawyer at Davis Polk & Wardwell. 
Mr. Silver contributed to the founding of Brandeis University and gave gifts to Columbia Law School and other educational institutions. But his gifts to N.Y.U. began modestly, with donations of $100 a year for several years in the 1950's and $500 in 1959. The university started to cultivate him, leading to a $10,000 gift for scholarships in 1961 and $8 million for a student dormitory at what was then the Bronx campus. At N.Y.U.'s main campus at Washington Square, three faculty residence buildings are named after him.
Still, the gift of his estate was anything but a sure thing. In the mid-1990's, after Mr. Silver's wife died, Mr. Oxman asked N.Y.U. how it might spend a gift from him, without revealing how much. N.Y.U. suggested a couple of possibilities, each involving a few million dollars. 
Mr. Oxman called Naomi Levine, then a senior vice president at N.Y.U., and asked her to think more grandly -- perhaps around $100 million. That is when Dr. Oliva pulled out his dream for a "chair machine" -- an idea that captivated Mr. Silver.
The chairs will be named after Mr. Silver, and his late wife and daughter, Roslyn S. Silver and Enid Silver Winslow, as will N.Y.U.'s Main Building on the east side of Washington Square Park.
Although Mr. Oxman advised N.Y.U. several years ago that Mr. Silver planned to give more than $100 million, Mr. Silver did not want the gift announced until after his death. Last month, after he died, N.Y.U. discovered that the gift would be at least $150 million.

HEADLINE: Oklahomans Try to Save Their California Culture 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: WEEDPATCH, Calif. 

 BODY:
The relentless geometry of the farm fields still vanishes into infinity. When Earl Shelton, a 68-year-old retired oil refinery mechanic, walks the grounds of the former Weedpatch camp to which he and thousands of other Okies migrated during the Depression, the scrapbook in his mind turns to the image of Slab 529. That spit of concrete with a tent on it was home, on and off, for 13 years.
 Mr. Shelton was 7 when he arrived at the camp, which was immortalized by John Steinbeck in his 1939 novel "Grapes of Wrath." Like many other Dust Bowlers, who have revived the once-derogatory word "Okie" as a term of endearment and source of pride, he can vividly summon the chapters of his own life: Of losing a wheel at night en route to Needles and burning a Sears catalog for light, of hot summer nights cooled only by bedsheets soaked with a hose and then draped over the tent. 
 In the 1930's, Mr. Shelton's father, Tom, a widower with four sons, joined tens of thousands of other dispossessed farmers -- real-life Tom Joads hailing from Arkansas, Texas and Missouri as well as Oklahoma -- leaving the log house three miles from Scipio, Okla., in a Model A. In these fertile fields they sought deliverance from drought and the Depression in the largest peacetime migration in the nation's history. "I don't recall going hungry," Mr. Shelton said. "But I know my dad did."
He and other members of the local Dust Bowl Historical Foundation are now trying to raise money to restore the remaining original buildings of Weedpatch camp, which opened in 1936 as a response to unsanitary living conditions among migrants.
But, in this year of the centennial of John Steinbeck's birth, the vestiges of Okie culture are vanishing, as the Dust Bowl generation ages and the texture of the community changes. Every morning, Doris Weddell, a retired librarian who is spearheading the preservation effort, picks up her scissors to clip the obituaries: Ann M. Heid (1929, Cici, Okla.), Alice R. Terry (1912, Anadarko, Okla.), Roy Earl Livsey (1913, Thayler, Tex.).
There are new migrants now, who have altered the face of small towns like Arvin and Lamont, Calif. In Lamont (population 13,295), not far from the corner where a young Buck Owens used to play hard-knocks country music on a cotton truck, Mexican panaderias, or bakeries, open at 5 a.m. while in Arvin (population 12,956), the old Safeway is now a supermercado.
In 1950, 33 percent of the population in the southern San Joaquin Valley were whites from the Southwest; today, just under 10 percent is, said James N. Gregory, an associate professor of history at the University of Washington and the author of "American Exodus: The Dust Bowl Migration and Okie Culture in California" (Oxford University Press, 1989).
"It's a generation passing," Professor Gregory said. "Because their experience was memorialized by artists and writers, they are an important and very special part of the American memory."
Every Thursday morning, several Dust Bowlers have breakfast together at a bowling alley in Bakersfield, 90 miles north of Los Angeles.
"We called ourselves rich Okies, because we had two mattresses," said Billy Ross, 66, a retired high school teacher. "It made me not want to look at a farm the rest of my life."
Discrimination was rampant. Although "Grapes of Wrath" is now required reading in California schools, in 1939 it was burned in downtown Bakersfield. The Arvin Federal Emergency School, an innovative school for Okie children known locally as the Weedpatch School, was created in 1940 largely because of public resistance to educating migrants' children.
"I remember coming home dirty from the fields and going to a store in Upland," Mr. Ross said.
"Mother went in to get some milk, and they didn't want to sell her anything," he said. "But it was clean dirt she had on. Clean, honest dirt."
The Weedpatch camp, now the Sunset Migrant Center, has continued to operate, housing migrant workers who are mostly from Mexico by way of Texas or the Coachella Valley. The Kern County Housing Authority, which runs it, is replacing 100 termite-infested, substandard modular cabins, hauled in by truck in the 1970's, with permanent stucco houses with foundations. The new houses are being paid for by $6 million in state and federal money.
Preservationists hope to raise $250,000 to restore the historic buildings and create a small historical park.
Half of seasonal agricultural workers in California have incomes below the poverty level, according to the Department of Labor. In the Lamont area, which is 89 percent Latino, and in Weedpatch (population 2,726) -- a dusty intersection down the Weedpatch Highway -- about 95 percent of students are eligible for a free or reduced-cost lunch, compared with 60 percent in the rest of Kern County, said Roy Malahowski, a lawyer with Greater Bakersfield Legal Assistance, a nonprofit organization.
In some stretches of Weedpatch, three or more families share a mobile home in the summer, and it is not uncommon to see three or four small backyard cabins filled with families, an electrical cord running from the main house to the shacks. 
At the former Weedpatch School, now the modern Sunset Middle School, 8 percent of the student body is Latino, a quarter of them migrants, said Miguel A. Gonzalez, the principal.
Seventh graders there read "Children of the Dust Bowl: The True Story of the School at Weedpatch Camp," written by Jerry Stanley, a retired history professor from California State University at Bakersfield.
"It makes you feel there were other people like you," Emilio Vela, 12, said.
An identification with poverty still marks the lives of even the most successful and highly visible Okies like Buck Owens, who left Texas with his family in a 1933 Ford sedan and spent his childhood as a "fruit tramp." His Crystal Palace dinner club on Buck Owens Boulevard is a false-fronted shrine not only to his music empire, which includes three country radio stations, but also to the "Bakersfield sound," a raw brand of country honed in No. 3 galvanized tin wash tubs and hot tents.
In Tulare, an 83-year-old poet, Wilma McDaniel, the fourth of eight children born to Oklahoma sharecroppers, writes poems in longhand each morning with felt-tipped markers. She stores them in a plastic dishpan. "It used to be a shoebox," she said. "I've moved up."
She has 14 books in print but never finished high school. She has been a maid, a governess and a farm worker in fruit cutting sheds and alfalfa fields. From her small apartment, she writes of hard times large and small, her words as straightforward as twine.
In "Pies," for instance, she recalls 1933, her unemployed father's job prospects dwindling, her mother's mulberry pie the only thing to bring "a crinkle of hope around his eyes."
"I feel that if I do not tell what I know about my past it will be lost," Ms. McDaniel explained the other day. "I wrote what I wrote and I lived what I lived."

The musician Buck Owens, right, developed his style of country music there. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
From monkeys to M&M's, Madison Ave. mostly opts to entertain the Super Bowl's TV fans.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
MADISON AVENUE, take a bow.
 There was widespread anxiety before Super Bowl XXXVI that advertisers buying commercial time during the game would seek to capitalize on Sept. 11 by unleashing several mawkish, hyperpatriotic ads that would have reasonable viewers cringing by halftime. 
 Instead, most of the spots that appeared were entertaining or enjoyable, even in some instances moving. They generally struck the right tone, a difficult task given the uncertain national mood.
That is certainly not to say that all 29 advertisers, ranging from AOL Time Warner to Yahoo, deserve pats, New England or otherwise, on the back. Many of the nine commercials for coming movies were jarringly violent or jingoistic, particularly for the films "Blade 2," "Collateral Damage" and "Hart's War." Also, two spots for the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy by the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, seemed to exploit the tragedy by asserting that buying illegal drugs helps support terrorism. 
What follows is an assessment of some of the 56 paid commercials shown nationally during the game, for which advertisers paid Fox Broadcasting, part of the News Corporation, an estimated average of $1.9 million for each 30 seconds.

AT&T WIRELESS -- All the questions generated by an elaborate "teaser" campaign for AT&T Wireless, including four commercials in the first two quarters of the game, were answered in the third quarter when a 60-second spot revealed that "mlife" is the mobile way to live.
Sure, it was cute to liken the snipping of the umbilical cord to leading "a wireless life," as the announcer intoned, but as Peggy Lee, God rest her soul, would have asked, is that all there is? This campaign will be salvaged or savaged by the subsequent installments. Agency: Ogilvy New York.

ANHEUSER-BUSCH -- Nine commercials, the most for any advertiser, were bought by Anheuser-Busch, which may want to ask for a partial refund.
Three Bud Light beer commercials bordered on smutty. Two, by the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, centered on boudoir and barroom misadventures; a third, by Fusion Idea Lab in Chicago, featured a sexually predatory falcon.
A Budweiser spot, also by DDB Chicago, was much better, showing how a woman may spend hours picking the right greeting card while a man will grab one off the rack at the convenience-store checkout as he buys beer. Expect more such "True" spots for Bud showing guys behaving like guys.
Then there was a spot featuring the Budweiser Clydesdales traveling to Lower Manhattan to bow before the skyline and the Statue of Liberty. It was crass to depict brand characters in a Sept. 11 commercial; what next, a statue of Mr. Peanut, Aunt Jemima and the Jolly Green Giant as firefighters raise the flag at ground zero? Still, it was stirring in an understated, sentimental way. Just don't do it again. Agency: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

E*TRADE FINANCIAL -- The chimp that appears in spots for E*Trade Financial returned for its third annual spoof of Super Bowl advertising. This year, the monkey was "fired" for the poor performance of an imaginary Super Sunday musical extravaganza to promote the company's changing its name from the E*Trade Group.
The commercial was busier than an online brokerage during a dot-com meltdown, but the plot about an employee dismissed by an impatient boss is certainly timely in this worrisome economy. That same concern surfaced in another commercial, for the Lipton Brisk tea sold by PepsiCo and Unilever, in which the brand's puppet characters "lost" their jobs. E*Trade agency: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of Omnicom. Lipton Brisk agency: J. Walter Thompson, New York, part of WPP.

GENERAL MOTORS -- The Cadillac division of General Motors, abandoning a series of spots centered on the symbol "&," replaced that gimmick with "and," as in "Rock and Roll," as in that song by Led Zeppelin, the first time the band's music has been heard in commercials.
One ad, linking the Cadillac brand's heritage and its new models, was stirring. A second, showing a tiny car called a Kleinschnittger fitting into the back of an Escalade EXT, was a treat. Agency: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Troy, Mich., part of the Bcom3 Group.

MASTERFOODS USA -- This division of Mars offered a hilarious twist on the tradition of pillow chocolates at ritzy hotels when a talking red M&M shares a bed with an unnerved lodger. Agency: the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, a division of Omnicom.

MONSTER.COM -- The job-search Web site operated by TMP Worldwide departed from the relentless Super Sunday ballyhoo to present a spot featuring Rudolph W. Giuliani saying "Thank you, America," for "all the help" New York City received after Sept. 11. The plug for Monster.com was mercifully brief. Agency: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising.

PEPSI-COLA -- The Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo rarely uses nostalgia in its ads, ceding that tactic to its rival, Coca-Cola. But a 90-second commercial in which Britney Spears recreated six decades' worth of Pepsi pitches was delicious, effectively demonstrating why, in a jingle reprised in a separate 30-second spot, Pepsi is still "for those who think young." Agency: BBDO New York.

PHILIP MORRIS -- Two antismoking commercials from Philip Morris missed the mark by nagging adults to talk to children about cigarettes but offering no reasons to shun smoking, unlike two hard-hitting winners from the American Legacy Foundation about the harmful ingredients in cigarette smoke. Philip Morris agency: Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of WPP. Foundation agencies: Arnold Worldwide and Crispin, Porter & Bogusky, Miami.

SUBWAY -- This commercial was a dreadful waste because it hid Jared, the charmingly nerdy star of previous spots for Subway Restaurants, who was seen only fleetingly. Two spots for a Subway competitor, Quizno's, were far better, standing out with audacious parodies of fast-food marketing methods. But what do I know? The Subway spot came in second among all Super Bowl commercials in a survey of advertising effectiveness released yesterday by Merwyn Technology in Cincinnati. Subway agency: Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Quizno's agency: Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Left, a chimpanzee that has starred in E*Trade spots for three years made a return in a big musical number. An Anheuser-Busch ad, right, featured the Budweiser Clydesdale horses bowing before the Manhattan skyline and the Statue of Liberty as a tribute to New York.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
StockIndexes Tumble Again On New Fears About Audits

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Worries about accounting problems in other companies in the wake of the Enron scandal sent stock prices sharply lower again yesterday, with the three major indexes all down more than 2 percent.
 The stock market fell last week on such concerns. Then, over the weekend, investors were given a new look into Enron and its accountant, Arthur Andersen, when a committee of the Enron board issued a detailed report on Enron's collapse. 
 Among the report's findings was that Enron had manipulated its publicly reported earnings to conceal "very large losses." 
Many stocks that fell last week dropped again yesterday.
"It's pretty clear that the more you scratch, the more you find that Enron is not the only company with funky accounting," said Thomas McManus, the equity strategist at Banc of America Securities. "I think people are right to say there is more behind this and right to wonder if earnings are overstated by 10 percent."
The focus on what other companies may be hiding in complex financial statements could intensify as Congress holds hearings on Enron and its fallout this week.
Tony Crescenzi, chief bond market strategist at Miller Tabak & Company, said, "The hearings are one reason we have a higher level of anxiety right now."
Tyco International, a Bermuda-based conglomerate, lost almost one-sixth of its market value, with its shares closing down $5.73, or 16.1 percent, to $29.90. The company lost access to the commercial paper market and said that it was drawing down $5.9 billion in bank lines of credit, largely to repay its $4.5 billion in commercial paper. Two credit rating agencies downgraded ratings on Tyco's bonds.
The shares of Enterasys Networks plunged 61.1 percent, or $6.60, to $4.20, after the company, a maker of networking hardware and software, announced that it was delaying its fourth-quarter earnings report and that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Among the stocks touched with the accounting concerns last week that fell again yesterday were PNC Financial Services, down $2.88, or 5 percent, to $54.79, and General Electric, off $1.85, or 5 percent, to $35. PNC Financial said last week that it was cutting its net income for last year by $155 million because the Federal Reserve was troubled with the way it had accounted for problem loans and venture capital holdings. G.E. is among the large companies whose financial statements now appear to many investors to be too complex to understand.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 220.17 points, or 2.2 percent, to 9,687.09, less than 70 points from its low for the year. The Nasdaq composite index fell 55.71 points, or 2.9 percent, to 1,855.53, its lowest close since November. The index, which is heavy in technology, is now down 4.9 percent for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished down 27.76 points, or 2.5 percent, at 1,094.44. Like the Nasdaq, this index is now at its low for the year, down 4.7 percent. The Dow is off 3.3 percent for the year.
As it has recently, the bond market became a haven for investors when stocks fell. The price of the Treasury's 10-year note jumped 19/32 , to a price of 10024/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.90 percent from 4.98 percent on Friday.
The 30-year bond climbed 20/32 , to 10012/32 . Its yield dropped to 5.35 percent from 5.39 percent.
Another factor pulling stocks lower yesterday was concern about the outlook for the economy. In comments on Sunday at the World Economic Forum, Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman, said that he did not expect a big uptick in the economy or the technology sector this year. Shares of Microsoft fell $1.54, or 2.5 percent, to $61.12 yesterday.
"The market has priced in a rebound," said Mr. Crescenzi of Miller Tabak. "But right now the rebound has not exceeded expectations." If the recovery is more in line with Mr. Gates's forecast than that of many analysts, stocks could pull back.
Mr. Crescenzi says, however, that the worry about accounting and misleading earnings will pass if the problems do not spread too far. "The market will be looking at these companies case by case," he said, "and if they come up empty-handed, that will ease concerns."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: HEALTH SPENDING; 
Buckets for Bioterrorism, But Less for Catalog of Ills

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
While President Bush is proposing a major increase in spending to defend against bioterrorism, other public health programs, like preventing chronic diseases and birth defects and controlling infectious diseases, would be cut under the 2003 budget the White House unveiled today.
 Excluding money for bioterrorism, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the nation's public health agency, would receive roughly a $340 million cut under the president's budget, bringing its nonbioterrorism budget to about $4.1 billion, down from more than $4.4 billion last year. 
 "To be perfectly candid with you, we had to make some tough decisions," Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said this afternoon at a briefing.
Over all, the president is requesting $489 billion for the Health and Human Services Department, a 6.3 percent increase over 2002. The vast agency, which oversees the nation's welfare and Medicare programs as well as the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration and the disease control centers, accounts for nearly one-quarter of all federal spending, Mr. Thompson said. 
In his proposal, the president lives up to his commitment to complete a five-year initiative begun by the Clinton administration to double the budget of the National Institutes of Health. Mr. Bush has requested an increase of $3.7 billion, or 15.7 percent, for that agency, raising its overall budget to $27.4 billion.
Mark B. McClellan, a member of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, said the increase reflected Mr. Bush's belief that the institutes, which finance pioneering biomedical research, provide taxpayers with a high rate of return on their investment.
But the increase is not distributed evenly across the various institutes that make up the N.I.H. Nearly half of it, or $1.5 billion, is devoted to new research on bioterrorism, primarily at the National Institute on Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
That agency, which is trying to develop a new vaccine against anthrax, would receive the biggest raise, an increase of $1.4 billion over its $2.5 billion budget in 2002. The second-biggest increase would go to the National Cancer Institute, which would receive an additional $515 million, raising its total budget to $4.7 billion.
The budget calls for the disease control centers to spend $1.6 billion on bioterrorism preparedness next year. That is a decrease of $661 million from 2002, but the drop reflects the agency's purchase of $757 million worth of pharmaceuticals and vaccines, a one-time expenditure in the aftermath of the attacks on Sept. 11. 
The disease control centers' bioterrorism budget includes $100 million for a new laboratory at the agency's branch in Fort Collins, Colo., as well as $940 million to improve state and local preparedness, the same amount the agency will spend in 2002.
While public health officials view bioterrorism preparedness as important, they cautioned today that it should not come at the expense of other programs. They note that just five Americans have been killed by bioterrorism over the last year, while thousands die each year of chronic illnesses and infectious diseases.
"We will be very concerned if we are funding one thing at the expense of another," said Dr. Georges C. Benjamin, president of the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials. "If you really want to push people towards better health, you have got to keep these programs in place."
At today's briefing, Mr. Thompson described himself as passionate about disease prevention, and he pledged that his agency would "aggressively take on preventing the onset of diseases such as diabetes," which can often be prevented through diet and exercise.
But the budget proposal calls for a $57 million cut in the disease control center's program for chronic disease prevention and health promotion. Infectious disease control, meanwhile, would be cut by $10 million, at a time when public health officials are particularly concerned about the threat of new and emerging infections.
Financing will remain flat for a number of programs, including those devoted to childhood immunization, environmental health, preventing birth defects, and sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS.
Marsha Martin, executive director of AIDS Action, argued that Mr. Bush was sending "a clear message that our nation's public health has fallen off the administration's radar screen."
Ms. Martin added, "Homeland security also means investing in prevention and care services for people at risk and living with H.I.V."
The administration had already announced much of its major new spending for health care in today's budget, including $190 billion over 10 years to "modernize" Medicare and create a prescription drug benefit for the program's elderly beneficiaries. 
Prospects for major action on Medicare are considered poor this year, given the deep divisions between Republicans and Democrats, budget constraints and the coming midterm election. Mr. Thompson said today, however, that he remained optimistic.
"I understand everyone has written the obituaries for Medicare reform this year," he said. "I haven't."
The administration repeated its proposal, first raised in the presidential campaign, to use tax credits to help the uninsured buy coverage -- $89 billion over 10 years. The White House also considers community health centers to be an important way of reaching the uninsured, and Mr. Thompson proposed a $114 million increase for such centers in the new budget, raising their financing to $1.5 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason McKitrick, left, and James Cantwell, health analysts for the House Budget Committee, studied the Bush budget proposal for 2003 yesterday. President Bush proposes cuts for a number of health programs, mostly so money can be directed toward fighting bioterrorism. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
