HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: NEW YORK PERSPECTIVE; 
Bush Budget Renews Battle Over Pledge Of Aid to City

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
President Bush did not include any more of the $20 billion he had promised in federal aid for rebuilding New York in the budget plan he issued today, an omission that New York lawmakers were quick to point out. 
 Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, emphasized that the Bush administration was still committed to providing aid to the city and state in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. 
 "Aid to New York will eventually total well over $20 billion," Mr. Daniels said during a budget briefing. "It's not going to be proposed that way in any one budget because this is going to be a multi-year project. It's going to take years to rebuild infrastructure, subway, perhaps sea wall and other very expensive things. We won't know for a long time exactly how much it is." 
To date, the administration and Congress have agreed to provide $11.1 billion for New York's recovery efforts. But New York lawmakers are pushing to get the rest of the money as soon as possible, concerned that the city's case for aid will become weaker as new demands for federal money arise from other states and memories of the attack begin to fade.
Mr. Daniels further aggravated the existing tensions between the White House and New York lawmakers, who have been fighting a protracted battle to obtain more aid, when he suggested later in the day that he planned to count roughly $5 billion from a federal fund for victims of the attack against the $20 billion pledge. 
At first, Mr. Daniels appeared to justify counting the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund, saying: "Well, it's cash dollars going straight into the pockets -- almost all, if not all New York, but the vast majority are people in the New York area. And it would be preposterous not to count it. But you know, I'm just going to tell you: for us, this has never been -- it seems strange to me to treat this as a money-grubbing game. The idea is, what is the federal government going to do? What are we going to get done? And then when we total up the amount later on, I guarantee you it will be more than $20 billion."
Democratic lawmakers from New York seized on those comments as evidence that the Bush administration was seeking to renege on the president's commitment and, in the process, pit the need to rebuild Lower Manhattan with the need to help victims. "This money is not related to the cleanup, rebuilding or economic recovery in New York," Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Democrat of New York, said of the victims' compensation fund.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, also a Democrat from New York, said Mr. Daniels's comments came close to being a "breach" of the commitment the president made. 
"It was explicitly clear that the victims' money was not part of New York's $20 billion," he said.
As criticism swelled after lawmakers learned of Mr. Daniels' remarks, the White House budget office began backing away from including the billions of dollars in compensation against the emergency aid already pledged.
Amy Call, a spokeswoman for Mr. Daniels, said, "New York will get $20 billion without counting victims' comp." 
Senator Clinton and other lawmakers also complained that the New York emergency aid did not have a separate line in the president's budget plan. 
"The president's budget provides zero to fulfill the commitment," Senator Clinton said, noting that the president's plan came with illustrations of the recovery effort in Lower Manhattan. "I wished the pictures had been matched by resources."
But Mr. Daniels also told reporters today that the White House still backed a $5 billion economic stimulus package to help rebuild Lower Manhattan, including the creation of a Liberty Zone for business that has yet to be passed by the Senate. That money would be in addition to the $20 billion.
The president's budget proposal will of course undergo considerable changes in Congress, which has its own priorities as its members head into the mid-term election season this fall. Other parts of the president's budget plan would affect teaching hospitals in the New York region. Hospital officials said today that they would lose hundreds of millions of dollars in federal Medicare money under the president's proposal.
The budget today included the Medicare cuts even though they have been strenuously opposed by politicians and hospital administrators in the New York region and in other states with large concentrations of teaching hospitals.
Hospital administrators and their allies in Congress had argued that the cuts could be prevented if President Bush moved to eliminate a cost-cutting provision enacted in the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 to reduce the size of Medicare, the health care program for the elderly.
Now, the matter goes to Capitol Hill, where lawmakers in both parties are warning that it will be difficult for the federal government to meet the broad array of needs that are suddenly arising around the country in this era of budget deficits.
"It's going to be a huge fight," said Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat from Brooklyn.
Nationwide, teaching hospitals will lose roughly $708 million annually once the cuts go into effect, by October of this year, according to industry officials. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the cuts will total roughly $170 million a year once they are in place.
The 1997 Balanced Budget Act called for reducing projected spending on Medicare by $115 billion by 2003. But hospital officials and their allies on Capitol Hill note that the cuts have already totaled more than $200 billion and should, therefore, be suspended.
"The Balanced Budget Act's impact has gone well beyond what its authors intended," said Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "For the sake of the health care system, we should be suspending any further cuts."
The Medicare cuts apply to additional payments that teaching hospitals receive to help them cover the costs of training new doctors. It also compensate these hospitals for the specialized, high-cost care they provide, like cancer therapies, burn treatment and cardiac care.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE CONTEXT; 
As Troubles Multiply, the Equation Changes

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
Do the math, President Bush told Congress a year ago. The projected budget surplus, he said, was so large that the nation could afford the biggest tax cut in two decades and still have plenty left over to address its other needs and keep a buffer in reserve.
 Today, Mr. Bush sent Congress a new budget plan, one in which the surplus has shriveled and there is little extra money for anything other than national security and the administration's proposal for new and extended tax cuts. 
 Clearly, the terrorist attacks and the evolving response at home and abroad have changed the equation enough that the budget, as a dollars and cents expression of the nation's priorities, had to change with it.
Still, against the backdrop of an economy that has come thudding back to earth and in an atmosphere in which the collapse of the Enron Corporation has reopened questions about fairness and the gulf between haves and have-nots, some new calculations jump out.
For instance: Is gradually repealing the tax on estates of more than $1 million -- a step included in last year's tax bill and one that would be worth $54 billion to tens of thousands of families in 2011 -- enough of a priority to constrain the nation's ability to help tens of millions of retirees pay for their prescription medicines?
More immediately, Congress will have to decide whether to go along with the administration's request to cut, freeze or tightly limit spending increases for nearly every function of government aside from national security. From job training and environmental protection to highway building and public housing, social needs will be pitted against national security and fiscal prudence.
The potential for such painful trade-offs was apparent a year ago when Congress took up Mr. Bush's tax cut. But the conventional wisdom at the time was that the surplus would grow bigger, not smaller, and Congress chose to believe that it would not have to make any difficult choices.
With the pool of available money diminished, and with new wartime demands being placed upon it, this budget returns Washington to a partisan and ideological battle over how to distribute the nation's resources.
The debate, said Kim Wallace, a political analyst in Washington for Lehman Brothers, the investment firm, gets at basic philosophical differences over the best way to help the economy and address social ills.
"For the republic," Mr. Wallace said, "is it better policy to let 10 or 15 percent of society have the freedom to do more for themselves than it is to use that money to make sure 50 percent of society doesn't get worse off?"
Mr. Bush's commitment to tax cuts has not wavered since he began running for president. He has argued that tax cuts are necessary when the nation is flush with prosperity and when it is in the economic dumps, in peacetime and in wartime, to get rid of the budget surplus and to restore it.
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said the tax cut was not constraining the administration's agenda in the least.
"Its opponents have blamed the tax cut for everything except mad cow disease," Mr. Daniels said today. 
Mr. Daniels said taxation, as measured as a share of total economic output, remained near its all-time highs even after last year's tax cut. The best way to regenerate the surplus and the flexibility it provides in addressing the nation's needs, he said, is to make the economy vibrant again. And the best way to make the economy strong again, he said, is to keep pushing taxes lower.
Democrats suspect that the administration and its Republican allies on Capitol Hill are not at all unhappy to have placed the government in a fiscal vise.
"Their goal last year was not simply to return money to the hands of the American people, but to starve the beast, to take all the money off the table," said Thomas S. Kahn, staff director for the Democrats on the House Budget Committee. "They did a good job of it. And not only are they not chastened, but they are emboldened to do more."
But only the more liberal of elected Democrats are making an argument that policy has become unduly skewed toward tax cuts that favor upper-income people. And only the most politically secure of those Democrats are calling openly for delaying or rolling back Mr. Bush's tax cut. 
Kevin Phillips, a political analyst and author of the forthcoming "Wealth and Democracy: A Political History of the American Rich," said the muted response of Democrats to the questions about the distribution of the tax cut was tied to the campaign finance system.
Inevitably, Mr. Phillips said, moderate Republicans as well as Democrats respond to their wealthy benefactors, effectively silencing or co-opting the voices of elected officials who would otherwise do more for people at the bottom of the income spectrum.
"Uniquely in the history of the republic, there's going to be a correlation between tax fairness and campaign finance," he said.
Alan J. Auerbach, director of the Robert D. Burch Center for Tax Policy and Public Finance at the University of California at Berkeley, said fiscal policy has historically swung back and forth in response to economic and political pressures. 
After President Ronald Reagan's signature tax cut in 1981, which conservatives still view as the high water mark of public policy, Congress quickly turned its attention to the burgeoning budget deficit. It subsequently raised taxes in each of the next four years, and overhauled the entire tax code in 1986.
Mr. Bush has already warned against a repeat, saying the tax cut will be rolled back over his dead body. Still, Mr. Auerbach said, it could happen, if not now then sometime.
"No one wants to talk about it or propose it," he said, "but what it means is that there's going to be a suspension of the tax cut eventually."

A preview: More security, less taxation, bigger deficits. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times); President Bush released his $2.13 trillion budget yesterday, a blueprint wrapped in a billowing flag. HEADLINE: Chances of a Shooting Similar to Diallo's Are Less, Mayor Says 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered a simple, concise answer when asked yesterday what had changed in the New York Police Department in the three years since Amadou Diallo was shot and killed in the Bronx by four police officers.
 "Ray Kelly and Mike Bloomberg," he said, referring to himself and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. 
 He made the comment at his news briefing, on the third anniversary of the death of Mr. Diallo, an unarmed West African immigrant. 
Asked to elaborate, the new mayor said: "I think that Ray Kelly is providing the leadership and the training for the Police Department so the likelihood of an event like that is diminished." 
"And I will do the best I can to make sure if and when -- unfortunately, probably when -- events happen that we wish had not taken place," he continued, "that the outreach and the confidence in all communities that Ray and I are building will be sufficient to explain to people, comfort people, and convince people that we'll take steps to make sure whatever event takes place doesn't happen again."
Mr. Bloomberg's remarks -- which came hours before about 100 people gathered in the Bronx for a candlelight vigil marking the anniversary of Mr. Diallo's death -- were yet another indication of how he envisions changing relations between New Yorkers and the police from the top down, as well as a glimpse of how he views his role alongside the police commissioner's. His comments also appeared to tacitly criticize his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who, along with the police, was the object of daily protests and acts of civil disobedience after the Diallo shooting. The Diallo case had exacerbated Mr. Giuliani's chilly relations with some members of minority groups. 
Since his election, Mr. Bloomberg has met with many black elected officials, clergy members and community advocates as he tries to establish connections throughout the city. While it is unclear whether Mr. Bloomberg will maintain a solid relationship with those he has met recently, he has received a warm reception, with many commenting on the contrast to the reception given to the Giuliani administration. After the Diallo shooting, the former mayor was accused of failing to keep in contact with many black officials. 
A spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani did not return a call seeking comment. 
The Rev. Al Sharpton, who was instrumental in organizing the daily protests after the Diallo shooting, in which more than 1,000 people were arrested for committing acts of civil disobedience outside Police Headquarters, praised the remarks and Mr. Bloomberg's efforts to strike an inclusive tone. "Not only is it a different tone, it's a whole different sound system," Mr. Sharpton said, adding that he hoped Mr. Bloomberg's deeds would match his words when put to the test.
It was typical of Mr. Bloomberg to mention Mr. Kelly first in his comments. So far in his young mayoralty, Mr. Bloomberg has seemed more than content to hang back and allow Mr. Kelly to be the public face of the Police Department, another notable change from the prior administration. Further evidence of Mr. Bloomberg's preference occurred on Sunday when he went to the front lines where demonstrators protesting the World Economic Forum were facing off with the police, surveyed the scene, and conferred with Mr. Kelly. He left without holding his own impromptu news conference, telling reporters that Mr. Kelly would conduct a briefing later.
And when two students were shot and wounded last month at Martin Luther King Jr. High School on the West Side of Manhattan, in the first shooting incident in a city school in eight years, Mr. Bloomberg did not race to the scene. He left the policing to the Police Department.
But the mayor has taken to promoting the city's crime statistics. Over the weekend, he noted more than once that the number of killings committed during the first four weeks of his mayoralty had dropped 40 percent compared with the same four-week period last year, to 33 from 55. And on Saturday he went to the scene of a fire on East 86th Street, not far from his town house on East 79th Street.
The mayor spoke about the anniversary of the Diallo shooting at a news conference to announce the appointment of the new deputy police commissioner for legal matters: Stephen L. Hammerman, 64, a former prosecutor who was most recently vice chairman at Merrill Lynch.
Mr. Hammerman joins two other recent recruits to the top echelons of the Police Department with impressive and unusual resumes: Frank Libutti, a retired Marine Corps general who is now the department's deputy commissioner for counterterrorism, and David Cohen, a retired spymaster with the C.I.A. who is deputy commissioner of intelligence.
"We need somebody to make sure that the Police Department does its job within the law," Mr. Bloomberg said in announcing the appointment.

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: AFTER HOURS; 
It Was Clinton at Waldorf Instead of Dessert

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM and DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
It was perhaps the quirkiest intimate session at the World Economic Forum: Dinner for 80 at Daniel Boulud's top-rated French restaurant, Daniel, with a dessert discussion of food, culture and national identity. But at 10:10 p.m. Sunday, just as diners savored the last scraps of braised veal cheeks, the word came down: "If you are going to the Clinton nightcap, it's completely full, and the buses are leaving for the Waldorf right now!"
 In a flash, half the room rushed for the exit as if a fire alarm had rung, skipping not one but two desserts. The planned panel discussion collapsed like a fallen souffle. But back in a crowded conference room at the Waldorf, some 300 world leaders in politics, industry and finance were held spellbound by a freewheeling, solo seminar conducted by someone whose idea of a great meal was the Mexican platter at the White House mess: former President Bill Clinton, the ultimate Davos Man, always ready to expound on globalization until the last top-dog dies. 
 So what if platters of chilled pineapple, tapioca and mint fruit soup with coconut sorbet, and banana-Manjari chocolate clafoutis with macadamian nougat went uneaten in Mr. Boulud's elegant dining room on East 65th Street? Fifteen blocks to the south, Mr. Clinton was just getting up a good head of steam as midnight approached.
Dapper in a double-breasted blue blazer and hand-held microphone, the man the official program described as "Founder, William Jefferson Clinton Foundation," held forth on North Korea, the Middle East, Enron and health care. At one point, he welcomed a guest star, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, who declared, "I wish we'd had just a few more months, then we'd have peace in the Middle East."
Inevitably, a questioner pressed Mr. Clinton for his thoughts about President Bush's "axis of evil," the nuclear-eager combination of Iran, Iraq and North Korea. "We have to take these countries each in turn," he warned. "They may all be trouble, but they are different." Support for sanctions against Iraq in the United Nations had eroded, he said.
Iran, he said, "has two governments now," progressive elements that the United States can work with and hard-liners whose every move must be watched.
"On North Korea, I have a totally different take," he said, recounting how close he believed he was to a deal with Pyongyang to end its missile program in December 2000. He nearly went to the Stalinist nation to seal it, he said, but he had to stay in Washington working on a last-minute Middle East peace initiative that, he noted ruefully, fell apart.
With North Korea, he said, "I figure I left the next administration with a big foreign policy win, " one that he hinted Mr. Bush had squandered with unnecessarily hard language early last year.
When asked later about what advice he gave his successors after Sept. 11, he talked about calling the White House to alert them to a vulnerability in the way American computer databases are searched, but he refused to get more specific. When a questioner quizzed him, he snapped: "Are you with the press? That's none of your business."
He was equally reticent about what he thought the next steps in seeking Middle East peace should be, saying, "I think the less the rest of us all say about this publicly the better."
But he could not resist suggesting that he had already left the clear recipe for the final deal. "Some day when there is peace in the Middle East, it'll look an awful lot like what they walked away from last December," he said, meaning the last month of his term.
"We actually know within a two or three percent variance, what the final deal has to be," he said, no doubt thinking about those maps of Jerusalem that he had spread out at Camp David with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Ehud Barak, who was then prime minister of Israel.
But by the evening's end, after Mr. Clinton declared, "I have cried for Argentina" and greeted old friends like Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the diminutive sex therapist, ("She was a sniper in the early days of Israel!" he declared), the former president summed up by saying, "I did the best I could and had a good time trying."
The foodies who lingered at Boulud said much the same thing, even if their effort to hold a serious discussion led by the likes of Theodore Zeldin, an Oxford scholar and a distinguished historian of France, failed in the face of the Clinton-inspired exodus. Instead, Professor Zeldin made do with a mild observation on food and fellowship, appropriate to the global conference.
"If you hate your neighbor, however good the food," he said, "you cannot enjoy your meal."

HEADLINE: FORUM IN NEW YORK: VIEW FROM ABROAD; 
A Yawn, a Grumble, and After All It's Just Not Europe, Is It?

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
The very private Elton John concert in New York last Friday did not draw much notice, nor did the marchers in the streets. Nor did anyone seem surprised that New York proved, once and for all, that it was open for business despite the events of Sept. 11.
 In press coverage of the World Economic Forum in Europe and elsewhere, no one seems to have doubted that New York was indeed back on its feet. So the high-powered talkathon was relegated, much as it has always been, to the back pages and business news segments of the evening news. 
 Far from dwelling on the swirl of meetings and parties that descended on New York, many journalists did as they usually do, dutifully reporting subject and speakers, little more. The heavy police presence caught some eyes. There was some grumbling about whether America, given an opening, had greedily snatched a European event.
Some commentaries also raised the question of whether the forum, which had for decades convened in the Swiss resort of Davos, really belonged in a bustling Manhattan setting with its costly restaurants, hotel suites and long elevator waits.
In its weekend issue, the French daily Le Monde described overbooked seminars, long lines, packed elevators and a sense that instead of being able to meet quietly back at one's hotel for a private chat, people were easily getting lost.
It worried as well that the usual back-and-forth of ideas between world leaders had been more one-sided than usual.
"In moving the World Economic Forum to New York this year, the risk was great that the Davos meeting would become Americanized while America would not become Europeanized -- that the focus would become America's worries without opening America's eyes to the worries of others in the world," the newspaper said. "And that is, unfortunately, what has happened."
Swiss papers had not devoted much attention to the affair until Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg talked about having the meeting come back to Manhattan. (It is scheduled for Davos next year.) The Swiss daily Le Temps ran a front-page headline, "New York Snubs Switzerland," and an accompanying article said Swiss officials had been "flabbergasted" by the mayor's remarks.
"The opportunism of the American at the very least annoys and embarrasses Swiss officials," the article reported. Some in the Swiss entourage, the article continued, could not stop talking about the boorishness of Americans who "in the middle of ceremonies dedicated to victims of Sept. 11 cannot help talking about money."
Some journalists seemed to find New York's security precautions over the top. A Saturday story in the English daily The Guardian, was titled "12,000 Police Aim to Ensure This Is Just a Storm in a Coffee Cup," noting that "as New York waited on high alert for anticipated violence surrounding the 32nd World Economic Forum, almost every branch of Starbucks north of 40th Street boasted its own detail of four or five armed police."
Ultimately, the papers divided as to the effect of the protesters. Today the headline in the British daily The Times read "Protests Mar Forum's Close"' while one of its competitors, The Independent, ran a headline saying: "Anti-Forum Activists March and 'Twinkle' to Little Effect."
In Argentina, whose government representative came to the United States to plead its case for aid, money and high living did not escape comment. Clarin, the daily newspaper, used the headline "A World Apart" to describe a New York setting for the rich and powerful to dine in expensive restaurants and occupy $1,200 hotel rooms when Argentina has been driven into bankruptcy.
"These are not prices for people with heart conditions or members of the middle class with their savings frozen in the bank," the newspaper commented.
In several countries, the alternative -- and larger -- World Social Forum in Porto Allegre, Brazil, competed with the attention given to the Davos meeting.
This was true in Germany and Britain, though even more true in France, where the Brazil meeting almost always got the upper hand.
On Thursday, the conservative daily Le Figaro gave Porto Alegre a banner headline across the front page. Inside were another two long articles on who was there -- a contingent of ministers from the Socialist government of France and several presidential candidates -- and what was being said.
The Davos meeting, meanwhile, was consigned to a small corner at the bottom of an inside page. It mostly focused on the difficulties of getting around New York and the increased cost of moving the event to the United States.
In Moscow, the coverage was slanted to Russian interests, with many reports noting that Russia seemed more like a member of the club. Russian officials were quoted saying that discussions in New York were now "devoid of dramatism." 
In Japan, as well, coverage focused on national worries. An editorial today in the financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun bemoaned the fact that few forum participants discussed Japan as a potential contributor to the world economic recovery.
"The world has now given up all hope for Japan's economic upturn in the near future, as the country is perceived not to be doing what it clearly needs to do to pull the economy out of the morass," the paper said. "Japan seems to be slipping out of the policy-making consciousness of world political and business leaders."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Russia:Oil Strategy Emphasized 

BYLINE:  By Sabrina Tavernise (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Russia may scrap reductions in crude oil exports in the second quarter if American and European economies show signs of growth, Mikhail Kasyanov, the Russian prime minister, said after meeting with President Bush in Washington, according to Russia's Itar-Tass news agency. 
The comment followed a similar statement over the weekend, when Mr. Kasyanov, at the World Economic Forum in New York, said the country's energy strategy is to increase oil production. Russia is flexing its muscles as the world's No. 2 oil producer and its stance has created tension with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which has been pushing for cuts in output to help support prices. Sabrina Tavernese (NYT)

HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH: GLEN GABBARD; 
A Rare Day: The Movies Get Mental Illness Right

BYLINE:  By ERICA GOODE 

 BODY:
It was 1980 and the patient in Dr. Glen Gabbard's consulting room had a pressing request.
 She had just seen "Ordinary People," she told him, and in the movie, Judd Hirsch, who played the therapist, hugged Timothy Hutton, who played the suicidal patient. 
 "It really helped him a lot," the woman said, "so I was wondering if you could hug me."
Dr. Gabbard explained to the young woman that "Ordinary People" was a movie. 
"This is therapy," he said, "and we need to use words."
"Yes, I know it was a movie," the patient replied, "but the hug helped a lot."
Where does the public get many of its ideas about psychiatry and mental illness? From Hollywood, of course.
And Hollywood, said Dr. Gabbard, who has spent many years examining the rendering of his field in the movie theater, has mostly preferred distortion and stereotype over more true-to-life representations.
Yet inaccurate as such portraits are, they are also compelling.
"People don't make distinctions between what's reality and what's on the great silver screen," Dr. Gabbard said. 
At the Menninger Clinic in Topeka, Kan., where he trained as a psychoanalyst and later became medical director, patients often asked him to hypnotize them so they could recover repressed memories.
"I'd say, 'Why do you want that?' " Dr. Gabbard said. "And they'd say, 'I saw it in "The Three Faces of Eve." ' "
Dr. Gabbard came by his passion for movies naturally: his parents are professional actors. And after a while, psychoanalyzing psychiatry's relationship with the motion pictures became a hobby, eventually resulting in the 1987 book "Psychiatry and the Cinema," written with his brother, Dr. Krin Gabbard, a professor of comparative literature at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
As an added perk, Dr. Gabbard noted, his sideline gave him "an excuse to watch bad movies and call it part of my work."
"I can really get into bad movies," he added.
Yet very occasionally, he said, screenwriters and directors who tackle the subject of mental disorders and their treatments get it right.
In Dr. Gabbard's view, "The Sopranos" is the best depiction of psychotherapy "ever to appear on film or television." (His new book, "The Psychology of the Sopranos," is scheduled for publication by Basic Books this summer.)
And "A Beautiful Mind," Ron Howard's award-winning drama chronicling the genius and the battle with schizophrenia of the mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr., who won the Nobel Prize for economics in 1994, is as accurate a portrait of the illness as Hollywood has produced.
In a recent conversation, Dr. Gabbard placed "A Beautiful Mind" in context.

Q. How has schizophrenia typically been portrayed in the movies?

A. First of all, in most films, a distinction is not made between serious mental illness and schizophrenia. It's only in recent years that schizophrenia itself has been defined in any way approaching reality.
Out of over 400 films depicting psychiatric treatment, I can think of less than five that I would call accurate. One was "I Never Promised You a Rose Garden," based on Hannah Greenberg's book. And one other film that was fairly accurate was "Benny and Joon."
But inaccuracy goes back as far as 1909 to a D. W. Griffith film called "The Maniac Cook." In this film, a cook becomes distressed and starts attacking her employers and is led away by the police. She escapes and first plans to kill her employers in their bed with a kitchen knife, but instead kidnaps the baby and puts it in the oven to roast.

Q. Violence is often linked with schizophrenia on the screen, is it not?

A. Yes, this stereotype of the homicidal maniac has been one of the primary myths perpetrated by the cinema about the seriously mentally ill. A more modern version of this can be seen in films like the "Halloween" series, where the Michael Myers character is the Devil himself.
Another stereotype has been to portray schizophrenia inaccurately as split personality. In "Me, Myself and Irene," the recent Jim Carrey film, you saw that. But probably the classic film of this ilk would be "Psycho." In what appears to be a severely psychotic individual, we see Norman Bates taking on the personality of his mother and dressing like her and becoming a killer of women who arouse him sexually.
And then, of course, there is Brian De Palma's 1980 film, "Dressed to Kill," which has a similar theme.
Yet another stereotype grows out of the R. D. Laing and Thomas Szasz idea that mental illness either does not exist or is an enlightened expression of rebellion against a crazy society. An example of this would be "A Fine Madness," in which Sean Connery plays a poet with writer's block, and he is shown as a free spirit who is fighting alone against the psychiatric establishment.
The other classic film of this type is "King of Hearts," a French film, in which Alan Bates plays a Scottish soldier sent on a mission to disarm a bomb in a small French town. All the townspeople except the patients in the local mental hospital have been evacuated. And the patients take over the town and show themselves as a fun-loving group capable of creating a utopian society.
One other stereotype I might mention I've called the zoo specimen. You see this in films like "Snake Pit" and "Marat Sade," the 1966 film based on the play. In "Snake Pit," for example, Olivia de Havilland is hospitalized and comments on the similarity between the patients on the wards and animals in their cages in a zoo.

Q. What makes "A Beautiful Mind" noteworthy in its approach to mental illness?

A. Overall, it's one of the better portrayals, if not the best, of what the disease is like.
As the title implies, it shows that someone with schizophrenia can be capable of having a beautiful mind -- in the sense of making significant contributions in an academic field, having loving relationships, helping students.
One of the things I liked about the film was that they showed that in the long term, some people can actually return to functioning despite the illness, that they can learn to manage it in the same way a diabetic learns to manage diabetes. The other thing is that they portrayed the kind of chronic struggle that both the patient and the family goes through around complying with medication, and around trying to adjust to the psychotic thinking by ignoring it and recognizing it as not real. That was nicely depicted.
Also, it portrays medication as effective and useful. To put this in context, when we wrote "Psychiatry and the Cinema," we could only find one film that really showed the effectiveness of psychiatric medication, and that was "As Good as It Gets." But one reading of that film would be that it was the love of Helen Hunt rather than the medication that cured Jack Nicholson.
In "A Beautiful Mind," it's clear that when he does take medication he gets better, and when he's cheeking it and hiding it he doesn't.

Q. Are there ways in which the portrait of schizophrenia in "A Beautiful Mind" departs from realism?

A. The major departure would be the emphasis on visual hallucinations. The vast majority of hallucinations in schizophrenia are auditory, that is, hearing voices. On the other hand, the cinematic medium demands visual representations of the inner world. In a novel, you can have a first-person narrator describe in detail what's going on in his mind. But in the movies, there has to be some way of visually representing a delusional world.

Q. Doesn't the film romanticize mental illness, for instance in associating genius with schizophrenia?

A. Of course it romanticizes mental illness.
The job of a filmmaker is to fill the seats at the theater. So the entire arc of John Nash's life and marriage is all romanticized.
The idea that madness and genius are very closely related is also a recurring theme in Hollywood cinema. We can think of recent examples like "Pollock," and most films about musicians, like Mozart in "Amadeus," will show a connection between genius and madness.
But the research suggests that there is probably a much closer relationship between genius or extraordinary talent and manic depressive illness than schizophrenia. Schizophrenia causes such a global deterioration that works of genius would be very difficult to sustain.
Even when a person is successfully treated with medication and various kinds of therapy there is usually a continued deficit in functioning. And you can see that pretty well portrayed near the end of "A Beautiful Mind." We're not led to believe that Nash has been completely restored to his previous level of functioning.

Q. Do the images of mental illness in the movies arise from misconceptions that already exist in the culture, or vice versa?

A. Well, let's look at things historically. There were times when mental hospitals in the United States charged admission so the public could gawk at the mentally ill. So we have this tradition of looking at the mentally ill as strange, exotic and totally different than Me. And the movies, to some degree, appropriate a pre-existing stigma that was rampant in the society.
But there's another aspect we ought to bring up. The Hollywood cinema operates on cultural mythology. In fact, I would say that just as the ancient Athenians went to the theater and got their sense of what it means to be human from Sophocles, contemporary citizens in the United States learn what it means to be human from the movies. So that both the Greek dramas and modern American movies are mythopoetic in that sense.
One of the things we see in movies about psychiatry or mental illness is a mythic narrative that audiences want to see rather than a mirror held up to reality. And we really can't expect Hollywood to give us the stark reality that we see in psychiatric hospitals or psychiatric outpatient clinics.
For example, in the movie, John Nash looks like Russell Crowe, Mrs. Nash looks like Jennifer Connelly. He gives a stirring speech at the Nobel Prize ceremony that he never really gave. The homosexual relationships he had in real life and his divorce are also excluded from the movie.

Q. Do you think that people who see "A Beautiful Mind" will start to think differently about mental illness?

A. I think there is an educational benefit. It shows that someone with schizophrenia can be very intelligent, can retain a sense of humor and can persevere with this illness. And it does educate the public that this can strike anybody, and even people who are talented and gifted.
The fact that Russell Crowe is playing the character with schizophrenia is also very significant. Russell Crowe is becoming the John Wayne of our era. Here's a guy who just won the Oscar for playing in "Gladiator." If this masculine, sexy movie star can be connected in people's minds with serious mental illness, then there is a certain cachet. We live in a celebrity-mad culture. And the association of something with celebrity has tremendous influence.

HEADLINE: Cutting Taxes Faster Would Help Everyone 

BYLINE:  By Daniel Mitchell; Daniel Mitchell is a senior fellow in political economy at the Heritage Foundation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The bulk of President Bush's tax cut won't take effect until at least 2004. It is scheduled to disappear in 2011. The president may have been pushed into this deal politically last year, but it was a mistake. Fortunately, in his State of the Union address last week, he asked Congress to correct this problem by speeding up the tax cut and making it permanent, even though opponents like Senator Edward Kennedy want to head in the opposite direction, proposing to postpone tax rate reductions scheduled to take effect in 2004 and 2006.
 Lower tax rates increase incentives to work, save and invest, and these rate reductions will provide a significant stimulus when they take effect. Consider the historical pattern. Cuts in tax rates during the 1960's and 1980's resulted in faster growth, rising incomes and more job creation. Critics in those decades complained that rate cuts would allow the rich to keep too much of their money, but upper-income taxpayers actually wound up paying a greater share of the tax burden during those decades, in part because lower rates reduced the incentive to hide, shelter and underreport income. 
 In the 1960's, President John F. Kennedy cut the top rate to 70 percent from 91 percent. Between 1961 and 1968, as the economy expanded by more than 42 percent and tax revenues rose by one-third, the rich saw their share of the tax burden climb to 15.1 percent from 11.6 percent.
In the 1980's, the top marginal rate was cut to 28 percent from 70 percent. Critics charge that this caused higher federal budget deficits, but they misread the evidence. Although the Reagan tax cut was approved in 1981, it was phased in slowly (much as the Bush tax cut is scheduled to be). Once the cuts were in place, the economy grew and tax revenues soared. Revenues from personal income taxes increased 28 percent (adjusted for inflation) by 1989. And yes, the rich wound up paying more. The share paid by the top 10 percent jumped to 57.2 percent from 48 percent of total income tax revenues. The share for the top 1 percent rose to 27.5 percent in 1988 from 17.6 percent in 1981.
Unfortunately, few members of Congress seem to understand how taxes affect the economy. They cling to the belief that tax cuts boost growth by putting money in the pockets of consumers. Because they think consumer spending is the way to jump-start a weak economy, they focus on temporary tax cuts like last year's tax rebate checks.
But government can't inject money into an economy unless it first takes the money out. So even if rebates succeed in slightly boosting consumer spending, the funds for the rebate came from a reduction in spending elsewhere in the economy (probably from private investment). This explains why last year's rebate was a flop -- and why Japan, for example, despite repeated stimulus packages intended to pump up spending, has been mired in a 10-year slump.
Last year's tax cut included the politically popular rebate checks, but those checks didn't have much impact on the economy. Only tax cuts that make saving and investment more attractive, like lower income tax rates and a repeal of the inheritance tax, will have a measurable impact.
Even the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has noted that the United States has relatively high top rates for income and estate taxes. It also suggests that tax revenues from high-income taxpayers might rise if their tax rates fell.
The Bush tax cut is reminiscent of Clint Eastwood's old spaghetti western "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly." Last year's tax bill included very good provisions to boost the economy. But the vast majority of the good provisions don't take effect until 2004, 2006 and 2010. That's the bad news.
President Bush has won tremendous public support for his leadership in the past five months. He is right to insist that his pro-growth tax provisions be made permanent. President Bush is right to say that any effort to undo his tax cut is "wacky," but having a tax cut that's only good between 2004 and 2010 isn't much better. The president wants to fix this mistake. He should also push to speed up the tax cuts immediately. Congress should rally to support these important improvements to last year's tax bill.

HEADLINE: On Cuba Visit, Mexico's Chief Meets Quietly With Dissidents 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox of Mexico trod lightly on sensitive diplomatic territory today, ending his good-will mission to Cuba by meeting with several of its government's most prominent opponents.
 In a statement issued after the meeting, Mr. Fox pressed Cuba's government, the last Communist one in the region, to pursue democratic reforms and increase human rights protections. 
 Mr. Fox, whose election 18 months ago ended the 71-year rule of Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party, held several hours of private conversation with President Fidel Castro, who has been in power here for 43 years. Mr. Fox said he was particularly interested in seeing Cuba abolish the death penalty. 
"I expressed my hope that Cuba can move toward the standards on human rights and democracy that, day by day, help make things more secure not only in Latin America but in the rest of the world," Mr. Fox said. He said that he told dissident leaders that he was "always ready to hear all the voices of Cuban society."
Elizardo Sanchez, president of the Cuban Commission on Human Rights and National Reconciliation, said the meeting provided important awareness for the efforts of Cuban dissidents, whose organizations are not recognized by the government. Many dissident leaders have been jailed for their activities.
"The government tries to treat us as if we do not exist," said Mr. Sanchez, a former professor of Marxism at the University of Havana. "The visit with President Fox demonstrates that we are here and it gives us a voice." 
Mr. Fox said President Castro "accepted it as a right that we have and he accepted that I have a very strong commitment with human rights and with democracy." 
The Cuban foreign minister, Felipe Perez Roque, said after Mr. Fox had boarded his plane, 'We are satisfied with the visit." He said that the two countries had agreed on the need to increase trade and other forms of cooperation and on "respect for sovereignty."
Mr. Fox is the first Mexican head of state to meet in Havana with dissident leaders. The sensitivity of the 30-minute gathering at the Mexican Embassy seemed clear from Mr. Fox's behavior. He said he had told Mr. Castro ahead of time about his plan to meet with the dissidents. But he did not announce the meeting to the press and did not issue a statement about it until he had left Cuba.
Walking the incendiary line between Washington and Havana, Mr. Fox made important gestures toward both.
On Sunday, he walked with Mr. Castro, who limped heavily, through the crowded streets of Havana, proclaiming the strength of Mexico's century-old relationship with Cuba and holding out prospects for increased Mexican investment in the flagging Cuban economy.
The visit here was preceded by a storm of pressure on Mr. Fox from political forces in Mexico and abroad. Traditional leftist leaders in Mexico urged him to restore damaged relations with Cuba, and officials in Washington pressed him to meet with the dissidents.
Tensions between Cuba and Mexico, once one of Latin America's closest alliances, had risen over the last decade after Ernesto Zedillo, President Fox's predecessor, criticized the Cuban government, saying it was standing against the wave of democracy sweeping across the region. Those tensions continued in the early months of Mr. Fox's presidency, when Mexico abstained from voting on a critical resolution against Cuba in the United Nations Human Rights Commission but issued a statement of concern about lingering human rights violations here.
The Mexican foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda, assured his Cuban counterpart that Mexico would not sponsor a new human rights resolution against Cuba in the United Nations, where Mexico occupies a temporary seat on the Security Council. 
Mr. Perez Roque said that Cuba was especially pleased with what he called Mexico's "categorical affirmation" that it would not support a vote to condemn Cuba for its human rights record.
Mr. Fox also reiterated his objections to United States trade sanctions against Cuba, saying that they had stifled Mexican investments in Cuba.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: POLITICAL MEMO; 
Bush Budget Is Blueprint For Clashes in Congress

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
The budget documents President Bush sent Congress today are important politically because they display all the president's programs in one place and because they set an agenda for the coming battles between the White House and the Capitol.
 But they are not a very good description of what will actually happen this year and in the years ahead in terms of taxes and spending. 
 One reason, of course, is that while Congress will probably adopt the additional spending the president wants for the military and domestic security, it can be expected to reject many of the cuts he proposed in other areas. In an election year, it is highly unlikely, for example, that Congress will approve the spending cuts Mr. Bush envisions for highway construction and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
Beyond the question of spending cuts in popular programs, Congress has repeatedly rejected the idea of using federal education funds to help children in failing public schools move to private schools, and there is no reason to believe Mr. Bush can change minds this year. The president's plan for further tax reductions as an economic stimulus will also probably be defeated, certainly in part if not in whole.
Mr. Bush could veto bills that permit more spending than he requested, but that might create problems in an election year. Not only would it force Republican lawmakers to cast difficult votes, but it would also keep Congress in session well into the fall. Twenty of the 34 Senate seats up for election this year are held by Republicans, and the incumbents are eager to adjourn early so they can have more time to campaign. 
Another reason the budget is probably unrealistic, especially in its long-term estimates, is that much of it is predicated on extended economic forecasts. Over the years, such forecasts have proved unreliable. 
The White House predicts a deficit for three years, a return to budget surpluses in the 2005 fiscal year and $1 trillion in total surpluses over the next 10 years. For that to happen, Congress will either have to cut popular spending programs or raise taxes, neither a very good bet, and the economy will have to begin growing again at a fairly robust rate of well over 3 percent a year.
Presidential budgets used to be more meaningful, said Charles L. Schultze, who was budget director under President Lyndon B. Johnson. They were the only complete source of data about federal taxes and spending and the only place where fiscal priorities were considered. In those days, Congress considered each tax and spending measure separately.
But since the 1970's, Congress has had its own budget process and its own budget office where data are compiled. Moreover, said Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, the president's budget is much more likely to represent what will probably come to pass when the White House and Congress are controlled by the same party. This year, not only do Democrats have a majority in the Senate, but the House and Senate are beginning the year controlled by different parties for the first time in 16 years.
Largely as a result of the divided Congress, the Congressional budget process may break down this year.
When the system is in gear, Congress approves a budget resolution early in the year that sets the framework for taxes and spending, and then all the legislation for the rest year is fit into that framework. 
This process has not worked smoothly for years, but it has contributed to some efficiency in the way Congress has handled budget bills. Its main benefit -- or drawback, depending on the point of view -- has been that under Congressional rules, it made one budget bill a year immune from filibuster in the Senate. Without such a system, President Bush's large tax cut last year probably could not have been enacted.
The prevailing view in the Capitol is that the Senate and House will be unable to agree on a budget resolution this year, something that happened only once, in 1998, in the last quarter-century.
Another factor that may lead to a free-for-all when Congress considers the budget is that for the first time in more than a decade, there will be no statutory caps on discretionary spending and no restrictions on tax cuts and entitlements.
Since 1990, the total amount Congress could allocate for discretionary programs -- those that get annual appropriations -- has been fixed by law, and every tax cut and increase in spending on entitlements like Social Security and Medicare had to be offset by other tax increases or spending cuts.
Those rules, which have expired, were instrumental in eliminating the budget deficit in the 1990's. They were more or less disregarded with little consequence when the budget went into surplus. But now it may be difficult for Congress to restrain the new deficit without the discipline of those rules.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE DEMOCRATS' RESPONSE; 
Leading Democrats Open Fire on Plan to Dip Into Social Security Surplus

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats sharply criticized President Bush's $2.13 trillion budget today as a plan that returns the nation to deficit spending and drains the Social Security surplus just when the government should be preparing for the retirement of the baby boom generation.
 Their comments, at the start of an election year battle over government priorities, suggested that Democrats were trying to position themselves in their familiar role as defenders of the popular government programs for the elderly. 
 Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, who heads the Budget Committee, said Mr. Bush would use more than $2 trillion of the Social Security and Medicare surpluses in the next decade to pay for other needs and make up for tax cuts. 
Mr. Conrad said that was a "serious error, given the fact that the baby boomers start to retire in just six years." He called the budget reminiscent of the deceptive financial practices of the Enron Corporation that led the company to file for bankruptcy protection.
"They said that the biggest problem with Enron was that they were hiding debt," Mr. Conrad said, "hiding it from its shareholders, hiding it from the creditors, hiding it from themselves. I think that's exactly what the federal government is doing. The federal government is now engaged in hiding its debt and understating its debt."
Republicans called the deficits, projected to last for most of Mr. Bush's current term, a result of the Sept. 11 attacks and said Mr. Bush had put forward a wartime plan for security. "This is not necessarily a budget for bookkeepers, it is a budget for security and victory," said Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee.
The Social Security issue is sensitive because it is a potent campaign issue and because each party has pledged over the past few years to use Social Security taxes only to pay benefits or pay down the debt.
The two Democratic leaders, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, also put the focus on Social Security today.
"We need a plan that will keep our commitments to Social Security and Medicare without making deep cuts in benefits, shortchanging our other national priorities or running deficits," said Mr. Daschle, the Senate majority leader. "Unfortunately the budget the administration submitted today is not that plan."
Mr. Domenici acknowledged that Republicans had pledged to protect the Social Security surpluses and that he had once spoken of the need for a "lock box" to protect that money. But he said "that pales now in comparison with the challenges brought about by Sept. 11." 
Other Republicans also put an emphasis on the war effort. "We are living in dangerous and unprecedented times," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said the president had put forward a "responsible, common-sense budget that meets the needs of our nation in a time of war."
The debate amounted to an odd role reversal for the parties, with Republicans defending increased spending and Democrats calling for fiscal discipline.
A few conservative Republicans were pressing for a balanced budget, but House Republicans are expected to assemble a budget plan that closely resembles Mr. Bush's.
Democrats, who control the Senate by one vote, have little flexibility for drawing up a competing budget plan. Party leaders are reluctant to try to freeze or roll back part of Mr. Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut, fearful of being called big taxers. Nor do they want to look as if they do not support the military.
"I can tell you what we're not going to do," Mr. Conrad said. "We're not going to raise taxes in the midst of an economic downturn. And we are going to supply the president with the resources necessary to fight this war."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: MILITARY SPENDING; 
Rise in Budget Is Not Enough, General Plans To Testify

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
Even with the $48 billion increase in military spending that President Bush has requested, the Pentagon will still fall tens of billions of dollars short of what is needed to replace aging aircraft, ships and tanks, senior military officials said today. 
 If approved by Congress, Mr. Bush's request would be the largest military spending increase in 20 years, raising the Pentagon budget to $379 billion. But most of that growth, the officials said, would go toward what they called must-pay bills, including $14 billion for rising health-care costs and salaries, $6.7 billion for inflation costs on existing programs and $19 billion for the war on terrorism. 
 "We could not do all of the things we wanted to do in certain areas," the Pentagon comptroller, Dov S. Zakheim, said. 
The financing mismatch is widely expected to be a major theme of the testimony that Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will present to Congress this week. According to a statement delivered to Capitol Hill for review on Friday, General Myers contends that the armed services need to spend $100 billion to $110 billion a year "for several years" to replace fighter jets, ships and other weapons that should be retired.
"We cannot continue to defer procurement as we did over the last decade," General Myers plans to tell the Senate, according to a copy of his prepared testimony. "We must accelerate the replacement of aging systems if we are to sustain our capability to meet near-term challenges and all of our 21st-century commitments."
But some Democrats, military experts and Pentagon watchdog groups said the real problem was that Mr. Bush and Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, had not cut or killed older weapons programs to help pay for the new ones. Thus, the critics said, the Pentagon will have big-ticket programs on its books that it cannot afford for many years. 
"The budget is just too big," said Michael E. O'Hanlon, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "It deprives the nation of a sound fiscal policy, enough money for other counterterrorism efforts such as increased diplomacy and foreign aid, and enough money for a serious domestic agenda. Bush has gone from compassionate conservative to Ronald Reagan reincarnate. Rumsfeld has gone from defense reformer to Caspar Weinberger."
Even President Bush's plan, which calls for spending more than $2 trillion on the military in the next five years, would not reach the levels cited by General Myers until near its end. Under Mr. Bush's proposal, procurement spending -- weapons purchases -- would grow to about $70 billion next year, from $61 billion, and steadily climb to $99 billion by 2007. 
It has become an annual tradition for senior military officers to tell Congress that the Pentagon is underfinanced. In recent years, Republicans have seized on those requests to accuse the Clinton administration of shortchanging the military. 
This year, though, only a few hawkish Democrats -- possibly including Representative Norm Dicks of Washington -- are likely to level similar criticisms against Mr. Bush. Still, while there appears to be bipartisan support for Mr. Bush's $48 billion increase, many Democrats are likely to resist allocating more than that, worrying instead about restoring money Mr. Bush wants to cut from domestic programs. 
Mr. Zakheim said today that the Pentagon was all but certain to request more money in this fiscal year to pay for the war on terrorism. The military has already received $17.5 billion in emergency financing for the war, of which it has spent about $10 billion, officials said.
General Myers, in his prepared text as delivered to Congress, says that the older fleet of aircraft is taking a toll in increased operational costs for fighter jets, particularly F-15C/D aircraft, which have an average age of 17 1/2 years.
The budget would also not buy enough new ships to provide a fleet of 310 ships, as was advocated in last fall's Quadrennial Defense Review, the Pentagon's budget and strategy guide, which is issued every four years, officials said. 
Under the plan Mr. Bush formally sent to Congress today, the Pentagon is to spend $1 billion on unpiloted aircraft, including $158 million to build 22 new Predator surveillance drones, which have been used extensively in Afghanistan. Many of the new Predators will be modified to fire Hellfire antitank missiles, Mr. Zakheim said. 
The budget proposal also seeks to raise spending on Special Operations Forces, the units that also played a major role in the Afghan war, to more than $3 billion. Procurement for Special Operations Command would include four AC-130U gunships and new radar-jamming equipment.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1484 words

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE OVERVIEW; 
PRESIDENT SUBMITS $2 TRILLION BUDGET THAT RAISES DEFICIT

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 

 BODY:
President Bush sent Congress a $2.13 trillion budget proposal today that would squeeze much of government to bolster national security and continue cutting taxes, even at the cost of increased deficits for a few years.
 The plan immediately ignited a partisan battle on Capitol Hill. 
 Democrats said they would stand by the president in making available the money needed to fight terrorism. But they said the trade-offs sought by Mr. Bush would shortchange vital social needs in the short run and hobble government in the long run as it faces the huge costs of paying health and retirement benefits to a rapidly aging population. 
Mr. Bush cast his proposal, for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1, as a wartime agenda necessary to battle terrorism abroad and keep Americans safe at home. He called on Congress to begin a years-long, expensive process of adding to the nation's military might, and sought an infusion of money for domestic security programs including bioterrorism preparedness, increased border security and more support for police, fire and rescue teams.
To help pay the cost, Mr. Bush proposes cuts or freezes in a vast array of domestic programs. Page A19. 
The budget seeks $38.3 billion in new spending for the Pentagon, an 11.7 percent increase that would be the biggest since the Reagan administration. It asks Congress to give the president authority to spend $10 billion beyond that if necessary to fight the war in Afghanistan or elsewhere. Separately, it calls for $18 billion in new funds for domestic security, nearly doubling the budget for defending the nation within its borders.
"The budget for 2003 is much more than a tabulation of numbers," Mr. Bush said in his budget message to Congress. "It is a plan to fight a war we did not seek -- but a war we are determined to win."
But the budget proposal, which is sure to be substantially changed by the time Congress finishes work on the annual spending and tax bills late this year, is also shaped by its emphasis on tax cuts. It calls for the permanent extension of the $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax reduction Mr. Bush signed into law last year. It proposes a host of other, smaller tax cuts, including a permanent extension of a business tax credit for research and development expenses. And it reiterates the administration's call for an immediate economic recovery package, setting aside $175 billion over three years for tax cuts including an acceleration of the individual income tax rate reductions adopted in the law enacted last year. 
Administration officials said tax cuts were the key to restoring the economy to good health now and encouraging prosperity in the long run. The immediate debate over how to help the economy will reach a milestone on Wednesday, when the Senate is to vote on a Democratic version of a stimulus package; the legislation offers far less in tax cuts than the administration would like.
In all, Mr. Bush calls for $591 billion, beyond the $1.35 trillion already enacted, to be reserved for tax cuts over the next decade. This figure includes $343 billion to extend last year's tax cut for two years beyond its current expiration in 2010.
But the emphasis on tax cuts and on increased spending for the military and domestic security would come at a cost to the government's fiscal condition. The administration said that if its tax and spending recommendations were enacted, the government would run a $106 billion deficit this year -- the first deficit since 1997 -- followed by an $80 billion deficit next year and a $14 billion deficit in 2004. By the administration's projections, the budget would return to surplus in 2005.
The figures also show the government breaking a bipartisan pledge not to use that part of revenue generated by Social Security for any purpose other than to shore up the retirement system or reduce the national debt. They show the government spending a portion of the Social Security surplus each year for at least the next decade.
To keep deficits under control, and to advance its longstanding goal of restraining the growth of government, the administration would allocate little additional money to programs other than those related to national security. 
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said so-called discretionary spending -- the programs revisited by Congress each year -- would rise a total of just 2 percent in categories outside of the Pentagon and domestic security, about a third of the annual increase of recent years.
The budget calls for freezing or cutting spending in 6 of the 14 major cabinet departments, and for slowing or cutting spending on scores of programs.
The Labor Department's budget would be cut $856 million, or 7 percent, to $11.3 billion, with particularly big cuts in job training and international labor programs. The Environmental Protection Agency's budget would decline by $286 million, or 3.6 percent, to $7.62 billion. The Agriculture Department's budget would be frozen at $19.4 billion.
The Education Department's budget would rise by $1.8 billion, or 3.7 percent, to $50.3 billion. But to make room for increases in spending for special education and for aid to schools in poor neighborhoods, the administration would reduce spending on other programs, including vocational and adult education.
For the first time, an administration's budget proposal explicitly links financing decisions to a formal review of the effectiveness of various government programs. The White House said this effort in the current budget was just the beginning.
Despite having been rebuffed last year by Congress, the administration also stepped up its campaign to reduce pork-barrel spending, even singling out programs that it considered to be of questionable merit, like a $3 million renewable-energy project in Winona, Miss., and $2.25 million for "winter recreation opportunities" in Fairbanks, Alaska.
Members of both parties said it would be difficult, especially in an election year, for Congress to agree to the broad cuts or freezes Mr. Bush is seeking, particularly since the administration itself has proclaimed deficits to be acceptable for the next couple of years. 
Administration officials signaled that they would be flexible about how the budget was actually allocated by Congress, but suggested that Mr. Bush would veto any appropriations above the levels he seeks in broad categories of spending. 
"It may well come to that this year," said Mr. Daniels, the White House budget director. 
Democrats said Mr. Bush's budget was inadequate in addressing some of the biggest items on the national agenda, including the creation of a prescription drug benefit for retirees. The president's budget allocates $190 billion over the next decade to overhauling Medicare and creating a prescription drug plan, a figure that Democrats said fell a minimum of $100 billion short of what would be needed to establish a meaningful drug benefit alone.
Democrats said they were still discovering cuts in social programs throughout Mr. Bush's budget, and signaled that they would insist on more money for education, health care, environmental and other programs. But they were unable or unwilling to offer an alternative approach that would reconcile their insistence on fiscal responsibility with their demand for additional spending and their political fear of trying to roll back Mr. Bush's tax cut. 
Instead, they attacked the president today for the damage they said the budget would do in years and decades to come as the bill for Social Security and Medicare benefits begins to rise sharply.
Figures developed by the administration but not released publicly showed that the government would run "on budget" deficits -- that is, deficits not including the revenue generated by Social Security payroll taxes -- in every year through 2012.
As a result, nearly $1.5 trillion of a cumulative $2.5 trillion Social Security surplus over the next decade, money that both parties had counted on to reduce the $3.4 trillion national debt, would instead go to general government expenses. 
By the administration's calculations, the debt in 2012 will stand at $2.6 trillion. A year ago, the administration had projected that it would be pushed down to the lowest level practical, about $1 trillion, within this decade. Mr. Daniels said today that the administration remained committed to debt reduction but that fighting terrorism and nurturing an economic recovery must come first.
Democrats, however, said Mr. Bush's approach provided no money to shore up Social Security and would leave the country debt-ridden as it approached the demographic challenges of coming decades.
"If budgets demonstrate -- better than words -- what is important to us," said the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, "this budget does not make the commitment I would like to see to our seniors, and our future."

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 676 words

HEADLINE: The Axis-of-Inefficiency Budget 

 BODY:
President Bush's proposed $2.1 trillion budget embraces the word "security" at every turn. It provides more spending for military security and domestic security and more tax cuts for "economic security." But the budget undermines the security of the nation's social safety net and the government's ability to carry out some of its basic responsibilities over the next two decades. It jeopardizes the future of Social Security and Medicare, whose trust funds would be siphoned away to underwrite outmoded military projects and tax reductions favoring the rich. The budget embodies a divisive agenda for which Mr. Bush has no mandate, in spite of his popularity.
 For weeks the administration has cleverly leaked news about a handful of domestic programs like family nutrition, health research and food stamps that were targeted for spending increases. But the budget the administration presented yesterday revealed that everything outside these few programs was up for assault. According to Mitchell Daniels, the budget director, the administration is targeting only inefficient programs. The cuts, he insists, are not aimed at hobbling job training, environmental programs or labor safety -- although those are some of the areas that will suffer. The administration, he says, is simply trying to do away with bad management. Mr. Daniels has created a virtual axis of inefficiency, and declared war on it. 
 It is hard to accept Mr. Daniels's sincerity when the defense budget remains packed with cold-war-era projects that have no business in the kind of modern, high-tech military the Bush administration wants to create. The budget will lock in billions of dollars in future spending for outmoded technology like the 70-ton Crusader howitzer and the F-22 jet fighter. Apparently the only federal programs that can be inefficient are the ones the Republican Party's right wing doesn't like.
The most discouraging part of the new budget is the way it disguises the true cost of its tax cuts with accounting gimmicks and arbitrary expiration dates. Almost incredibly, Mr. Bush wants to accelerate and make permanent previously enacted tax cuts and add new tax cuts on top of them. He says that his actions would cost more than $600 billion over the next 10 years, but without the gimmicks they would cost more than $1 trillion.
The Bush budget is a road map toward a different kind of American society, in which the government no longer taxes the rich to aid the poor, and in fact does very little but protect the nation from foreign enemies. If the budget is adopted as proposed, over the next decade the increasing cost of the tax cuts will drain the treasury while the rapidly rising price tag of unnecessary military projects will make up a larger and larger piece of what is left.
Virtually everyone supports spending as much money as it takes to fight the war on terrorism at home and abroad. But national security does not require new corporate tax write-offs or contracting for a new fighter plane designed primarily for cold-war-era dogfights. Mr. Bush is using the anti-terrorism campaign to disguise an ideological agenda that has nothing to do with domestic defense or battling terrorism abroad. The budget discontinues the tradition of making 10-year projections into the future, possibly because the administration does not want the American people to see where the road is heading.
One of the many pieces of this budget that the public would never accept if consulted is the harm it does to the future of Medicare and Social Security. When asked yesterday to address charges that the administration was not leaving enough money to keep Medicare and Social Security solvent, Mr. Daniels said both were heading toward insolvency anyway. His policies seemed intent on starving the federal government of money to save them so that they can be "fixed" by privatizing them in ways that favor the well-to-do. 
The budget now goes to Congress, where it needs to be rethought and stripped of its gimmicks disguising the true cost of what it wants to do.
